webTitle: Coventry caught on counter by Flo

fields.headline: Coventry caught on counter by Flo
fields.standfirst: Lightning strikes twice to rescue point for Chelsea
fields.trailText: The old adage that says a team is never more vulnerable than when they have just scored was given additional weight last night when Coventry, through sheer hard graft and occasional inspiration, twice went ahead against Chelsea only to be brought back to parity within 60 seconds.
fields.body:
The old adage that says a team is never more vulnerable than when they have just scored was given additional weight last night when Coventry, through sheer hard graft and occasional inspiration, twice went ahead against Chelsea only to be brought back to parity within 60 seconds.

When Robbie Keane guided a header in off the post with nine minutes remaining hardly anybody inside this ground dared believe that Chelsea could repeat the trick that had seen Tore Andre Flo squash Cedric Roussel's earlier celebration. They did and he did, thanks once again to the guile of Gianfranco Zola.

Chelsea re-introduced a British presence into their ranks with the return after flu of Dennis Wise, hopefully a wiser, less impetuous Dennis given that he had recently assumed the responsibilities of fatherhood with the birth of a son, Henry. The shoulder injury affecting Marcel Desailly had also resolved itself and the Frenchman was immediately called upon when Celestine Babayaro's hasty back pass put him in a spot of bother.

The essence of Coventry's success against Arsenal on Boxing Day lay in the speed with which they denied their opponents space and time, and the same tactics were employed once more. It helped bring the crowd to life as Chelsea were forced to retreat, and Wise and Didier Deschamps had difficulty wresting control in midfield.

The regularity with which Roussel could find Keane in tight areas with precisely angled headers or cushioned vol leys also boded well for Gordon Strachan's Coventry team.

It seemed only a matter of time before Keane would produce something dynamic. In the 11th minute McAllister's quick thinking at a free-kick gave him a yard on Desailly, but unfortunately for the Irishman he lacked the extra inch which would have allowed him to bring the ball under control. Seconds later Keane again threatened as his markers once again allowed him to escape from view.

Then, when Roussel played in Keane down the right, Ed de Goey smothered at his feet. That came after Mustapha Hadji, again capitalising on a Roussel prompt, had dragged a drive across the goalmouth.

As the first half ended Coventry were still creating moments of danger but now they were having to share them with Chelsea, belatedly discovering the means to bring Zola into the contest. Twice he provided headers for Tore Andre Flo which the tall Norwegian could not keep down.

Chelsea's best chance came as Gary McAllister and Carlton Palmer allowed themselves to become distracted by Wise's niggly ways, ignoring their defensive duty as Zola prepared to take a corner. It resulted in a pair of shooting opportunities, both of which were blocked, and then led to Emerson Thome taking aim. No better opening has arrived for the new recruit to open his account, but his low attempt flew wide of the left upright.

Wise, keeping pace with Flo's right-wing surge, put a volley on target which Magnus Hedman was grateful to clutch above his head. Keane and McAllister, both from further out, proved less accurate at the other end.

Then came the first two goals, the first when a bout of close passing set up Hadji for a shot which Roussel blocked and then reacted quickest to steer home. However Coventry were given no time to savour ther breakthrough as Zola beat his man before cutting the ball back for Flo to steer in his first.

webTitle: United's rivals on the road to Rio

fields.headline: United's rivals on the road to Rio
fields.trailText: Group A
fields.body:
Group A

Al Nassr (Saudi Arabia)

Why they are there 1998 Asian Supercup winners
Coach Milan Zivadinovic. Began 1999 in charge of Yugoslavia but was dismissed amid allegations that he had signed a one-year contract to coach in Saudi. "Our ambition is to leave a good impression," he says
Players to watch:
Fuad Anwar (midfield). A former Saudi Arabia captain with almost 100 caps. Played in the past two World Cups, scoring twice in USA 94
Ahmed Bahja (striker). Played for Morocco in the 1994 World Cup but was omitted from the France 98 squad after a fall-out with the coach
Verdict Have bought several experienced internationals in recent weeks, including Algeria's Moussa Saib from Tottenham, but are likely to struggle
Odds 100-1

Corinthians (Brazil)

Why they are there 1998 Brazilian champions
Coach Oswaldo de Oliveira.
Promoted from assistant when Wanderley Luxemburgo left to manage Brazil. His first stint ended after a month when he was pushed back to No2. But he rose again three months later when his successor was fired Players to watch:
Dida (goalkeeper). Brazil's No1. An expert penalty saver and shot stopper
Freddy Rincon (midfield). Dropping deeper with age but the Colombia international remains a cultured passer of the ball. Voted the best player in the Brazilian championship in 1998
Verdict Brazil's finest. They won their second successive national title last month. Excellent on the attack, though vulnerable in defence. Tie against Real Madrid is likely to decide who tops the group.
Odds 9-4

Raja Casablanca (Morocco)

Why they are there 1999 African Champions League winners
Coach Oscar Luis Fullone.
An Argentine who has coached at Aston Villa, Millwall and Sheffield United. Renowned as a master tactician Players to watch:
Mustapha Chadli (goalkeeper). Member of the Morocco squad at the 1998 World Cup. Key figure behind a shaky back four
Abdellatif Jrindou (midfield). Club captain, his role as a ball winner is crucial to supplying the attacking players such as Reda Ereyahi
Verdict Achieved more than they expected in beating Tunisia's Esperance on penalties to win the African Champions League three weeks ago. Skilful and strong but lack quality. Will be happy just to beat Al Nassr.
Odds 33-1

Real Madrid (Spain)

Why they are there 1998 world club champions
Coach Vicente del Bosque. Standing in while Real seek a long-term successor to John Toshack. Guided club to two successive wins at the end of last month
Players to watch:
Roberto Carlos (defender). Returns home as one of the few players to have escaped criticism during Real's disappointing start to the season
Steve McManaman (forward). Now over the injuries which have frustrated him since his move from Liverpool. Real have generally prospered when he has played. Also look out for Nicolas Anelka
Verdict Will be delighted to escape the pressure at home. A good performance will do much to restore confidence. Should reach the final if they play to their potential
Odds 7-2

Group B

Necaxa (Mexico)

Why they are there 1999 Concacaf Champions Cup winners
Coach Raul Arias. Stepped up from assistant to succeed Manuel Lapuente, Mexico's coach since 1997. His team are most effective on the counterattack. Insists Manchester United "can be beaten"
Players to watch:
Alex Aguinaga (forward). Ecuador international with long hair and outstanding talent. Necaxa's playmaker has been at the club since 1989
Carlos Hermosillo (striker). Played for Mexico in the 1986 and 1994 World Cups. The 35-year-old recently returned from a spell with LA Galaxy.
Verdict Unlikely to progress, not least because of the inferiority complex that tends to hold back Mexican players against supposedly stronger opposition
Odds 33-1

South Melbourne (Australia)

Why they are there 1999 champions of Oceania
Coach Ange Postecoglou. A former South Melbourne player, he has led the club to two straight championships, though they are mid-table this season. Of Greek origins, like the club itself
Players to watch:
Paul Trimboli (forward). Club captain who had a trial at Manchester City under Alan Ball. Australia international who still works as an accountant
Michael Curcija (forward). A Liverpool fan, the skilful 22-year-old will play an integral part in Australia's under-23 team at the Sydney Olympics
Verdict Weakest team in group. Will do well to get more than a point, but should avoid embarrassing defeats.
Odds 500-1

Vasco da Gama (Brazil)

Why they are there 1998 Libertadores Cup winners
Coach Antonio Lopes. In his fourth spell in charge. The latest instalment has lasted three years, a lifetime in Brazilian football
Players to watch:
Romario (striker). Arrived in November after being sacked by Flamengo for a night on the razzle. Destroyed Manchester United while playing for Barcelona in 1994
Edmundo (striker). Arrogant and volatile like his strike partner but another potential match-winner. Should recover from a thigh strain for the game against United
Verdict In poor form domestically but they see the tournament as their No1 priority and may be formidable on home soil. The heat will help them in the crucial game against United
Odds 5-2

Related story

Pele turns up heat on Ferguson

webTitle: Thatcher issues defence before trial by video

fields.headline: Thatcher issues defence before trial by video
fields.trailText: Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher is facing a trial by television after the Football Association yesterday requested a video of his side's 1-0 victory over Sunderland at Selhurst Park.
fields.body:
Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher is facing a trial by television after the Football Association yesterday requested a video of his side's 1-0 victory over Sunderland at Selhurst Park.

Thatcher's elbow caught Nicky Summerbee in the face during the move which led to the only goal of Monday's game and the Sunderland winger had to leave the pitch with concussion.

The referee Graham Poll and his assistant Grant Hegley did not spot the incident and the FA's disciplinary committee will now study the video to decide what action to take.

"We requested a copy of the match video first thing this morning for our own disciplinary team to look at the Thatcher incident," said a spokesman. "The FA are looking to deal with it as a matter of priority."

Thatcher stated his case yesterday by denying that it was a deliberate foul. "I was running flat out for a 50-50 ball," he said. "He pulled out of the challenge after I'd already braced myself for contact. If my elbow caught him I apologise. It was certainly unintentional."

Sunderland's manager Peter Reid was furious that the match officials failed to act, and Poll said yesterday after watching the match on television that he was disappointed to have missed the incident.

Mel Machin and Gary Brazil, the managers of Bournemouth and Notts County respectively, have been fined and warned as to their future conduct by the FA after the match between the teams on November 9.

Machin was fined £100 for improper behaviour towards the referee Jeff Winter, and Brazil was fined £250 for comments made to Winter after the game.

The Scottish Football Association has ruled out playing Yugoslavia in a friendly before the World Cup 2002 qualifying campaign because of the potential political problems. Scotland's coach Craig Brown had indicated that he would like to play Yugoslavia to prepare for his side's qualification matches against Croatia.

Liverpool are to send Robbie Fowler for a third scan on his ankle injury after the striker was forced to miss his side's 1-0 defeat by Tottenham Hotspur at White Hart Lane on Monday. Fowler has played only 48 minutes since minor surgery in October removed a bone spur on his ankle joint.

 Manchester United will today dig up their Old Trafford pitch for the third time since the summer.

 Newcastle United have agreed a fee of £1.25m to sell Franck Dumas to Marseille.

 Sammy McIlroy, the former Northern Ireland international, has been named as the manager of his national team. He has signed a two-year contract and will take charge of Macclesfield for the last time on Saturday.

webTitle: Police help Smith lay down the law at Everton

fields.headline: Police help Smith lay down the law at Everton
fields.trailText: The Everton manager Walter Smith yesterday enhanced his reputation as the soft-spoken, ever-smiling disciplinarian of English football.
fields.body:
The Everton manager Walter Smith yesterday enhanced his reputation as the soft-spoken, ever-smiling disciplinarian of English football.

The Scot was most definitely not imbued with the Hogmanay spirit on New Year's Day when he fined two members of his squad, Michael Ball and Richard Dunne, for their failure to attend a morning training session.

Ball, an England Under-21 full-back, and Dunne, a Republic of Ireland Under-21 defender, were fined a week's wages apiece and told to stay away from Goodison Park on Monday, when Leicester City were the visitors.

Smith's mood darkened further when he was informed that his 18-year-old striker Francis Jeffers was arrested in Liverpool at around 2am on New Year's Day and later cautioned for being drunk and disorderly. Police released him at 6.25am.

Although Jeffers played in the draw against Leicester he was substituted after 71 minutes and he too faces the prospect of disciplinary action by the club as Smith seeks to bring into line the more rebellious elements within his team.

Jeffers claims he went to help a team-mate who was attacked after leaving the Cream concert at the Pier Head.

"I was walking from a celebration with my girlfriend, 50 yards behind my club captain Don Hutchison and his wife," he said in a statement yesterday. "Don was insulted and then physically abused by two men. I ran forward to prevent further fighting and got involved in the fracas.

"The police arrived and I was arrested and taken to the police station, whereupon I accepted a caution for being drunk and disorderly so as not to cause my club and my family any embarrassment.

"I deeply regret getting involved in a situation such as this and would like to apologise for any unpleasantness caused to anyone, and I hope that the club and fans will forgive my involvement."

Smith expects to reduce his club's wage bill further today by selling the former England Under-21 forward Michael Branch to Wolverhampton Wanderers in a deal which may eventually net the Merseyside club £700,000.

The Liverpool striker Robbie Fowler will learn today whether he will require a second operation on the ankle injury which has afflicted him for more than three months.

After being forced to miss Monday's defeat at Tottenham, the England forward had another series of scans yesterday in the hope of resolving a problem which he believed had been cured by corrective surgery back in September.

"Obviously this is a concern," said Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier. "Although we do not believe the problem to be too serious, we now need to know more about the injury.

"He does have a problem with a muscle near the ankle; this is obviously connected with the original injury. I am very, very hopeful that Robbie's recovery will be aided not by another operation but by a short rest."

webTitle: Tale of Trautmann bears two more retellings

fields.headline: Tale of Trautmann bears two more retellings
fields.trailText: Out of the blue comes a face and a voice from the past. Bert Trautmann, German prisoner of war and one of the finest goalkeepers ever to grace Maine Road, has a story worth retelling.
fields.body:
Out of the blue comes a face and a voice from the past. This Saturday evening a fascinating BBC2 Timewatch documentary tells of the 400,000 German prisoners left in Britain after the last war. The leading role is played by a tall, handsome, still recognisably smiling and straight-backed 76-year-old.

At this time of new year renewal and reflection, Bert Trautmann's tale is one to tell again - and coincidentally it is also being retold next Monday on Radio 5 Live when a profile of one of the Football League's grandest figures kicks off a relishable new series, Keepers.

As displayed by Saturday's riveting film by Catrine Clay, no goalie comes more heroic than Trautmann, who escaped from a Soviet prisoner-of-war camp only to be recaptured by the Allies in the last months of the war and deposited behind barbed wire in Lancashire when the British government defied the Geneva Convention and continued to hold prisoners for vital work in rebuilding a shattered Britain.

Only instead of being behind barbed wire Trautmann was in no time standing in front of Maine Road netting, succeeding the legendary Frank Swift.

It caused a vitriolic outcry at the time, particularly from Manchester's large Jewish community - till the local Rabbi Altmann gave his blessing: "He is a decent fellow, unconnected with any German crimes."

Trautmann still remembers the rabbi with gratitude. "His calming and generous words stopped all hell breaking loose." So he put on Swift's jersey and stepped up for, in all, 545 league and FA Cup matches.

"He became better than Swift," wrote Eric Todd in these pages. "Frank might have been more the showman but Bert could make saves no others could have dreamed of."

His old City colleague Roy Clarke says on the radio programme: "Bert was best in the world. Oh sure, he was better than Schmeichel. Yet he never played to the crowd."

Trautmann lived 23 years in England. Then he toured the world as a successful manager and coach. He now lives in contented retirement in Spain.

"I was a soldier at 17 and witnessed all the horror and beastliness of war. But my education only began at 22 on the day I arrived in England. People were so kind and decent, they didn't see an enemy prisoner, they saw a human being. The British made me what I am.

"Here in Spain, or when I visit Germany, they say to me, 'Be honest, you're English through and through.' And I'm mighty proud to so consider myself. I come back four or five times a year, and always think, 'Great, I'm home'."

For the BBC2 documentary they filmed him - where else? - above a Maine Road goalmouth.

He chuckles down the line: "Funnily enough, of all the saves, for some reason the one that always seems to stand out was at Old Trafford. It was not long before United's terrible Munich crash.

"If ever a football was a rocket it was at that moment. An outswinging corner from the left had Tommy Taylor running on to it from deep and he met it perfectly with his head, an absolute screamer for my top left-hand corner.

"As a header of a ball, Tommy was in a class with the other Tom [Lawton] and Nat [Lofthouse]. Anyway, I only saw its last few yards - and I still can't explain how I twisted up to palm it around for another corner.

"Every single Saturday you were up against one or two true-great forwards. I suppose Tom Finney was greatest all-rounder of them all.

"I still have my dish and follow everything, City especially. They are much fitter than we were, obviously, but what has gone is the individual's element of surprise. Now they just look to keep possession at all cost: the balls played square, balls played back. They are all in a rigid corset, not daring to do anything the coach hasn't mentioned."

You have to ask him: "Bert, how's the neck?" Famously, gallantly, he broke it, diving at the onrushing Peter Murphy of Birmingham City towards the end of the 1956 FA Cup final. It ensured the Cup for Manchester City. He was five months in plaster.

"It is not so stiff here in the Spanish sun. But there is still a twinge whenever I look sharp left in the car or on my bicycle. A nice reminder of the great old days, in fact."

"Frank might have been more the showman but Bert could make saves no others could have dreamed of." His old City colleague Roy Clarke says on the radio programme: "Bert was best in the world. Oh sure, he was better than Schmeichel. Yet he never played to the crowd." Trautmann lived 23 years in England. Then he toured the world as a successful manager and coach. He now lives in contented retirement in Spain. "I was a soldier at 17 and witnessed all the horror and beastliness of war. But my education only began at 22 on the day I arrived in England. People were so kind and decent, they didn't see an enemy prisoner, they saw a human being. The British made me what I am. "Here in Spain, or when I visit Germany, they say to me, 'Be honest, you're English through and through.' And I'm mighty proud to so consider myself. I come back four or five times a year, and always think, 'Great, I'm home'." For the BBC2 documentary they filmed him - where else? - above a Maine Road goalmouth. He chuckles down the line: "Funnily enough, of all the saves, for some reason the one that always seems to stand out was at Old Trafford. It was not long before United's terrible Munich crash. "If ever a football was a rocket it was at that moment. An outswinging corner from the left had Tommy Taylor running on to it from deep and he met it perfectly with his head, an absolute screamer for my top left-hand corner. "As a header of a ball, Tommy was in a class with the other Tom [Lawton] and Nat [Lofthouse]. Anyway, I only saw its last few yards - and I still can't explain how I twisted up to palm it around for another corner. "Every single Saturday you were up against one or two true-great forwards. I suppose Tom Finney was greatest all-rounder of them all. "I still have my dish and follow everything, City especially. They are much fitter than we were, obviously, but what has gone is the individual's element of surprise. Now they just look to keep possession at all cost: the balls played square, balls played back. They are all in a rigid corset, not daring to do anything the coach hasn't mentioned." You have to ask him: "Bert, how's the neck?" Famously, gallantly, he broke it, diving at the onrushing Peter Murphy of Birmingham City towards the end of the 1956 FA Cup final. It ensured the Cup for Manchester City. He was five months in plaster. "It is not so stiff here in the Spanish sun. But there is still a twinge whenever I look sharp left in the car or on my bicycle. A nice reminder of the great old days, in fact."

fields.headline: England on the rack
fields.standfirst: Cullinan and Boucher add 90 and take South Africa out of reach
fields.trailText: Defeat is staring England squarely in the face here at Newlands after an eighth-wicket partnership between Daryll Cullinan and Mark Boucher put on 90 runs and pushed the tourists backwards once more.
fields.body:
Defeat is staring England squarely in the face here at Newlands after an eighth-wicket partnership between Daryll Cullinan and Mark Boucher put on 90 runs and pushed the tourists backwards once more.

England, in keeping with the bulk of their cricket during this series, fought back hard and with spirit yesterday on a ferociously hot day, but they had lost so much ground during their lackadaisical, inept second day that a win is now beyond them and worse is in prospect.

They are without Andy Flintoff, whose fractured metatarsal in his left foot has ruled out further participation this winter, and even allowing for the the South Africa captain Hansie Cronje's conservatism, only the mightiest of efforts from the batsmen will allow them to wriggle off this particular hook and go into the final Test at Centurion Park with the series still alive.

With the day's end in sight yesterday South Africa were all out for 421, a lead of 163, leaving the England openers the tricky prospect of a single over from Allan Donald before the trip back to the hotel. In fact it was the left-arm spin of Paul Adams which confronted Mark Butcher and he duly survived the six deliveries, punching one boundary in the process.

Earlier, much earlier, Chris Silverwood had managed to take the wicket of Gary Kirsten in the day's first over and before he had added to his overnight 80. Darren Gough then removed Jacques Kallis with the second new ball, although not before he had made 105, the sixth hundred of his Test career.

But England had to endure a classy century from Cullinan who, missed by the substitute fielder Darren Maddy at square leg when on 89, was last out for 120 having hit 10 fours and a six in a shade under six hours. Kirsten and Cullinan now share the South African records for the most centuries in Tests, 10, and the highest score, 275.

There was due reward, though, for Silverwood's unflagging effort and ruddy-faced optimism as he hurled himself into the fray for 32 overs to take five for 91, the first five-wicket haul of his international life.

England needed to atone for their display of the previous day and, backed up by some tremendous fielding, all three seamers shrugged off fatigue and raised their games.

With the wickets for Silverwood, Gough finding bounce to remove Kallis and a snorter to bowl Lance Klusener, and Andy Caddick nipping out Cronje for a duck followed by Jonty Rhodes for 16, South Africa were pegged back from their overnight 200 for one to 307 for seven midway through the afternoon session.

But Cullinan was still there with a half-century to his name, and Boucher, surely the most prolific No9 batsman in Test history, contributed 36 to their partnership and looked set for a heap more before controversially becoming Silverwood's fourth victim.

Boucher can consider himself unfortunate to be given out leg-before by Cyril Mitchley, as poor a decision as any in this series. But the way that the wicketkeeper's dismissal was replayed several times on the giant screen by the scoreboard operators was no less scandalous, and such abuse of replays has to be stopped to protect the officials. The previous two Tests, by the way, had been umpired impeccably.

Silverwood was impressive. He has been on three tours now despite not being an original selection for any of them. This time he is here at the expense of Dean Headley, but he has leapfrogged into the side ahead of Alex Tudor by bowling faster than anyone else in the squad.

He had enjoyed some good fortune when Herschelle Gibbs, on the second day, spanked a short, wide delivery to point, and Boucher's wicket was a bonus. But it only compensated for the luckless overs he had sent down previously. And the balls that dismissed Kirsten, caught at the wicket from a delivery with an old ball which surprised the opener with bounce and movement, Rhodes, who edged an outswinger to second slip, and Donald, who was caught in the same position from the back of the bat, were fine deliveries.

The news of Flintoff was worse than expected. He saw a specialist yesterday morning and his foot was put in plaster and will remain so for a month. He will fly home with Mark Ramprakash at the end of this Test.

The reinforcements for the one-day squad - Mark Alleyne, Mark Ealham, Ashley Giles, Graeme Hick, Nick Knight and Vikram Solanki - will arrive in Port Elizabeth on Friday, and to take the heat off those who have played in the back-to-back Tests the newcomers will be available for the three-day match which begins there on Sunday. Presumably a replacement for Flintoff will be chosen in due course.

webTitle: Pakistan retaliate with call for video of Walsh

fields.headline: Pakistan retaliate with call for video of Walsh
fields.trailText: Tauqir Zia, chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board, yesterday began a campaign to save the career of the banned pace bowler Shoaib Akhtar by calling for video footage of three of the world's top bowlers.
fields.body:
Tauqir Zia, chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board, yesterday began a campaign to save the career of the banned pace bowler Shoaib Akhtar by calling for video footage of three of the world's top bowlers.

"We have asked the ICC to send us videos of Sri Lankan Muttiah Muralitharan, West Indian Courtney Walsh and South African Shaun Pollock so that we can compare Akhtar's bowling with their actions," said Zia, who is also understood to be interested in the bowling action of England's Darren Gough.

Shoaib has been suspended by the ICC for a month on the ground that his action is illegal, although Pakistan have lodged an appeal.

Zia rejected a statement by his board's secretary Shafqat Rana on Australian radio that the decision to suspend Shoaib was racially based. Rana said only Asian players were being affected. "It was a very immature and sad statement coming from a very senior official of the PCB," Zia said. "We accept the ICC and all its decisions but reserve the right to challenge its judgments."

Yesterday Shoaib was sent home from Australia by the Pakistan team manager Brigadier Khawaja Mohammad Nasir, who said the affair was affecting the team's preparation for the one-day series against Australia and India.

Shoaib has been advised by the former Australia pace bowler Dennis Lillee to spend a few days in a cricket academy in Perth to obtain film of his bowling action from different angles before his return. Three other former Test fast bowlers - West Indies' Michael Holding and the Pakistanis Imran Khan and Sarfraz Nawaz - will also be asked to help him.

New Zealand yesterday went 2-0 up in their one-day series against West Indies when an unbeaten half-century by their captain Stephen Fleming earned a seven-wicket win in Taupo.

They cruised past the target of 192 all out in a rain-shortened match to take control of the five-match series. Fleming shared in an unbroken fourth-wicket stand of 57 with Chris Cairns to guide his team home with more than six overs to spare.

Earlier West Indies were indebted to 69 from Jimmy Adams but were bowled out three balls short of their 42-over allotment. The slow left-armer Daniel Vettori (four for 24) was New Zealand's most successful bowler and was named man of the match.

Sri Lanka have named the former captain and vice-captain Arjuna Ranatunga and Aravinda de Silva in a 22-man squad for next month's tour of Pakistan. Sanath Jayasuriya will lead the side.

Sri Lanka squad: S Jayasuriya (capt), M Jayawardena, A de Silva, A Ranatunga, M Atapattu, R Arnold, M Muralitharan, U Chandana, R Kaluwitharana, P Wickramasinghe, C Vaas, C de Silva, I de Seram, I Gallage, T Dilshan, P Jayawardene, R Herath, N Perera, U Fernando, K Sangakkara, R Pushpakumara, N Zoysa.

fields.headline: Cullinan continues his Cape monopoly
fields.standfirst: Record-making batsman offers no crumbs of comfort under the Table
fields.trailText: Paul Allott on Daryll Cullinan, who yesterday passed 700 runs at Newlands to confirm himself as South Africa' premier batsman.
fields.body:
Daryll Cullinan relishes playing here at Newlands. He does not get much time to admire one of the finest stadiums in the world or the wondrous backdrop of Table Mountain which is its signature, because he spends more time batting here than any of his contemporaries.

His Test record here is superb. Yesterday he passed 700 runs on this ground while confirming himself as South Africa's premier batsman.

As he strode to the crease he had an average of just under 60 in Test matches at Newlands, compared with an overall Test average of 42. And while his colleagues unexpectedly wilted under a superb onslaught from England, he stood firm. He alone dominated the third day when it had been expected that all the batsmen would capitalise on this true pitch and South Africa would make more than 500 runs.

Cullinan had a marvellous 1999, beginning with a century, at Newlands of course, against West Indies in January. Three more hundreds followed, including 275 not out against New Zealand on an Auckland pitch that had had its cracks literally glued together by the groundsman. That propelled him into the record books with South Africa's highest score in Test cricket, a score since matched by Gary Kirsten in Durban.

Last year Cullinan was the sixth highest run-scorer in Test cricket with the highest average at just over 71, and he has begun the new millennium in this ever improving mood.

When he reached 85 here he had completed 1,000 runs in Tests against England at an average of exactly 50. Of the 10 fifties he scored against England only one had been converted into a hundred, a statistic that would have irked him considerably and made him even more determined to go through to three figures yesterday. When he did so he joined Kirsten as the leading century-scorer for South Africa with 10 each.

Cullinan has been around South African cricket for 16 years. He was the youngest South African to score a first-class century when he was 16, and he also holds the domestic scoring record for his 337 not out for Transvaal.

He made his Test debut in 1992 and has a steadily improving record since then, the only blips coming when he has played against Australia or Pakistan. Remarkably for such a gifted player he averages under 13 in his 13 innings against Australia and has suffered at the hands of Shane Warne, who completely demoralised him. And he averages only 19 against Pakistan, the wiles of Saqlain Mushtaq and Mushtaq Ahmed proving too much.

As a result he was thought to be a poor player of spin, but paradoxically he averages more than 50 against India and Sri Lanka, and the way in which he attacked Phil Tufnell by using his feet to hit cleanly down the ground suggested he had anything but a weakness against the slower bowlers.

Cullinan has had one sortie into English county cricket when he played for Derbyshire in 1995. The variety of pitches he played on in that season helped to complete his cricketing education and his Test career blossomed. In 14 matches for Derbyshire he scored 1,003 runs but could not be enticed back, preferring to further his international career by concentrating his efforts in South Africa.

Those efforts have paid dividends for him and he is now firmly where he wants to be. He is the most consistent South African batsman and is now forging his way into the top 10 in world cricket. He has capitalised on a beautiful wicket at Newlands and would dearly love to roll up the pitch, pop it in his cricket bag and bat on it at every opportunity.

webTitle: McGrath puts India out of their misery

fields.headline: McGrath puts India out of their misery
fields.standfirst:
India 150 and 261
Australia 552-5 dec
fields.trailText: Australia defeated India with two days to spare in the third and final Test in Sydney yesterday to win the series 3-0.
fields.body:
Australia defeated India with two days to spare in the third and final Test in Sydney yesterday to win the series 3-0.

Even a defiant 167 from Venkat Laxman could not save the tourists. Needing 402 to make Australia bat again, they were bowled out in their second innings shortly before stumps.

For Australia, 331 for four overnight, Justin Langer took his score from 167 to 223 - the best individual innings by an Australian against India - and Ricky Ponting made 141 not out, his second century of the series. Glenn McGrath then took five for 55 to finish with 10 wickets in the match.

Indian commentators have pointed to several decisions that went against them in the three Tests, including those in favour of Langer in this match as well as three dubious ones against the Indian captain Sachin Tendulkar through the series. They also pointed an accusing finger at the International Cricket Council match referee, Sri Lanka's Ranjan Madugalle, who imposed a fine and a one-match suspended sentence on the Indian medium-pace bowler Venkatesh Prasad but let off McGrath after he gave Tendulkar a "send-off" in Sydney.

The most controversial decision involving Tendulkar, who made only four yesterday, was in the first Test in Adelaide when he was given out lbw without scoring as he ducked into a McGrath bouncer which struck him on the shoulder.

But Steve Waugh, the Australian captain, suggested the Indians had only themselves to blame for their third-Test defeat. "I would have to say they were pretty negative from the start," he said. "But it's not easy when you haven't got such a good away record."

Waugh claimed the only real injustice was Tendulkar being named player of the series. He scored 278 runs at an average of 46.33, but Ponting made 375 at 125 and McGrath took 18 wickets at 13.72. "I'm not surprised because it always happens to us," Waugh said.

Tendulkar refused to join the debate. "It's been a tough tour," he said. "It's an altogether different ball game when you play in Australia compared to India. But there are quite a lot of things we have learnt on this tour and they should help to broaden our knowledge."

fields.headline: Blair Witch bandwagon rolls on
fields.standfirst: Also today, Hopkins sinks his teeth in, Shakespeare goes Pulp Fiction, in brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: There will definitely be more Blair Witch projects, the producer of last year's hit spooky mockumentary confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
There will definitely be more Blair Witch projects, the producer of last year's hit spooky mockumentary confirmed yesterday.

In an interview with USA Today, president of Artisan Entertainment, Amir Malin, promised both a Blair Witch prequel and a sequel but admitted that they would not be shot on video like the first feature.

"[The sequel and prequel] will not be shot with a digital camera that looks like it was made for $50,000 to $60,000," Malin said.

"In keeping with the franchise, I think it's not going to appear like a David Lean film, either. We'll keep that sense of reality and add a little more meat to the bone." That 'little more meat on the bone' amounts to a budget of between $7m and $10m for each film. Compare that to the original Blair Witch which converted a budget of $40,000 into a $140.5 million gross, making it history's most proportionately successful film ever.

Malin would not be drawn on the story of the sequel, but said the return of the three student film-makers who went AWOL in a Maryland forest remains a possibility. Scheduled to direct is Joe Berlinger, who made the award-winning documentary Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills. Casting is also underway, with a view to start production in six weeks time. The plan is to have the film in the can in time for a Halloween release date.

Blair Witch directors Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez will return to write, direct and produce the prequel which, Malin says "will go back to the early days of the [Blair Witch] mythology to the late 18th century and lead up to where we left off [in the first film]". Current plans call for the duo to step into the third film project upon completion of their non-Blair related second feature, Heart of Love, which is currently in production. Blair 3 is tentatively scheduled for a release in the summer of 2001.

Hopkins sinks his teeth in

Anthony Hopkins might have a bone to pick with Jodie Foster after she pulled out of Hannibal, the sequel to The Silence of the Lambs (See yesterday's news), but he remains committed to the project, according to his publicist Catherine Olim.

The sole sticking point is Hopkins's fee for reprising his Oscar-winning role. Variety quotes Olim as saying: "assuming they can work out a deal - and all of that remains to be ironed out - he wants to do it. He's always said it would depend on the script. He's read the script". Universal yesterday confirmed that Hopkins did not make a decision until he had read and been satisfied by Steve Zaillian's Hannibal rewrite.

Step back Pulp Fiction, Titus is here

Those desperate to see Anthony Hopkins revelling in gore need not wait as long as the release of Hannibal. The actor, long hailed as a worthy successor to Sir Laurence Olivier, stars as Titus Andronicus in Julie Taymor's Shakespearean adaptation Titus, which has just been released to great acclaim in the States.

Certainly punters expecting the jolly froth of Shakespeare in Love are in for a shock. Noted for her Broadway hit The Lion King, Taymor has apparently conjured Shakespeare's maligned first play about vengeance in imperial Rome into a veritable blood-fest. One online reviewer, commenting on the high rate of severed hands, heads and tongues ends his critique: "if you like slasher movies, check it out".

webTitle: Pele turns up heat on Ferguson

fields.headline: Pele turns up heat on Ferguson
fields.standfirst: 'O Rei' sees problems for the European champions
fields.trailText: Pele believes Sir Alex Ferguson's players should make the most of the sun and sand, because they will struggle when they go into action on Thursday.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin and Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Pele tends to be friendly to tourists. On the road from the airport his face can be seen smiling down from a large billboard. "Welcome to Brazil," he beams. The greeting he reserved for Manchester United was different.

The man known in his homeland as O Rei , the king, likes to speak his mind. And as the World Club Championship approached its opening in Sao Paulo tonight, he hinted that Sir Alex Ferguson's players should make the most of the sun and sand, because they would struggle on grass.

"The weather and the conditions will make it very difficult for Manchester United," he said. "Do not underestimate how much it could affect them. They will have to adapt their style of play. That will be a decisive factor.

"I don't believe the draw has been kind to them either. Vasco da Gama are very strong. They have been building for this competition. They regard it as the most important series of matches of their season.

"The match between Vasco and Manchester United in the Maracana [on Saturday] promises to be the highlight of the tournament. I believe whoever wins will go on to win the championship, and for me that will be Vasco."

The 7-0 hammering Vasco dealt to a demoralised Algerian XI on Monday suggests they will not be short of confidence. More than 40 minutes before kick-off, a mass of Vasco supporters were banging drums and dancing arm-in-arm across the vast concrete steps.

The teams emerged to a crackle of fireworks, blazing flares and streams of enough toilet paper to keep a favela, never mind a family, clean for a year.

For all the skill and sharpness of Romario, Donizete and Felipe, however, Vasco look vulnerable to the counterattack, particularly through the middle. But first United must overcome Necaxa tomorrow.

Ferguson is here to win and is looking forward to the Maracana. To him it signifies how far his career has come.

"When you start off it's your big ambition to get to Hampden Park," he said. "Then you hope to get to FA Cup finals, to play on a great platform like Wembley. I've also been in three European cup finals, in Gothenburg, Rotterdam and the Nou Camp. But playing at the Maracana will cap the lot.

"I'm sure the players are excited; it's an incredible place, with great history. It used to hold 200,000 people. Brazil, the greatest international team, play there. It was there that Pele scored his 1,000th goal."

Only 400 or so United fans are here, no surprise when the club warned of the dangers of Rio and one official 16-day package cost £1,149. The good news for them is that Roy Keane, whose left knee was heavily strapped in training yesterday, should play. And their numbers will be swelled by fans from Vasco's great rivals, Flamengo. So great is the antipathy between the Rio clubs that scores of Flamengo supporters greeted United at the airport in half-Flamengo, half-United shirts.

Another special-edition T-shirt is available on the internet. It one features a cod with a cross through it, a symbol which history and gastronomy explain: Vasco are the team of Portuguese immigrants and, since salted cod is a Portuguese delicacy, they have assumed the nickname "The Cod".

The hand, or feet, of Cod will almost certainly determine whether United progress to the final as group winners or to the third-place play-off as runners-up. It is hard to imagine Necaxa or South Melbourne defeating them, unless the conditions destroy the treble-winners' rhythm.

Even with 6.15pm kick-offs local time, the temperature will be slightly warmer than in Salford. Ferguson, of course, has come prepared. "We have brought 12 backroom staff with us, including our own chef and nutritionalist, and we took advice from several experts on diet and what to drink before we came out," he said.

"The players are dealing with it very well. So far they have been losing 4lb in training sessions. That is typical in these conditions and they have put it straight back on afterwards. The most anyone has lost so far is Jaap Stam, who lost 5lb. But it's not been that hot so far."

As well as countering the heat, Ferguson must ensure his players keep their cool. Suspensions will be carried into Fifa and Uefa competitions next season, potentially ruling players out of the Champions League or even a World Cup qualifier. Suspensions of up to two months are possible. But, Fifa explained, fines may be imposed instead.

As United prepared to play for the £3.7m winners' prize, their chairman and chief executive Martin Edwards talked of why the world's best player, Rivaldo, will not be moving to Old Trafford. "He interested us but it didn't work. We have spent millions on [Dwight] Yorke and Stam and can't play around with money. The problem with Rivaldo is that the Brazil team calls him up to the squad the whole time."

Roberto Carlos should be among the Brazilians on show when Real Madrid play Al Nassr in the first of tonight's two games in the Morumbi Stadium. The Saudis have been able to train only at night because of Ramadan, which may be welcome news to Nicolas Anelka. He is likely to start in Real's attack alongside Morientes; Raul is injured.

Despite a sway of opinion in Britain that this tournament makes the Auto Windscreens Shield look important, it is almost certainly here to stay. "We believe this competition represents the future of football," said the chairman of the organising committee, Abdullah Al Dubal.

As Ferguson said: "If Fifa is involved I expect it to become something big." He must just hope Pele is wrong.

webTitle: Party divided over Kohl slush fund scandal

fields.headline: Party divided over Kohl slush fund scandal
fields.trailText: Senior members of Germany's Christian Democrats were for the first time openly split last night over the campaign funding scandal enveloping their former leader and ex-chancellor, Helmut Kohl.
fields.body:
Senior members of Germany's Christian Democrats were for the first time openly split last night over the campaign funding scandal enveloping their former leader and ex-chancellor, Helmut Kohl.

As the party chairman, Wolfgang Schäuble, nailed his colours to the mast of Mr Kohl's foundering ship, another senior Christian Democrat called on the former chancellor to leave politics - and was himself condemned by a colleague.

On Monday, prosecutors in Bonn began proceedings to decide whether Mr Kohl should stand trial after he admitted channelling anonymous donations through secret accounts. Although German law calls for all political contributions over DM20,000 (£6,400) to be made public, the former chancellor refuses to name donors who gave the party DM2m .

Mr Schäuble, who replaced Dr Kohl as head of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), said the party did not necessarily have to hand back the money. He said he found it "rather difficult to understand" the the basis of the prosecutors' inquiry and said there were no grounds for a criminal investigation.

He was clearly at odds with the CDU's general secretary, Angela Merkel, who last month hinted that Mr Kohl, who is still an MP, should pull out of public life. Yesterday, Michael Luther, a deputy chairman of the CDU in parliament, called openly for Mr Kohl's retirement. "It would be best for everyone if Helmut Kohl could decide to make an orderly exit from politics," he said.

Mr Luther's remarks were swiftly attacked. "It is politically tasteless and tactically not very clever," said Peter Ramsauer, an official in the CDU's Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union.

But the appeal confirmed what Mr Schäuble had denied - that the Christian Democrats are split over the party's duty to defend its former leader at all costs.

Mr Schäuble dismissed speculation that the CDU, which has set aside nearly £2.5m to cover fines arising from the affair, could be ruined by the case. "Whoever hopes we will end up bankrupt can forget it," he said. He added that the obligation to return the slush fund cash would be lifted as soon as the identity of the benefactors was made known.

His remark offered Mr Kohl, who has said he owes a debt of honour to the donors, a way out of the crisis. Mr Schäuble has given him the opportunity to claim an overriding responsibility to the party.

Mr Schäuble is himself in difficulties over claims that the parliamentary party transferred a large amount of money to head office while he was in charge. It is against German law for parliamentary groups to make donations to their own parties. But Mr Schäuble said the ban only applied to money from the taxpayer, and not from MPs' own incomes.

webTitle: Women in record South Pole walk

fields.headline: Women in record South Pole walk
fields.trailText: British explorers achieved a double record last night when the first  women and the first married     couple completed a walk to the South Pole.
fields.body:
British explorers achieved a double record last night when the first women and the first married couple completed a walk to the South Pole.

Catherine Hartley and Fiona and Mike Thornewill arrived at the pole at 9.30pm GMT after covering 730 miles over 61 days and beating a rival team of British women, which included the Queen Mother's great niece.

On reaching the pole, recruitment consultant Mrs Thornewill, 33, who suffered painful infection in her legs during the journey, said: "I am totally exhausted and totally elated. All day I have been able to ignore the pain from my bleeding feet and the infected sores on my legs knowing that it will soon be over."

Ms Hartley, 34, a stage manager from Clapham, south London, who had no previous experience of such an arduous trip, said she had come through relatively unscathed adding: "I have no injuries except a sore toe but I am very very tired. But I am thrilled and amazed."

Mr Thornewill, 37, a police officier from Nottinghamshire, who was realising a 30-year dream, told the Daily Telegraph: "I am incredibly excited, it is unbelievable, everything that we planned has come true. I'm feeling a bit tearful. It has been a struggle but it has been worth all the hardship, pain, and hunger. I am overwhelmed.

"It has been a hell of a journey for a married couple to go through. We knew we would be fine together but we have come back with a far deeper understanding of one another having shared something so demanding."

Prime minister Tony Blair sent a message of congratulations to the three and called their achievement "a wonderful start to the millennium".

Mr and Mrs Thorne had little experience of polar exploration. Before the expedition they had only spent 10 days at Spitzbergen in the arctic, a trip which gave them the idea for the nine-week trek. They braved temperatures as low as -30C, searing 40-knot winds, and the constant threats of frostbite and crevasses.

Mary Alton, Mr Thornewill's 61-year-old mother, said the expedition proved the couple would go to the end of the earth for each other.

Mr Thornewill claimed the experience had taught him his wife was "far tougher than I thought," especially as she refused to leave her vanity case behind and carried with her a cake to mark his 37th birthday - seven weeks into the trek.

The other British team, led by film financier Caroline Hamilton and including the Queen Mother's great niece Rosie Stancer, 38, a writer from Prague, set off some days behind its rivals and is expected to reach the pole next week.

fields.headline: Tony's pet project
fields.standfirst: Guardian political editor Michael White sketches the political landscape that faces Tony Blair over proportional representation
fields.trailText: Two and a half years in power Tony Blair remains a uniquely popular prime minister among voters. But he is also a lonely one among fellow Labour MPs and party activists over one of his pet projects.
fields.body:
Two and a half years in power Tony Blair remains a uniquely popular prime minister among voters. But he is also a lonely one among fellow Labour MPs and party activists over one of his pet projects.

Mr Blair would love to see Labour and the Liberal Democrats edging towards a centre-left coalition, allowing 'progressive' politics to marginalise what he likes to call "the forces of conservatism" - on both left and right - in the way that the Tories marginalised Labour for much of the 20th century.

If his 1997 majority had been smaller than the record 179-seat landslide he planned to take Paddy Ashdown into his cabinet. That would have been unpopular in his party too. But, in that moment of triumph, it might have worked.

The other big casualty of the landslide was faltering Labour interest in electoral reform for Westminster, changing the way Britain elects its 659 MPs from the historic first-past-the-post (FPTP) system to one of the many versions of proportional representation (PR).

After losing four elections Labour had been wondering if PR was the answer. Neil Kinnock was a convert, the late John Smith set up a commission which recommended a cautious yes. He also promised a referendum on PR which Blair endorsed. Though pro-coalition, he was personally "unpersuaded" on the case for PR, and knew his party was largely hostile to both. Peter Mandelson, Mo Mowlam, Robin Cook, were - and are - pro-PR, John Prescott, Gordon Brown and Jack Straw are hostile.

But the PM wanted to keep the Lib Dems on side. He didn't need their 46 votes - but one day he might do, to neutralise a resurgent left. So in 1997 he asked Lord Jenkins of Hillhead, the ex-Labour chancellor and SDP leader, to produce an independent report on the issue.

The old Liberal Party had been campaigning for PR since the 1920s, when it first collapsed. In 1929 the minority Labour government came within a whisker of granting it. Its heir, the Liberal Democrats, still believe that FPTP is unfair because its takes no account of the 'wasted' votes of people who don't vote for the winning candidate.

Lib Dems also believe that PR will provide more stable and representative government which prevents an "elective dictatorship" by a cabinet backed by only 43 per cent of the votes - the share that won Margaret Thatcher power three times. Most countries have PR, they argue. They favour STV, the single transferable vote system, which requires voters to list candidates in order. As those with fewest votes in multi-member seats see their second preferences transferred the result would reflect the votes cast: a party with 40 per cent of local votes gets 40 per cent of the MPs.

Supporters of FPTP say that is all nonsense; that PR creates unstable coalitions and, far from ending backroom deals, puts minor parties into the driving seat - not "fair" at all. They point to tensions in Israel which has pure PR and even to the Scottish Executive which the PR system used ( a "top-up" system called the additional member system or AMS added a "fairness" element) to produce a Lib-Lab coalition.

Jenkins came up with a clever compromise. Four fifths of MPs would still be elected in traditional constituencies, retaining that key link. But they would have to get more than half the votes cast first under a modification called the alternative vote (AV) which asks people to list candidates in order of preference: the winner must get 50 %.

As in Scotland's AMS the Jenkins 'AV-Plus' scheme would 'top up' the result by allocating extra MPs to parties which got votes but too few seats under AV voting. Both sides of the PR debate contain impassioned partisans, sceptics and anoraks. Most voters tend to be agnostic, though pro-PR backers say they would win a referendum if Mr Blair campaigned for a yes.

As things stand, he won't. Labour's huge losses in last June's Euro-elections when a 'closed list' system of PR was introduced (it lost 33 of its 62 seats at Strasbourg) shook the whole party. Blair is also worried about the impact of different forms of PR on devolution elections and the mayor for London, where PR could help Ken Livingstone win as an independent.

The PM is biding his time - and could jump either way. Charles Kennedy, the new Lib Dem leader, wants a referendum after the next election if it gives a better chance of victory. He wants to keep the joiunt Lib Lab cabinet committee with Blair. But if he doesn't get PR his activists will kill it. If Blair concedes it and wins a referendum his party activists may kill him.

fields.headline: Ideal Holmes show
fields.trailText: Sherlock Holmes - and I say this on the basis of absolutely no evidence, having preferred Christie to Conan Doyle in that teenage crime phase - is a con. Like Hercule Poirot, he upholds the power of deduction over detection and tries to convince us that all crimes are soluble.
fields.body:
Sherlock Holmes - and I say this on the basis of absolutely no evidence, having preferred Christie to Conan Doyle in that teenage crime phase - is a con. Like Hercule Poirot, he upholds the power of deduction over detection and tries to convince us that all crimes are soluble. But, in an arbitrary world, his confident application of reason flies in the face of the facts. Sometimes things just don't make sense; they are, my dear Watson, far from elementary.

That, of course, is the secret of Holmes's phenomenal success, both in the late 19th century, when he captivated magazine readers, and through the 20th century, when Conan Doyle's books continued to sell in vast numbers and his other-worldly detective found new life on the screen. We want to believe that logic conquers all, but it is Holmes's brand which seems to be winning. Nor is there any sign of the interest flagging: there are numerous Holmes societies around the world and growing internet interest in the minutiae of life at 221B Baker Street. Conan Doyle attempted, unsuccessfully, to kill off Holmes (his fans refused to let him die) and, 70 years after the author's death, his creation is in as rude health as ever.

Murder Rooms: The Dark Beginnings Of Sherlock Holmes (BBC2) is further proof of Holmes's durability. It suggests that the detective was based closely on Conan Doyle's tutor at Edinburgh, Dr Joseph Bell, a forensic pathologist who gets his kicks by helping the idiotic Edinburgh police force with their inquiries. Bell - obsessive, slightly potty, driven by some inner demon, always right - is, to all intents and purposes, Holmes, with the young Conan Doyle falling immediately into the Watson role. All that remained, this argument runs, was for Conan Doyle to run short of cash, summon up his Edinburgh experiences and write the 60 Sherlock Holmes stories.

The Bell-Holmes theory is far from proven, but it made for an interesting hybrid - part crime thriller, part late-Victorian costume drama, part documentary about the genesis of Conan Doyle's fiction. Ian Richardson enjoyed himself hugely as Bell; Robin Laing was suitably wide-eyed as the young Conan Doyle; the blood flowed freely, and the romantic interest was only mildly irritating. There is a profusion of plot lines - dead busker, mad father, crazed student opposed to the introduction of women to the university, strange goings-on in a brothel - to be tied together in tonight's concluding episode. A con - but an enjoyable one.

The young women in Au Pairs (BBC1) travelled abroad full of hope, expectation and trepidation; only the last of these proved justified. The children were impossible; the parents were worse; and the women, deriving no comfort from the company of strangers, couldn't cope.

In the great tradition of docusoaps, this was intrusion masquerading as social commentary. Au pairs are manifestly underprepared for the work they do: there are dangers for them and for the children they look after. The programme had an agenda and it would be interesting to know how these three women were chosen: was there an expectation (a hope even) that things would go wrong? What sort of show would it have been if everything had gone wonderfully - a version of the holiday programme, presumably, with sunny scenes from Spain, Italy and Washington?

For Donna, a 20-year-old from a tough Welsh working-class background looking after a two-year-old in Italy, things went horribly wrong. You knew it would when she arrived in the promised land to the strains of a gut-wrenching aria from Tosca. While the family was away on a skiing holiday, she was assaulted by a man from her Italian class. Where, one wondered, was the camera at the time of the assault? That begs further questions: how do docusoaps decide when and where to film, and to what degree can we trust the narrative?

You were left feeling desperately sorry for Donna, but wondering too about the point of it all. The producers would argue that they were exposing a potentially dangerous situation and making a case for greater regulation of an industry that appears to be a free-for-all, but were they really doing anything more than expose the naivety of three vulnerable young women?

Like Hercule Poirot, he upholds the power of deduction over detection and tries to convince us that all crimes are soluble. But, in an arbitrary world, his confident application of reason flies in the face of the facts. Sometimes things just don't make sense; they are, my dear Watson, far from elementary. That, of course, is the secret of Holmes's phenomenal success, both in the late 19th century, when he captivated magazine readers, and through the 20th century, when Conan Doyle's books continued to sell in vast numbers and his other-worldly detective found new life on the screen. We want to believe that logic conquers all, but it is Holmes's brand which seems to be winning. Nor is there any sign of the interest flagging: there are numerous Holmes societies around the world and growing internet interest in the minutiae of life at 221B Baker Street. fields.headline: Pinochet leaves hospital after tests
fields.trailText:
General Augusto Pinochet has left a London hospital after undergoing medical
tests to determine whether he will be extradited to Spain to face torture charges or sent home to Chile.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet has left a London hospital after undergoing medical tests to determine whether he will be extradited to Spain to face torture charges or sent home to Chile.

The 84-year-old former Chilean dictator arrived at Northwick Park Hospital in Harrow shortly before 9am with a large entourage from the Chilean Embassy. Almost seven hours later, he emerged holding a walking stick and left the hospital without comment, avoiding the photographers staked out around the building.

The tests were requested by Chile last November after reports that Pinochet, 84, was in poor health as he awaits the outcome of moves by Spain to extradite him on charges of torture. Pinochet's supporters say he is frail and has suffered a series of strokes.

Pinochet was examined by a neurologist and a specialist in diseases afflicting the elderly. Home secretary Jack Straw can block his extradition on compassionate grounds if he thinks Pinochet is too frail to stand trial.

However, human rights campaigners said Pinochet should be tried even if he would never serve a day behind bars.

"We believe that a full and fair trial of General Pinochet would be tremendously valuable in establishing a record of his crimes, even if he doesn't serve a day in prison," said Reed Brody of Human Rights Watch. "He should only be returned to Chile if he is unlikely to survive the legal process."

Juan Garces, one of the Spanish lawyers pressing for Pinochet's extradition, said the medical team should confine its checks to Pinochet's mental faculties and declare him fit for trial.

"The physicians' statement should be delivered in the context of a legal case. If he was expected to be in an athletic competition, certainly the statement of the doctors should be in another direction," Garces told BBC radio. "(But) in a judicial case... the mental capacities are the issue."

But shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe said Mr Straw was obliged to act according to the medical reports. "Jack Straw is bound by the decisions of the courts and must risk medical conditions being taken into account," she said.

Meanwhile, it emerged that the NHS hospital where Pinochet underwent tests is so busy that it has resorted to treating emergency patients in a special van parked outside. While the former Chilean dictator was being examined in a wing separated from other patients at Northwick Park, the hospital's accident and emergency department is so stretched that patients are being attended to in a mobile treatment vehicle parked on a ramp outside the hospital entrance.

webTitle: Business as usual for Kremlin cronies as Putin era begins

fields.headline: Business as usual for Kremlin cronies as Putin era begins
fields.trailText: In his first interview since becoming Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin last night said that it was hard for Boris Yeltsin to leave the Kremlin on New Year's Eve because there was so much "linking him to the people who work there".
fields.body:
In his first interview since becoming Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin last night said that it was hard for Boris Yeltsin to leave the Kremlin on New Year's Eve because there was so much "linking him to the people who work there".

Mr Putin may have been displaying a well-hidden talent for irony because for any Russian, the remark was double-edged. The Yeltsin "family" which has been running the Kremlin and Russia for years has given politics a bad name.

It is a powerful network of cronies, relatives, business associates, and sycophants, notorious for its byzantine, ruthless and, it is alleged, corrupt ways.

Mr Yeltsin found it sad to leave, Mr Putin said, "because there is so much that links him with these walls, these rooms, these buildings". Not least among the many qualities that make up Mr Putin's appeal to Russians is his image as a Mr Clean. But he himself emerged from the Yeltsin inner circle.

Moscow analysts are speculating madly about what will become of the Yeltsin courtiers now that the Tsar has gone. Are they safe with Mr Putin?

"He's their man," said Mikhail Gorbachev, the last president of the Soviet Union. "The regime won't change, there won't be a fight against corruption. The interests and the privileges of the oligarchy will be fully protected."

As Mr Yeltsin's bitter enemy, Mr Gorbachev is jaundiced, but there is little Mr Putin does not know about the family.

Before becoming prime minister he spent 17 years in the KGB, two years in the Kremlin administration and a year as head of the FSB - successor to the KGB. There can be few figures in Russia as well-informed about the foibles of the Yeltsin entourage.

Prominent members of the family have been cock-a-hoop at the Putin takeover, suggesting that they have nothing to fear. Anatoly Chubais, the former Yeltsin chief of staff, said Mr Yeltsin's resignation was a stroke of genius.

But Mr Putin has swiftly removed Tatyana Dyachenko, Mr Yeltsin's daughter, who has been highly influential in the Kremlin for years. The official position of Mrs Dyachenko, 39, was "image adviser" to the president, but she served as a political aide and also controlled access to Mr Yeltsin.

It was signalled on Friday that she would not keep her post and it was made official on Monday, even though Mr Putin is said to have a good relationship with her.

Mr Putin has also brought in his own spokesman, but the man he replaced, Dmitri Yakushkin, keeps a job in the administration. Another two Yeltsin aides will retain jobs with the ex-president.

As soon as Mr Yeltsin resigned on Friday, his chief of staff, Alexander Voloshin, also stepped down. He was immediately reinstated by Mr Putin in what appeared to be part of a handover deal. The staff changes, a Kremlin aide told the Interfax news agency, do not signal "a new broom".

Mr Putin's first act as acting president last Friday was to sign a decree guaranteeing Mr Yeltsin immunity from prosecution. The reaction to this in Moscow was that there can be no smoke without fire - that if Mr Yeltsin had nothing to hide, he would not need to be immune from prosecution.

It is a very detailed and legalistic decree. Not only is Mr Yeltsin immune from prosecution, so are all members of his immediate family. The Yeltsin homes, offices, and cars cannot be searched. His correspondence cannot be tampered with. His phones cannot be tapped. Moreover, all members of his family, not just his wife Naina, will receive pensions on his death.

For now, it appears that the Yeltsin clan is safe, although Mr Putin may launch a law and order crackdown to buttress his public support.

But if he is to reject the sleaze which many Russian believe had infested the Yeltsin camp, he is unlikely to do so before the presidential election, expected in March.

webTitle: Hunt for rail crash bodies continues

fields.headline: Hunt for rail crash bodies continues
fields.trailText: Rescuers at first light today resumed searching the wreckage of two Norwegian  trains that crashed head-on and burned, killing up to 33 people and injuring more than two dozen others.
fields.body:
Rescuers at first light today resumed searching the wreckage of two Norwegian trains that crashed head-on and burned, killing up to 33 people and injuring more than two dozen others.

There was said to be little expectation of finding additional survivors. Authorities found seven bodies and said another 26 of the 100 people aboard were missing, feared dead.

"They are probably not alive. The damage was so great that they could not have survived," district police chief Magnar Lynum said at a news conference on Tuesday in Elverum, located 10 miles south of the crash site.

A fire that engulfed one of the trains burned for about six hours, leaving the wreckage too hot to search. Firefighters confirmed there were no more survivors aboard.

Rescue crews spent the night in military tents set up at the site, 110 miles north of the capital Oslo.

If the death toll reaches 33, it would be Norway's worst train wreck in more than 25 years. In 1975, two passenger trains collided in central Norway, killing 27 people.

"This is a catastrophe," said Norwegian minister of transport Dag Jostein Fjaervoll.

The two passenger trains, with 100 people aboard, crashed head-on at high-speed yesterday about 110 miles north of Oslo. Seven people were found dead shortly after the crash and 26 more were missing and feared dead. Another 30 were injured.

"What we are doing now is bringing the bodies out," said Ove Osgjelten of the district police. He said it would probably take all day Wednesday and Thursday to recover the bodies, many of which were badly burned.

A fire engulfed the trains, burning for hours and blocking efforts to rescue those trapped inside or recover additional bodies until early today. Some victims burned alive.

"The worst thing to experience is to stand there and watch people burn... going through that train and seeing people who were alive and conscious who we couldn't help," said Ola Sunderaal, an ambulance crewman who was one of the first on the scene.

Officials said the search of the still smouldering wreckage would be slow and difficult, as many bodies will have to be cut out of the wreckage.

"One of the locomotives, which weighs 100 tons, is leaning and it is impossible to know if it is secure," Haakon Grimstad of the state railways directorate told The Associated Press. He said it wasn't even clear in which cars the missing victims were located.

A group of eight Britons and a Dutch couple were on board the train but had all survived without serious injuries, police spokesman Per Ravnkleven said.

A local train with 17 people aboard and a larger regional express with 83 people aboard were probably each going up to 55 mph around a curve when they crashed head on, according the state railroad directorate. The diesel trains - one southbound and the other northbound - collided at about 12.30 GMT at the Aasta Station in Aamot township near the town of Rena.

The cause of the accident was being investigated. The section of track did not have a system that would automatically stop trains headed for each other, but was due for an upgrade next year.

Survivors told of initial calm, then chaos and frustration. Passenger Rasmus Alme, 20, said he tried to save two old women who were caught in the wreckage, before the flames forced him to flee.

"It was terrible. I so badly wanted to save them," he was quoted as telling the Oslo newspaper Verdens Gang. "The heat was so intense. The women asked me to stay, but I had to jump." In the despair, there were moments of triumph.

Steffen Solberg, head of the medical team, said rescuers worked for four hours to cut a 33-year-old woman out of the wreckage. He said firefighters kept the blaze from consuming her until she was finally rescued.

"That was the biggest experience of my life. When she was brought out there were smiles everywhere in this middle of this tragedy and tears in many eyes," he said.

It was the second serious public transport accident in Norway in just over a month. On Nov. 26, 16 people drowned when a high-speed ferry ran aground and sank.

webTitle: Cold compresses, Motorway service stations and Bearded Frenchmen

fields.headline: Cold compresses, Motorway service stations and Bearded Frenchmen
fields.trailText: CARRY ON SPENDING
fields.body:
CARRY ON SPENDING

Liverpool fans may want to sit down on their Bill Shankly bean bag before reading much further. The Fiver has come into possession of a league table which, for some reason, has the Reds at the top. Occasionally the Fiver turns the table upside down, or inside out, or subjects it to carbon dating tests, or examines it for watermarks for authenticity. But whatever it does, Liverpool still come out top. Of the spending league, that is.

In the year of 1999, £348m was spent on players in the Premiership, and Gerard Houllier was responsible for magicking away £28.7m of that. He would argue that he also took in £14.7m from player sales, but most of that has been spent on Vladimir Smicer's cold compresses. The arch-capitalist Reds are a good £4m ahead of second-placed Arsenal, who spent a paltry £24.9m on five players at the same time as recouping an astromungous £26.3m. The latter figure must have been invented however, as lonely Nic Anelka never asked for anyone to pay that much money for him and they should all just leave him alone.

Leeds, Newcastle and Chelsea qualify for places in the European spending leagues, taking third, fourth and fifth places respectively. But the surprise hits at the top of the charts are Derby and Wimbledon who spent £17.6m and £16.5m last year in order to battle relegation more glamorously. The size of Wimbledon's outlay means that each season ticket holder at Selhurst Park has contributed around £2m to the cause, and that's including Palace fans.

Before Money Mart writes in, Manchester United came a very abstemious 12th, spending a mere £11m on new reserve goalkeepers and the like. Watford would probably love to have Massimo Taibi in their line-up (indeed they would probably play him up front). The Hornets come bottom of the table having spent only £1.9m all year. Which can only be a tribute to Elton John's sound financial husbandry.

WORRY BEDE

After John Elsom regained control at Leicester City after months of unseemly wrangling, you'd have assumed that everything would go swimmingly at Filbert Street for ever more. Sadly, this has not been the case, because Elsom has been forced to emerge from behind the top table to make a solemn announcement - Leicester have pulled out of plans to build a stadium at Bede Island South, thus ending the club's dream of becoming the first league club to play at a ground which sounds a bit like a motorway service station.

"The board of Leicester City plc have this morning announced that the club's solicitors have been instructed to formally notify the planning inspectorate that Leicester City plc will be withdrawing from the forthcoming planning inquiry for the proposed new stadium due to commence on January 11!" quipped Elsom on Leicester's fun website (www.lcfc.co.uk). It seems the board were not convinced that developers Goldwing could buy all the land required to squeeze in the planned walloping stadium. "The scheme can only be viable if all necessary land interests are acquired," Big John explained. "We have received clear and unanimous advice from our professional advisors that we should not proceed."

Elsom and his pals will now look elsewhere for a place to hoick up their 40,000-seat home: "The board is committed to looking at all opportunities open to us in order to provide a higher capacity stadium for the club at the earliest opportune time. We hope that our shareholders and fans will recognise that we have acted with their best interests in mind." Whether excited fans already looking forward to plush new surroundings will recognise these best interests or not is anybody's guess. Whatever, it's back to boring old Filbert Street for a while longer. Tum te tum... hey, what about giving that Barrie Pierpoint chap a ring? He always livens things up...

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"When we signed John Hartson... there was logic to the situation. We were sixth and only three points off the top three. I thought the time was right to throw everything, including the kitchen sink, at our attempt to try to bridge the gap to the top three. I knew the chances would be very low." - Wimbledon owner Sam Hammam describes the resignation he felt after going on a £7.5m bender.

THE CRACK OF DUMAS

It seems only a couple of months ago that Franck Dumas desperately wanted to stay at Newcastle, declaring he would never leave a job half done. And it seems only a few weeks back that the venerable Bobby Robson Esq. would never let such a talented, and determined, defender as Franck Dumas leave Newcastle. In fact it was only a couple of months ago. Which explains why Dumas is today in the throes of completing a £1.5m move to Marseille after playing only seven games for the Toon.
