"That's what our supporters deserve and that's going to be our policy for the future." Pity he couldn't have thought of that two years ago.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Newcastle United have made a £4m bid for Velez Sarsfield's Argentinian midfielder Christian Bassedas.

Bayern Munich defender Markus Babbel may join Liverpool for a nominal fee later this month. Babbel is understood to want to move to Anfield and is prepared to wait until the summer when he can move under the Bosman ruling.

Leicester City are interested in Danish international striker Soren Fredericksson. Martin O'Neill will take a look at the 27-year-old Aalborg striker in a reserve match.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Nigeria may invoke Fifa sanctions against Arsenal if they do not release Kanu for the forthcoming African Nations Cup. With Dennis Bergkamp and Marc Overmars unfit, Arsenal need Kanu for their FA Cup tie against Leicester. But Nigerian coach Amodu Shaibu is prepared to call in Fifa if Arsene Wenger plays the striker after January 6. "If he plays for them after that date we will invoke FIFA sanctions against them - even if that means their removal from the Cup," said Shaibu.

The FA have charged Wimbledon defender Ben Thatcher after examining video evidence of the incident where he elbowed Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee in the Dons' 1-0 victory at Selhurst Park.

Rangers have bought Turkish international midfielder Tugay Kerimoglu from Galatasaray. The fee, according to chairman David Murray, is "substantially less" than £2m. The player will move to Ibrox before the end of the season subject to a work permit being granted.

Coventry's on-loan striker Cedric Roussel is to complete a £1.5m move from Ghent to Highfield Road. The striker attracted interest from Leeds and Tottenham, but he has agreed a five-year contract with the Sky Blues. The deal is expected to go through in the next couple of weeks.

The Scottish Premier League have decided against switching the date of the Celtic-Rangers game on February 23 despite it clashing with a host of international friendlies. Eyal Berkovic, Giovanni Van Bronckhorst and Arthur Numan are all likely to miss the game, but neither club has complained.

However, Saints chairman Rupert Lowe is optimistic an appeal will prove successful: "Broadly speaking we comply with the spirit of the current regulations and I hope we can convince people that things like Fifa rankings are a fairly volatile yardstick of performance."

Peter Beagrie has signed a new extended contract which keeps him at Bradford until June 2001.

fields.headline: Keeping the faith
fields.standfirst:
While Joanna Moorhead loathes the 'desperate sexism' of the Catholic church, she doesn't want to deprive her daughter of a spiritual heritage. But now first communion is looming, she finds herself facing new dilemmas

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: While  Joanna Moorhead  loathes the 'desperate sexism' of the Catholic church, she doesn't want to deprive her daughter of a spiritual heritage. But now first communion is looming, she finds herself facing new dilemmas
fields.body:
Five months to go to my daughter's big day - and already the date has been chosen, the dress agonised over, and we're starting to think about who to invite. According to friends of mine who went through it all with their offspring last year, you can't start the planning too early. Because, make no mistake about it, this first holy communion business is a big deal: get it wrong, and you'll have not only the wrath of the Almighty down on you, but that of a seven-year-old to boot.

And seven-year-olds, as everyone who has one knows, are an excitable bunch. They're also made for an adventure like this one: still young enough to play with their Barbies, but old enough to stay up for Top of the Pops; young enough to be fobbed off with Ribena most of the time, but cool enough to know that Coke is where it's at. In short, they've started to understand self-definition, but rebellion - thank goodness - is still a few years away.

Which is why they're so ripe for the first holy communion experience, with its chance to be star of the show in a white dress while being admitted to the grown-up Catholic in-crowd.

That's not, of course, what it's all about, as I try to tell Rosie, my first communicant hopeful, as she undertakes her hundredth design of The Frock. It will, she says, be a white, fluffy number, with lace at the wrists and at the hem, and a lacy bit down the front. Fine, I say. But we mustn't forget, must we, that it's a religious occasion? We mustn't forget that your first holy communion is about God, not just about dresses?

OK, says Rosie, without batting an eyelid. We'll remember God in the shoes: they'll be lovely white satin, and on one will be written "Jesus" and on the other "Christ". At least she hasn't asked for the latest first communion accessory from the US, a tiara which - at the flick of a switch in the pocket - lights up for the crucial moment at the altar rail when the priest whispers the words "The body of Christ" and presses the host of bread into the small, eager hands.

It takes you back, having a seven-year-old going to first communion classes. I remember every detail of my own big day three decades ago. I remember the silky smoothness of my dress, and the scratchy net of the petticoat underneath. I remember the concentration with which I walked in procession around the garden before mass, so as not to trip.

I remember scanning the pewfuls of proud mummies and daddies and the little leap of joy in my heart when I recognised my own, and I remember my devout prayer that I wouldn't fall over as I genuflected before taking my place. And I remember, before the ceremony itself, my fear that I would eat something by accident, breaking my obligatory pre-communion fast, like the child in the story Sister Mary related to us. She had to have her first communion postponed until another day, despite her contrite tears.

Now it's all before my own little daughter and, though the shared experience will bind us together, one generation to the next, I also feel a little uneasy at the path she is taking and my part in ushering her along it. I am still a Catholic, but at times I feel I hang on by my fingertips. Like so many of my faith I have rejected, reassessed and realigned my beliefs many times: as one priest friend of mine says, I am one of those Catholics who has chucked away the table d'hõte in favour of the à la carte, preferring to pick and choose rather than swallow the menu whole.

While at times I am inspired by the truly holy people my church has moulded, at other times I baulk at those among its leaders who seem driven by ambition or cowed into silent submission. Then there's the church's sexism, which is as desperate as its spirituality is awesome; if I hang around because of the latter I am also forced, miserably, to endure the former.

Pity, though, those parents who, though on the brink of lapsing, chose to remain in the church for a place in a Catholic school. Now, three or four years on, they find themselves sucked reluctantly back into the fold. Because it's not just the seven-year-olds who have to turn up for their first communion classes: we adults, too, have to show our faces at the regular parents' evenings, at which we are gently chided for our non-attendance at confession, and reminded that, for our children's sake if not our own, we should return, on bended knee, to seek God's forgiveness for our sins.

There are also Rosie's questions to contend with. How did God make the world? Who made God? Where exactly is heaven? And, wherever it is, will we all be going there, even Daddy who is an unbelieving Presbyterian (and, as such, totally bemused by all this first communion stuff)? I answer as best I can, admitting a lot of ignorance - it isn't what Rosie wants to hear, but it is honest.

At least I can ensure that she, unlike me, isn't misled by a misogynist theology: God, I tell her firmly, is as likely to be female as male, and there's no reason why we shouldn't refer to her as "She". To emphasise the point, I go through her first communion course handbook, writing "or She" alongside mentions of God as "He". Rosie, when she sees it, is appalled. Have I gone out of my mind, writing in her first communion book? She will be told off, and no one will believe it was her mother. Now she will have to go through it all with a rubber to erase my mad scribbles.

Rosie is horrified by my unorthodox ideas - life is still black and white when you're seven, and she doesn't want to hear my grey thoughts. So I help her with her communion class homework as best I can, smiling as she gravely compiles a list of "Who matters most in my life" (God, interestingly, comes in at number eight, behind Granny and Granddad and bizarrely enough only just ahead of PC Coster, the local road safety officer). I suppress a giggle when shown a picture of a well-endowed Adam and a bosomy Eve in the Garden of Eden, and obligingly answer all her questions about where, when and how she was baptised. We talk about sacraments and apostles, the Devil and the Pope, the Last Supper and the First Easter. Oh, and the first communion day feast: is it to be a hired marquee, as her friend Sorcha had last year, or will we have a small family lunch?

Amidst the preparations, I begin to wonder whether I really am all that different from my parents and grandparents and their unquestioning belief. But, at the end of the day, I do want to pass on to my children a cultural and spiritual heritage. It's a kind of ballpark for faith: if I hand it on, at least it's theirs to do something with. What they do, in the long term, is up to them. They might want to accept it, they might want to reject it, they might - like me - want to help it to change. There are times, I think, when parenting is about being a link in a chain: and however much you want to explain the link, however much you want to clarify it and overprint it with your own impressions, the bottom line is that you don't want to break it.

fields.headline: When the kids are United...
fields.standfirst: Do your children eat, sleep and breathe Manchester United (even when they are playing in Brazil)?  Pete May  can help
fields.trailText: Do your children eat, sleep and breathe Manchester United (even when they are playing in Brazil)? Pete May can help
fields.body:
Tony Blair has already said he wants to play football with his new baby in the garden of Number 10, and there have already been jokes that Manchester United's David Beckham will come over to teach the new nipper. But that's not something Blair, a Newcastle fan, could ever be happy with. Forget all those worries about attending superpower summits with fromage frais smeared on his jacket. Blair will now be facing the fear that grips every modern Dad: what if my child grows up to be a Man United fan? After all, the new baby's brother, Nicky Blair, has already succumbed to becoming a Cockney Red, despite being brought up in Islington.

Supporting Man United is fine, of course, if you come from Manchester. But for your child to support United when they live nowhere near the city is the equivalent of them choosing multinational Coca-Cola over locally produced organic orange juice, and about as inevitable. According to the latest figures, United have 3.3m fans in Britain alone. At the end of last year, as United won the Intercontinental Cup in Tokyo and claimed to be the world's best team, accountants Deloitte and Touche announced that Man United are also its richest.

The club has souvenir shops in the East and Far East, and sells shirts in Japan and China. Its 1999 accounts reveal a turnover of £110.674m, with a profit of £32.3m. Merchandising alone generated a whopping £22.5m, which is a lot of romper suits, and more than the entire annual turnover of the English third division.

United's directors now have their minds on the money-making exercise that is the FIFA World Club Championship, which begins in Brazil today. United's jaunt to Brazil has meant they've withdrawn from the FA Cup, devaluing the whole event. The danger is that United's triumphalist young fans will start to see the world's greatest and most magical cup competition as an irrelevance too.

I feel that giving my 17-month-old daughter Lola decent footballing values is at least as important as checking school league tables. I could just about cope with her growing up to support the local team Arsenal instead of her Dad's West Ham. I even, in my wilder imaginings, see her turning out as a 20-year-old for the Doncaster Belles. But not Man United. I want her to know there's more to fandom than easy victories live and exclusive on Sky.

Football means more than God to most children and, at its best, it teaches them lessons about patience, loyalty and faith. Every supporter knows instinctively that you find out more about life through 5-0 away debacles than from easy home wins. And, in the outside world too, you learn more about yourself when you're at your lowest. Be it in relationships, work or leisure, most of us don't have the personal equivalent of winning the league very often. Most of our seasons are mid-table or worse, but just occasionally we glimpse possible promotion or European qualification.

There's even psychological evidence to support this theory, says Professor Stuart Biddle, who specialises in the psychology of children in sport at the Department of Sports Science at Loughborough University.

"In terms of having easy success, supporting Man United is probably not a good idea," agrees Biddle. "Most psychological research shows that if children can learn to be a success as a result of being challenged, that's good. Affiliating with a local side, however, would be good for kids; it's good for them to feel a sense of belonging. When I moved to Leicester, we encouraged our kids to support Leicester City. Mind you, they do still support Man United as well!"

I've seen the United worries of my companions. They know that playground pressure may make their kid end up wearing one of United's three current kits - at £29.99 per kid's shirt. I could almost feel the relief when my friend Michael, a Fulham fan, emailed me the news about his 10-year-old daughter: "I took Lily to Old Trafford and she was yelling 'We're going up, we're going up, you're not!' at United fans. At school, she's now known as 'the Fulham supporter'. Supporting a smaller team gives her more of an identity."

The Football Supporters Association (FSA) is certainly behind people supporting local sides. Chairwoman Alison Pilling says: "Football is a live experience, but the Man United thing is more and more a TV product." She adds that, since she's taken her six-year-old son to watch the reserves at Leeds, which is free, he's really got into football. "And after he's heard the roar of the crowd at first team games I feel - which might be me being a bit of a football snob - that he's more like a proper fan. Supporting a team is about being part of the crowd. You learn one of life's great lessons: you don't always win."

Thankfully, many smaller clubs are realising they have to work to attract young supporters. Preston North End make their own shirts to keep the costs of replica kits down for parents and Charlton have a "kids a quid" scheme for home matches. Nearly every club now has a community programme, funded by the PFA, local authorities and companies. These offer football courses after school, at weekends and in the holidays.

At third division Leyton Orient, season tickets for under-16s cost just £23, and the club's community scheme is probably the best in the country. The football courses at local leisure centres are open to all ages, all abilities and both sexes, and a five-day course costs just £30. "On the courses we give out vouchers for free Orient games. Most of kids we work with haven't been to a live match so they really appreciate it," says development officer Neil Taylor.

The Orient scheme does more, though. "In our outreach work," says Taylor, "we go into the local estates and try to use football as a means of getting kids off drugs or improving their schoolwork. They come in the ground and use computers, do their homework and see that the football club isn't such a scary place to be."

Seeing your child make up their own mind about their local club can be immensely rewarding. My mate Dave has noticed a big change in his son Sam: "It was United and the Spice Girls when he was seven, but now he's 11 he's old enough to start looking for individuality. He made up his own mind that supporting the number one group or team was dull, and that he was a target for the money men. So he dropped Spice and then it dawned on him that he'd have to make the ultimate humble move of admitting that he was duped (though he wouldn't say so himself) by dropping Man U - because, in his words, 'it's boring because they they've got so much money they always win'. Very impressively, he went all the way and picked up on our local team, Brighton. He hasn't thrown out his Man United duvet and kit bag, just realised slowly that he was taken in by the advertising machine and he's made me very proud in so doing."

The likes of Sam must be encouraged. The joy of winning a trophy is even greater - and my team West Ham did once win a trophy, back in 1980 - when you've known the pain of failure, and that's what our children will benefit from. As St Mirren supporter Bill Leckie said of being a football fan in his book Penthouse and Pavement: "It's about being willing to accept a lifetime of frustration in return for one day of utter wonderment." Glory hunter or dreamer. Which is best for your child?

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: It's January and time to think about getting away for the summer. But is there really such a thing as the perfect family holiday?
fields.trailText: The Question: It's January and time to think about getting away for the summer. But is there really such a thing as the perfect family holiday?
fields.body:
Surinder Bains Mother of Amber, six, and three- year-old Rohan

We've had quite a few holidays with other families - when they work, they're wonderful. You get shared bathtimes, shared storytimes, shared meals. And you share the work, so you get a real break. The vital ingredient is that you're compatible with the other family. You need to know them very well so you're sure you'll get on. It's important for the children to be friendly with each other. It's great having other adults for conversation at the end of the day when the children are in bed. You can all spend lots of time together, but there's scope for you to go off on your own as well.

Catherine Colley Mother of two-year-old Juliet and five-year-old Harrison

I think you can have a perfect holiday, but you can only do so much to plan for it - the rest is luck. Last year we went to a resort in Corsica with childcare. In theory it should have meant lots of time for my husband and I, but in practice Juliet wasn't happy in the creche. You have to pre-book it, so can't get your money back. Also, it wasn't very flexible. You were tied to getting back for the children's club closing time. For it to be perfect you need good flights, good weather, happy and healthy children. You simply can't plan ahead for these. But if you're lucky it can be perfect.

Jeannette Page Travel editor of the Guardian and mother of two

Not a perfect holiday, no. But you can maximise your chances of a really good one if you take your children as the starting point. If they're happy, you've got a chance of being happy, too. Think friends. Whatever their age, children like to meet other children. There's no sense in looking for bargains; they don't apply unless you've got maximum flexibility, and you don't if you want to go away during school holidays. Because opportunities are so limited, you have to book early. Some people have already booked for the summer. If you want what you're looking for, you'll have to get in quickly.

Kate Calvert Editor of Family Travel and mother of a four-year-old

Preparation is the key. You've got to think about what you really want to do, and then about how you're going to get to do it. What kind of people are you? What kind of children do you have? What's going on at home during the rest of the year? Are you all exhausted and need to flop, or would you like an adventure? Involve the children: whittle the brochures down to a few, then let them help you decide. And before you go, look at books and talk to them about the country you're visiting. (For details of Kate Calvert's subscription-only magazine, visit her website: www.family-travel.co.uk

Margaret Galea Mother of four children, aged one, three, five and seven

We go to Malta every year to stay with my parents-in-law. It's lovely for the children to go back each summer. They know what to look forward to, they love seeing their cousins, and they're laying down lots of memories for the future. We also know exactly where to go for the best beaches and so on. My parents-in-law are willing babysitters, so we get a chance to go out on our own, although we're usually so tired after we've got all the children to bed that we don't bother! But it is a bit limiting, seeing the same place every year. I feel I'd like to go somewhere different once in a while.

Linda Bushell Single mother with a nine-year-old son

Perfect holidays are about good company and everyone being happy. We've had wonderful ones. But they can be difficult for single parents. Price structuring, based on two adults and two or three children, discriminates against us. Deals promising "no single supplement" are often bogus. They're for during term time. Kids need other kids, but at child-friendly resorts often you end up among couples - very depressing. My best holidays of late have been with the Single Parent Travel Club (0181 578 9739), which teams you up with like-minded parents.

webTitle: The diary of a part-time father

fields.headline: The diary of a part-time father
fields.standfirst: My name is Joe but please call me Dad
fields.trailText: My name is Joe but please call me Dad
fields.body:
At the designated hour, my three oldest children came back from the home of their mother Dilys and her daft dearly beloved, Chris The Pillock. As always, my wife Angie and I were nervous. Gloria, Jed and Billy had been in fine form when we'd last said goodbye to them on Millennium morning, weary from their failed attempts to stay awake until midnight but happy, affectionate and warm. A lot, though, can change in two nights at Chez Pillock. And, sure enough, as they trooped in the mood was heavy.

Gloria avoided my eyes, and didn't even kiss her baby half-sister Estelle. So Angie swept the girls upstairs to begin de-briefing, leaving me to probe the boys. Jed, as ever, kept a stubborn silence. Billy, as ever, talked and talked:

"Joe, you know Chris?"

"Yeah, Billy, sort of."

"Guess what?"

"What?"

"Chris and his friends slept in a spooky forest."

"Yeah?"

"And Joe."

"Yeah?"

"Do you know what?

"What?"

"There was a huge hairy man who came up from this lake, yeah? And Chris had to go and tame him!"

"Amazing!"

I thought: "Jesus Christ, the rubbish he gets up to on those Warrior Weekends." But I said: "Billy, why are you calling me Joe? What's wrong with Dad?"

"Oh, I dunno," he shrugged, and disappeared.

We needed food. I piled the boys into the Vectra, telling them we were heading for a palace of sensual wonders, where men may learn the secrets of the feminine domain. "Oh, no," they groaned, "not Safeway." I wondered what horrors Angie was digging out of Gloria. Something was definitely up. Already, I was feeling raw.

We pulled into the car park to find the family section full. I scowled through the windows of the occupying cars: no child seat, no child seat, no child seat. Bastards! When, like me, you've done a stint as a lone parent, you acquire an awful gift for moral fury. Then, right under our noses, two wasp-waisted young women emerged from a purple soft-top, with no children in tow.

"So where are your kids, then?"

The women looked at me, then each other. "Where are your kids?" I fumed.

One of them raised a blood-red middle finger. "Oh look," I countered, sweetly. "It's Mrs Shit and her invisible kids. You ought to be on telly."

"Fuck off," she replied.

"Oh, right! How about these two? Can they fuck off as well?"

I pushed on, rummaging for a coin to unlatch a shopping trolley. Jed, being Jed, inquired almost inaudibly if he could put the money in, but my mind was still replaying the fracas with the women. Then Billy, being Billy, asked a lot more loudly. I passed him the coin. So Jed shoved Billy over, and vanished into the store.

Furious, I searched the aisles, Billy blubbering in tow. One minute passed. Two minutes. Five. Then, at last, there he was, sulking by the Cheese and Owens. I was so relieved I could have hit him. But only women hit their children in supermarkets; men are too concerned with looking virtuous. So I just hissed at him instead: "I thought I'd lost you, stupid."

"Sorry, Joe."

"Now you're at it. Why 'Joe' all of a sudden? What's wrong with 'Dad'?" Silence from them both. Then something weird happened: Jed opened his mouth first.

"Mum, I mean Dilys, said we had to do it..."

So that's the little bombshell they've delivered from Chez Pillock, the reason Gloria was prickly and mute. Squatting among the snack foods, I squeezed out the details. Dilys cannot tolerate them thinking of Chris as merely a stepfather, a man of less significance than me. So she's stripped away the plainest symbol of my paternity, the designation "Dad". She's stripped herself of "Mum" as well. But that's a price she'll gladly pay if our children start believing Chris The Pillock is my equal - at the very least. Dutifully, Jed conveyed her miserable excuse: "It wasn't fair on Chris."

And what am I to do? I can rant, rave and resist and thereby make my contribution to tearing the kids apart. Or I can just give in. It's no choice at all. "All right then, call me Joe if she insists. Call me Fred or Eric. Call me Desperate Dan. Just remember, I'm the only one who'll ever be your dad."

That really got through to them. It had them thinking very hard: "Who on Earth is Desperate Dan?"

fields.headline: The bullying blindspot
fields.standfirst: Why do we always assume bullying is done by other children and never our own?  Dea Birkett  warns of new guidelines typifying such thinking
fields.trailText: Why do we always assume bullying is done by other children and never our own? Dea Birkett warns of new guidelines typifying such thinking
fields.body:
Imagine your child in this scene. It's the lunch hour and an eight-year-old girl with a Tarzan hairband is spinning one end of a skipping rope. Another girl, from the same class, comes up and asks to have a go. She's only just started her turn, so says no. But the girl won't go away: "Give me the rope, fatso." The skipping child just stands there, turning the rope and playing with her hair. "I said give me the rope." The girl hands it over and walks off, pretending not to cry.

Ninety-nine per cent of you will have imagined your child is the girl with the Tarzan hairband. But there are two young people in this everyday playground tale. Both are aged eight, both well behaved, both pretty ordinary kids who have just passed their SATs. We just have to start admitting that our child might also be the bully.

This week, the National Association of Head Teachers (NAHT) published new guidelines to tackle the "insidious problem" caused by bullies like these. Last month, a poll of more than 2000 Hertfordshire and north London primary school children suggested almost half had experienced similar verbal bullying, and a quarter suffered physical attacks several times a week. But the NAHT's solution to this perceived epidemic is startling: whether it's a case of sending to Coventry or prolonged punching, the accuser is always in the right.

"Whilst others may not feel that certain actions or words are of a bullying nature, if the recipient feels they are being bullied that is sufficient evidence to treat the case as prima facie bullying," the guidelines read.

This is good news for the alleged victim. Whatever porky pies they utter, however they embellish their experiences with their childish imaginings, they will, initially at least, be believed. But for the child who is accused of bullying, these guidelines are very bad news indeed. "Good!" I can hear parents cry. "It's about time those little bastards who harass my child were given a good hiding." But where is the alleged bully's right of defence? What if they were, after all, innocent? "Honest, I didn't do it, Miss" is no longer accepted. If a chubby child's pointy finger stabs in your direction, then you're as good as guilty. Nothing you attempt to say will ever get you off.

But bullying is not a clear-cut crime. Unlike nicking something from another kid's locker, when the Bounty bar is indisputably discovered in your schoolbag, there's no hard and fast evidence that bullying has taken place. And what counts as bullying is open to debate; the NAHT guidelines list pinching, unwanted physical contact, name-calling and sarcasm as culprits.

When bullying is interpreted so broadly, it's hardly surprising that the majority of children believe they have been victims. Nor is it a shock to learn from the Hertfordshire research that less than 3% admitted being habitual physical bullies. Yet even a five-year-old can see that these figures don't add up. Who would confess to being a bully and risk being permanently branded? The same research revealed how anti-bullying policies failed to work, based, as they are, on "poor" victims and "bad" bullies.

The playground is a messy emotional landscape, upon which adults are trying to impose a simple morality tale. On one side of an uncrossable chasm are the victims of bullying - good children, little angels. On the other stand the bullies - evil children, little devils. But according to the same Hertfordshire research, most bullies have themselves been bullied. "We need to get away from the notion that kids who bully other kids are somehow different," says Andrew Mellor, a teacher who drew up the Scottish Council for Research in Education's influential anti-bullying leaflet. "Bullies are just normal folk. Their bullying is a result of the situation they find themselves in, but there's nothing intrinsically wrong with them. In a different environment, they might not bully at all."

Bullying expert Barbara Maines, who pioneered the No Blame Approach, believed it is never right to single out one child. "Even if the bullying is secret, behind the bike shed, one to one, we've always discovered that there's consent. We've always discovered that the other kids knew that something wasn't right and they've just kept out of it."

fields.headline: More Matter by John Updike
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss assesses the critical verdict on John Updike's latest collection journalism, reviews and occasional writings
Buy More Matter at BOL
fields.trailText: Another year, another John Updike. The man is indefatigable, inescapable. A new novel, Gertrude and Claudius, is due shortly, and his 50th book, More Matter, appeared in time for Christmas. Although, as Peter Walker pointed out in the Financial Times, Santa would have needed quite a large sack.
fields.body:
Another year, another John Updike. The man is indefatigable, inescapable. A new novel, Gertrude and Claudius, is due shortly, and his 50th book, More Matter, appeared in time for Christmas. Although, as Peter Walker pointed out in the Financial Times, Santa would have needed quite a large sack. "More Matter is vast - an immense collection of what Updike himself calls 'factual prose'. If it lands on your foot, goodbye metatarsal. If it landed under the Christmas tree, goodbye January."

John Sutherland, in the Sunday Times, was equally astonished: "Light reading as much of it is, More Matter, at 900 pages, half a million words and 3lb, is no lightweight book. The mind boggles at the thought that it is the fifth volume of the author's collected journalism, reviews and occasional writings. How deep down the barrel is John Updike prepared to scrape? As deep as arms can reach. For Updike, wastepaper is a contradiction in terms. He shamelessly reprints his essay for The Official Souvenir Program of the 1992 Olympic Games and his address for the 100th anniversary of the United States Golf Association."

Sutherland, never one to mince words, seemed ready to annihilate the book. "Updike has already been handsomely paid for these mercenary effusions. Why not let them rot in peace? Nothing escapes: no review, however hastily thrown off; no pensée, however random. The book chain Borders solicits the great author for the 'Books that Changed my Life' in 150 words. Here again are the words, lest by some oversight we missed the advertising brochure in which they first appeared. The piece probably took less time to write than it does to read... In his preface, he laughs it off as harmless authorial vanity ('I like seeing my name in what they used to call hard type'). One recalls, unkindly, Howard Hughes on the top floor of the Sands Hotel, storing his bodily waste in jars."

Strong stuff, but Sutherland was playing a game of two halves, and by the end of his review the egomaniac had become a hero, and an act of folie de grandeur a simple case of bad editing. "Updike is, for my money, the best American novelist never to have won the Nobel prize. He writes like an angel, even when he is writing non-fiction for hire. Embedded in the doughy mass of More Matter are 300 pages of superb prose. But you must look to find them. What was it Ernest Hemingway said - 'Less is more.'" (Hemingway? Mies van der Rohe, surely.)

Walker, in the FT, also mixed admiration with a drop of acid: "Updike has ranged too far and wide, and perhaps too high. He has set himself up as a sort of national seer, archbishop and chief astronomer, and his landscape is not only hazy to the reviewer - you feel it is rather hazy to Updike himself... When looking through the lens of a creative imagination - his own or another's - Updike is superb. Otherwise, a grey man looms towards the podium... I blame Queen Gertrude, and can only hope the next Updike collection opposes her dictum. More art, with less matter."

John Gross, in the Sunday Telegraph, had no such qualms. "The book's variety is as impressive as its bulk. So is its quality. Most of the pieces began as humble journalistic assignments, but you hardly ever get the feeling of Updike writing to order... His occasional writing is recognisably the product of the same pen, or word processor, as his novels and short stories. It is witty and observant; it takes equal pleasure in recording social surfaces - fashions, manners, idiosyncrasies - and penetrating beyond them, to the life within." Gross did, though, raise the old complaint: "The chief weakness of his writing is excessive fluency. When he is not on his guard against it, his pleasure in words can run ahead of what he is trying to say, and muffle its impact."

Adam Mars-Jones, in the Observer, echoed the criticism: "Some of the more serious pieces suffer from a sense of being commissioned as much as felt." But compared with the critical drubbing some of his recent novels have received (remember Toward the End of Time? No, I thought not) and the way he has been vilified by feminists in the US - "just a penis with a thesaurus" - the critics have been generous. Who else could publish 900-plus pages of ephemera and live to tell the tale?

webTitle: Deaths no coincidence, Shipman trial told

fields.headline: Deaths no coincidence, Shipman trial told
fields.trailText:
It would be "quite incredible" if the 15 alleged victims of Dr Harold Shipman
had died natural deaths, the GP's murder trial jury was told today.
fields.body:
It would be "quite incredible" if the 15 alleged victims of Dr Harold Shipman had died natural deaths, the GP's murder trial jury was told today.

Prosecuting counsel Richard Henriques QC told the jury at Preston crown court that it could not be coincidence that all the women patients had died on the same day as he had seen them.

Mr Henriques said in his closing speech to the jury that Dr Shipman had breached the trust that the victims and their relatives had placed in him. "It is a quite incredible proposition that these 15 ladies could have died a natural death having regard to their state of health prior to facing Dr Shipman," he said.

The 53-year-old doctor denies killing the women with injections of diamorphine. He also pleads not guilty to forging the £386,000 will of one of them. The trial, which started in early November, resumed today after a break of 22 days.

Mr Henriques told the jury that Dr Shipman had "duped" the relatives of his victims "in order to save his own skin". He had falsified medical records to cover his tracks.

"He took advantage of their grief and their lesser knowledge of medicine and procedures," said Mr Henriques. "As they grieved this determined man employed every device to make sure no post-mortem examination took place." He said Dr Shipman would "overbear, belittle and bamboozle" relatives until they accepted his word that they should not put their mothers through a post-mortem examination.

A meeting between relatives of three of his alleged victims would have exposed the "incredible" fact that the doctor was claiming that they were suffering from serious illnesses known only to him and treated by him, yet unknown to their families.

Mr Henriques said each of the alleged victims had died a sudden and unexpected death. "While of course sudden deaths do occur, Dr Shipman faces the problem he saw each and every one of these deceased patients on the day that she died."

He said that in some cases the patient was found dead later, but the act of diamorphine being administered must have coincided with Dr Shipman visiting them. "They would not have submitted peacefully to [being given diamorphine by] any other person," said Mr Henriques.

He said that the reason why Dr Shipman had been so determined to avoid post mortem examinations in any of the cases needed no elaboration. There was the danger that if pathologists had become involved, the coroner would have been informed.

In four cases Dr Shipman had lied about the alleged victims telephoning his surgery before they died. This had given him a pretext of visiting them.

The doctor had not tried to resuscitate any of the patients. "There was of course no point - he knew they were dead," said Mr Henriques.

In all of the 15 cases there had not been a single post mortem, a single ambulance called by Dr Shipman, a single proper examination of the patient by him or a single attempt at resuscitation. "And in case you had the slightest doubt what was going on, there are seven patients in respect of whom the defendant falsified medical records," he said.

fields.headline: Hold the front page
fields.standfirst: A professional approach has helped to attract funding and raise the profile of  breast cancer, reports Jane Feinmann
fields.trailText: A professional approach has helped to attract funding and raise the profile of breast cancer, reports Jane Feinmann.
fields.body:
How did the end of the cold war bring about the development of the latest miracle drug for breast cancer? It's not a riddle. Back in 1993, the US government responded to intensive lobbying by a newly formed organisation of women with breast cancer by handing them $300m from a defence budget that the Pentagon no longer needed.

Part of the money was used to fund clinical trials for Herceptin, a drug that, against expectations, has shown itself able to shrink breast tumours in certain women - and which may never have seen the light of day if the Berlin wall hadn't fallen.

The story doesn't only show the benefits of ending the arms race. It has also been a lesson in the power of advocacy. Persuading the Pentagon to hand over its millions was a spectacular coup for the US National Breast Cancer Coalition, a network of female volunteers determined to take breast cancer off the style sec tions of the newspapers and on to the front page of the New York Times.

The new style of lobbying channels the feelings of anger and the desire to do something that so often accompanies the experience of major illness, especially when all has not gone well. While staying on the amateur side of a pro fessional PR campaign, the coalition makes no excuses for spending money to create a well-oiled publicity and lobbying machine.

Politicians, they say, are far more attentive to properly organised campaigns. So individual advocates have access to professional training designed to put across a national message in an individualised way. It's a system that is spreading fast in the US.

Organisations representing people with diabetes, Alzheimer's, Aids and multiple sclerosis all have thousands of active advocates, prepared to lobby at local and national level at the drop of an email.

On this side of the Atlantic, breast cancer advocacy is again leading the way. A year and a half after her mother died of breast cancer, dress designer Stella McCartney was the guest speaker at the first meeting of the newly formed advocacy coalition, Europa Donna, in Montreux last November.

She appealed to European women to check their breasts regularly. At the same time, members of the coalition debated their plans to mobilise women to press for better physical and psychological care and treatment and more money for breast cancer research.

UK patient advocacy groups are growing fast, determined to exploit the opportunities created by the commitment within the NHS to public consultation.

In March, the UK Breast Cancer Coalition plans a Westminster fly-in, copying the Washington fly-in concept used by a number of patient support groups in the US. Volunteers will spend the morn ing receiving training in London, followed by a mass lobby of parliament.

At its first training day at the end of last year, Advocacy in Action volunteers received tactical advice from the vice-president of the US organisation (for example, take a photographer along to a meeting with legislators as they're more likely to turn up if they know they're going to be photographed).

Health economist Nick Bosanquet urged concerted action. He said that advocates could make a substantial difference by lobbying MPs and organisations such as Nice (the National Institute for Clinical Excellence) at national level as well as health authorities and primary care trusts.

"The NHS needs effective, informed advocates to make a difference and changes in govern ment health policy provide a window of opportunity," he said.

In the UK, where sufferers are increasingly denied new drugs widely available in the rest of Europe and the US, and where there is a dangerous shortage of oncologists, there is much to lobby about.

Herceptin is already licensed in the US and will shortly be licensed in Germany but, as yet, there are no plans for it to be available in Britain.

Elsewhere there have been concerns that advocates might be compromised if they were funded by the pharmaceutical industry which might profit from their activities. Peter Cardy, chief executive of the Multiple Sclerosis Society, says he has heard of industry "invent ing" advocacy groups. But he insists the major charities can't be bought that easily. "They work with pharmaceutical companies where there are shared interests but never let them call the shots."

The chief executive of the NHS Confederation, Stephen Thornton, is less trusting. "Explicit advertising to the public by the pharmaceutical industry is not permitted. Yet worldwide, there is a staggering amount of pharmaceutical money invested in patient groups which puts their drugs on the advocacy agenda. That's why the role of patient advocates should be in helping to shape and design local services - not advising cash-strapped health authorities on where resources should be spent."

He's also concerned that if more NHS funding goes to breast cancer others will lose out. "Advocacy groups are becoming more apparent in NHS management - but it's an uneven marketplace." There are some organisations which are well-funded and have the ear of politicians and the media.

Others have little or no clout. There are no advocates for heart failure or lung cancer, for example, and we can't have an NHS where those that shout the loudest get the most resources.

It's a charge denied by the UKBCC which sees itself as a role model for less assertive campaigners. "We're saying we want a bigger share of a bigger cake," says Coalition's spokesman, Graham Covington. "Look at what the Americans achieved with money from the defence budget. No one suffered as a result of that."

fields.headline: Words of warning
fields.standfirst: When scientists talk of 'absence of evidence' of risk, take cover. Geoff Tansey on a new report
fields.trailText: When scientists talk of 'absence of evidence' of risk, take cover. Geoff Tansey on a new report.
fields.body:
Public scepticism about the rapid and widespread adoption of GM crops and foods is not ill-founded, a report on the politics and risk of GM food has confirmed.

A simple reliance on "sound science" will not get government and industry out of the mess they are in, and is itself unscientific, the report says. It summarises the results from part of Britain's biggest ever social science research programme - the 10-year, £15m Global Environmental Change Programme (GECP), funded by the Economic and Social Science Research Council, which has drawn in some 355 researchers in 150 projects since 1991.

The report calls for research to tackle difficult scientific questions, like the cumulative effects of many GMOs, but it also urges government to recognise that science is "ill-equipped to tackle the diffuse effects of existing technologies" and "that definitive answers do not and cannot exist in the face of uncertainty and 'ignorance' about new technologies".

Public mistrust arises partly because the way the issue is being handled breaches the fundamental trust between the public and the powers that be - political and corporate. Public concerns include how decisions are made, who makes them in whose interests, what should be taken into account like cultural, ethical and political issues, a lack of public involvement, and responsibility and liability for any damaging consequences.

One danger, the report suggests, is that "scientists are often under real pressures to reach conclusions that can inform commercial and political decisions" when no such conclusions can be reached.

A nother problem is that standard risk assessment techniques are inadequate. "Current approaches neglect the scientific basis for dealing with ignorance and fail to recognise that the underlying assumptions used at the start of the process of risk assessment affect the outcome," says Dr Andy Stirling, a GECP researcher from the science policy research unit at the University of Sussex. "Politicians must take care not to portray an 'absence of evidence' as 'evidence of absence' of problems and risks," says the report.

Nor is the present regulatory system up to the job. "No ecologists have been included in the various advisory committees," says the report. These anyway fail to deal with the need for GM food, social benefits, potential for indirect, cumulative and synergistic ecological and/or health effects arising from GM crops and foods, and the wide effects on the countryside.

Unsurprisingly, "the public mistrusts the scientific approach to ignorance - unknown factors that may lead to 'surprises' in the future", says the report. It calls for better ways to make decisions about this kind of new technology.

Both government and industry have dipped their toes in the water with a few initial experiments using consensus conferences, citizens' juries, focus groups and deliberative polls. The basis against which risks are measured also needs to become more sophisticated. Simply assessing the effects of GM technologies and crops against existing practices in conventional agriculture, especially when conventional industrialised agriculture itself is under attack for being unsustainable.

Genetic engineering is only possible because all species share a very early prehistory. fields.headline: Have a heart
fields.standfirst: Poverty and heart disease are so intimately linked that if  death rates are to be reduced, writes Imogen Sharp, the  government must tackle the inequalities in our society
fields.trailText: Poverty and heart disease are so intimately linked that if death rates are to be reduced, writes Imogen Sharp, the government must tackle the inequalities in our society.
fields.body:
Word is out that we may soon have a new champion, or tsar, for coronary heart disease. The question is, what should his or her priorities be?

As the UK's single leading cause of death and disability, heart disease deserves the priority status that it has been accorded by government and particularly the new secretary of state for health, Alan Milburn. It kills over 140,000 people each year and, while one has to die of something, some 20,000 of these victims do not live to celebrate even their 65th birthday. Heart disease is often seen as a quick way to die.

What is perhaps little recognised is the illness and disability it can cause. Over a quarter of adults now suffer from a cardiovascular condition, such as angina, heart attack, diabetes or high blood pressure. Reducing this suffering is clearly an important task.

Tackling health inequalities, and improving the health of those in society who are worst off, is the new mantra of the Labour government. Heart disease is already a disease of deprivation and disadvantage. Today, unskilled men are almost three times more likely to die prematurely from heart disease than professionals. While death rates for the disease are falling, the decline has been unequal and as a result, the social class gap has widened in the past two decades. The risk of heart disease has almost halved in professional groups but the risk for those in unskilled groups has barely changed.

With the political will, however, this leading killer could be virtually eliminated as a cause of death among under 65 year olds. The inequalities in death rates from heart disease are not simply due to inequalities in access to the health services and to treatment. They largely reflect inequalities in illness from the disease, as the recent health survey for England shows. The poor are more likely to suffer heart disease in the first place, and thus more likely to die from it.

Furthermore, the main determinants of cardiovascular death are largely the same as those causing illness from the disease. Smoking, one of the major causes, is associated with poverty. The poor have poor diets, most marked in their low consumption of vegetables and fruit, not because they don't know what to eat but because of high cost and poor access.

The disease, as government acknowledges, is largely preventable. So the priority has to be to stop people getting sick in the first place. What is vital for the health service bill, as well as waiting lists, is to stem the tide of illness and morbidity. To prevent cholesterol and blood pressure levels from rising and needing a drugs budget to bring them down; to stop children taking up smoking and needing nicotine patches in adulthood to help them give up and to reduce the number of heart disease patients arriving at the NHS door.

There are signs, in the recent health survey for England, that heart disease rates have begun to rise over the past five years. The resource implications are clear: rising rates means rising costs, and rising waiting lists. Coronary heart disease already costs the NHS an estimated £1.6bn each year. Hospital care for people with heart disease accounts for over half of these costs; drugs and the costs of dispensing them cost about a third. By comparison, a paltry 1% of these NHS costs are spent on prevention.

But greater investment and focus on preventing avoidable illness would allow the NHS to concentrate on treating the illnesses that cannot be prevented. That way, waiting lists would not build up, and may even decline.

The priority in tackling heart disease must be not just to make NHS services among the best in the world, which Milburn is keen to do, but also to make our prevention policies among the best in the world. Tackling the root causes of heart disease would also make a big impact on the nation's other chronic diseases - cancer and stroke - which share determinants and risk factors and also strike the poor disproportionately.

What the tsar must do is to bring vision and innovation to reducing heart disease rates. We know many of the causes and some of the solutions. A strategy is required which focuses on deprived groups and tackles disadvantage and adapts prevention policies appropriately.

The job needs a social perspective to address social factors. To be successful, the secretary of state's 10-year blueprint for heart disease must include the whole of government policy. Leadership on tackling coronary heart disease means also taking on some of the global industries, such as the tobacco industry, which contributes to chronic diseases.

A report at the end of last year from Bristol University suggested that "subtly, slowly and almost imperceptibly, the priority of reducing inequalities in health has dropped down the agenda".

Heart disease has become a symbol of unequal health. The job of the tsar in helping to eliminate early deaths from the disease is to eliminate its status as a disease of deprivation by working to stop the poor getting sick in the first place.

 Imogen Sharp is director of the National Heart Forum.

fields.headline: Hit the target
fields.standfirst: Charities need to co-ordinate resources to attract  government funding, argues John Grant
fields.trailText: Charities need to co-ordinate resources to attract government funding, argues John Grant.
fields.body:
Leave it to charity. That, so far, has been the broad approach of successive governments to funding for cancer research. There has never been a better time to secure an emphatic and radical change.

The present government has elevated the fight against cancer to a top priority within the NHS. Research, though, has yet to receive any special attention. If prevention is better than cure - and for sound social, medical and economic reasons that is surely the case - then health secretary Alan Milburn must move meaningfully and generously to share the burden of research costs.

I can offer him a model to work from out of my own first-hand experience. Back in the mid-1970s, the then ministry of overseas development launched the Pound for Pound scheme, a bold initiative to help voluntary organisations with their efforts in the developing world. I was the minister responsible for negotiations and consultations with those organisations to see that the scheme met with their requirements and with ours.

Where a specific project was approved by the ministry, we matched the overseas aid charities' contributions. Our main criteria was to direct resources to the poorest people in the poorest countries.

A similar scheme for cancer research would undoubtedly require a far greater government commitment to make a real impact. The UK spends about £130-£140m a year on cancer research, but the government's contribution is about 10% of it, a miserly sum given the scale of the problem.

To be fair, the 600 or so cancer charities hardly help themselves by their failure to co-ordinate their case for more assistance. Prof Gordon McVie, director-general of the Cancer Research Campaign, which alone will spend £56m this year, openly acknowledges that there is a wasteful duplication of resources, which is counter-productive, divisive and confuses the public.

Apart from the CRC and the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, where up-to-date facilities are extensive, there are umpteen smaller charities which are research-based or include research in their operations.

Separate charities exist for almost every kind of cancer, and some donors clearly prefer to give towards combating that kind of cancer which has hit them or their families.

So far as my own prostate cancer is concerned, I am uncomfortably aware that a mere £47,000 went into research on it in 1998. One of the latest projects is the Pelican Centre, based at the North Hampshire hospital, which concentrates on precision surgery in the pelvic region, for which it says the world standard is 10 years ahead of the UK. It has an ambitious target of £5m from donors by the end of 2000. It points out that more than 90% of cancer cures result from surgery, yet surgery receives only 1% of research funding.

Worthy causes abound. It would be foolish to seek to inhibit giving to a particular favoured one. Nevertheless, needless overlap among the cancer charities is a matter for concern. It is not, though, an excuse for inaction by the government.

Tony Blair has turned the spotlight on the Big C. There is to be extra cash and a cancer tsar has been appointed to ensure that what is promised is delivered. Even so, Britain's cancer specialists have said bluntly that this is nowhere near enough if the government's target of a one-fifth reduction in cancer deaths in 10 years is to be achieved.

A Pound for Pound scheme for cancer research, with clear guidelines for applicant bodies, using additional government resources for carefully vetted projects to avoid replication, would be a huge boost for all those involved in this never-ending struggle.

Doubtless, the department of health would need to put an annual cap on such spending, as does the DFID. But such an innovation would raise still further public awareness and increase confidence that philanthropy in this area is well justified. That, in turn, could mean substantially more donations.

It would mean, too, a new partnership between government, charities and the individual citizen - a partnership to speed up and facilitate the vital research of those aspiring doctors and scientists who are the only real hope of defeating the deadly disease on behalf of generations to come.

 John Grant is a former MP and minister in the Wilson and Callaghan governments, 1974-79 .

fields.headline: Brave new world (II)
fields.standfirst: Science may soon offer the rich a chance of  cleverer, healthier, more beautiful babies. Tom  Shakespeare warns of the dangers
fields.trailText: Science may soon offer the rich a chance of cleverer, healthier, more beautiful babies. Tom Shakespeare warns of the dangers.
fields.body:
During 1999, anti-GM demos replaced road protests as the direct action of choice. Headlines about Frankenstein foods, and crop-stomping peers of the realm and soap opera characters, have reflected a popular backlash against the application of genetic technology. The impact of all this opposition causes disabled people like me to ask: why aren't people equally worried about genetically-modified human beings?

Human genetics, as currently practised, seems as publicly acceptable as plant genetics is controversial. Most prospective parents are happy to use pre-natal testing to screen out congenital abnormality. Can you imagine activists trashing experiments in human genetics research institutes? If it were to happen, the media response to such actions would surely be very different to the current half-approving coverage of GM crop damage.

Why is there such a different response to intervening in childbirth than to intervening in the grocery department? Isn't our internal personal environment just as important as the external global environment? Perhaps the first difference is that much of the opposition to GM food is based on a distrust of big business. Consumers oppose corporate power, feeling that "they" are manipulating our food, exploiting developing-world farmers and trying to control the world - hence the Seattle protests.

But the public face of human genetics tends to be doctors in white coats dangling healthy babies. Whereas the GM food debate has revolved around the need to empower consumers and provide information so they can choose not to buy new products, the rationale for genetic intervention in reproduction has been parental demand for access to new tests and procedures.

Secondly, most people can't see the point of GM food. Why change products which seem perfectly adequate? Recent Wellcome Trust research showed the public found it much more difficult to understand why Dolly was cloned, than to understand how Dolly was cloned.

There are few perceived benefits to the modification of plant or animal genes. On the other hand, human genetics has the alibi of improving health. It operates on a mechanistic model of removing "faulty" bits of the human being - or else preventing the birth of "faulty" humans - and it has the rationale of "reducing suffering".

Whereas there seems little public anxiety about genetic screening or even gene therapy, there is widespread disquiet about human cloning. This is where human genetics seems to connect to genetic modification. People find it difficult to connect cloning to the reduction of disease or suffering. It seems unnecessary, and above all, unnatural.

But there are some important connections between food genetics and human genetics. For example, consumer choice in reproduction is much more limited than the rhetoric implies. Implicit pressure from medics to screen out genetic differences, and a lack of proper information about disability, mean that parental choices are not as free as they seem.

Moreover, human genetics is about big business and corporate profits too. Gene patenting will enable biotechnology companies to exploit the demands for testing. Companies with exclusive control over tests will be able to prevent other laboratories testing for genes associated with breast cancer or other conditions, or else demand payment of licensing fees. In Britain, NHS genetics services are very concerned about the cost implications of these diagnostic monopolies.

Economics also influences the direction which genetic research will take. Biotechs, despite the propaganda about health, are only interested in certain kinds of human diseases. Rare genetic conditions, for which the market in tests or therapies will be limited, are of little concern. The big money is in everyday health problems such as cancer, hypertension, obesity and depression. At the same time, access to new therapies - or new methods of creating designer babies - will come at a cost. Those countries who cannot afford modern pharmaceuticals, or those couples who cannot afford advanced embryo selection techniques will be the genetic losers.

Princeton embryologist Lee Silvers has talked about the development of a genetic underclass, restricted to reproducing traditionally, while the "GenRich" choose cleverer, healthier, more beautiful offspring.

The long term consequences of releasing GM organisms into the environment are a source of deep concern to opponents. There is a similar need for caution in the extension of new methods of making babies, selecting embryos and experimenting with gene therapies.

Again, while thousands of test-tube babies have been born world-wide, the technology is only two decades old. No one knows whether genetically modified human beings might face problems as they begin to age, or when they themselves come to reproduce.

There are three areas in which there might be a value consensus among those concerned about GM food and GM people. First, there is an anxiety about the exploitation of the natural world and the dignity of living beings.

There is considerable concern about the application of cloning to use animals as "living medicine factories", or the breeding of transgenic pigs to provide spare parts for humans. There is particular anxiety about cloning human embryos solely to provide material for experimental treatments.

Second, respect for nature means distinguishing between interventions to improve quality of life, and interventions which are disruptive of normal processes. Reducing suffering is an important goal, but we should be concerned about doctors "playing God".

While research to combat cancer seems a good idea, research to combat natural human ageing seems like hubris. We must draw a line between trying to cure disease, and trying to engineer a better human species. If it worked, somatic gene therapy to help individuals might be desirable, but germline gene therapy, affecting subsequent generations, could cause real problems in the future.

Finally, science is not the real answer to human problems. After all, applications of science usually reinforce social inequalities rather than remedying them. Both environmental campaigners and disability rights activists suggest that the real causes of suffering are social barriers, not biology. After all, enough food is grown to feed the world, and global inequality is the real cause of famine.

Disabled people argue that our problems are not caused by our bodies, but by the discrimination and prejudice we face in society. Rather than seeking individual solutions - either by eliminating people with impairment, or engineering a better soya bean - we should campaign for structural and global changes.

Links are growing between those who protest against GM foods, and those who are concerned about disability rights and human genetic engineering. Personally, I do not believe that we should reject all that genetics has to offer. But there is an urgent need for informed debate and for democratic accountability. Society should set limits to the genetic modification of the human species, just as much as to that of plants and animals.

 Tom Shakespeare is research development officer of the Policy, Ethics and Life Sciences Research Institute, Newcastle. He was a witness in the Trial of the Century, Channel 4, on Sunday. He has the genetic condition achondroplasia, causing restricted growth

Rare genetic conditions, for which the market in tests or therapies will be limited, are of little concern. The big money is in everyday health problems such as cancer, hypertension, obesity and depression. At the same time, access to new therapies - or new methods of creating designer babies - will come at a cost. Those countries who cannot afford modern pharmaceuticals, or those couples who cannot afford advanced embryo selection techniques will be the genetic losers. Princeton embryologist Lee Silvers has talked about the development of a genetic underclass, restricted to reproducing traditionally, while the "GenRich" choose cleverer, healthier, more beautiful offspring. The long term consequences of releasing GM organisms into the environment are a source of deep concern to opponents. There is a similar need for caution in the extension of new methods of making babies, selecting embryos and experimenting with gene therapies. Again, while thousands of test-tube babies have been born world-wide, the technology is only two decades old. No one knows whether genetically modified human beings might face problems as they begin to age, or when they themselves come to reproduce. There are three areas in which there might be a value consensus among those concerned about GM food and GM people. First, there is an anxiety about the exploitation of the natural world and the dignity of living beings. There is considerable concern about the application of cloning to use animals as "living medicine factories", or the breeding of transgenic pigs to provide spare parts for humans. There is particular anxiety about cloning human embryos solely to provide material for experimental treatments. Second, respect for nature means distinguishing between interventions to improve quality of life, and interventions which are disruptive of normal processes. Reducing suffering is an important goal, but we should be concerned about doctors "playing God". While research to combat cancer seems a good idea, research to combat natural human ageing seems like hubris. We must draw a line between trying to cure disease, and trying to engineer a better human species. If it worked, somatic gene therapy to help individuals might be desirable, but germline gene therapy, affecting subsequent generations, could cause real problems in the future. Finally, science is not the real answer to human problems. After all, applications of science usually reinforce social inequalities rather than remedying them. Both environmental campaigners and disability rights activists suggest that the real causes of suffering are social barriers, not biology. After all, enough food is grown to feed the world, and global inequality is the real cause of famine. Disabled people argue that our problems are not caused by our bodies, but by the discrimination and prejudice we face in society. Rather than seeking individual solutions - either by eliminating people with impairment, or engineering a better soya bean - we should campaign for structural and global changes. Links are growing between those who protest against GM foods, and those who are concerned about disability rights and human genetic engineering. Personally, I do not believe that we should reject all that genetics has to offer. But there is an urgent need for informed debate and for democratic accountability. Society should set limits to the genetic modification of the human species, just as much as to that of plants and animals.  Tom Shakespeare is research development officer of the Policy, Ethics and Life Sciences Research Institute, Newcastle. He was a witness in the Trial of the Century, Channel 4, on Sunday. He has the genetic condition achondroplasia, causing restricted growth

fields.headline: Ask the people
fields.standfirst: Councils are increasingly testing local opinion over their plans for spending - and the tax needed to support it. Steve Brown reports
fields.trailText: Councils are increasingly testing local opinion over their plans for spending - and the tax needed to support it. Steve Brown reports.
fields.body:
There is a commonly held political belief that no one votes for tax rises, at least not when they are in the privacy of a polling booth. But the myth, which has helped shape successive government policies in recent times, was exploded at the beginning of last year, when residents in Milton Keynes voted in their masses for a 10% rise in council tax.

The referendum was hailed by newspaper leader writers at the time as marking the rebirth of local democracy - with a "turnout" of nearly 50% of the local population. They had some justification, and the unitary council is still seen as something of a pioneer. But it is not alone: a number of councils up and down the country are following, albeit more tentatively, in their footsteps. What singled out the Milton Keynes exercise, and was almost certainly instrumental in the unusually high response to the postal and phone ballot, was the council's declaration that it would stand by the result. Others have not been so gung-ho, but the direction of travel is clear.

Consultation is the name of the game, and in future the public will not have to wait for a local election to register its views on recent budget or council tax levels. Last year, the London Fire and Civil Defence Authority won massive public support for a 20% rise in its element of the capital's council tax bills, although it later set a much more modest 7.7% increase. And this year Birmingham city council, Hertfordshire county council and the London borough of Enfield are among a number of authorities all putting council tax choices, in one form or another, before the people - even if they are only guaranteeing to feed the public's views into the council's own decision making processes.

Birmingham's exercise has involved a 1,000-strong people's panel, although it has also run a major poster campaign to encourage the general public to have its say. While detailed consultation is continuing, the work has already led the country's largest metropolitan council to declare its intention to keep its tax rise within the 5.5% set last year.

Hertfordshire has decided to build on previous years' consultation by asking residents to choose between 5.5%, 7% or 7.7% tax rises. A leaflet was sent to some 440,000 households. Out of some 10,000 responses, 50% opted for the highest increase, 12% for the middle option and 26% the lowest (12% gave no preference). According to Ben King, head of government services at Mori, which ran the survey, the roughly 2% response rate is typical of this kind of consultation exercise. And while it would be easy to dismiss the survey as potentially unrepresentative, a similar result was reached by a survey of the council's citizens' panel. Georgina Stanton, the council's head of corporate communications, says that, taken together, the two consultation exercises provide a "robust indicator" of the public's tax preference.

But it is perhaps in Enfield where one of the more comprehensive consultation exercises is taking place. Despite recognising that other councils are moving in the same direction, Enfield believes its budget consultation is truly ground-breaking. Following on from the more traditional Mori survey, measuring residents' satisfaction with council services, and a series of budget workshops, in November it issued a green budget to residents' organisations, businesses and voluntary groups. This document laid out options for this year's budget and sought views on how funds should be divided.

It is possibly one of the first attempts to engage the public in the detail of setting the council budget. While proposing to maintain a policy of prioritising education and social services, the document clearly spells out that this means making up to £5.7m of cuts to other services and attempts to engage the public in deciding what level of cuts is acceptable and where they should be made. The council's cabinet has identified a package of cuts amounting to £4.1m that would mean a tax rise of between 6% and 7%, but says that the final budget level is still up for grabs. Whether the consultation has led to changes in those recommendations will be discovered next week as the council firms up its proposals in a budget white paper.

There have been some criticisms that using referendums and other consultation to take difficult budget decisions is just a way of elected members abdicating their responsibility and passing the buck. But Doug Taylor, leader of Enfield, refutes this. "Councillors are only temporary custodians of the money of the people of the borough," he says. "You need a dialogue to determine how they see the priorities." Kevin Wilson, leader of Milton Keynes, goes further. He says that given the low turnouts for local elections, most councillors are elected by less than 13% of the population. "That's hardly a mandate for spending the public's money," he says.

But while more and more councils are becoming convinced by the need to consult on budgetary issues, it provides an interesting dilemma for government. As part of its best value initiative, the government is pushing councils to consult widely. But it also wants to keep a lid on council expenditure. And although the old capping regime is officially dead and buried, new reserve powers for the secretary of state, which come into force in April this year, are seen as capping by another name. So what happens when councils follow one piece of government guidance and consult on their budget only to win a mandate for a cap-busting tax rise? The tension was clear last year when Milton Keynes won praise from the government for holding its referendum, but was subsequently one of 12 authorities to be named and shamed over their tax and budget rises.

For many the lack of any serious punishment is a sign that budget consultation does offer councils a way out of the government's financial straitjacket. "Milton Keynes was warned," says Neil Kinghan, finance director of the Local Government Association, "but crucially it wasn't capped. And it is not clear the government would have felt comfortable with capping. If a local authority has a referendum and gets a clear majority in favour of a significant tax rise, it puts the government in a difficult position."

But the government is still talking tough. A spokeswoman for the department of the environment, transport and the regions told the Guardian that it was difficult to construct a referendum that was fair and unbiased and holding a referendum was not a way of justifying big spending decisions.

Whether the government would be prepared to step in and lower a budget in the face of big local support for the increase has yet to be tested.

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Signs have been put up in the dressing rooms at Ford open prison, West Sussex, warning visiting football teams to beware of thieves.
fields.body:
Obvious threat: Signs have been put up in the dressing rooms at Ford open prison, West Sussex, warning visiting football teams to beware of thieves.

The future is yellow: A goalkeeper was booked during a Medway Sunday league football match in Kent after refusing to hang up on a mobile phone call.

Stiff resolve: Producers of a pantomime in Bury St Edmonds, Suffolk, are refusing to change the script, despite complaints from Mary Whitehouse about the audience being asked to shout 'Viagra' to help raise the castle gates.

Last orders: The landlord of a pub in Saddleworth, Greater Manchester, has had his back garden consecrated as a burial ground.

Busy doing nothing: A lollipop man in Glasgow is still being paid to patrol outside a school that closed three years ago.

Drama school: A pregnant woman went into labour while watching her three-year-old daughter perform in a nativity play at a nursery in Clacton, Essex.

Love boats: Couples hiring barges for romantic weekends are causing damage to waterways near Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire, because the rocking of the boats is eroding river banks.

Marked absent: A hammer and a set of punches used to mark property as a deterrent against theft were stolen from a crime prevention caravan parked outside Godalming police station, Surrey.

Mixed feelings: A lesbian group has severed its links with a sexual health charity in Inverness following a row over a transvestite man's bid to join the organisation.

Trip to the nick: A man who claimed his drink had been spiked with LSD was arrested after coming out of a pub in Hartlepool and driving off in a police patrol car.

Burning question: Firefighters called to a flat in Blyth, Northumberland, discovered that the thick smoke was caused by spontaneous combustion of the peat in a yucca's plantpot.

Snap decision: Officers of the RSPCA are considering taking legal action after being called to remove a five-foot Mississippi alligator kept in the bedroom of a flat near Chesterfield, Derbyshire.
