fields.headline: NHS care cost varies widely
fields.trailText: Hospital operations can cost up to 20 times more in one part of England as in another, government statistics revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Hospital operations can cost up to 20 times more in one part of England as in another, government statistics revealed yesterday.

The statistics showed a huge variations in the cost of many operations and other treatments, with some health authorities spending 80% more than the national average on the same combination of cases and treatments, while others spend 33% less.

Critics claimed the tables, which for the first time included non-surgical procedures such as back pain treatment or delivery of babies, showed that the government had failed to end the "lottery of postcode prescribing", under which patients received different levels of medical care depending on where they lived.

High spending health authorities are to be set targets to reduce their costs, while health chiefs are to investigate the causes of the cost disparities across more than 20m hospital in-patient and out-patient sessions in 244 trusts across England included in the tables.

The figures highlighted the gulf between the minimum and maximum costs across the country for the same operation. A lung transplant could cost as little as £2,488 but as much as £31,430, with an average of £19,292, while a hip replacement operation varied from £354 to £7,784 between hospital trusts, with an average of £3,755.

The national reference cost index placed South Derbyshire community healthcare service NHS trust at the top of the table, spending 86% more than the national average. St Mary's hospital NHS trust in London, which spent 33% below average, was at the foot of the table.

Health minister John Denham blamed the "unacceptable variations" on the internal market introduced in the NHS by the Conservatives. Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, welcomed the greater transparency on NHS figures.

webTitle: 'My doctor did not tell me of life-saving drug'

fields.headline: 'My doctor did not tell me of life-saving drug'
fields.standfirst: Price of a life: As new figures show four in 10 Britons will get cancer, one woman describes her fight to live
fields.trailText: Price of a life: As new figures show four in 10 Britons will get cancer, one woman describes her fight to live
fields.body:
Jackie O'Donnell was diagnosed with advanced ovarian cancer 14 months ago. It was a shocking enough diagnosis in itself, but what was to come undermined her faith in the entire medical system she had always trusted implicitly.

After surgery, she still had five tumours left. Her consultant told her he would prescribe the standard treatment, a platinum-based drug. She spent all the rest of the day going over and over the interview, convinced that something was wrong and trying to work out what. Suddenly it hit her. She had read in a magazine that the best treatment for ovarian cancer is now a combination of two drugs, the platinum derivative and Taxol.

"I phoned my consultant back and he said yes - that is definitely what you need. He seemed relieved. He wasn't allowed to tell me because the health authority wouldn't pay for Taxol, which costs £1,500 a session and you need six to eight treatments.

"It was absolutely horrific," she said. "It is bad enough being diagnosed with cancer, particularly advanced cancer. But then to be told that you can't have the best treatment that's available... It's where you live deciding whether you live.

"You just trust doctors, don't you? You trust the hospital to give you the best treatment available. And then something like this smacks you in the face."

Jackie, 54, and her husband Geoff, a 49-year-old sales manager, decided there was no alternative. Somehow they would have to pay for Jackie's Taxol if she was to survive. So in November 1998, she began her course. The first two bills dropped through the letter box and they stowed them away in a drawer. The third one did not arrive. Instead she got a phone call from the hospital. "It was someone in the payments section who said she wouldn't send me the rest - she was going to hide them away and hope the hospital would forget about them," said Mrs O'Donnell.

By that time, Mrs O'Donnell's sense of horror had turned to outrage and she was campaigning at full throttle, speaking out in local newspapers and on television about the unfairness of it all. She did it for other women too, she said: "Other women in my position backed away. I think they felt they might have been victimised. I think they thought the hospital must know best."

Eventually, last April, South Tees health authority gave way and agreed to fund Taxol for ovarian cancer. But they are still one of the few that does. Jackie O'Donnell's cancer had disappeared within three months of her treatment and she has had two clear scans since then.

The battle over expensive cancer drugs is one of the hardest fought because it is so visible and so obviously discriminatory - one area will pay for them on the NHS and the next, a few miles away, will not.

The government has asked the national institute for clinical excellence to look at the most controversial and expensive cancer drugs as a matter of urgency, for that reason.

But cancer treatment has been underfunded in the past in many areas, and some say this government, for all its prioritisation of cancer, is still not yet ready to invest enough to bring Britain up with coun tries like America and parts of Europe.

Cancer specialists meeting in London in early November demanded their numbers be doubled to 1,200 if the NHS was to deliver the government target of an extra 100,000 lives saved by 2010.

It is not only specialists who are in short supply. More cancer nurses and support staff are needed - for instance to deal with the bureaucratic side of clinical trials of new cancer drugs and to encourage patients to go on such trials. Research has shown that patients do better if they are in clinical trials; not only those who get the new drug but also the others because they are so carefully monitored.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has made cancer one of his personal priorities in the modernisation of the NHS, and announced an extra £80m funding in October. John Toy, medical director of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, which is the largest voluntary provider of funds to cancer research, said the money was welcome, but in his view, cancer funding was wrongly balanced.

Charities are stumping up double the amount of money that the government spends on cancer research - last year about £62.4m, Dr Toy said.

"The major charities are being complemented by the government," he said. "One might imagine it should be the other way round. Government should do something about this terrible problem of cancer. But it is voluntary donations that are leading the charge."

Jean Mossman, chief executive of CancerBACUP, which supports those with cancer, would like to see more cancer doctors.

"I'd like to see us invest in more specialists," she said. "You need a specialist to get the best treatment. I'd like to see better provision of cancer information and support and I'd like to see a commitment to funding treatments that have been shown to be effective."

fields.headline: Malfunction! Malfunction!
fields.trailText: And we thought the millennium bug had passed without incident. Today England malfunctioned terminally to lose the fourth Test, the series and much of the respect that they had built up over the last two games.
fields.body:
And we thought the millennium bug had passed without incident. Today England malfunctioned terminally to lose the fourth Test, the series and much of the respect that they had built up over the last two games.

You have to feel for Nasser Hussain. Given out lbw today to a ball that he nicked through the slips for four, and non-culpable in the first innings, he spent half the match on the balcony watching his batsmen get out to a dazzling array of foolhardy shots. His series record as captain now reads: played two, lost two. He deserves better.

It is not so much the loss of the series which is so depressing - no serious commentator expected England to win it. It is the fact that here in Cape Town, in front of their families and the biggest English crowd of the tour, they did so in such an Olde England way. The collapses, the bowed heads, the wild strokes - it was all horribly familiar. They had done so much right on this tour that it all seems so wrong. Maybe it is our fault for being so hopelessly optimistic that English cricket is about to turn a corner. Why after a scratchy draw and a honourable one did we start to think that England might be capable of drawing level with the second-best side in the world?

England didn't even make South Africa pay for omitting Nantie Hayward on a good batting wicket. Before this match only three English players had passed fifty in this series. fields.headline: Labour's antique antics
fields.standfirst: It comes as no surprise to learn that Blair's MPs are opposed to proportional representation. But it's not their decision to make, says Derek Brown. It's ours
fields.trailText: The preliminary findings of a Labour party internal consultation exercise, expertly leaked to the Times, suggest that a large majority of MPs and activists support the retention of first-past-the-post voting in Westminster elections.
fields.body:
The preliminary findings of a Labour party internal consultation exercise, expertly leaked to the Times, suggest that a large majority of MPs and activists support the retention of first-past-the-post voting in Westminster elections.

Well, they would, wouldn't they? No other electoral system in the developed world allows politicians to monopolise parliamentary power, without the tiresome necessity of winning a majority of the votes. Our government enjoys a grotesque majority of 180 in the House of Commons, achieved with the support of just 44% of the people who bothered to turn out in the 1997 general election. Subject to the feeble checks of the Westminster committee system, it can do whatever it pleases.

Most MPs of the two big parties are desperate to hang on to our clapped out voting system, for it guarantees the continuation of Buggins' turn. Every few years, a modest swing of opinion sends a new tenant into Downing Street. Even in the days when it was possible to distinguish between Labour and Conservative policies, neither party could ever claim to represent a majority of the people.

They call this strong government. It is nothing of the kind. It is secure government. Get enough bums on to the polished green leather of Westminster, and you can control the affairs of the nation for five years, whatever scandal or calamity occurs.

Defenders of this psephological antique roadshow love to sneer at feckless foreigners with coalition governments. Italy, the favourite example, has just dumped its 56th - or is it 57th? - post-war government. Ho ho, very comical. But hold on uno momento: Italy in 1945 was a defeated, invaded, and occupied country. Its economy, even taking account of the ravages of war, was no more than a third of the size of Britain's. Its politics reflected a brutally polarised society facing a real threat of civil war. Yet for all its disadvantages, Italy has muddled through pretty well. The extremes of left and right have been marginalised and democracy is firmly rooted. With a population almost identical to Britain's, Italy now has (by some measures) an economy fully 20% bigger. Not bad for a comic opera country.

Contrast that with the post-war record of this country, lurching between ideologies for 40 years and now complacently basking in consensus politics. We have shed our Empire (hooray) and our influence in much of the world (boo). We have destroyed our manufacturing capacity and become almost wholly dependent on trade in services. We are dismantling the welfare state, which was once the envy of Europe, and we no longer know where we belong in the world.

But we do have dear old Westminster. We have our treasured constituency system and all of us, regardless of how or whether we vote, have our very own representative in parliament. (Hands up all those who can name their constituency and MP. There, told you so.)

The Blair government came to power on a very clear set of promises for constitutional change. It has delivered devolution in Scotland and Wales. It is doing its best to bog up the establishment of a proper municipal authority in London, but that too will happen. The Lords has been belatedly reformed. But we are no nearer to the fulfilment of the most important constitutional promise of all: to hold a referendum on voting reform.

The leak to the Times this morning strongly suggests that the party apparatchiks are softening up public opinion for a shameless retreat. We know that Blair himself is not keen on proportional representation. But in a proper representative democracy the choice is not his. It is ours, and we have been denied it too long.

A Europe of migrants?

From the United Nations today comes a fascinating, some would say disturbing, demographic survey of Europe, suggesting that native populations are set to plummet in the next half century. Germany, say the UN researchers, is likely to see its population decline from 82m to 73m by 2050. Italy will lose proportionately even more declining from 57m to just 41m.

Overall, Europe currently has five adults of working age for every person over 65. But in 50 years' time, there will be just two workers for every pensioner. Clearly, if the UN has got it right - and modern demography is a precise science - there are staggering implications, both social and economic.

Many people, particularly those of a green inclination, will doubtless welcome the potential for more breathing space in our crowded continent. But that begs the question of who will provide the wealth and services needed to sustain a smaller but rapidly ageing population. The UN's suggestion is that Europe stands in urgent need of a tide of immigration, by implication from the developing world. Germany alone, say the researchers, already needs 500,000 new immigrant workers a year to sustain its economy.

webTitle: Party hits Blair hopes of PR reform

fields.headline: Party hits Blair hopes of PR reform
fields.standfirst: Grassroots poll shows hostility to ditching first-past-the-post
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has lost another round in his struggle to keep alive Liberal Democrat hopes of electoral reform for Westminster. Labour activists and trade unionists are signalling their overwhelming support for the retention of the traditional first-past-the-post system for electing MPs.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has lost another round in his struggle to keep alive Liberal Democrat hopes of electoral reform for Westminster. Labour activists and trade unionists are signalling their overwhelming support for the retention of the traditional first-past-the-post system for electing MPs.

Provisional results of a consultation exercise by the Labour party were leaked last night by supporters of the status quo. They showed that around two thirds of submissions received by officials at party headquarters were hostile to any form of change in line with the blueprint produced in 1998 by the commission chaired by Lord Jenkins of Hillhead, the former Labour cabinet minister and SDP leader.

If it is confirmed that around 1,200 submissions oppose proportional representation in almost any form, let alone the subtle "alternative vote-plus" compromise devised by the Jenkins commission, it amounts to a further defeat for Mr Blair.

This grassroots rebellion inside the Labour party would produce a certain no-vote when the issue is finally dis cussed during the Citizenship and Democracy debate at next October's party conference.

That will be an embarrassing moment for Mr Blair who knows that few of his senior colleagues and almost as few members of the party rank and file share his enthusiasm for the joint cabinet committee he chairs with the Liberal Democrats, as well as his personal hopes of an eventual centre-left coalition against "the forces of Conservatism" of left and right.

The prime minister has kept alive the hopes of Lord Jenkins and Paddy Ashdown, both personal friends, and persuaded Mr Ashdown's successor as Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, that his intentions are sincere.

But even Mr Kennedy now accepts that there is no chance of the promised referendum this side of the expected 2001 general election.

Mr Kennedy is reported to be willing to break off informal co-operation with Labour if the referendum pledge is not renewed in Labour's next manifesto. In reality he is more of a realist and knows that a referendum lost is worse than one delayed.

Meanwhile he is angling for PR for local council elections, which may break the one party stranglehold in some cities. Mr Blair would welcome that, as would Peter Mandelson and, probably, Robin Cook though not John Prescott, Gordon Brown or Jack Straw.

It emerged in the last few days that Mr Prescott threatened to resign in the autumn of 1997 when Mr Blair planned to appoint two Liberal Democrats to the cabinet. Paddy Ashdown revealed in his diaries that the plan for a Lib-Lab coalition was dropped as a result of Mr Prescott's resignation threat.

The consultation only ended last Friday and was instantly leaked. The results will now go to Labour's national policy forum to be endorsed by a majority vote. A minority report will keep the debate alive but big unions will guarantee a massive 2-1 no-vote in October.

Mr Blair knows this and the consultation, predictable in its outcome, was set up to buy time. Both pro- and anti-PR camps lobbied hard and Labour's anti campaigners are said to be delighted with the results of the exercise.

fields.headline: Dome boss responds to critics
fields.standfirst:
Official Dome page
Polly Toynbee on the Dome
fields.trailText: Millennium Experience Company boss Jennie Page today defended London's latest attraction amid widespread complaints about queues and food shortages at the site.
fields.body:
Millennium Experience Company boss Jennie Page today defended London's latest attraction amid widespread complaints about queues and food shortages at the site.

The embattled chief executive of the dome company told the Today programme: "You'll never please everybody all of the time. We've had thousands and thousands of people who tell us that they had an absolutely fantastic day at the dome - they've really enjoyed themselves." Ms Page said some people were so pleased coming out of the millennium show they were "actually hugging" the staff.

But many people have given a thumbs-down to the dome, starting with the grand opening on New Year's Eve when thousands of people had to queue for hours. Since then, people have complained about the long lines for the main attractions such as the Body Zone, as well as food shortages.

Ms Page insisted that Dome caterers had coped "extraordinarily well", and food was available throughout all the zones. She added: "Our experience to date is that the Dome is working well and we will, of course, after four days' experience, be fine-tuning it to make it even better and to improve the quality of the experience for everybody."

Ms Page responded to critics of the £758m Dome as a committee of MPs prepared to investigate the problems which turned the opening into a fiasco. The chairman of the Commons select committee on media, culture and sport, Gerald Kaufman, said an inquiry on the Dome had already been planned by for several weeks and it would be a wide-ranging investigation, not just an inquiry into the problems of the Dome. The probe would formally begin in the spring.

An internal review by the New Millennium Experience Company has blamed the first-night party chaos on the failure to post 3,000 tickets on time.

"The root cause of the problem was the delay in sending out tickets before Christmas. Once that timetable fell behind, there was a knock-on effect," said a Dome official. "It was absolutely necessary to have thorough security searches at Stratford station on the night."

There is speculation that Ms Page, who is on a basic salary of £150,000 could lose her £200,000 performance-related bonus if her board of directors decides she is responsible for the blunders.

Julie Kirkbride, a Conservative MP on Mr Kaufman's committee, said: "I would like our culture committee to closely question Miss Page about the way the event was organised on millennium eve. I think if much of the press speculation turns out to be true then she herself ought to consider whether or not she is worthy of the bonuses organised within her payment structure."

The government's Dome spokesman, Lord Falconer, already has publicly apologised to the thousands of guests, many of them VIPs, who spent hours queuing for their Dome entry passes at a chilly railway station on New Year's Eve.

webTitle: Hell and high water: a new rain of terror

fields.headline: Hell and high water: a new rain of terror
fields.standfirst: For millions, the 90s were the decade of living dangerously. And there's worse to come, reports Tim Radford
fields.trailText: Here is how to become a disaster statistic. Move to a shanty town on an unstable hillside near a tropical coast. Crowd together as more and more people arrive. Wait for the world to get a little warmer. More evaporation means more rain, which means the slopes will get more waterlogged. One day the land will turn to mud, and the neighbourhood will begin to go downhill. Literally.
fields.body:
Here is how to become a disaster statistic. Move to a shanty town on an unstable hillside near a tropical coast. Crowd together as more and more people arrive. Wait for the world to get a little warmer. More evaporation means more rain, which means the slopes will get more waterlogged. One day the land will turn to mud, and the neighbourhood will begin to go downhill. Literally.

A landslide can accelerate to more than 320km/h. Nothing can withstand it. What roads there may have been are gone. Clinics and health services will have been erased. Rescuers will not be able to get in, survivors will have trouble getting out. There will be no food, no clean water. The uncounted dead will remain in the soil beneath your feet. Epidemics of cholera and fever will follow. The survivors will be so weakened as to be most likely counted among the dead next time.

It has just happened in Venezuela, and it will happen again somewhere else soon. Peter Walker, director of disaster policy for the international federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent societies in Geneva, has seen it too often. "One, your house has been washed away; second, the land that you farmed has disappeared; and third, the mud and the debris have spread across other bits of land you might have been able to farm, so it's now useless."

The catastrophe in Venezuela came in the last days of the United Nations international decade for natural disaster reduction. The theory was that as people were made aware of hazard, they would prepare themselves to survive it. It didn't work out like that. During the 1990s the world's population grew at the rate of 10,000 people an hour: 240,000 potential new victims every day, nearly 90m a year, almost a billion in the decade. Most of the growth was in the developing world, where people desperate for work moved to the cities, found homes on marginal soils, crowded into substandard buildings. Politically, too, life moved on. The idea that governments have an obligation to consider the welfare of all their citizens has been progressively weakened throughout the decade.

On top of that, add climate change and global warming. Seven of the 10 warmest years have occurred in the 1990s. The other three were in the late 80s. A hotter ocean breeds fiercer cyclones and hurricanes. It surrenders greater quantities of water as evaporation, and more powerful winds dump this water against mountainsides with increasing fury. 1998 - the warmest on record - was the worst year yet for climate-related disasters. According to Red Cross calculations, 57,513 people died and 335m people lost their homes, or their livelihoods, or their crops, or their livestock, or their hopes. The estimated economic bill exceeded $50bn.

"Maybe it is the decade of heightening awareness to the fact that natural disasters actually kill far many more people than wars do. The figures for 1998 make appalling reading," says Walker. "We have appealed for more funding [in 1999] than any year in our history. Part of that is Kosovo rebuilding. But in terms of natural disasters, particularly those associated with rainfall and cyclones, it has been one of the worst on record."

There have been recent floods in Vietnam, Yemen and the Congo. Three hurricanes in succession hit the eastern seaboard of the United States, killing 14. People in Vanuatu were swept away by a tsunami in November. The death toll exceeded 10,000 when a cyclone hit eastern India in October. Avalanches in alpine France and Austria caused at least 55 deaths, and storms last month left more than 130 dead across Europe. More than 14,000 died in a huge earthquake in Turkey in August; within a month 2,000 were killed in a quake in Taiwan. There were more than 75 major natural disasters - floods, drought, windstorm, earthquake, avalanche, volcanic eruption and forest fire - in 1999.

Experts believe that things will get worse. A burgeoning population will go on competing for unevenly shared resources in a world in which sea levels will rise and arable land will dwindle. At the same time as millions are made miserable by torrential rain and coastal flooding, many arid zones will become drier.

Survivors of disasters will be in temporary shelter for years, at the mercy of increasingly inhospitable skies. That is because a warming world means a stormier world, as people in low-lying countries such as Bangladesh discover repeatedly, and as Venezuela has learnt, cruelly.

"There are 40% more intense Atlantic hurricanes now than there were 30 years ago," says vulcanologist Professor Bill McGuire of the Benfield Greig hazards research centre at University College, London. "That's one effect of warming the sea. You are going to get more windstorms. You are going to get unprecedented amounts of rain in very short times."

An estimated 500m people live within range of a volcanic eruption. There are more than 500 active volcanoes, and about 50 of those erupt each year. An even greater number of people live at risk from earthquakes.

Geological evidence shows that 73,000 years ago there was a super-eruption that caused the kind of global winter you might expect only after all-out thermonuclear war. "It reduced temperatures by maybe 6C in some places and plunged the whole planet into winter for at least a few years," says McGuire. "It was devastating. There was no growing season. There are about two of these events every 100,000 years, and the last one was 73,000 years ago."

There are 30,000 earthquakes a year, most either relatively mild, or in uninhabited areas. Experts estimate an average of one major disaster each year. A big earthquake in a rich nation could trigger effects that would ripple round the world. Even if a disaster doesn't cost lives, it costs money. With worldwide economic growth, more is at stake. The insurance losses in 1998 were more than the total for the entire 1960s.

"The big one everyone is waiting for is Tokyo. It will come, and that will result in global economic chaos, and it will kill a hell of a lot of people as well," says McGuire. "There are still a million wooden buildings in the Tokyo region. The gross domestic product of the area is greater than that of Britain, and if that is wiped out, the Japanese will have to bring all their monetary resources from abroad, and that will devastate the global economy. There are lots of things worse than the Venezuela tragedy coming up."

Survivors of disasters will be in temporary shelter for years, at the mercy of increasingly inhospitable skies. That is because a warming world means a stormier world, as people in low-lying countries such as Bangladesh discover repeatedly, and as Venezuela has learnt, cruelly. "There are 40% more intense Atlantic hurricanes now than there were 30 years ago," says vulcanologist Professor Bill McGuire of the Benfield Greig hazards research centre at University College, London. "That's one effect of warming the sea. You are going to get more windstorms. You are going to get unprecedented amounts of rain in very short times." An estimated 500m people live within range of a volcanic eruption. There are more than 500 active volcanoes, and about 50 of those erupt each year. An even greater number of people live at risk from earthquakes. Geological evidence shows that 73,000 years ago there was a super-eruption that caused the kind of global winter you might expect only after all-out thermonuclear war. "It reduced temperatures by maybe 6C in some places and plunged the whole planet into winter for at least a few years," says McGuire. "It was devastating. There was no growing season. There are about two of these events every 100,000 years, and the last one was 73,000 years ago." There are 30,000 earthquakes a year, most either relatively mild, or in uninhabited areas. Experts estimate an average of one major disaster each year. A big earthquake in a rich nation could trigger effects that would ripple round the world. Even if a disaster doesn't cost lives, it costs money. With worldwide economic growth, more is at stake. The insurance losses in 1998 were more than the total for the entire 1960s. "The big one everyone is waiting for is Tokyo. It will come, and that will result in global economic chaos, and it will kill a hell of a lot of people as well," says McGuire. "There are still a million wooden buildings in the Tokyo region. The gross domestic product of the area is greater than that of Britain, and if that is wiped out, the Japanese will have to bring all their monetary resources from abroad, and that will devastate the global economy. There are lots of things worse than the Venezuela tragedy coming up."

fields.headline: Cancer now hits four in 10
fields.trailText: The number of cases of cancer in Britain is rising inexorably, it was revealed yesterday. New figures show that four out of every ten people in Britain will develop cancer at some point in their lives.
fields.body:
The number of cases of cancer in Britain is rising inexorably, it was revealed yesterday. New figures show that four out of every ten people in Britain will develop cancer at some point in their lives.

Experts yesterday predicted a significant rise in the number of cancer sufferers in the coming years, based on data released by the Cancer Research Campaign. In 1996, for which figures have just become available, 41% of men and 38% of women were at risk of developing cancer in their lifetime. In 1981, it was just 32% of men and 31% of women.

The figures are likely to increase the pressure on the government to allocate more money for research into the causes and cures of the disease.

Although the health secretary, Alan Milburn, has declared cancer a personal priority and last autumn pledged to devote £80m to fighting the disease, few doubt that far more is going to be needed.

Doctors believe that more of us are getting cancer because we are living longer, thanks to better diets, healthier lives and the power of modern medicine. The killers of old, such as infectious diseases like pneumonia and septicaemia from wound infections, are increasingly treatable and efforts to tackle heart disease have also lengthened lifespans.

Nearly 30 years ago, men could expect to live to 69 on average and women to 75. Life expectancy now is 74 and 80 respectively.

Most cancers - more than 65% - are diagnosed in people over the age of 65. Breast, bowel and prostate cancers are all on the rise in this age group.

In 1986, one woman in 12 would develop breast cancer. Now it is one in ten. However, one of the main reasons for the rise is thought to be the increased detection rate, thanks to the breast cancer screening programme. An increasing number of women are delaying the birth of their first child until they are in their 30s, or deciding to remain childless, which also increases the risk of breast cancer.

The four most common cancers - lung, breast, large bowel and prostate - account for half of all new cases.

But while the numbers of cancers are going up, the death rates are dropping. The latest survival figures for England and Wales show that over the last 25 years, the number of men diagnosed with cancer who survived for five years rose from 19 to 31%. Among women, five-year survival rates went up from 32 to 43%.

According to Professor Gordon McVie, the director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, there is great hope on the horizon in the shape of new cures and treatments, many of them stemming from the rapidly-expanding field of genetic research.

"I believe that, were I to live for another 50 years, there would be no job for me and no need for the Cancer Research Campaign," he said. "Cancer may not be cured by the year 2050 but it will be beaten and the disease will be as readily controlled as diabetes is today."

However, Britain still lags behind the US and Europe in the treatment of some cancers. Professor Mike Richards, a leading cancer specialist, has been appointed to the role of "cancer tsar" to oversee reforms of treatment methods.

"What has importantly happened is that the importance of cancer for the British public has now reached a high point on the agenda for the government," said Dr John Toy, medical director of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, although he, like Professor McVie, believes cancer research is under-funded.

However, Dr Toy said that the future now appeared to hold exciting research developments after 15 years of sluggish progress. "It has been a struggle," he added. "It is an extremely difficult one to crack."

But according to Jean Mossman, chief executive of the support charity CancerBACUP, more money is needed not just for research but to alleviate the pain of sufferers. "I think the scientists are finding new approaches to treating cancer but I'm concerned that too much emphasis is put on cure and not on actually living with cancer," she said.

"While it might be the case that in 50 years' time we are able to prevent many cancers and effectively treat those that do develop, there are 50 years of living with cancer that we need to think about."

fields.headline: Stand by your nan
fields.standfirst: A drama set in the cut-throat world of curry houses?  Chris Arnot thinks Balti Kings will go down a treat
fields.trailText: A drama set in the cut-throat world of curry houses? Chris Arnot thinks Balti Kings will go down a treat
fields.body:
It is lunchtime in the kitchen of an elegant house in Wimbledon. Cooker and sink are close at hand, but neither is in use. The two women present are sitting at a table instead, writing dialogue.

Sudha Bhuchar and Shaheen Khan are working on their third series of Girlies for Radio 4, but I'm here to ask them about Balti Kings, the play they've written for the Tamasha Theatre Company's 10th anniversary. Now on in Birmingham, it soon starts touring.

Baltis are a bit thin on the ground in Wimbledon and a trip to Khan's cousin's restaurant in Tooting would keep them away from the keyboard for too long. So we stroll a few hundred yards up the road, buy some sandwiches and eat them in the vast atrium of the Centre Court Shopping Centre. "I feel a bit agoraphobic," mutters Bhuchar, who has spent a lot of time lately cooped up in kitchens. Not just at the Khans', but in the restaurants of Birmingham's Balti Triangle.

"Tamasha has a loyal audience in Birmingham," she says, "and we wanted to give them something local. Whenever we're at the Rep or at Pebble Mill, we usually go for a balti afterwards. It struck us that in this country everyone likes Indian food, but nobody stops to think who makes it."

The writers decided to find out. And the actors came too. Apart from anything else, they would have to learn how to chop onions properly and turn out nan breads the size of cot blankets. The on-stage cooking in this production is for real.

Ten Tamasha members split into pairs and armed themselves with tape recorders. "I think some of the owners thought we were from the Inland Revenue or Immigration," Bhuchar recalls. "One or two refused to allow us in their kitchens."

Khan intervenes: "Mostly, though, owners and staff were really happy to have someone interested in their lives. These are people working 14 or 15 hours a day in a place where competition is fierce, margins are low and a lot of people are struggling to survive."

Indeed, the plot revolves around the hidden threat from the Karachi Karahi Restaurant, set up by a wealthy Asian entrepreneur with the intention of putting smaller competitors out of business. One of them is Yahsin Anwar, a fictional figure whom Bhuchar and Khan are putting forward as the man who pioneered balti (in Sparkhill rather than Kashmir). His sons, Shakeel and Shahab, have plans to diversify with a buffet and "curry-oke" session, led by two visiting Bollywood stars.

"It's not a comedy per se," says Khan, "but nor is it a dull and worthy piece about exploitation, which was the way Asian drama was seen at one time."

"We want people to feel free to laugh," Bhuchar puts in, "and we hope they'll feel like going for a curry afterwards."

Preferably in a karaoke-free zone. In a tense and heated argument, Yahsin demands to know why his sons want to waste good money flying in celebrities when they come in for nothing. "Look at that wall," he says, pointing to a photograph. "Loyd Grossman - who could be more famous than him? He walked in here himself."

Apart from the generation gap and the financial threat, the other dramatic tension comes from the passions bubbling behind the great vats of food. The chef and one of his assistants fancy the same woman, a cleaner from Bosnia. Rare was the balti kitchen in which Bhuchar and Khan didn't find someone from Bosnia, either peeling spuds, washing up or mopping floors. "They're all Muslims of course," says Bhuchar. "In the play, Islam isn't an issue. All the characters live and breathe it. What we've tried to show is that, even though people come from the same culture, they don't necessarily all turn out the same. These are multi-layered characters."

Sudha Bhuchar herself is a Hindu married to a Muslim. Shaheen Khan is a Muslim married to a Jew. Both women came to this country from east Africa when they were 11 - Khan in 1971 and Bhuchar three years later. Both have a working knowledge of Punjabi, which stood them in good stead during their research. Their skill as writers has been to turn this knockabout street language into English that Asians can believe in yet can be also clearly understood by the whites in the audience.

The success of East is East has given Tamasha a new appetite for cultural crossover. It was this company which commissioned Ayub Khan-Din's Salford saga and backed it financially. So could history be about to repeat itself? After all, the balti has conquered not just Birmingham but most of Britain. Radio 4 is already committed to turning the play into a six-part series, and this production is due to play in places like Oxford and Plymouth, not renowned for their non-white populations.

"We'd love to turn it into a film and try to keep some control over it," says Kristine Landon-Smith, co-founder of Tamasha with Bhuchar, and the director of Balti Kings. She's on the other side of London, just off the Caledonian Road, in a rehearsal room strewn with metal karahis, boxes of poppadoms and bowls full of potatoes.

Landon-Smith has a pounding headache but remains exhilarated by the script, judging by the effort she's been putting into conveying every nuance to actors who are having to remember their lines while moulding pastry or chopping vegetables. "It would have been lazy of us not to have cooking on stage," she says. "It helps the audience to believe that a buffet of 35 dishes is being created before their eyes."

And if some of the audience wonder why their eyes are streaming, it could be the writing. Or it could be the onions.

 Balti Kings is at Birmingham Rep (0121-236 4455) till Saturday, the Lyric Hammersmith, London W6 (0181-741 2311), from January 12 to February 19, then touring

fields.headline: Tudor at the crossroads
fields.trailText: Good team man that he is, Alex Tudor would have been quick to congratulate Chris Silverwood for taking five against South Africa in Cape Town. But he must know that he's now even further behind in the queue of fast bowlers. Despite being a more than handy batsman, it's not at all likely that Tudor will take the place of Andrew Flintoff for the final Test at Centurion. Darren Maddy is a more likely replacement. It's been a disappointing tour for Tudor and unless a bowler gets injured, it looks as if it will end that way. But it's good to see him in apparently good spirits. His tour diary entries on these pages suggest a man who is, yes, disappointed, but who refuses to be downbeat. Make no mistake, though: he's facing a defining moment in a career which has failed to take off after starting so promisingly.
fields.body:
Good team man that he is, Alex Tudor would have been quick to congratulate Chris Silverwood for taking five against South Africa in Cape Town. But he must know that he's now even further behind in the queue of fast bowlers. Despite being a more than handy batsman, it's not at all likely that Tudor will take the place of Andrew Flintoff for the final Test at Centurion. Darren Maddy is a more likely replacement. It's been a disappointing tour for Tudor and unless a bowler gets injured, it looks as if it will end that way. But it's good to see him in apparently good spirits. His tour diary entries on these pages suggest a man who is, yes, disappointed, but who refuses to be downbeat. Make no mistake, though: he's facing a defining moment in a career which has failed to take off after starting so promisingly.

He's been a big-impact player in the Tests he has played - taking five good Australian wickets and batting well in his debut in Perth, and then that nightwatchman's innings in Birmingham. Then, disappointingly, he got injured, and has not looked the same player since. True, his bowling was out of sorts in the match in which he scored 99 not out, but Test cricket is sometimes about helping your team out in a role that may not necessarily be your designated one. Footballers talk a lot about having "bottle". Tudor seemed to have it, and until his injury, he was about the defy the predictions of the more short-sighted observers and take his place in the next side despite not bowling particularly well.

How he must regret that injury and the attendant public-relations shambles. Not only has it cost him his place, but it seems to have arrested his development. Some reports out of South Africa suggest he's gone backwards, and despite those two big performances, he seems to have arrived back at the same place he was on his first Australian tour: a young cricketer with enormous potential who'll have to prove it. With the emergence of Silverwood, and Gough and Caddick certainties, his rivals have been busy. Alan Mullally has done reasonably well when he's played, and his left-arm seamers have looked dangerous at times. Silverwood's pace has also been a revelation, and at Port Elizabeth he was the third-fastest in the world behind the now discredited Shoaib Akthar and Nantie Hayward. Worryingly too for Tudor, England are starting to get runs out of Andrew Caddick, a fact that Tudor himself has noted. Until his foot injury, Flintoff was improving in both departments of his game. The longer Tudor stays out of the side, the less important that 99 will become, and, barring injury to one of the other bowlers, the harder it will be for him to break back in.

Nasser Hussain is clearly more comfortable with a spinner in the side, so there is unlikely to be a vacancy for a seamer in the fifth Test at Centurion unless the pitch is overgreen. Tudor, as usual, has been spurned for the one-day series, so he will not get another chance until the summer, when England face Zimbabwe and, for the first time in Tudor's career, the side where he can trace his roots - the West Indies. In his diary Tudor has spoken of the loneliness of the gym exiles - the forgotten men for whom tours can be very long. It now looks as if he'll finish the tour doing more time on the treadmill rather than time out in the middle. Happy New Year, Alex.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist.

fields.headline: Extradition
fields.standfirst: A Nazi war criminal suspect is deported while General Pinochet is fighting extradition. Patrick Barkham explains the difference between the two and why extradition is one of the big international issues of the moment
fields.trailText: A Nazi war criminal suspect is deported while General Pinochet is fighting extradition. Patrick Barkham explains the difference between the two and why extradition is one of the big international issues of the moment
fields.body:
What is extradition?

The Home Office defines extradition as "the return of a wanted criminal from a country where he or she is found, to the country where he or she is accused of, or has been convicted of, a criminal offence".

It prevents criminals escaping punishment by fleeing to another country. In the US, extradition also applies between states to stop criminals evading justice by crossing a state border.

One example of extradition followed the arrest of William Beggs by Dutch police in Amsterdam. He is currently in custody until extradition procedures are completed to return him to Scotland, where police want to question him about a recent murder.

What about deportation?

Extradition is not deportation, which is the simple removal of a person from a country. Home secretary Jack Straw decided to deport suspected Nazi war criminal Konrad Kalejs. He will not be handed over to a particular nation seeking to prosecute him.

Can any "wanted" person be extradited?

There are many cases where extradition cannot, or does not, occur. Extradition was developed piecemeal by particular countries in the 19th century. Today there is no international law which obliges countries to hand over wanted criminals. Extradition occurs only when specific, bilateral treaties exist between countries.

Where should a Briton on the run flee to?

Criminal bolt holes are steadily being obliterated, as more extradition treaties are arranged. According to a 1998 foreign office survey covering 138 countries, Britain has extradition agreements with 105 countries, including the 33 signatories of the European Convention on Extradition. There are 33 countries with which Britain does not have an extradition agreement: Afghanistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Belarus, Bhutan, Cameroon, China, Dominican Republic, Egypt, Ethiopia, Georgia, Iran, Japan, Kazakhstan, Kuwait, Kyrgyzstan, Madagascar, Mongolia, Namibia, Oman, Pakistan, Qatar, Russia, Saudi Arabia, South Korea, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, UAE, Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Venezuela and Yemen are all potential havens for British criminals.

Spain gained a reputation as the desired des res for ageing British villains after the collapse of a 100-year-old extradition treaty in 1978. A new agreement was made in 1985, which closed the loophole.

A celebrated escapee is Great Train robber Ronnie Biggs, who lives in Brazil after escaping from prison in Britain in 1965. A 1997 extradition treaty between the two countries led to a formal request to return him, which was blocked because Brazil ruled that those responsible for crimes carried out more than 30 years ago could not be extradited.

What exemptions are there for extradition?

Exemptions depend upon the complex treaties agreed. Extradition from Britain is reputed to be difficult to secure although, as General Pinochet has discovered, this is often simply because of the complex judicial procedure an extradition request must go through.

Extradition agreements usually decree that the offence which has triggered the extradition request must be considered a crime in both countries. A "double jeopardy" rule is also commonly evoked to protect a person from being tried twice for the same crime in different countries.

Many treaties provide for political and human rights exemptions, which can prevent the extradition of a person who is accused of political crimes or seeking sanctuary in a country which believes the extradition-seeking state will persecute them. In November 1998, French authorities refused a British warrant for the extradition of former spy David Shayler on such grounds.

Such agreements are different from asylum laws, which grant refugee status to fugitives from another nation who are judged to face state persecution if they return to the country they fled from. If refused, asylum-seekers tend to be deported.

When can extradition requests be blocked?

Even when countries share an extradition treaty, one can block the extradition of a wanted person to another. Extradition is usually decided by the judiciary, but Britain's Extradition Act of 1989 gives special powers to the home secretary, who can forbid an extradition if it is "unjust or oppressive".

In March 1998, Jack Straw used this power to block the German government's demand to return Roisin McAliskey - then imprisoned in Britain - to stand trial in Germany for the bombing of a German barracks. He ruled she was too ill; General Pinochet hopes to benefit from a similar appeal to ill-health, which could yet see Mr Straw blocking his extradition to Spain.

Is extradition a good thing?

One school of thought holds that the tightening of extradition arrangements could create a global legal mechanism capable of bringing dictators to justice for their crimes against humanity. The other interpretation is that it could come to constitute an international system of oppression, with extradition used against ordinary individuals such as political activists, allowing one state's oppression to spread beyond its frontiers.

At present, it remains easier to extradite ordinary individuals suspected of straightforward crimes. The extradition of prominent, political figures, such as General Pinochet, arouses more controversy.

As a foreign office minister said recently: "It has been a paradox of our century that those who murder one person are more likely to be brought to justice than those who plot genocide against millions"

fields.headline: Straw defends deportation decision
fields.standfirst: Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday defended the decision to deport the suspected war criminal Konrad Kalejs. Meanwhile fresh documentary evidence emerged that he was a senior member of a Latvian death squad which slaughtered thousands of Jews during the second world war.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday defended the decision to deport the suspected war criminal Konrad Kalejs. Meanwhile fresh documentary evidence emerged that he was a senior member of a Latvian death squad which slaughtered thousands of Jews during the second world war.

Nazi hunters wanted Kalejs, 86, prosecuted in Britain but Mr Straw yesterday stressed that a review of evidence by Scotland Yard found there was insufficient evidence to prosecute him.

The furore erupted after it was discovered that Kalejs, an Australian citizen, had entered Britain in September and could legally stay until March. The home secretary ordered an inquiry into how someone deported from both the United States and Canada for involvement in war crimes could still enter Britain.

It is now believed that Kalejs entered Britain as long ago as the summer of 1998. He was traced last month to a Latvian retirement home in Leicestershire where he was yesterday deciding whether to fight moves to deport him, or leave as soon as tomorrow. Kalejs has repeatedly denied being a senior officer in the Arajs Kommando, which collaborated with the Nazis in killing an estimated 30,000 people, mainly Jews.

But according to documents lodged with the US appeals court, seen by the Guardian, Kalejs wrote that he was a senior officer in the unit. A signed note in his own hand, written to the registrar of Riga university, says he was a senior officer in the unit, also known as the Latvian auxiliary security police.

Dated "Riga, 15 May 1943", the note says: "I hereby inform you that I am in the service of the Commander of the Security Police and SD of Latvia - in the Latvian Security Section as a company commander."

Other documentary evidence tying Kalejs to the unit comes from Victor Arajs, after whom the mobile killing squad was named. He was sentence to life imprisonment in Germany for war crimes. A form sent to Riga university on November 28 1941 and signed by Arajs says: "First lieutenant Konrads Kalejs has been a member of the Latvian Auxiliary Security Police from 29 July, this year, to the present."

Another form from the dep-uty chief of the unit on November 5, 1942, gave details of Kalejs's service in the Latvian security section.

The Tory home affairs spokeswoman, Ann Widdecombe, said Mr Straw had been too hasty in reaching his decision. She said it would be a "betrayal of justice and human rights" if new evidence emerged after he had been banished from the country.

fields.headline: Letter from Jack Straw
fields.standfirst: Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: You say I am "to deport the suspected war criminal Konrad Kalejs, rather than attempt to prosecute him" (Deportation, not trial, January 4). I have no powers to order the detention, arrest or prosecution of any individual with a view to criminal proceedings, and nor should I.
fields.body:
You say I am "to deport the suspected war criminal Konrad Kalejs, rather than attempt to prosecute him" (Deportation, not trial, January 4). I have no powers to order the detention, arrest or prosecution of any individual with a view to criminal proceedings, and nor should I. In our democracy, it is not for the home secretary to make these decisions but for the police and independent prosecuting authorities on the evidence before them. It is an irony that former Nazis are afforded rights they never extended to others. But that is the difference between the rule of law and the descent into barbarism.
Jack Straw MP
Home secretary

webTitle: I paid up, I queued up, and now I'm thoroughly fed up

fields.headline: I paid up, I queued up, and now I'm thoroughly fed up
fields.standfirst:
As one of its early supporters, I'm sorry to say that the Dome is a lemon

The Millennium: special report
Is it worth taking children to the Dome? Tell us what you think on the Education Unlimited talkboards
fields.trailText: As one of its early supporters, I'm sorry to say that the Dome is a lemon
fields.body:
This is not an I-told-you-so column. Quite the contrary, I didn't. I was not among the multitude who wished the Dome ill, hoped it wouldn't open in time or complained of its monumental cost. Governments are for bread and circuses. Great moments deserve great monuments and flamboyant popular festivals are all too rare. Time passing is better marked by extravagant celebration than with wars or monarch's reigns.

But alas this is not a great exhibition. It is a deep disappointment. It doesn't work on any level, from the most mundane purchase of a cup of coffee to any bit of really good fun. Lord Falconer is busy apologising to the VIPs for their chaotic first night queuing, but he'd better stand at the door grovelling to the paying public too. There is a replica pillory just outside where the queues could pelt him with rotten vegetables (except the management would run out of vegetables, as they run out of everything else).

As a Dome enthusiast, I bought 10 tickets ages ago to take my family for the day: £20 a head didn't seem exorbitant for the "Amazing Day" promised. (I pass over the difficulty of buying tickets from a local lottery outlet that had never heard of the Dome.) Hugo Young, writing here yesterday about his dismal experience as one of the 10,000 VIPs invited for the night itself, was subjected to the added insult of having to listen to high-flown political boasting about the Dome's high purpose. But I never had elevated expectations of finding millennial meaning in the Dome. All that was required was a bit of Wow! Any old Wow! would have done - fantastic rides, an amazing spectacle, something witty, startling futurism, geewhiz science, anything memorable would do.

The trouble with queuing is that expectations rise exponentially with every minute queued. If you stand outside the body zone for an hour it had better be worth it, but all you get is seven minutes of nothing much. The mildly surreal beating of a heart or Tommy Cooper's brain telling jokes is an utterly inadequate reward for those who have queued angrily for so long.

And there were queues for almost everything worth seeing, (none for the faith zone), so in eight hours I couldn't see all the zones: maybe I missed something wonderful, but I doubt it. Who are we, one zone asks? British phlegm and patience suggests we are people who queue with pride, the same odd British psyche that celebrates the Dunkirk spirit: there was no rebellion, have-a-nice-day hosts were not lynched and no one ran amok. Having queued 45 minutes for a coffee, for lunch we chose what looked like the shortest food queue. An hour later we reached the Trade Winds serving hatch: all the food had run out. In fact, everything, everywhere ran out - though it was rumoured you could get a McDonald's in only 15 minutes.

But the serious problem is that there was nothing worth queuing for. At a breezy gallop the whole experience could be quite fun. But in the play zone, with long queues for each item, none of the games approach the ones most kids have at home: Nintendo's Golden Eye makes these look like ancient history.

The best, a team game played by a hundred at a time, was pretty feeble. It came, like everything else, with a moral message about teamwork (though actually it proved the opposite). The moral messages in the work zone were unpleasantly threatening (No Skills, No Job), breeding instinctive rebellion, and the "hand-eye co-ordination" games insulting to the idea of serious skill. Parents of young children were complaining bitterly at how bored they were. Teenagers made disparaging comparisons with modern arcade machines.

Everywhere high minded messages are matched with low tech exhibits. Nothing here is as astounding as the internet, nothing is as creative as the best television programmes, all of it assem bled by exhibition organisers with nothing to exhibit. The best space is wasted on a vast auditorium for a show of ugly banality: the West End does better with almost any musical, De La Guarda has more dazzling dance and acrobatics and the fair outside Buckingham Palace had far better rides. In days of austerity the Festival of Britain had no competition, but the Dome can't contend with state of the art modern entertainment already so full of creative Wow!

If they had acknowledged that problem from the start they would have handed the central theme over to artists, the only begetters of anything good here. What's memorable is the building itself, grubby by day but startling when lit at night like a iridescent jellyfish. The body zone as a sculpture is a wonderful thing in shimmering orange tiles, but crammed in a corner its splendour is diminished. Inside the otherwise mindless mind zone is a lovely statue of a squatting boy.

On a platform in the river a fine Antony Gormley work rises in silvery jagged shapes. Gerald Scarfe's splenetic sculptures shine in an otherwise dead zone, while the rest zone is a beautiful, empty, illuminated igloo. If you can shut your eyes passing through the faith zone's appalling sententious sayings and theology for morons, inside there is a miraculous blue spiral light sculpture by James Tirrell.

There never could have been message or meaning in an exhibition of this kind. In the end only art transcends the platitudes of politicians, the empty exhortations and the hollow Christian attempts to impose a banality of its own. The lesson is that only those elements created by artists have meaning. Sadly they are too few and far between to rescue the Dome, but in future this should tell governments to rely on artists whose work will long outlast them. Who cares now what event Handel's Water Music celebrated?

Is it too late to redesign and refine the Dome over the next months? They could still junk the worst and move more art to centre-stage. To make it a bearable day out, they must halve the number of tickets sold - though word of mouth alone may do that. Even Sainsbury's delicatessen counter knows how to give out numbered tickets instead of making people queue.

I hate to join the chortling ranks of Dome rubbishers in the rightwing press or the leftwing puritans who think money should never be spent on extravagant fun and display. Both lots gleefully proclaim that all this vacuity symbolises the emptiness of Blairism, which of course it doesn't. Success or failure, it never needed to symbolise anything much but, alas, I have to admit the Dome is a lemon by any reckoning.

fields.body:
The Odeon cinema in London's Leicester Square plays host to the premiere of Universal Pictures International / Paramount Pictures' Angela's Ashes on Tuesday January 11. Based on Frank McCourt's Pulitzer Prize-winning memoir, Angela's Ashes is directed by Alan Parker and stars Emily Watson and Robert Carlyle.

Tipped by many as the crowning achievement of Parker's career, Angela's Ashes (15 certificate) is a richly observed tale of growing up poor in post-war Limerick. Soulful, funny and heartfelt, it looks certain to rank among the most important movies of the new year.

Courtesy of UIP, you can win a pair of premiere tickets, watch the film and ogle the stars at what promises to be a glitzy, high profile night complete with attendance by Alan Parker, Emily Watson and a host of other celebrities. The prize includes transport and accommodation at a top West End hotel.

Don't miss out on this fantastic opportunity to catch a film exclusive and mingle with the players that matter.

Click here to enter the competition.

Angela's Ashes, certificate 15, is released in the UK on January 14, 2000.

fields.headline: Mickey's last stand
fields.standfirst:
The little fellow

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Mickey Mouse has made a comeback in what many consider his finest hour, the Sorcerer's Apprentice sequence from Disney's Fantasia (1940), now incorporated into the bigger, louder Imax extravaganza, Fantasia 2000.
fields.body:
The end of the 20th century was a good time for what used to be known as the Little Fellow. Comedian Norman Wisdom - a favourite of the Queen, and a living legend in Albania, where he's known as "Pitkini" - was listed for a knighthood. And Mickey Mouse made a comeback in what many consider his finest hour, the Sorcerer's Apprentice sequence from Disney's Fantasia (1940), now incorporated into the bigger, louder Imax extravaganza, Fantasia 2000.

Although critics over 18 didn't rate the film much, prepubescent viewers vox-popped by this paper enthusiastically agreed that the original Mickey sequence was the best in the film. That ought to prove the undying appeal of Mousehood, but I have my doubts. The Sorcerer's Apprentice and its star may well be timeless, but only in the particular sense in which a cultural phenomenon is entirely of its time, absolutely represents its age, and is therefore dated, albeit in a transcendental way.

Standing specifically for the last century, Mickey has no chance of making it as an icon into the 21st. He's a curiously repellent figure in ways that only the professionally lovable can be. His history is one of rapid institutionalisation and embourgeoisement, from the surreal elastic imp of the 20s to the tolerant suburban patriarch and corporate spokesman he had become by the 50s. The lanky, rubbery hero of 1928's Steamboat Willie is a bizarre, elemental creature, but it didn't take the corporation long to make him stocky and leaden, formalise his costume and turn him into a smiling yes man, glad- handing theme-park punters. Mickey became not just the company's figurehead, but its very being, its chairman by proxy. It's no accident that Variety still routinely refers to Disney as the Mouse House or, tellingly, just the Mouse.

Fantasia 2000 shows today's Mickey still playing the obliging corporate mascot, dashing on between musical sequences to make cheeky, squeaky backchat with the conductor. This only underlines the conservative lesson of the Sorcerer's Apprentice sketch. Mickey is warned by the beetle-browed magician not to make trouble, but quite reasonably wants to harness the boss's magic for his own ends, so borrows his hat. He brings a broom to life and makes it carry buckets of water for him, but the brooms multiply uncontrollably, and an army of them floods the cell with water. At last, the angry sorcerer restores order, retrieves his hat, and sends Mickey - who shoots the boss the very definition of the shit-eating grin - scuttling ignominiously back to his corner. And we're still supposed to be charmed by this "timeless" parable of the workers knowing their place.

Mickey's original persona was rooted in the mythology of modern industrial society, no less than the other Little Fellow archetype, Charlie Chaplin. His early battles were against technological chaos: Mickey would be the one malleable yet stable figure at the centre of a storm of clattering stovepipe machinery. Objects would malfunction and mutate around him, but Mickey would genially bend to the chaos, at once master and servant of technology's rhythms. Through him, the art of animation - the unnatural cinema technology par excellence - dramatised its own mechanical nature and in a roundabout way advertised its approachability.

While Mickey was promoted to the board, the Disney hero who still seems contemporary remains an outsider - Donald Duck, no one's idea of the resiliently accepting Little Fellow, but a crazed romantic rager against the inconveniences of the world, whether natural or technological, who might at any moment erupt into a libidinous cataclysm in his own right. Donald is the precursor of Jack Nicholson, Travis Bickle and Seinfeld's sidekick George Costanza, yet - shame - even he has been co-opted by Fantasia 2000, pressed into service as an obliging steward on Noah's Ark.

Similarly, the silent comedies that don't seem timeless, as Chaplin's do, but of the present, are Buster Keaton's, whose battles can't be reduced to those of the early-21st-century industrial struggler. Paradoxically, what makes Keaton modern is that he is a parodic hangover of an archetype from an earlier age, a comic avatar of the 19th-century Byronic hero - the loner in the wilderness, racked by the elements, impassioned, unbowed and above all, never submissive to the audience's approval. Where Chaplin was forever tipping a winsome wink to the crowd, Keaton acted as though the audience simply wasn't there - he seemed as unconcerned by the mechanisms of entertainment as by the industrial mechanisms that defined the plucky toiler hero, whether Chaplin, Mickey or Norman Wisdom.

Mickey's last stand, and Wisdom's knighthood, surely represent an adieu to the archetype of the eager little loner - cloth-capped, bowler-hatted or big-eared - on the shop floor. Is it too early to hazard a guess on the comic archetype of the coming age? For that, we do have a model: Jacques Tati, like a distracted stork legging and pecking his way through the attractions of the post-modern consumer metropolis in his under-rated 1967 masterpiece, Playtime. Tati couldn't be a more timely icon, a model for the punters sceptically and bemusedly inspecting the variously mystifying and ludicrous attractions of the Millennium Dome.

fields.headline: Big numbers: Online French couture
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The Vicar of Dibley is to join the growing band of aspiring internet entrepreneurs. Comedian Dawn French, who plays the cleric in the BBC television series, is planning an online expansion of her oversized clothing company, Sixteen47.
fields.body:
The Vicar of Dibley is to join the growing band of aspiring internet entrepreneurs. Comedian Dawn French, who plays the cleric in the BBC television series, is planning an online expansion of her oversized clothing company, Sixteen47.

Ms French and her business partner, designer Helen Teague, are in talks with PR agency Matthew Freud Communications about setting up a new interactive website which would enable women sized 16-48 to "try on" and buy clothes online.

Mr Freud is one of the founders of online toy-seller Toyzone, due to float for about £250m this year.

The Sixteen47 site is likely to focus initially on the French & Teague designer line launched last year, which sells through the British Designer Collections at Liberty in Regent Street in London. A cheaper range featured in Littlewood's catalogue and a medium-priced line sold at Sixteen47's London shop are likely to be included.

Sixteen47 was set up in 1991, inspired by the fact that manufacturers have historically neglected the 47% of women sized 16 or over.

webTitle: How Churchill plotted against 'our bitter foe' De Gaulle

fields.headline: How Churchill plotted against 'our bitter foe' De Gaulle
fields.trailText: Churchill plotted to oust General de Gaulle as leader of the Free French forces during the second world war, describing him as "a bitter foe of Britain" who left "a trail of Anglophobia" behind him everywhere he went, secret documents released yesterday disclose.
fields.body:
Churchill plotted to oust General de Gaulle as leader of the Free French forces during the second world war, describing him as "a bitter foe of Britain" who left "a trail of Anglophobia" behind him everywhere he went, secret documents released yesterday disclose.

He hatched the plot - at the height of the war - with President Roosevelt who also strongly distrusted the man who was later to lead a French revival based on national pride and deep suspicion of the United States and Britain.

The mutual antipathy between Churchill and De Gaulle, who spent most of the war in London, is well documented, but the lengths to which Britain's wartime leader was ready to go to get rid of the man who was to be France's greatest postwar statesman has never been disclosed until now.

British diplomats in Paris were uneasy when they were told recently about the decision to release the papers at the public records office.

The documents consist mainly of a series of coded telegrams between London and Washington, where Churchill was holding talks with Roosevelt.

In a furious dispute with his war cabinet in May 1943, Churchill told Clement Attlee, his deputy prime minister, and Anthony Eden, the foreign secretary: "I ask my colleagues to consider urgently whether we should not now eliminate De Gaulle as a political force."

De Gaulle, said Churchill in this May 21 cable, "hates England and has left a trail of Anglophobia behind him everywhere".

The man's removal was necessary, given Britain's "absolutely vital interest in preserving good relations with the United States".

Churchill sent his cabinet colleagues a personal memo he received from Roosevelt describing De Gaulle as having a "messianic complex" with "dictatorial" tendencies.

The US president added: "He has the idea that the people of France itself are strongly behind him personally. This I doubt."

Roosevelt said he did not know what to do with De Gaulle, telling Churchill: "Possibly you would like to make him governor of Madagascar!"

In an accompanying telegram to Eden, Churchill referred to a French source in Washington who described De Gaulle as "thoroughly unfriendly both to Britain and to the United States and [that] while affecting communist sympathies he had fascist tendencies".

Churchill added: "This again tallies with my own feelings."

If De Gaulle were removed, Churchill's cabinet colleagues argued, the ranks of the French resistance "would consider that the Anglo-Saxons had betrayed their leader, and a further swing towards Russia would be inevitable". French internal affairs ought not to be manipulated "with a view to treating France as an Anglo-American protectorate".

The special Anglo-US relationship was so distrusted by De Gaulle when he became postwar president of France that he repeatedly blocked Britain's belated attempts to join the common market, the forerunner of the EU. Those tensions remain.

fields.headline: Amazon not thinking about profit
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Amazon.com chief executive Jeff Bezos says he will continue to expand the on-line retailer aggressively into new areas and "think later" about the company turning a profit.
fields.body:
Amazon.com chief executive Jeff Bezos says he will continue to expand the on-line retailer aggressively into new areas and "think later" about the company turning a profit.

Mr Bezos, Time Magazine's person of the year in 1999, said: "We don't have time to lose. We'll think later about balancing the accounts. Our losses are tied to investments. We are expanding our presence from books to other sectors to become not only the biggest bookstore in the world but also the biggest supermarket on the web. Even if no one believes it, I never follow the short-term progress of my shares," he told the Rome daily la Repubblica.

Seattle-based Amazon said its losses would increase in the last quarter of 1999 as it had increased advertising and marketing campaigns in a drive to win new customers. However, it believed its bookselling business would move into profit. Amazon.com was launched in 1995 and now has 13m customers.

Visitors to electronic commerce sites jumped 27% in the Christmas week compared with the same week last year, according to Media Metrix.

Amazon.com was the most-visited shopping site from November 22 to December 26, averaging 5.7m daily visitors from November 22 to December 26, followed by auction site eBay.com with 4.1m and eToys.com with 1.7m.

The biggest gainers for Christmas week were greeting card sites, such as www.123greetings.com which saw its average number of daily visitors jump 168% to 153,000 visitors.

fields.headline: Britain's true colours
fields.standfirst:
It's a symbol of a unity that no longer exists. It's a badge of fascism and aggression. Or it's a design icon reclaimed by mods, the Spice Girls and manufacturers of boxer shorts. Jonathan Glancey asks what the Union Jack means to us now and wonders if it is time for a change
