fields.trailText: I know, let's rebrand Britain. Duh. Done that. Or at least some of Blair's   boys did a couple of years ago in an attempt to spin doctor this sceptr'd   isle into something hip, hop and happening.
fields.body:
I know, let's rebrand Britain. Duh. Done that. Or at least some of Blair's boys did a couple of years ago in an attempt to spin doctor this sceptr'd isle into something hip, hop and happening.

It didn't exactly work. A recent survey of the way Britain is perceived after two years of feverish rebranding shows that Johnny and Janet Foreigner still think of the United Kingdom as being old fashioned, grubby and interestingly cranky. All those heaving bars and cafes lining the streets of fashionable city centres designed by standard-issue, goatee-sporting young architects can't dent an internationally recognised aesthetic rooted in hundreds of years of class distinction, pigeon-fancying, warm beer and supermarket food. These things - as British as mom's apple pie is American - are held together symbolically by one of the greatest graphic designs of all time, the Union Jack (more properly the Union flag).

At the start of the 21st century what does the Union Jack represent? Indeed, in an era of devolution and internationalism, does the flag that earned its nickname because a 'jack-crosstree' was naval jargon for a flag flown from the bowsprit of a ship have any tangible meaning at all. If it does, are we the people happy with that meaning?

For some, an older generation, it symbolises a time of greater certainty, when Britain had an empire, the king was on his throne and a pound was worth a pound. To classic cars buffs it means great green vintage Bentleys racing the Blue Train from Paris to Marseilles in the 1920s (one did just that, and won). To old soldiers on Remembrance Sunday, it calls to mind their comrades who died in two world wars so we could eat burgers and sniff glue, or just live in peace.

But if its history is the Union Jack's strength, it is also its weakness. For sections of the British public it represents outdated political and social beliefs: it can be read as the standard under which Ireland was annexed and subdued with the subtlety of a sledgehammer. It can be seen as the banner of an empire that made white people feel superior to black people. It has been worn as a badge of fascism, nationalism and hooliganism, a gesture of aggression, narrow-mindedness and brutality. The issues are no longer clear. The flag - and with it the very notion of Britain and what being British means - is losing the mythologised identity that has held it together.

Perhaps many of us have never been particularly happy with the idea of Britishness. The Welsh, Scots and Irish are clearly very different people from the mainstream English. Even then, this is a difficult thing to talk about with anything like clarity. While the evident majority of Irish, Scots and Welsh are Celtic in terms of ethnic roots, the English are an extraordinary melange. True, you will find villages in East Anglia where the people seem to be the very embodiment of Anglo-Saxons, I mean Danes, or is it Vikings, or were Danes in fact Vikings anyway.

Scratch an Englishman and you will find a mongrel. I think of myself as English, but my blood is a mix of Anglo-Saxon, Irish Celt and Celtic Spaniard, more or less. It's not just immigrants of the post-war years whose races are mixed, roots uncertain and nationality a matter of myth as much as geography.

The Union Jack, however, is first and foremost a symbol of political unity. It emerged, step by step, cross by cross, from the union of Scotland and England in 1606 when James IV of Scotland became James I of England. The new flag displayed the cross of St George of England (red on white) superimposed on the cross of St Andrew of Scotland (white on blue), or vice versa.

Oliver Cromwell added an Irish harp to the flag when he subdued Ireland, but this was removed by Charles II at the time of the restoration of the monarchy in 1660. The act of union in the reign of Queen Anne in 1707 brought Scotland, England and Wales together as the United Kingdom; Ireland joined the gang in 1801 and the Union Jack as we know it was given its definitive and highly distinctive look. The Irish cross, nominally of St Patrick, but in fact that of the Geraldines, a powerful Irish family, was added into the already complex criss-crossing of St George and St Andrew. The result was far from the mess it might have been: it was a masterpiece.

Today, though, the English (whoever they are) want their cross of St George, the Scots their cross of St Andrew, the Irish (careful what you say here . . .) their cross of St Patrick and the Welsh, the red dragon you can't see - presumably, for all those red, blue and white crosses and because Wales has been dominated by England since the death of Owen Glendower in battle in 1416. Whether much will change with a Millbank stooge as leader of the new Welsh Assembly when it gathers in its smart new Richard Rogers-designed building is hard to say.

Devolution contains within it the possible final lowering of the Union Jack. But it is more likely that there will long be occasions when the English, Welsh, Scots and Irish will wish to work and play under the same banner. And as for Remembrance Sunday, that will be held under the banner of the Union Jack for as long as it endures, because those hundreds of thousands of people who lived and died so that we could wear Union Jack underpants did so together, and not as Micks, Jocks, Taffys and their English comrades (no collective nickname, note, for the lads representing the dominant culture of these islands).

They fought, wittingly or unwittingly, for a set of powerful collective beliefs against the forged creed of Nazism represented by a flag - black swastika in white circle on blood-red backdrop - that was as simple as the Union Jack was complex. Liberty implies complexity: Nazism, the reduction of human life to simplistic certainties.

The flag has other saviours: design and fashion. What would designers do without the Union Jack? It gave Mods their look in the early 60s. The Who wore Union Jack clothes long before the Spice Girls. It seemed to be made for the imagery of the pop era, and was used promiscuously by painters, designers and costumiers in the 'I'm backing Britain' days of Harold Wilson's second Labour government (Old Labour, but great modernisers) of 1966-70. And it had been used to style the interiors of fashionable society houses even before the second world war. In his satirical poem Interior Decorator, John Betjeman has his camp narrator say: 'I put Red Ensigns on the seats/And hung Blue Peters down their backs/And on the beds, instead of sheets/Enormous pairs of Union Jacks.'

The Union Jack may well be slightly threadbare politically and in terms of devolved national sentiment, but it remains, in design terms at least, one of the most potent icons of all.

It seemed to be made for the imagery of the pop era, and was used promiscuously by painters, designers and costumiers in the 'I'm backing Britain' days of Harold Wilson's second Labour government (Old Labour, but great modernisers) of 1966-70. And it had been used to style the interiors of fashionable society houses even before the second world war. In his satirical poem Interior Decorator, John Betjeman has his camp narrator say: 'I put Red Ensigns on the seats/And hung Blue Peters down their backs/And on the beds, instead of sheets/Enormous pairs of Union Jacks.' The Union Jack may well be slightly threadbare politically and in terms of devolved national sentiment, but it remains, in design terms at least, one of the most potent icons of all.  See the designs  Design your own and win a Guardian Yearbook

fields.headline: The best icon scene
fields.standfirst: Dogma
fields.trailText: A large group of people are gathered outside a church as a voice announces: "And now, the guiding force behind Catholicism Wow! ... Cardinal Glick".
fields.body:
A large group of people are gathered outside a church as a voice announces: "And now, the guiding force behind Catholicism Wow! ... Cardinal Glick".

Cardinal Glick (George Carlin) takes the stage to rapturous applause.

"Now we all know how the majority and the media in this country view the Catholic Church. They think of us as a passé, archaic institution. People find the Bible obtuse - even hokey. Now, in an effort to disprove all that, the church has appointed this year as a time of renewal, both of faith and of style. For example, the crucifix. While it has been a time- honoured symbol of our faith, Holy Mother Church has decided to retire this highly recognisable, but highly depressing symbol of our Lord crucified. Christ didn't come to earth to give us the willies! He came to help us out. He was a booster. And it was with that take on the Lord in mind that we've come up with a new, more inspiring, sigil. So it is with great pleasure that I present you with the first of many revamps the Catholicism Wow! Campaign will unveil over the next year. I give you The Buddy Christ!"

A choir sings Hallelujah, as a figure of Jesus, winking and giving a jovial thumbs-up, is wheeled out.

"That's not the sanctioned term we're using for the symbol, just somethingwe've been kicking around the office. But doesn't it pop?"

See also: Bad Lieutenant, Orphans, Planet Of The Apes

Don't see also: Beverly Hills Ninja, The Robe

Pointless trivia: George Carlin was the first ever host of the legendary show, Saturday Night Live.

fields.headline: Hamilton turns on 'dying' Tory party
fields.standfirst:
He joins Howe, Major and Clarke in criticising the state of the party
Special report: Hamilton, Al Fayed libel action
5 January: Another grandee takes a swipe at Hague
fields.trailText: Neil Hamilton became the latest high-profile Tory to criticise William Hague's party, going on breakfast television to describe it as "lying down and dying".
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton became the latest high-profile Tory to criticise William Hague's party, going on breakfast television to describe it as "lying down and dying".

The former minister, publicly rejected by the Conservatives after his failed libel action against Harrods boss Mohamed Al Fayed last month, also branded party chairman Michael Ancram "inhumane" for hoping Mr Hamilton would disappear into the background.

Mr Hamilton insisted he and his wife were not suicidal despite the "tragedy" of their failed court action. In contrast, he told GMTV: "It is the Conservative party that appears to be lying down and dying at the moment, if I may say so.

"I don't think Michael Ancram's rather inhumane and self-interested comments in the aftermath of the verdict in my case merit more than two seconds consideration. He showed himself up for what he was."

Last month, the former Tory minister said he was a "broken man" after a High Court jury rejected his claim that he had been libelled by Mr Al Fayed, who accused him of accepting cash for asking Parliamentary questions.

"We're not pretending it didn't happen," Mr Hamilton added today. "We've got to get on with life. Plenty of people have worse tragedies than we had and they have to get on with their lives.

"We're not suicidal. We know we've got problems, we intend to solve them. My career in politics is at an end and, at the relatively advanced age of 50 - but I feel much younger - we're going to try to make new careers for ourselves."

Speaking about the strength of their marriage, Mrs Hamilton said: "I do find it a rather sad reflection on society that a marriage like ours is regarded as extraordinary."

fields.headline: All about my father
fields.standfirst: His films are beguiling and convoluted tales in the magical-realist vein, but Basque director Julio Medem tells  Dan Glaister they are based on real life - his own
fields.trailText: His films are beguiling and convoluted tales in the magical-realist vein, but Basque director Julio Medem tells Dan Glaister they are based on real life - his own
fields.body:
Julio Medem is excited. No, let's be honest about this: Julio Medem is hugely excited. In London for a day to talk about his latest, fourth feature film, The Lovers of the Arctic Circle, the soft-spoken Basque director can talk about nothing more than his fifth film, as yet untitled, which he had finished writing the night before. "I have a sty," he says, pointing to a red mark on his lower eyelid. "I was staring for so long at my computer screen - and the protective filter is broken - that it gave me a sty."

The Lovers of the Arctic Circle takes Medem's usual preoccupations - love, death, nature, accident - and wraps them up in a typically convoluted, magical-realist tract. We meet the lovers in question, the palindromically challenged Ana and Otto, as they race each other through the woods. But at this stage, aged eight or so, they do not yet know that they are to be lovers. They are merely running, against each other and with each other, the boy chasing a football, the girl running away from her mother. From such simple schoolyard beginnings Medem spins and weaves a tale that takes the two through adolescence, through togetherness and separation, and eventually leads them to the north pole and back to the film's very first scene, a poetic, fluttering image of a newspaper flying through the air.

Like Medem's earlier efforts, Vacas, The Red Squirrel and Tierra, the structure and the feel of his new film are baroque, sometimes wilfully confusing, sometimes frustrating but always beguiling. If there is a tendency to overelaborate, the director-writer's enthusiasm and sympathy for his subject carry the audience through. Does he know where he is going when he writes these stories, or is he as confused as the audience?

"With Lovers, I knew I was going to write a love story, and I knew I was going to alternate the narrator, telling it from his and from her perspective," he says. "Then an image came into my head, the image of the race between the two children, and I thought, ah, here's something that interests me. But I didn't know where I was going. The race was like an escape, a sort of flight, with these two characters escaping one reality for another. I wrote it without wanting to know about the next scene, I wanted to sustain the uncertainty about where I was going."

Characters like to run in Medem's films; or Medem likes to make his characters run. In among the motorcycle madness of The Red Squirrel - his most successful feature to date, at least in export terms - the most memorable scene has the two male protagonists racing each other to catch up with the disappearing Emma Suarez. Breathless and straining, the two are suspended by Medem's camera in a study of Basque machismo. Machismo, too, is one of his recurrent themes: Vacas (Cows), his debut feature, was a tale of rugged, broad-shouldered Basque men competing to see who could chop tree trunks most swiftly. In Tierra, his third feature, another Basque man - in fact, the same actor from the first two films - wages a lonely struggle to impose order on an unruly, pest-ridden countryside, another allegorical test for the Basque machismo.

Yet the very theme that has provided the 40-year-old Medem with much of his inspiration - the Basque condition - is also a source of irritation. Consequently, his new film is set in Madrid, his home for the past three years. "It hurts me to have left the Basque country, but I think I have gained something. Leftwing nationalism is fascistic. They tell you how you have to be to be a true Basque, how you should feel. The nationalist press exaggerates and promotes difference, but everybody should have the right to behave as they feel." The director then embarks on a lengthy, rambling discourse: the Basques are proud, closed, fearful, noble, strong, sober, competitive... before stopping himself with a meek word of apology.

But if he is embarrassed in person, on film Medem does not curtail his enthusiasms, entwining the particulars of his personal history with grander, more abstract propositions. In person his intellectualism is not so prominently on display. While he has a Paul Austerish air about him - dark, delicate good looks, a flash to the eyes - he shies away from overt exposition of any credo, preferring to view his films as fragments of autobiography.

Tierra was addressed to his father, a Franco supporter, whom the young Medem "blamed personally for all the disasters in the world". Lovers of the Arctic Circle tells, in part, the story of his father's brother, Otto - played as a young boy by Medem's own son - a pilot who joined Franco's contribution to the Nazi cause, the Blue Squadron, a volunteer force that helped Hitler bombard Russia in the second world war.

"I think that every film I make is different, and then when it's done it turns out not to be so. But I'm not control mad. I collaborate, I prefer a loss of control to an excess of respect."

Would he like to do this for ever? "I wrote a novel when I was young, being an adolescent, I suppose. And some poetry as well. But I don't write much. I hadn't written for two years until this latest script. But I suppose I would like to keep doing this. At least there's nothing routine about it. Maybe I'll just do less of it."

For now, Medem wallows in critical acclaim - the New York Times accorded Lovers the honour of a front-page review - and wonders about the audience. While at home each new film has won him a greater share of the box office, abroad his fortunes have been mixed. Everyone everywhere loved The Red Squirrel, but Tierra has fared less well, and was barely released in this country. Lovers too disappointed in France and Germany, and only appears here some two years after it was screened at Cannes.

But there's always Hollywood. He's frequently offered directing gigs in the US, and an English-language remake of The Red Squirrel has been optioned. "Apparently there's a script, but I don't really know. Sometimes they just option things to stop anyone else doing it."

And then he tells me - in enormous, intricate detail - about his next film, another love story, taking the characters from Lovers but changing their fortunes, making them happy, fulfilled people. Its lack of sense is intriguing and charming. This time there is no ice, no polar winter. "Oh no," he says, "it is all very warm, very sensual, they live on a tropical island." It may sound idyllic and a little dull, but in Medem's hands, one thing is certain: it will not be what it seems.

 Lovers of the Arctic Circle opens on Friday.

fields.headline: Churches back Cuban boy's return
fields.trailText: US church leaders, in Cuba to try to resolve the long-running battle for custody of six-year-old Elian Gonzalez who was shipwrecked off the US east coast in November, have called for the boy to be returned to the island as soon as possible.
fields.body:
US church leaders, in Cuba to try to resolve the long-running battle for custody of six-year-old Elian Gonzalez who was shipwrecked off the US east coast in November, have called for the boy to be returned to the island as soon as possible.

Leaders of the US Council of Churches, which represents 35 protestant churches, travelled on Monday to Elian's home town of Cardenas to meet his father. Juan Miguel Gonzalez has demanded his son's return ever since Elian was rescued by Florida fishermen after spending two days clinging to an inner tube.

He is currently with a great uncle in Florida who, backed by Cuban-American politicians, wants him to be given political asylum in the US. But the powerful US Council of Churches thinks this would not be in the boy's best interests.

"We are more convinced than ever that this boy belongs with his family in Cuba," said Dr Joan Brown Campbell, who heads the church delegation. Speaking from Elian's father's home, she said Elian had a loving family in Cuba, who were more than capable of looking after him, and she appealed for President Bill Clinton to intervene.

"We have to help our president see that the issue is a moral one - not political," she said. But at this stage, that has become very difficult; the church leaders were met by a crowd in Cardenas carrying placards with Elian's photograph saying "Free Elian".

Havana has accused Miami exiles of kidnapping and psychologically torturing the boy, rallies demanding his return are continuing, and the government has printed hundreds of thousands of T-shirts and posters. The issue has also dominated television and radio.

In Florida, leaders of Cuba's expatriate community have made Elian a symbol of its fight against communist oppression.

US government officials seem anxious for Elian to be returned - in part to prevent a precedent from being set for custody disputes involving other countries, where parental rights take precedence.

US officials want Elian's father to be allowed to travel to Miami to speed things up, but Mr Castro has ruled that out.

A US immigration hearing will be held on January 21, at which time Dr Brown Campbell has promised Elian's father to act as a voice for the Cuban branch of the family.

But the council's high profile and its support for building closer US-Cuba ties, may make it hard for it to mediate. The Catholic church, which also says Elian should be returned to his family in Cuba, may prove to be more acceptable mediators to Florida exiles.

Cuba said yesterday it had lodged a $121bn claim for damages against the US government with the Havana people's tribunal to compensate for economic losses allegedly caused by four decades of hostility from Washington.

The claim demands compensation for "direct and indirect economic losses caused to the nation by the US's economic war and blockade, and by physical attacks organised, carried out and promoted by the US government," a statement from Havana said.

webTitle: KLM's budget Buzz takes to the skies

fields.headline: KLM's budget Buzz takes to the skies
fields.trailText: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines's new low-cost carrier Buzz took off yesterday, injecting a fresh dose of competition into Europe's booming budget airline market.
fields.body:
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines's new low-cost carrier Buzz took off yesterday, injecting a fresh dose of competition into Europe's booming budget airline market.

Buzz is initially flying to seven European destinations - Berlin, Dusseldorf, Frankfurt, Milan, Lyon, Paris and Vienna - from Stansted airport, carrying the first of what it hopes will be 1m passengers in its first year. Helsinki, Marseilles, Hamburg and Bordeaux will be added to the network from March 27.

Buzz is offering two fare types. A "done deal" return with restrictions starts at £50 to Paris and Frankfurt and goes as high as £90 to Vienna, while the "open deal" at a higher price offers flexibility for business and other travellers, with prices starting at £60 and going as high as £120.

The new airline is flying into main airports at European cities.

"It's a premium offering at a low-cost price, which is a powerful combination as echoed by our £1m sales to date," said commercial director Tony Camacho.

Buzz - whose fleet sports a yellow, green and purple livery - was unveiled last September and is the latest entrant into the fastest growing segment of Europe's airline industry.

British and Irish airlines are leading the pack of low-cost carriers, which have burst on to Europe's skies in the past two years since deregulation, allowing airlines to fix fares and compete freely on intra-European Union routes.

webTitle: The bug that did not bite

fields.headline: The bug that did not bite
fields.standfirst:
The damage has been minimal - so far

The Millennium Bug: special report
fields.trailText: Last year there were many disasters around the world that were not predicted. But the one that was expected to happen - the millennium bug - did not. Or at least not yet.
fields.body:
Last year there were many disasters around the world that were not predicted. But the one that was expected to happen - the millennium bug - did not. Or at least not yet.

Yesterday the City breathed a collective sigh of relief when dealings reopened without serious problems after the new year closure period. Robin Guenier, chairman of Taskforce 2000, however, argues that bug-related problems are spread over a long period and that 65% have yet to surface. He may be proved right. But to most business people, the worst of the scary scenarios is over. The debate now is about whether the $400bn to $500bn spent teaching computers to tell the time properly was brilliantly successful or a complete waste of money that could have been better spent on building hospitals and schools.

Questions are being asked that will keep business schools occupied for years. For instance: how is it that countries spending very little on bug prevention (ranging from Italy in the developed world to most countries in the third world) appear so far to have escaped serious effects? Of course, just because governments (as in Italy) may have spent very little, it does not follow that companies, with more to lose, will have done the same. Even if there was not a problem in the first place - a difficult hypothesis to prove - the episode has led to a global refurbishment of computers which ought to make industry more efficient (besides helping to fuel the stock market boom). That does not necessarily justify the expense incurred - but maybe the business school students should look at that too. If the total bill is $500bn, that amounts to $83 for every man, woman and child in the world, including the vast majority of people in China, India and Africa who do not have computers. An audit is clearly needed. But even that will not stop the debate. It says something about the millennium spirit that we seem as worried about disasters avoided as disasters experienced.

That does not necessarily justify the expense incurred - but maybe the business school students should look at that too. If the total bill is $500bn, that amounts to $83 for every man, woman and child in the world, including the vast majority of people in China, India and Africa who do not have computers. An audit is clearly needed. But even that will not stop the debate. It says something about the millennium spirit that we seem as worried about disasters avoided as disasters experienced.

fields.headline: Money we spent
fields.standfirst: The Millennium Bug: special report
fields.trailText: It is hard to be triumphalist about a non-event, and the people responsible for busting the so-called Y2K bug didn't manage it. "Hey, nothing happened. Wasn't that wonderful?" While a gunpowder trail of exploding fireworks snaked across the globe, computer dates turned from 99 to 00 and country after country reported no serious effects.
fields.body:
It is hard to be triumphalist about a non-event, and the people responsible for busting the so-called Y2K bug didn't manage it. "Hey, nothing happened. Wasn't that wonderful?" While a gunpowder trail of exploding fireworks snaked across the globe, computer dates turned from 99 to 00 and country after country reported no serious effects. Planes failed to fall out of the sky. Civilisation did not sink. There were a few hiccups, but no date-related heart attacks - at least, not of the computer kind.

Even the four countries considered most at risk and therefore the subject of Y2K-related travel warnings from the US state department (Belarus, Moldova, Russia and Ukraine), failed to report any disasters. Their nuclear reactors kept on working.

John Koskinen, chairman of President Clinton's Council on Year 2000 Conversion said of his organisation's global tracking: "At this point we are not aware of anything that is broken as a result of Y2K." Bruce McConnell, director of the International Year 2000 Cooperation Center (IY2KCC), concurred: "From an infrastructure standpoint, we expect a continuation of the non-event." The UN-backed organisation tracked progress on its website at www.iy2kcc.org. Tom Olsen, principal investigator for Y2K at a leading commercial research organisation, International Data Corporation (IDC) in Massachusetts, went to Copenhagen to monitor turn-of-the-year events in Europe. "It went better than I'd predicted," he said yesterday, "and I was the low predictor. Some of my competitors were predicting Chicken Little: The sky fell on me!"

The inevitable question is whether the $200bn to $600bn spent tackling the date change problem world-wide had been wasted. Was the bug hype overdone? Not according to the experts. Peter de Jager, the Canadian who did more than anyone to get the Y2K bandwagon rolling with an article called Doomsday 2000 published in September 1993, reckons not.

"The truth of the matter is this. All the hype, including some of the more ludicrous statements, forced companies to do one thing and one thing only. It forced competent managers round the globe to examine their systems with the single-minded goal of answering a simple question: did this thing called Y2K pose a threat to their computer systems? "If the answer was yes, then they took appropriate action. If the answer was no, then they rightfully ignored it."

In other words, companies and governments didn't spend money fixing a problem that didn't exist. The fact that the sky didn't fall on you doesn't mean there was no Y2K problem, but that serious problems have been averted. So far.

Whatever the result, the cost of fixing the Y2K bug has been frightening, even for an industry with a global turnover of about $1 trillion a year. Assessments of the cost range from about $200bn (Koskinen's ballpark figure) through $600bn (GartnerGroup's prediction) to a high of $858bn (Cap Gemini America). IDC's Project Magellan has made a good case for $320bn, spent over seven years, with 1999 spending of $101bn.

But Bruce McConnell at the IY2KCC says: "I don't think anybody knows - or will ever know." At least $100bn of the remediation costs have been spent in the US, which is the world's most computerised nation. According to the US department of commerce, that's $365 for every man, woman and child. It sounds a lot compared with, say, the costs of Hurricane Floyd ($134m) or the $8bn it would cost to repair the damage from the Turkish earthquake. On the other hand, it is not much more than the $85bn annual turnover of the biggest computer company, IBM.

As for De Jager, he spent the millennium flying to London on United Airlines flight 928 (there were only 42 passengers so they all got upgrades) to demonstrate his confidence in the bug fix, rather than in a bunker with his family, as once seemed possible. And if he is now unemployed, it is not all bad news. His company offered the internet domain name www.year2000.com - home of the Year 2000 Information Center since 1995 - for sale on eBay, the online auction house, and had received two $10m bids by the time the sale closed at midnight on January 1. The bids might be fake - on eBay, a 13-year-old boy once bid $500,000 for a Van Gogh - but could be an unexpected bonus for years spent preaching the Y2K message.

 Jack Schofield is the Guardian's computer editor

fields.headline: Family maintains millennium doomwatch
fields.standfirst: The Millennium Bug: special report
fields.trailText: The sacks of rice lie uneaten in the cellar of the remote farmhouse. As yet, there has been no need for the water purification tablets.
fields.body:
The sacks of rice lie uneaten in the cellar of the remote farmhouse. As yet, there has been no need for the water purification tablets.

The stockpiled medicines remain untouched. But the family who gave up mainstream life to escape the millennium bug yesterday claimed it was too early to return to normality.

Almost two years ago, Angela Perron and her family abandoned their Wiltshire home and headed to a hillside cottage near Forres, Moray.

They feared Y2K could bring food shortages, the accidental discharge of nuclear weapons, the breakdown of global capitalism and rioting on the streets.

Yesterday, as utilities functioned normally and the stock market got back to work with no apparent problems, the family admitted their worst fears had not been realised. But Mrs Perron said she would not be fully confident the world had been spared millennial chaos until April.

"We are glad that we have done what we have done," she said. "There could still be problems: nobody knew what was going to happen before January - why else do you think the government was building bunkers? I don't think we can be certain of an all clear until at least April."

On Hogmanay, the family took their children to local celebrations in the early evening, before heading back to their self-sufficient cottage. With its own generator to provide electricity, water available from a nearby stream, vegetables growing in the garden and hens willingly providing eggs, they felt safe.

Mrs Perron and her husband, Jeremy, put their children, Amber, seven, and Jeremy, two, to bed, before settling down for the night with the knowledge that they had enough food to last a year should things get bad.

"I know people probably think we are mad survivalist eccentrics," said Mrs Perron. "The task force was doing a lot to address the problem, but computer projects are notoriously late and we did not want to take any chances. We have no regrets and we will be staying in Forres. It is still not entirely safe."

In April 1998, Mrs Perron, a publisher, and her husband, a computer programmer, sold one of their cars, hired a lorry and drove more than 500 miles from Neston, Wiltshire, to Forres. They bought their hillside cottage, which has no running water or mains electricity, and began preparing for the millennium.

Mr Perron learned to shoot in case food distribution broke down completely and they needed to kill rabbits for food.

Although the Perrons were the first British family to head for the hills, in the States survivalists had been heading for the mountains of Montana since the mid 80s. In various locations across Scotland, other families also sought refuge from the millennium bug.

Briony Williams, a founder member of the Y2K community action group, produced leaflets urging people to stockpile food and prepare for the worst.

The speech researcher at Edinburgh university yesterday dismissed claims that she had been alarmist. "The short term problems may not yet have materialised, but even the government spokespeople say we are not in the clear," she said. "The long-term problems, the death by a thousand cuts, may still happen."

Ms Williams, however, said she no longer saw any point in stockpiling food and medical supplies.

fields.headline: Peter Stead
fields.standfirst: Urban designer who dreamed of a Pennine city
fields.trailText: Peter Stead, who has died aged 77, was a pioneer in urban design. Farnley Hey, his Bauhaus-inspired house built near Huddersfield in the 1950s, was recognised as a revolutionary concept and awarded a medal by the Royal Institute of British Architects.
fields.body:
Peter Stead, who has died aged 77, was a pioneer in urban design. Farnley Hey, his Bauhaus-inspired house built near Huddersfield in the 1950s, was recognised as a revolutionary concept and awarded a medal by the Royal Institute of British Architects. Nicholas Pevsner described it as "one of the best post-second world war houses in England". In 1961, Stead designed and built a house in Almondbury, Huddersfield - "the best new single house in the UK" said Theo Crosby, his mentor for many years, and the designer of the new Euston station.

Born in Huddersfield, Stead was educated at Wycliffe College, Gloucestershire. His time as an apprentice bricklayer in the family construction firm of Law, Stead & Son was in the Yorkshire tradition of "starting from the bottom up".

At the age of 18 he volunteered for the RAF and served as a fighter-pilot throughout the Burma campaign, winning the Distinguished Flying Cross.

In the 1950s, he established the Symon Quinn Gallery in Huddersfield. Though shortlived, it was heralded as the most vigorous private gallery outside London for abstract art after the dearth of the war years.

When able to get to Cornwall, he formed friendships with Wilhelmina Barns-Graham, Patrick Heron, Barbara Hepworth and others of the St Ives group. He and sculptor Stephen Gilbert discovered a mutual interest in the possible synthesis of painting and architecture, notably through translating into three dimensions the work and teachings of Dutch abstract painter Piet Mondrian.

From 1963 to 1965 he was visiting professor in urban design and associate professor of architecture at Carnegie Mellon university, Pittsburgh. There he founded an urban design consultancy with the British architect David Lewis.

After he returned to Yorkshire, he and Yona Friedman proposed a design for a revolutionary glass and metal city high on the Pennines near Huddersfield. He also collaborated with Victor Pasmore on plans for Peterlee, the idealistic new town for Durham mining families.

In 1973, he was invited to study at the Architectural Association, first using the ideas proposed for Pennine City and then, with John FC Turner, developing self-build housing for low-cost home ownership. He continued this until the 1980s, working on important projects in south London, Scotland and elsewhere.

Stead was working as an enthusiastic adviser to environmental and civic organisations in Huddersfield right up to his death. He was also still working on construction maquettes developed from Mondrian's ideas, and he and Lynne Green were working on a joint book about them.

He married three times, his third marriage ending in divorce; he is survived by two daughters from his first marriage, and a son and daughter from his third.

John Bourne

 Peter Stead, urban designer, born April 6 1922; died December 25 1999

webTitle: Blairs take one last break before baby arrives

fields.headline: Blairs take one last break before baby arrives
fields.standfirst: Blairs' babe: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his wife, Cherie, are to squeeze in a quick new year holiday without their children to help Mrs Blair get over the "tiredness" of a fourth pregnancy at 45.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his wife, Cherie, are to squeeze in a quick new year holiday without their children to help Mrs Blair get over the "tiredness" of a fourth pregnancy at 45.

But they have not been wholly able to escape prime minister's workload - the couple will stay at the British embassy so that Mr Blair can stay in direct charge of the government.

He will also spend at least one day in talks with his Portuguese counterpart, Antonio Guterres, about the special European Union summit on enterprise and reform which will be held in Lisbon in March.

Downing Street announced yesterday that the Blairs had slipped quietly out of Heathrow on Monday to spend most of this week resting in Portugal before returning at the weekend.

Their other children, Euan, 15, Nicky, 14 and Kathryn, 12, at home in Downing Street in the care of their maternal grandmother. Their new school term begins today.

Mindful of missed schooldays because of last year's family winter holiday in the Seychelles, officials were also quick to head off puritanical denunciations of the prime ministerial holiday rota.

The holiday is likely to be a welcome break and is almost certainly the Blairs last free time together before their fourth child is born in May.

Witnesses reported that Mrs Blair had flu and was tired to the point of tears during the part of the millennium ceremonies on the Thames last Friday.

Mr Blair admitted as much in a Woman's Own interview published yesterday. "She's a bit tired at the moment," he said. "She's normally got bags of energy. In fact she still does an awful lot, probably too much at the moment. Yes, she is, she's fine - but tired."

He also revealed how much news of the pregnancy had surprised him. "I really did fall off my chair at first," he said.

"I honestly was delighted but shocked at the same time, really shellshocked. But now I'm getting used to it, I'm really looking forward to it now."

Downing Street officials yesterday emphasised that Mr Blair would be keeping in constant touch with day to day events in Britain thanks to his host, British ambassador, John Holmes.

Mr Holmes, a former principal private secretary in the Downing Street office who played a key role in the Northern Ireland peace process, is a personal friend.

"Staying at the residence means the prime minister has access to secure communications and all the rest and can keep in touch," Mr Blair's spokesman said.

That did not stop John Redwood, the Tory environment spokesman, from detecting what he called "another vote of no confidence in John Prescott".

Mr Redwood, who rarely takes a holiday, added: "He is sidelined with the prime minister on holiday. He must be feeling his neck very gingerly at the moment."

Downing Street called that "silly", stressing that Mr Prescott remained at his desk in the department of the environment, transport and the regions and that Mr Blair was keen to sharpen up the agenda for the special EU summit.

webTitle: Russian offensive grinds to halt in Grozny

fields.headline: Russian offensive grinds to halt in Grozny
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian onslaught to capture the Chechen capital Grozny appeared to have hit an impasse yesterday, with fierce but stationary battles between Russian armour and Chechen guerrillas 10 days into Moscow's ground campaign against the city.
fields.body:
The Russian onslaught to capture the Chechen capital Grozny appeared to have hit an impasse yesterday, with fierce but stationary battles between Russian armour and Chechen guerrillas 10 days into Moscow's ground campaign against the city.

While the rebels continue to hold on in defiance of Russian claims that the capital would fall by the new year, the Russian military appeared to be making advances in the mountainous south of Chechnya, which apart from Grozny is the last part of the breakaway republic under rebel control. But there too the guerrillas were reported to be mounting fierce resistance.

The Russian army said that the situation in Grozny was "extremely difficult", although officially its casualty toll yesterday was put at only three dead and eight wounded.

Russian artillery and aircraft pounded central Grozny in an attempt to ease the advance of the ground forces. But there was bitter fighting even in districts which the Russians had claimed to control days ago. Heavy clashes were reported in the north of the city and at the main railway station.

"The rebels are offering fierce resistance, firing from mortars and anti-aircraft systems," the Interfax news agency reported, citing the Russian military. "The operation to dislodge the rebels in Grozny is being complicated by a large number of mines on the roads and in buildings."

The fate of Grozny's civilian population is unclear. Estimates of the number of civilians left vary from 15,000 to 40,000. There are no gas, water or electricity supplies. Food is extremely scarce.

While the Russians advanced on the rebel strongholds in the southern mountains, there was fierce fighting at Alkhan-Yurt, south-west of Grozny, at Duba-Yurt and Chishki, further south, and at Vedeno and Kharachoi to the south-east, close to the Dagestan border.

The Russians say they have captured the heights overlooking Vedeno, an important guerrilla stronghold.

Alkhan-Yurt was captured and demolished by the Russians in fierce battles before Christmas. Yesterday rebel sources said they were close to recapturing it.

Moscow claimed that 4,000 rebel fighters, led by 27 field commanders, had signalled a willingness to surrender. "They are ready to lay down their arms if personal security guarantees are given to them," said Malik Saidullayev, the head of the Chechen state council, sponsored by Moscow.

A Russian kidnapped from Ingushetia 18 months ago and held for ransom in Chechnya was freed by Ingush security officials, Itar-Tass news agency reported. Ravil Galyamov, 47, had one of his fingers cut off to drive home demands for the payment of $300,000 ransom.

Yesterday rebel sources said they were close to recapturing it. Moscow claimed that 4,000 rebel fighters, led by 27 field commanders, had signalled a willingness to surrender. "They are ready to lay down their arms if personal security guarantees are given to them," said Malik Saidullayev, the head of the Chechen state council, sponsored by Moscow. A Russian kidnapped from Ingushetia 18 months ago and held for ransom in Chechnya was freed by Ingush security officials, Itar-Tass news agency reported. Ravil Galyamov, 47, had one of his fingers cut off to drive home demands for the payment of $300,000 ransom.

fields.headline: Danger in Kashmir.
fields.standfirst:
A flashpoint the world has forgotten

The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: The international community's approach to the intractable problem of Jammu and Kashmir is, by and large, to ignore it. Since 1948-49, when UN resolutions seeking to end the territory's post-Raj partition and facilitate a plebiscite came to nothing, both India and Pakistan have entrenched on either side of the Line of Control.
fields.body:
The international community's approach to the intractable problem of Jammu and Kashmir is, by and large, to ignore it. Since 1948-49, when UN resolutions seeking to end the territory's post-Raj partition and facilitate a plebiscite came to nothing, both India and Pakistan have entrenched on either side of the Line of Control. Two wars and an 11-year-old insurgency which has claimed an estimated 25,000 lives have not altered this crude balance of power. India has consistently rebuffed international mediation efforts, insisting it is an internal matter. The fact that its authority is upheld through a repressive military presence and that Kashmiris conducted a mass boycott of last October's national elections is apparently no contradiction to Delhi's stubborn way of thinking.

Pakistan, occupying Azad ("free") Kashmir and Gilgit and the Northern Territories, doggedly maintains its own, unrealistic claim to sovereignty over all Kashmir, India's only majority Muslim state, and appeals for the world's support. It regularly tests its pretensions and India's defences through armed border incursions and proxy terrorism, responsibility for which it implausibly but persistently denies. Both governments refuse to countenance the idea of an independent, united Kashmir. Both exploit the issue for their own domestic ends.

Long though the problem has been allowed to fester, neither India and Pakistan's criminally delinquent behaviour, nor international apathy, can continue much longer. As the Christmas hijacking of an Indian plane demonstrated, militant Islamic fundamentalists are already internationalising the Kashmir question, whatever Delhi may say. In many cases, these people hail not from Kashmir but from Afghanistan, Iran, the Gulf, even Britain. They do not belong to the tolerant, multicultural tradition of pre-partition Kashmiriyat . And although they may have the backing of elements within Pakistan's security apparatus, Islamabad cannot ultimately control them either. Such fanatics apart, Kashmir in any case demands international action. Both India and Pakistan are nuclear-armed these days; the next Indo-Pakistan war over Kashmir may not be containable. This is one reason why Bill Clinton, who declared a "personal interest" in resolving last summer's Kashmir border crisis, may visit India this March. He should not hesitate to step in forcefully and, if necessary, knock some heads together.

webTitle: Winter weather adds to misery for quake survivors

fields.headline: Winter weather adds to misery for quake survivors
fields.standfirst: The earthquake in Turkey: special report
fields.trailText: Strong winds and driving rain destroy hundreds of temporary homes in Turkey's tent cities
fields.body:
High winds, driving rain and heavy snows have destroyed hundreds of tents in Turkey's earthquake zone over the past two weeks, ushering in a miserable new year for tens of thousands of homeless people.

"Our tents literally flew away," said Kadir Mert, as he surveyed the scene. "We are being destroyed."

Fear of fire prompted electricity cuts in several areas, and a tent housing a temporary police station was among those that collapsed.

On the edge of towns such as Golcuk, row after row of hastily built prefabricated housing units stand empty after people hunkered down for the winter under canvas across north-western Turkey. "They put the prefabs in the wrong place," said Ali Ozari, standing outside his Swedish-made winter tent. "This is much warmer, and it's right next to my house."

Some people are less lucky. They could not get their hands on high-quality shelters in what became a lottery of relief distribution, and they know the worst of the winter is yet to come. Many residents have packed up and left. Locals say about half the population of Golcuk has migrated to nearby villages, or returned to native towns in eastern Turkey. Some have no plans to return.

Golcuk bore the brunt of the devastation when the first of Turkey's two earthquakes struck in August. Thousands of people died as the quake ripped through the middle of town and a huge wave swept in from the sea of Marmara.

"People still think about that day," said Serkan Yazgi as he unpacked boxes, in a chemist shop with huge cracks in the walls. "We just can't get it out of our minds." The shoreline is desolate and entire streets have been cleared of buildings in scenes reminiscent of London after the Blitz.

Other badly-damaged homes and shops stand empty, waiting for the demolition experts to move in. Big blue crosses have been painted on the front of blocks of flats which are no longer safe.

There has been little seasonal cheer. In the middle of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, time passes even more slowly. Cold and hunger fray tempers. Relief workers have adjusted the distribution of food to make sure a hot meal is available as soon as the daily fast ends at dusk.

"It's not easy to fast under these conditions but Ramadan is important to the people here," Ali Ozari said. "It gives them something to hold on to."

There is precious little else. Unemployment has become a big problem in Golcuk, and many people spend their days resting inside their tents. Toilet facilities could be improved, but the overwhelming chaos of the first few weeks has gone.

In spite of the suffering, there are signs that people are determined to get back on their feet. On one street an internet cafe has opened, offering bored teenagers an escape from the monotony of life in the tent cities.

In the next building Gunay Balaban is refurbishing an office. He lost his wife in the earthquake and his three-year-old son is still missing. The boy vanished shortly after neighbours saw him emerge unscathed from the ruins of the family home in August.

"I'm reopening my business to help my friends and family," Mr Balaban said, "but I still have to find my boy. Maybe tomorrow, maybe four months, maybe one or two years. I will find him."

Those who have decided to stay are determined that they will eventually get their lives back to normal, but the next few months are likely to test the patience of the hardiest of survivors.

The Turkish government has promised to begin a multi-billion pound project to build new towns and cities in the spring.

"The quake taught us a lot," the president, Suleyman Demirel, said recently. "We lost a lot of lives and we suffered a lot of pain - [but] by the end of 2000, all the wounds will be healed."

For many survivors it will take a lot longer. Their trust in the state was shattered when little help was provided in the first few days of the disaster. Turkish officials have since worked hard to rebuild public confidence, but it will take more than words to replace what has been lost.

fields.headline: Dome doves and hawks
fields.trailText: Most of what you say about the first night in the Dome (Leader, January 3) seems all too painfully true, but to refer in such disparaging tones to "a theatre composer called Jonathan Dove" merely betrays ignorance.
fields.body:
Most of what you say about the first night in the Dome (Leader, January 3) seems all too painfully true, but to refer in such disparaging tones to "a theatre composer called Jonathan Dove" merely betrays ignorance. Certainly he is a composer who has written a great deal for the theatre, but he is also the composer of, among many other things, one of the few successful full-scale operas to have been produced professionally in this country in the last decade (Flight, commissioned and presented by Glyndebourne 1998 and revived in 1999). To imply he does not bear comparison with Peter Maxwell Davies is rude and wrong.
Genista McIntosh
London

According to your leader, there has been no feminine contribution to British culture for the past 1,000 years worth the mention. You appear to be entering the new century with the patriarchal attitudes of the last but one. Women literary geniuses such as Jane Austen, George Eliot, Emily and Charlotte Bronte, Elizabeth Gaskell, to name only the novelists, struggled for and won the right to have their voices heard in the 19th century.
Carrie Johnson
Coldharbour, Surrey carrie@anstie.waitrose.com

Leave Jools Holland alone! My life has been made so much better for having heard Jools live on many occasions and bopping 'til I drop.
Helene Perrin-Summers
Nailsworth, Glos

Lord Falconer's apology for the Dome ticket fiasco is hopelessly inadequate (Report, Janaury 3). Doesn't he realise the VIPs who had to queue with "ordinary" people included some newspaper editors? I have only regained my composure at the thought that such an outrage will not occur for another 1,000 years.
Richard Knott
Leighton Buzzard, Beds

Stand in line for three hours to watch a variety act? And you call yourselves editors? Many readers will think you got what you deserved.
Bill Williams
Editor, ArtWork es@artwork.co.uk

Who, in all honesty, could give a stuff about the £800m Dome with it's quasi-experiences and viewing the nobs all linking arms singing Auld Lang Syne etc. My millennium experience was real. I took a very old, demented and injured lady to accident and emergency and waited five and a half hours to be seen. I suppose you could call it the "going round the bend zone".
Isobel Barker
Torpoint, Cornwall manager@silvermead-plymouth.co.uk

fields.headline: To the Finland station
fields.trailText: Peter Preston is right to call for reform of the honours system (Comment, January 3). But Mr Preston was wrong that "you do not pick up your CBE any longer merely by being permanent secretary in the ministry of silly walks".
fields.body:
Peter Preston is right to call for reform of the honours system (Comment, January 3). But Mr Preston was wrong that "you do not pick up your CBE any longer merely by being permanent secretary in the ministry of silly walks". The permanent secretary of the ministry of agriculture for the past seven traumatic years has just been rewarded with a knighthood. If leading Maff through BSE, food wars and the GM tragic-comedy gets a "K", the mind boggles at what chaos it would take to get a ticket to the Lords.
Prof Tim Lang
Thames Valley University

Instead of abolishing honours, could we consider following the example of the Finns and distribute them much more widely? My guess is that at least 10% of them achieve membership of the White Rose or the Finnish Legion. They don't seem to lack modernity because of it.
Brian Knox
London

webTitle: Don't give in to military blackmail

fields.headline: Don't give in to military blackmail
fields.trailText: The revelations in the leaked army documents on Kosovo (Report, January 4) have led to predictable calls for increased defence spending. They should be resisted. Each year the government spends around £9bn of public money on military equipment. The latest report from the national audit office shows that the 25 largest current defence projects are almost £3bn over budget, with an average delivery delay of three and a half years.
fields.body:
The revelations in the leaked army documents on Kosovo (Report, January 4) have led to predictable calls for increased defence spending. They should be resisted. Each year the government spends around £9bn of public money on military equipment. The latest report from the national audit office shows that the 25 largest current defence projects are almost £3bn over budget, with an average delivery delay of three and a half years.

The faulty personal radios were due to be replaced by the Bowman system and subject to competitive tendering. In 1996 the two consortia (Siemens/Plessey with Racal and a group led by ITT) merged to form a single monopoly supplier. The project is now seven years late and £17m over budget. British troops in peacekeeping roles need modern equipment; the public deserves value for money. They will not get them while overspending, inefficiency and secrecy remain integral parts of the ministry of defence. It should be opened up to proper parliamentary and public accountability.
Tim Webb
London webbie@dircon.co.uk

So the army is leaking stories about how its "underfunding" threatened its effectiveness in Kosovo. This follows pre-Christmas medical gripes about the "underfunding" of the NHS. Your leader (January 4) begs at least two questions. Is a moderately affluent country like Britain able to afford indulging in international policing games? Does its population want to finance such activities when funds could alternatively be used to reduce illiteracy and ill health? Single topic advocacy may make your readers feel good, but confuses the resolution of fundamental issues which involve hard choices. Beware the advocates of more funding: they may merely be seeking to increase their incomes.
Prof Alan Maynard
York Health Policy Group akm3@york.ac.uk

So the army is concerned that its equipment is not to as high a specification as it would like. Might I suggest they do what PTAs and leagues of friends have had to do in these circumstances for decades and organise some jumble sales and fetes.
Denis Beaumont
Fellowship of Reconciliation

fields.headline: Mother of all experiences
fields.trailText: Sending Hugo Young to review the Dome (Comment, January 4) is a bit like sending Andy Gray to review the opening night of Glynde-bourne. Fortunately, the future of the Dome rests not with the opinions of patrician Guardian journalists, but with the people - and particularly young people voting with their feet.
fields.body:
Sending Hugo Young to review the Dome (Comment, January 4) is a bit like sending Andy Gray to review the opening night of Glynde-bourne. Fortunately, the future of the Dome rests not with the opinions of patrician Guardian journalists, but with the people - and particularly young people voting with their feet. My children found the Dome fun and exciting and so will the millions of others who see it for themselves in the year ahead. Perhaps it is not the Dome which is typical of the end of 20th-century Britain, but Hugo Young's all too predictable response?
Lord McNally
tmcnally@Shandwick.com

While I would not disagree with Hugo Young's opinions of the Dome project, he clearly knows something that has passed over the heads of the rest of us. He claims that the dome "detracts from what the government is doing". In my opinion it does no such thing. It clearly demonstrates that this government is acting simply as a caretaker, continuing Tory economic policy, continuing privatisation and avoiding real issues of government until the Tories have cleansed themselves sufficiently to be re-elected. The real tragedy is that New Labour are frightened of the Tory press and are only being allowed to govern as long as they don't step out of line.

Meanwhile the issues of transport policy, the health service and the continued erosion of our industrial base remain unaddressed while the government panders to the whims of the already privileged by avoiding the issues of a fair taxation system.
Rod White
Uley, Glos fuelrod@btinternet.com

To me a good bank holiday Monday is incomplete without a country village fete. This bank holiday, then, I was glad to be at the Dome - the nation's village fete. Like a fete it was neither slick nor sophisticated and had endearing touches of amateurism. The learning and work zone had the kind of games - simple but fun - usually found on the vicarage lawn. The body zone looked like a giant papier-mache doll made by the local primary school and the faith zone provided the gentle, cheery sermon a parish worthy would be happy to give. Unlike other theme parks, it seemed a very real experience. There was a purpose to being there and a palpable sense of community. We shall go again.
Dr Matt Jones
London m.jones@mdx.ac.uk

At 5pm on New Year's Day our party of 11 (including four children) emerged from the Dome still intrigued by our experiences. Five hours (the maximum time available), including a magnificent show, was not long enough to see all we would have liked and, on the whole we regarded it as a success. The staff demonstrated an air of involvement and pride and were eager to be of assistance, which in itself is a rare experience. The mind zone is aimed at those prepared to employ their minds, the learning zone is designed for extension of learning both in the short and long term and the children found the play zone exhilarating. To those of us comparing it to the 1951 Festival of Britain, the extent of commercial sponsorship intruded and somewhat removed the feeling of it being a national achievement. We shall be returning and this time will be sure to allow a full day.
Allan and Jenny Cheetham
Upminster, Essex cheetham@acserv.demon.co.uk

The 1951 Great Exhibition featured a dome (a symbol of female sexuality) and the skylon (a phallic symbol). In 2000 we have a dome and a giant wheel: two female symbols with not a phallus anywhere to be seen. Does this herald the dawn of a new matriarchal society?
Debbie Knight
St Leonards on Sea, E Sussex debsk@freeuk.com

fields.trailText: I know it is a thin time for news, but should the break up of Spice Girl Mel B and Jimmy Gulzar really appear at a length of 48 column centimetres, while 18 deaths in Kashmir merited seven?
fields.body:
I know it is a thin time for news, but should the break up of Spice Girl Mel B and Jimmy Gulzar really appear at a length of 48 column centimetres, while 18 deaths in Kashmir merited seven?
Chris Huhne MEP
chrishuhne@cix.co.uk

You seem baffled by Longitude director Charles Sturridge's decision to cast the "goodies" as blunt and northern and the "baddies" as rich southern ponces in wigs (Last night's TV, January 4). The reason for this is that goodies are blunt and northern while baddies are rich southern ponces in wigs.
Paul Baldwin
London

If 35% of the readers of the UK's foremost folk and roots magazine really do read the Guardian (Letters, January 4) then it is surely time for this newspaper's coverage of such music to be increased.
Derek Schofield
Crewe, Cheshire derek@dschofield.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Feuding is bad for you.
fields.standfirst:
The Tories know it, but cannot stop

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Though he has been away skiing, William Hague will no doubt have been keeping up with the newspapers, so he probably knows by now that the government has set up a group called the Near Earth Objects Taskforce to examine the threat of lumps of matter exploding out of the sky and destroying whatever they fall on.
fields.body:
Though he has been away skiing, William Hague will no doubt have been keeping up with the newspapers, so he probably knows by now that the government has set up a group called the Near Earth Objects Taskforce to examine the threat of lumps of matter exploding out of the sky and destroying whatever they fall on. At a moment when even the news that Teresa Gorman is not after all defecting to the UK Independence Party can be represented as some sort of triumph for the Conservatives, Mr Hague may feel he could do with a taskforce like that himself. While the rest of the world has been taking a languorous Christmas plus new millennium holiday, the Conservative party has been hit by a succession of near earth objects which have left it looking more grievously dented than ever.

The latest trouble began with Shaun Woodward's defection. A good man lost, moaned the left. Good riddance, the right riposted: the party was better off without the kind of woolly liberal toIerance which was even soft on Clause 28. Then in a chatty session on BBC radio's World at One, the former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, warned his party against a lurch to the right, recalling that Labour's lurch to the left in the 80s had made it unelectable. He also told it to drop its obsession with Europe. Next came the former leader, John Major. Any further shift to the right, he said, would be a disaster. There must be no going back to Thatcherism. Sir Edward Heath took much the same line. So did the London mayoral contender, Steve Norris.

Several more near earth objects, some anonymous and some Norman Tebbit, people for whom a party brought back to Thatcherism is the only kind of Conservative party worth having, now took up the pounding. They would take no lectures on electability from Major and Clarke, who had steered the party to its worst results in 160 years. At which point rumours arose that some Euro-sceptics, despairing of Mr Hague's failure to stand up for British sovereignty, were planning to switch to the UKIP. Mrs Gorman has now denied she is one, and the latest name in the frame is a mere former MP. Then yesterday Lord Howe joined the festivities. "To put it gently," he said, the party as Mr Hague was leading it was not widely seen as a credible alternative to Labour. It risked becoming a political Catherine wheel, with MPs flying off it in all directions.

And maybe it would now be better for Mr Hague if some of them did. All political parties are coalitions and the day sometimes comes for a coalition when more divides it than unites it. The Conservative party is now in that nasty condition. Both sides are correct. If the party moves right, it loses the chance of recapturing voters who three years ago defected to Labour. But if it moves where Mr Clarke would like it to move, especially on Europe, it will shed core support. Either way, it is going to lose.

When Labour split in the 80s, it was seen as the left's conclusive triumph over the right. Yet in the long term - a very long term, 18 years - it taught Labour a powerful lesson: that you cannot win elections by turning your back on the people. The ultimate result of that split has been to give us a Labour leadership in some respects way to the right of the old SDP. Perhaps some similar parting of ways is becoming the best long-term hope for British Conservatism. But till then, Mr Hague is doomed to proceed much as before, devoting himself to the wholly impossible task of trying to keep both wings happy, while day after day the merciless hail of near earth objects pours down upon him.

webTitle: Israeli president resists calls to quit over scandal

fields.headline: Israeli president resists calls to quit over scandal
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's President Ezer Weizman was holding out against increasing pressure to resign yesterday after it was revealed that he accepted undisclosed gifts of $453,000 (£283,125) from a French Jewish textile magnate, Edouard Saroussi.
fields.body:
Israel's President Ezer Weizman was holding out against increasing pressure to resign yesterday after it was revealed that he accepted undisclosed gifts of $453,000 (£283,125) from a French Jewish textile magnate, Edouard Saroussi.

The scandal overshadowed talks between Syria and Israel on the future of the Golan Heights and news that negotiators had finally agreed on an Israeli withdrawal from a further 5% of the West Bank - a move caught up for seven weeks in a dispute with Palestinian officials over maps.

The pullout - which had been due in November - will give Palestinians full or partial control of the area within 48 hours of a handover ceremony in Jerusalem. A further 6.1% is due to be handed over by the Israelis on January 20.

But it has been the financial affairs of the 74-year-old doyen of Israeli politics that has preoccupied the nation. He has been accused of failing to report or pay taxes on the cash gifts from Mr Saroussi, a long-time friend. These transactions are alleged to have happened between 1988-93, when Mr Weizman was a member of parliament and minister. The state attorney launched an investigation on Monday into the accusations.

Mr Weizman said yesterday that he was not considering quitting over the allegations that he took the gifts.

"I am going through a period that is not easy. I will pass through it. I am waiting to see what the prosecutor will decide and I am not ready to resign," he said on Israel radio.

Yoav Yitzhak, the journalist who broke the gifts story, said the president's office had pressed him not to publish, saying the chances of Middle East peace would be hurt if one of its most influential proponents was removed from the political arena.

Yesterday, Mr Yitzhak told a press conference that Mr Weizman was preparing to resign soon anyway, and would cite health reasons. The president's office denied this.

Mr Yitzhak alleged yesterday that Mr Weizman was collecting money from Mr Saroussi even during his years in the presidency, which began in 1993.

"From May 1993 until 1995 he (Weizman) and his family withdrew from the trust account money coming to over $55,000. And that's during his term as president," Mr Yitzhak said.

Mr Saroussi has acknowledged that starting in the early 80s he also gave $6.5bn (£4bn) to a political party Mr Weizman then headed. Some of the money for the party, Yachad (Together), was put into Mr Weizman's personal account, Israel radio reported.

Mr Weizman has denied any wrongdoing, saying the money was a nontaxable gift from a family friend who had no interests in Israel. Since Mr Saroussi is not a citizen of Israel, Mr Weizman's lawyers suggest, laws on reporting political contributions do not apply.

Mr Weizman, considered by some Israelis to be one of the last surviving heroes of Israel's founding generation and an influential figure in the country's 1979 peace treaty with Egypt, has generally been seen as an affable character despite his tendency for blunt talk. But tolerance may be ebbing away.

The rightwing Jerusalem Post has now joined the left-leaning daily Haaretz in calling on him to step down.

webTitle: Israel wants cruise missiles for Golan deal

fields.headline: Israel wants cruise missiles for Golan deal
fields.standfirst:
Defence minister presents the Pentagon with extensive military wish-list on day two of peace talks

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel has asked the US for cruise missiles as part of a $17bn security package which would compensate for ceding the Golan Heights under any Israeli-Syrian peace deal, according to reports from Tel Aviv yesterday.
fields.body:
Israel has asked the US for cruise missiles as part of a $17bn security package which would compensate for ceding the Golan Heights under any Israeli-Syrian peace deal, according to reports from Tel Aviv yesterday.

The newspaper Ha'aretz reported that the Israeli defence minister, Amos Yaron, had requested cruise missile capability in a lengthy wish-list of military hardware presented to the Pentagon. The list also included Apache helicopters, electronic warfare jets, funding for an anti-missile defence system, and a ground station which would allow Israel to receive constantly updated data from US spy satellites.

"I think there will be some costs associated with the security rearrangements," the US president, Bill Clinton, said about the scale of Israel's request. "I'm not in a position to say what dollar amount I would ask our congress for."

State department officials said they could not discuss the details of the talks, but confirmed that Israel had put its extra military requirements on the table at the US-brokered talks between the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Syrian foreign minister, Farouk al-Shara'a in Shepherdstown, West Virginia.

Tony Cordesman, a Middle East specialist at the Centre for Strategic and International Studies in London, said that Israel was in the market for a deep-strike missile that would make up for the natural defensive barrier the Golan had provided since its capture in 1967. The Israeli military would ideally like a missile such as the Tomahawk, which could be launched from a submarine, making it less vulnerable to pre-emptive strikes.

However, the US would have serious reservations about giving Israel cruise missiles in view of their capacity to carry nuclear warheads, he said.

"The US is unlikely to do anything that would enhance Israel's nuclear capability," Mr Cordesman said. "It could offset all the strategic advantages of a peace agreement, not to mention the difficulties it would cause with our allies and with international law."

The export of US cruise missiles such as the Tomahawk would violate the 1987 Missile Technology Control Regime, which bans the transfer of missiles with ranges of more than 300km. The Tomahawk has a range of up to 2,000km.

According to Ha'aretz, President Clinton has avoided making any specific promises, assuring Mr Barak only that the US would stand by Israel and help preserve the qualitative military advantage it currently enjoys against its regional rivals.

At the Shepherdstown talks, US diplomats scrambled to unravel an early agenda glitch; the Syrians, led by Mr Shara'a, had insisted that the fate of the Golan be negotiated first, while the Israeli delegation under Mr Barak wanted to begin with security issues.

After presiding over the first faltering day of talks, Mr Clinton said he would return to Sheperdstown yesterday afternoon to help Mr Barak and Mr Shara'a move forward.

"I think they're both very serious. I think they both want an agreement," Mr Clinton said. "I think there are difficult issues and we just have to hope that we work it out."

In a bizarre sideshow, Israeli negotiators have been lobbying their Syrian counterparts for the return of the remains of an Israeli spy executed in Damascus 35 years ago. The return of Eli Cohen's body has become a symbolic crusade, and Israeli officials have hinted that it would significantly improve Syria's image in the Jewish state, boosting the chances that any future peace deal would be ratified in an Israeli referendum.

webTitle: Thriving pub chain pledges 3,000 jobs to pull in drinkers

fields.headline: Thriving pub chain pledges 3,000 jobs to pull in drinkers
fields.trailText: The pubs ban music and smoking at the bar, they have no televisions for sports fans and they will soon have expanded tenfold in less than 10 years.
fields.body:
The pubs ban music and smoking at the bar, they have no televisions for sports fans and they will soon have expanded tenfold in less than 10 years.

The JD Wetherspoon chain yesterday revamped its already rapid expansion plans by promising to open 90 new pubs this year and so create up to 3,000 jobs.

It held out the prospect of similar increases each year to the end of 2004 - which would mean a total of 500 new pubs, employing 15,000 full and part-time workers in managment, bar work and catering.

"Most people come in for something to drink or to eat," a company spokesman, Eddie Gershon, said. "They don't want to find a disco or quiz night breaking out."

The cheap beer, "just a pub" philosophy has seen Wetherspoon grow from 44 pubs when it floated on the stock exchange in 1992 to its present 372.

It already employs more than 10,000 people, a far cry from 1979 when the chairman, Tim Martin, bought a pub in a converted betting shop in Muswell Hill, north London, from a friend.

The company's earlier megapub, no frills approach, risked accusations of lacking atmosphere in their cavernous surroundings - perhaps inevitable when the bars were established in former supermarkets, showrooms or post offices.

It still opens big pubs - its new 9,000 square feet operation in Plymouth employs 95 staff - but its more recent interest in old churches, banks and other prime town centre sites is also gaining it a reputation for sensitive conversions.

Wetherspoon rarely uses former pubs. "If they are good, people are not going to be getting rid of them," said Mr Gershon.

"We are not like McDonald's, all exactly the same. We are not like theme pubs. If you are going to go to the pub, for two hours, it would be silly to have one exactly the same as the one down the road."

Among buildings due to open this year are former banks in Airdrie and Stevenage, a former leisure centre in Arbroath, a former garage in Hull and a disused nightclub in Nottingham.

Other towns to get a Wetherspoon presence will be Worthing, Godalming, Buxton, Poole and Stourport-on-Severn.

Appropriately for a company using old banks, it is now experimenting with cash machines in some pubs.

The Campaign for Real Ale said: "We welcome what Wetherspoon do. They are becoming quite innovative in design, lighting, use of glass, seating and so on. They are certainly moving in the right direction and providing a good range of beers for a wider audience."

 The Yates Brothers Wine Lodges company has announced plans to add 31 new outlets, creating 1,200 new jobs, to its 110-strong chain.

Bar wars

Wetherspoon / Other pubs
No music / I Will Survive on the juke box
No pool / A poke in the back from bar-room cue
No-smoking areas / Tobacco haze, brimming ashtrays
No TV / Man United all hours of the day
All day food / Last orders for menu 2.30pm
No atmosphere? / See above
