webTitle: St Lucia envoy accused of 'colonial racism'

fields.headline: St Lucia envoy accused of 'colonial racism'
fields.trailText: A British high commission in the Caribbean is awash with colonial attitudes and racism, a former employee claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
A British high commission in the Caribbean is awash with colonial attitudes and racism, a former employee claimed yesterday.

Pamela Baptiste, a former consular officer, alleged that black domestic staff at the high commission in St Lucia were ordered to look down when speaking to white staff and refer to them as "master" and "mistress".

Mrs Baptiste, who is black, has lodged a claim of unfair dismissal against the foreign and commonwealth office. In what could be a landmark legal case, she is attempting to have the case heard in London on the grounds that the foreign office was her employer.

But the foreign office is fighting the case, claiming it was a matter for St Lucia and is outside British jurisdiction.

Mrs Baptiste, 43, who was born in Bushey, Hertfordshire, worked at the high commission from June 1991 until her dismissal in June 1998. Among the allegations in a statement submitted to an employment tribunal in south London, Mrs Baptiste says that a set of office keys had "white is right" written on the key ring.

A foreign office spokeswoman said the grounds for complaint had not yet been seen. "Mrs Baptiste has made complaints of racial discrimination against colleagues at the high commission. We take all such allegations seriously and we asked her to provide details so we could investigate. In spite of repeated requests, she never informed us of the grounds for her complaint."

In her statement yesterday, Mrs Baptiste said that her dismissal followed the arrival of Peter Hughes, who took over as high commissioner in January 1998. Mr Hughes, a career diplomat, had worked at the foreign office in London in the preceding four years, and had been posted to Sydney, Warsaw, Rome and Islamabad.

Mrs Baptiste, who earned £10,000 a year, a relatively high salary in St Lucia, added: "Shortly after his arrival Mr Hughes accused me of being paid too much."

"The race discrimination at the high commission was severe and smacked of colonial attitudes."

Asked to comment on the allegations yesterday, a spokeswoman in Mr Hughes's office in St Lucia yesterday said they were "not at liberty to discuss it at present" and referred the call to the foreign office.

The foreign office spokeswoman said: "The decision to terminate Mrs Baptiste's employment was unrelated to her complaint and came after she refused to comply with the terms and conditions of her employment. In December 1998, Mrs Baptiste began legal action against the British high commission in St Lucia, but in 1999 that action was withdrawn from court with the agreement of both sides."

In October, the foreign office was told that she had lodged a complaint with the industrial tribunal in Croydon. "We have asked the court to decide whether it has the jurisdiction to hear it as it was outside the UK," the spokeswoman said.

A foreign office source that claimed there were many discrepancies in Mrs Baptiste's version of the events. She had claimed, for instance, that she had to seek permission from Mr Hughes to use the staff car park, but the foreign office source insists there was no such car park.

In a two-hour preliminary hearing yesterday to determine whether or not the case should go ahead, Lawrence Davies, who is representing Mrs Baptiste, said she was covered by the British employment rights act and the race relations act because the high commission, like a British embassy, was considered as home soil.

He said: "The high commission doesn't exist as an independent entity. It is run by the foreign and commonwealth office in London, England. The salary was paid from London, all the money at the high commission comes from London. Absolutely everything - who gets paid, who gets dismissed - comes from Britain. [Mrs Baptiste] worked for what was essential a sub office of the foreign office. We argue that acts occurring in a British embassy are deemed to be in British jurisdiction."

Philip Coppel, representing the foreign office, said the case was outside the tribunal's jurisdiction. He said that Mrs Baptiste "enjoyed protection under local legislation" which had allowed her to receive a redundancy payment when she was dismissed under St Lucia law. "She could not be subject to both sets of employment rights."

Mr Coppel added: "There is absolutely no way that this woman, who lived and worked in St Lucia, was subject to the employment rights under British law."

Andrew Bano, the tribunal chairman, adjourned the case and told the parties a written judgment would be posted.
fields.bodyText: A British high commission in the Caribbean is awash with colonial attitudes and racism, a former employee claimed yesterday. Pamela Baptiste, a former consular officer, alleged that black domestic staff at the high commission in St Lucia were ordered to look down when speaking to white staff and refer to them as "master" and "mistress". Mrs Baptiste, who is black, has lodged a claim of unfair dismissal against the foreign and commonwealth office. In what could be a landmark legal case, she is attempting to have the case heard in London on the grounds that the foreign office was her employer. But the foreign office is fighting the case, claiming it was a matter for St Lucia and is outside British jurisdiction. Mrs Baptiste, 43, who was born in Bushey, Hertfordshire, worked at the high commission from June 1991 until her dismissal in June 1998. Among the allegations in a statement submitted to an employment tribunal in south London, Mrs Baptiste says that a set of office keys had "white is right" written on the key ring. A foreign office spokeswoman said the grounds for complaint had not yet been seen. "Mrs Baptiste has made complaints of racial discrimination against colleagues at the high commission. We take all such allegations seriously and we asked her to provide details so we could investigate. In spite of repeated requests, she never informed us of the grounds for her complaint." In her statement yesterday, Mrs Baptiste said that her dismissal followed the arrival of Peter Hughes, who took over as high commissioner in January 1998. Mr Hughes, a career diplomat, had worked at the foreign office in London in the preceding four years, and had been posted to Sydney, Warsaw, Rome and Islamabad. Mrs Baptiste, who earned £10,000 a year, a relatively high salary in St Lucia, added: "Shortly after his arrival Mr Hughes accused me of being paid too much." "The race discrimination at the high commission was severe and smacked of colonial attitudes." Asked to comment on the allegations yesterday, a spokeswoman in Mr Hughes's office in St Lucia yesterday said they were "not at liberty to discuss it at present" and referred the call to the foreign office. The foreign office spokeswoman said: "The decision to terminate Mrs Baptiste's employment was unrelated to her complaint and came after she refused to comply with the terms and conditions of her employment. In December 1998, Mrs Baptiste began legal action against the British high commission in St Lucia, but in 1999 that action was withdrawn from court with the agreement of both sides." In October, the foreign office was told that she had lodged a complaint with the industrial tribunal in Croydon. "We have asked the court to decide whether it has the jurisdiction to hear it as it was outside the UK," the spokeswoman said. A foreign office source that claimed there were many discrepancies in Mrs Baptiste's version of the events. She had claimed, for instance, that she had to seek permission from Mr Hughes to use the staff car park, but the foreign office source insists there was no such car park. In a two-hour preliminary hearing yesterday to determine whether or not the case should go ahead, Lawrence Davies, who is representing Mrs Baptiste, said she was covered by the British employment rights act and the race relations act because the high commission, like a British embassy, was considered as home soil. He said: "The high commission doesn't exist as an independent entity. It is run by the foreign and commonwealth office in London, England. The salary was paid from London, all the money at the high commission comes from London. Absolutely everything - who gets paid, who gets dismissed - comes from Britain. [Mrs Baptiste] worked for what was essential a sub office of the foreign office. We argue that acts occurring in a British embassy are deemed to be in British jurisdiction." Philip Coppel, representing the foreign office, said the case was outside the tribunal's jurisdiction. He said that Mrs Baptiste "enjoyed protection under local legislation" which had allowed her to receive a redundancy payment when she was dismissed under St Lucia law. "She could not be subject to both sets of employment rights." Mr Coppel added: "There is absolutely no way that this woman, who lived and worked in St Lucia, was subject to the employment rights under British law." Andrew Bano, the tribunal chairman, adjourned the case and told the parties a written judgment would be posted.

webTitle: Setback for prisoner who seeks to stay with baby

fields.headline: Setback for prisoner who seeks to stay with baby
fields.trailText: An 18-year-old mother's efforts to be allowed to keep her new-born baby in prison were dealt a blow yesterday after social workers confirmed the child should stay on the "at risk" register.
fields.body:
An 18-year-old mother's efforts to be allowed to keep her new-born baby in prison were dealt a blow yesterday after social workers confirmed the child should stay on the "at risk" register.

The decision is likely to influence prison officials who will meet tomorrow to review their decision not to allow the inmate a place in the mother and baby unit inside Holloway jail in north London.

The ruling from Brent area child protection committee came on the eve of a high court judicial review of the prison's decision. The hearing is likely to be adjourned until the prison's admission board de livers its final verdict. The inmate, on remand for robbery at knifepoint, began her legal challenge before she gave birth to a baby girl on December 28.

She is still in hospital in north London with the baby, but faces being separated from her daughter unless the prison ruling is reversed.

The prison service said the decision to keep the baby on the "at risk" register was taken by social workers.

Prison officials took their original decision on the basis of fears raised by Brent social services over the ability of the mother, identified only as L, to look after the child.

webTitle: Doctors to decide on Pinochet's fitness

fields.headline: Doctors to decide on Pinochet's fitness
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: A team of doctors will today perform medical tests on Augusto Pinochet to assess whether the former Chilean dictator is fit to be extradited to Spain to stand trial on human rights charges.
fields.body:
A team of doctors will today perform medical tests on Augusto Pinochet to assess whether the former Chilean dictator is fit to be extradited to Spain to stand trial on human rights charges.

The general, 84, agreed to undergo the independent tests at the request of the home secretary, Jack Straw, following a formal petition from the Chilean government asking for him to be sent home because of his failing health.

General Pinochet, who faces extradition to Spain on 35 charges of torture and conspiracy to torture, is said to be suffering from a heart condition, diabetes and depression. Allegedly, he has had three minor strokes since he was arrested in London in October 1998. His supporters claim his health is deteriorating because of the stress he is under.

If the doctors find he is as sick as his supporters claim, the home secretary could say that Gen Pinochet should not be extradited, even if the courts decide otherwise. If his lawyers drop the appeal against a magistrate's decision to extradite him, the general would be free to return to Santiago. Even then the Spanish authorities could challenge Mr Straw's decision. Judge Baltasar Garzon, the Spanish magistrate responsible for the general's arrest, would probably apply to the high court for a judicial review and demand a medical examination, too.

fields.headline: Old medical notes excite researchers
fields.trailText: The discovery of a unique collection of thousands of old medical records at Dundee university has prompted one of the largest studies of foetal development and links to adult illnesses.
fields.body:
The discovery of a unique collection of thousands of old medical records at Dundee university has prompted one of the largest studies of foetal development and links to adult illnesses.

The hand-written and detailed records of more than 50,000 births in Tayside were kept by the late professor of obstetrics, James Walker.

Unlike his contemporaries, Walker recorded a wealth of information about the mothers and babies under his care between 1952 and 1966, including the mother's height, eating habits and blood pressure, the length of the pregnancy, the head circumference and length of the baby, and whether the infant was breast or bottle fed.

The material, kept in cardboard boxes in the university for years, has given a team of researchers an opportunity to study how adult illnesses such as diabetes, hypertension and heart disease might be activated in the womb.

The team plans to computerise the records and then track the babies, now in their 30s and 40s, through a series of medical databases to see how they have fared. They also hope to study the link between breast and bottle feeding and later health.

And, because many of the infants are now themselves parents, they will look at possible intergeneration effects.

Stewart Forsyth, a consultant paediatrician at Ninewells hospital and one of the research team, said: "We knew these records were around. But when we sat down and looked at them and began formulating our hypothesis we recognised the enormous potential here.

"The advantage is that previous work in this area looking at foetal growth and later health has concentrated primarily on birth weight, but there are many factors that can influence birth weight.

"This data is of particular importance because it includes information on maternal height, length of pregnancy, maternal nutrition and other factors like measurements of the baby's head circumference and length. We will be able to look at the association between foetal growth and later adult disease more than has ever been possible before."

Previous research has found that smaller babies appear more likely to suffer from heart disease later in life. Low birth weight has also been linked to the onset of adult diabetes, and the diet of the expectant mother has been linked to a variety of ailments.

Dr Forsyth said Professor Walker had probably not foreseen the value of his work. "He was very interested in maternal health during pregnancy and also infant growth but he had not taken forward the hypothesis."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Teenage girl found hanged
A teenage girl has died after being found hanging at the entrance to a public park early yesterday.
fields.body:
Teenage girl found hanged
A teenage girl has died after being found hanging at the entrance to a public park early yesterday.

Joanne Harper, 17, was discovered by a police officer in the Orford area of Warrington, Cheshire.

Seven years for attacker
A baseball bat attacker who interrupted a lovers' tiff and fractured the boyfriend's skull was jailed for seven years at the Old Bailey yesterday.

Anthony McGlynn, 21, of Finchley, north London, admitted causing grievous bodily harm with intent.

Bosnich not to be charged
Manchester United goalkeeper Mark Bosnich will not face prosecution over an incident outside a Birmingham club last June.

West Midlands police said no action would be taken after an inquiry into a complaint by press photographer Jamie Jones.

Mother accused
A 51-year-old mother accused of killing her two disabled sons was released on conditional bail after she appeared yesterday at Winchester crown court.

Janquil Melody Turnbull has been charged with the murders of Robert, 23, and Richard, 20, at their home on the Isle of Wight.

Misery for commuters
Thousands of commuters yesterday returned from the holiday to face misery on the trains because of a dispute about overtime. Action by drivers affected travellers in Sussex and south London on Connex South Central services, with 50 trains cancelled in the morning rush hour.

Boy, 13, shot with airgun
A 13-year-old boy is critically ill in hospital after accidentally shooting himself in the head with an airgun.

He is believed to have discovered the weapon, belonging to his father, at the house in Langley, Berkshire.

Undercover revelations
Posh Spice Victoria Beckham yesterday told TV viewers how her soccer star husband David liked to borrow her undies.

Pushed by interviewer Johnny Vaughan on Channel 4's Big Breakfast, she admitted that he preferred to wear her g-strings.

webTitle: Billions wasted on computers, MPs say

fields.headline: Billions wasted on computers, MPs say
fields.trailText: Government is wasting billions of pounds on ineffective and useless information technology systems, a committee of MPs says in a report published today.
fields.body:
Government is wasting billions of pounds on ineffective and useless information technology systems, a committee of MPs says in a report published today.

The government is spending some £7bn a year on new systems, and the Commons public accounts committee draws together a decade of blunders - from the national insurance contributions system to the debacle at the passport agency, which disrupted tens of thousands of applications.

David Davis, Tory chairman of the committee, said yesterday: "Such projects are too often delivered late or not at all; they come in over budget or fail to work as intended at the outset.

"The consequence of such poor performance is that the citizen loses out. Basic errors are repeated time and again, but lessons do not seem to have been learned."

The MPs warn that unless the situation is resolved quickly, it will jeopardise Tony Blair's ambitious plans to put 25% of government business on line by 2002.

The report highlights 25 projects which have failed to deliver the promised improvements to the public and in some cases had to be abandoned because they did not work properly.

One of the worst ministries was the home office which is condemned for making a mess of a new system to deliver passports; for signing an unenforceable contract over processing nationality and immigration claims and for introducing a computer system that actually delayed payments for people handing in guns after the Dunblane massacre.

The home office blunders led to the cost of processing passports increasing from £12 to £15.50. A new passport now costs £28.

The section on the home office's failings concludes: "It is essential that departments learn from their past mistakes and consider how they can co-ordinate better their considerable resources to ensure better value for money from IT development."

Other departments heavily criticised include the NHS executive, the ministry of defence and the contributions agency.

The NHS was attacked for years of errors in co-ordinating information on hospital patients and failing to co-ordinate a system so different hospitals could share the information.

The ministry of defence had to abandon a top secret computer system never used at a cost of £40m and spent millions of pounds on a faulty computer system to handle the sale of surplus equipment.

The benefits agency and the contributions agency are attacked for trying to implement computer systems that were not capable of doing the job. The contributions agency has still not sorted out a new system to record national insurance payments with the result that people are still not being paid.

The failure in the national insurance recording system meant 172,000 pensioners were underpaid by between one penny to £100 a week because their contributions had not been collated.

The benefits agency spent millions on a benefit card system which was never introduced and is now considered out of date.

The report calls for widespread changes in the way computer contracts are handled, ensuring that departments employed skilled project managers to run them properly.

fields.headline: Missing Troubles archive surfaces
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Secret Irish government papers relating to one of the most controversial periods in the republic's history surfaced yesterday just as opposition calls for a police inquiry into how they had disappeared were beginning to snowball.
fields.body:
Secret Irish government papers relating to one of the most controversial periods in the republic's history surfaced yesterday just as opposition calls for a police inquiry into how they had disappeared were beginning to snowball.

The cabinet documents were due to be released in the new year under a 30-year-rule. But when Irish journalists asked for the files, the national archives office told them they had gone missing.

The papers covered August 1969, the onset of the troubles, and were expected to contain details of an alleged conspiracy involving government ministers to supply weapons to the IRA to defend nationalists from loyalist attack.

Among six men acquitted at a trial in Dublin the following year was Charles Haughey, then minister of finance. He went on to stage a remarkable political comeback, becoming Irish prime minister in 1979.

Jack Lynch, who was the taoiseach at the time of the arms crisis, had sacked Mr Haughey and his fellow minister Neil Blaney for failing to follow government policy before the trial. Mr Haughey, now 74, and with his reputation in tatters as Irish politics is embroiled in sleaze, is awaiting trial accused of obstructing the work two years ago of a tribunal inquiring in to payments to politicians.

John Bruton, the Fine Gael leader, who had demanded a Garda inquiry into the missing papers, yesterday reacted with scepticism after the NAO unexpectedly announced that the documents had been found. No explanation was offered, except that the files, marked "partition - government policy", had been transferred along with others in 1996 for safekeeping.

Irish government sources said that the documents would now be examined to determine if any material in them should be withheld. That process is expected to take several days.

Mr Bruton, who said he would insist on raising the fiasco in the Dail when it sits again later this month, said that the office of Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, had been sloppy in checking the 1969 files last year. He said he believed that any gaps should have been obvious, even to a casual reader, months ago. "The taoiseach's office has the use of the most advanced IT and operates under what it calls a system of 'strategic management', so how did it manage such a cock-up? The national archives office also have questions to answer about what they did with the material they got in 1996," said Mr Bruton.

But the whiff of scandal was receding last night, and that was a relief to Mr Ahern, a successor to Mr Haughey, both as Fianna Fail leader and as the taoiseach.

fields.headline: What 'cultured' Krays told doctor
fields.standfirst: Inside the minds of the twins: Public record office releases confidential medical reports from the time of the gangsters' trial
fields.trailText: Inside the minds of the twins: Public record office releases confidential medical reports from the time of the gangsters' trial
fields.body:
The Kray brothers presented themselves to home office psychiatrists at the time of their murder trial as high-brow, cultured men who liked listening to the operatic soprano Maria Callas and reading Robert Frost's poems.

But the confidential medical reports on Ronnie and Reggie Kray released yesterday at the public record office also reveal that both men were heavily dependent on tranquillisers and became very excited if they did not get their regular doses. The prison doctor's reports described Reggie Kray as having been a "rather nervous boy who was a bedwetter until he was 10 years old."

Ronnie Kray, by the time of his Old Bailey trial in 1969, had fought a 16 year battle against schizophrenia and the doctors noted that "if he does not have his tablets he becomes very depressed and suspicious and thinks that people are trying to injure him".

The Krays were sent down for at least 30 years for the shooting of George Cornell at the Blind Beggar public house in the East End of London and for the murder of Jack "the Hat" McVitie.

The case papers also provide some official confirmation of the alleged Kray connection with the escape and disappearance of a convicted murderer, Frank "mad axeman" Mitchell, from Dartmoor prison in December 1966. The twins were acquitted of killing Mitchell at their Old Bailey trial. An official note on the file says Mitchell escaped "with amazing ease" while on an outside working party on the moor as he had been left on his own without a prison officer present. It had been said the Krays sprang Mitchell to deal with Frankie Fraser, a gangland rival.

The Krays were charged along with three others but found not guilty of conspiring to help Mitchell escape and then murder him. His body was not found.

A note on the Old Bailey papers says: "Allegedly, he was kept in a London flat with two of the accused always guarding him and with a prostitute for company. Eventually Ronnie and Reggie Kray left with Mitchell and four shots were heard; various evidence (especially from crooks) of remarks that Mitchell was dead: 'four injections in the nut'. No body, of course. Much clearing up afterwards. Complete denials. Not very strong evidence."

The case papers show that the Old Bailey jurors were kept under police surveillance during the trial and given a Scotland Yard emergency number to ring.

The medical reports on the identical twin brothers were prepared by Denis Leigh of the Royal Bethlem and Maudsley hospitals after a five hour interview in December 1968 to establish whether they were fit to stand trial. Dr Leigh said Ronnie claimed that at school he had been a "very bad scholar, although he can read and write", and had been "slung out" of the Royal Fusiliers at 18 for assault on the guard, desertion and escaping from the guard house. After the army he had gone into the "club game". Dr Leigh recorded his marital status as "single. No girl friend. Denies that he is a homosexual."

Dr Leigh's notes go on: "Personality: describes himself as liking classical music, and singers such as Callas and Gigli. He is fond of reading biographies and quoted those of Gordon of Khartoum, Genghis Khan and Lawrence of Arabia.

"He says he is a friendly man, not bad-tempered normally, a believer in God but not a churchgoer. He is interested in the country and loyal to his friends and, in fact, showed me some photographs of his male friends who were boxers, and a photograph of his country house (in Suffolk) and of the donkey, Figaro, which the family keep."

The report continues: "Social status: he lives in a flat with his parents and his twin brother, Reg. He denied any social or financial stress. 'We get by'."

The two brothers refused to discuss their alleged crimes with Dr Leigh. He said Ronnie had suffered from a schizophrenic illness since the age of 22 it had kept been "under control for the last 10 years" through medication. Ronnie took 25mgms of Stemetil three times a day.

Dr Leigh's report on Reggie Kray says that he was dependent on Valium - 5mgs three times a day - "for a pressure on the forehead. It is an anxiety complex."

Reggie's wife had committed suicide a year before and he showed the doctor photographs of her and a poem he had written in her memory. The doctor said Reggie described himself as sociable and friendly and fond of the outdoor life, of horses and of gardening.

"He is interested in reading, particulary books on sayings and proverbs."

The medical report says Reggie was a heavy drinker - up to a bottle of gin a night. "Mentally he was alert, friendly, pleasant and indeed one might say charming," concluded Dr Leigh.

A year after the Krays' conviction, Dr Leigh again examined them and found them unchanged and still denying that they suffered from any mental disability.

The Krays were sent down for at least 30 years for the shooting of George Cornell at the Blind Beggar public house in the East End of London and for the murder of Jack "the Hat" McVitie. The case papers also provide some official confirmation of the alleged Kray connection with the escape and disappearance of a convicted murderer, Frank "mad axeman" Mitchell, from Dartmoor prison in December 1966. The twins were acquitted of killing Mitchell at their Old Bailey trial. An official note on the file says Mitchell escaped "with amazing ease" while on an outside working party on the moor as he had been left on his own without a prison officer present. It had been said the Krays sprang Mitchell to deal with Frankie Fraser, a gangland rival. The Krays were charged along with three others but found not guilty of conspiring to help Mitchell escape and then murder him. His body was not found. A note on the Old Bailey papers says: "Allegedly, he was kept in a London flat with two of the accused always guarding him and with a prostitute for company. Eventually Ronnie and Reggie Kray left with Mitchell and four shots were heard; various evidence (especially from crooks) of remarks that Mitchell was dead: 'four injections in the nut'. No body, of course. Much clearing up afterwards. Complete denials. Not very strong evidence." The case papers show that the Old Bailey jurors were kept under police surveillance during the trial and given a Scotland Yard emergency number to ring. The medical reports on the identical twin brothers were prepared by Denis Leigh of the Royal Bethlem and Maudsley hospitals after a five hour interview in December 1968 to establish whether they were fit to stand trial. Dr Leigh said Ronnie claimed that at school he had been a "very bad scholar, although he can read and write", and had been "slung out" of the Royal Fusiliers at 18 for assault on the guard, desertion and escaping from the guard house. After the army he had gone into the "club game". Dr Leigh recorded his marital status as "single. No girl friend. Denies that he is a homosexual." Dr Leigh's notes go on: "Personality: describes himself as liking classical music, and singers such as Callas and Gigli. He is fond of reading biographies and quoted those of Gordon of Khartoum, Genghis Khan and Lawrence of Arabia. "He says he is a friendly man, not bad-tempered normally, a believer in God but not a churchgoer. He is interested in the country and loyal to his friends and, in fact, showed me some photographs of his male friends who were boxers, and a photograph of his country house (in Suffolk) and of the donkey, Figaro, which the family keep." The report continues: "Social status: he lives in a flat with his parents and his twin brother, Reg. He denied any social or financial stress. 'We get by'." The two brothers refused to discuss their alleged crimes with Dr Leigh. He said Ronnie had suffered from a schizophrenic illness since the age of 22 it had kept been "under control for the last 10 years" through medication. Ronnie took 25mgms of Stemetil three times a day. Dr Leigh's report on Reggie Kray says that he was dependent on Valium - 5mgs three times a day - "for a pressure on the forehead. It is an anxiety complex." Reggie's wife had committed suicide a year before and he showed the doctor photographs of her and a poem he had written in her memory. The doctor said Reggie described himself as sociable and friendly and fond of the outdoor life, of horses and of gardening. "He is interested in reading, particulary books on sayings and proverbs." The medical report says Reggie was a heavy drinker - up to a bottle of gin a night. "Mentally he was alert, friendly, pleasant and indeed one might say charming," concluded Dr Leigh. A year after the Krays' conviction, Dr Leigh again examined them and found them unchanged and still denying that they suffered from any mental disability. webTitle: Great escapes of an IRA gunman

fields.headline: Great escapes of an IRA gunman
fields.standfirst:
Angelo Fusco shot his way out of captivity 19 years ago. Yesterday he escaped extradition - for the time being

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Angelo Fusco shot his way out of captivity 19 years ago. Yesterday he escaped extradition - for the time being
fields.body:
Just after 8pm on Monday, police in Kerry waved down another driver at an impromptu roadblock at Castleisland just outside Tralee. They were hunting new year drunken drivers, but instead had trapped much bigger fry: one of the IRA's most wanted men.

He was Angelo Fusco, 43, wanted for the shooting 20 years ago of Captain Herbert Westmacott, 28, the most senior of four SAS officers to die in the Troubles.

He offered no resistance as he was rumbled.

Fusco, along with seven other IRA men, shot his way out of Crumlin Road courthouse in Belfast in June 1981, two days before he was convicted there of Capt Westmacott's shooting 13 months earlier. He was sentenced to life in his absence, with the judge recommending that he serve a minimum term behind bars of 30 years.

He disappeared again in February 1998, just before Ireland's supreme court, the republic's highest legal authority, brought an end to his six-year fight against extradition.

As it did so, it issued a warrant for his arrest. But he had been free on bail and had already bolted.

In between times, he had spent 10 years at Portlaoise Prison, 50 miles west of Dublin and close to where he learned of his latest reprieve yesterday. He had been seized south of the border in January 1982, seven months after fleeing Belfast.

He was jailed under Irish law for 10 years for his escape in Belfast.

He even attempted to flee then. That escape bid was to earn him another three-year sentence, and, with remission, his release in January 1992.

Fusco was immediately served with papers ordering his extradition to serve his sentence at the Maze prison for Capt Westmacott's murder.

He won a landmark victory three years later when the the high court overturned the original Dublin district court's order, with Mr Justice Geoghegan ruling that, because of the time lag, it would be "unjust, oppressive and invidious" to order his extradition.

He settled in Tralee with his wife, Mary, and three children, Elaine, now 26, Joe, 20, and 18-year-old Maria, and lived openly.

Anticipating an unfavourable legal ruling once more, he disappeared just before the five members of the supreme court ruled against him.

He has kept himself scarce, but he is known to have had frequent contact with Martin Ferris, a senior Sinn Fein figure. He is known to be a close supporter of the Gerry Adams-Martin McGuinness leadership, and Sinn Fein's quick action yesterday nailed speculation that he had been held as part of the Garda's ongoing crackdown on dissident republicans.

Locals in Tralee said yesterday he was known to make several visits to the family home. He was held as he was driving away from Tralee.

Fusco, of Italian descent, was brought up in west Belfast. His family owned a fish and chip shop, and a close relative played football for Distillery, then the local Irish League side.

He is the second IRA man wanted for the murder of Capt Westmacott to be at the centre of an extradition row in the past three months.

One of those convicted with him, Robert Campbell, 45, risked arrest in October to carry the coffin of his son, Patrick Campbell, 22.

He died after a battle between Irish National Liberation Army activists and a drugs gang in Dublin, but was buried in west Belfast. The IRA formed a tight guard to ensure his father was able to attend.

The M-60 gang, named after the heavy-duty machine gun it used, murdered Capt Westmacott when he led an eight-member plain-clothes SAS patrol into a house in the Antrim Road in north Belfast to stop an imminent attack on the nearby RUC station. They rushed into the house next door, and Capt Westmacott was shot twice.

The IRA unit was surrounded, and later flew the white flag of surrender. They asked for a priest, and gave themselves up.

Capt Westmacott was posthumously awarded the Military Cross. He was one of eight members of the security forces killed in M-60 attacks.

A sharp-eye Garda is understood to have spotted that the tax disc on Fusco's car windscreen was out of date, and the officers decided to give the two occupants a closer look. He gave a false name and address.

Police immediately arrested Fusco so sparking extraordinary drama in the Irish Republic. It was a day when age-old but near-forgotten conflicts with Northern Ireland over the extradition of terrorist suspects were re-opened, with Sinn Fein's desperate pleas in the high court in Dublin successfully stopping Fusco's immediate return to the Royal Ulster Constabulary at Kileen on the Louth-Armagh border.

Others on the run from the north

According to Sinn Fein sources, a further four IRA members are fighting extradition proceedings aimed at returning them to Northern Ireland, and a fifth man is wanted by the police.

 Dermot McNally Escaped from H Block at the Maze prison during the 1983 breakout of 38 inmates. Now fighting 14 extradition charges linked to bomb making.

 Andrew Martin Believed to be wanted on conspiracy charges.

 Nessan Quinlivan Escaped from Brixton prison in July 1981 along with Pearse McAuley after a gun was smuggled into the jail in a shoe. Quinlivan is on separate bail of £60,000 awaiting an appeal against extradition to Britain on bombing charges.

 Tony Kelly Escaped from H Block during the 1983 breakout of 38 inmates.

 Robert Campbell Still on the run. Two days before the end of their trial in 1981 for the killing of Captain Herbert Westmacott, he and Angelo Fusco shot their way out of the courthouse in Belfast's Crumlin Road.

fields.headline: Woman PC wins 'easy rider' case
fields.trailText: The only woman rider in a police motorcycle team won compensation and the prospect of promotion yesterday, after senior officers caved in on the first day of a sex discrimination tribunal.
fields.body:
The only woman rider in a police motorcycle team won compensation and the prospect of promotion yesterday, after senior officers caved in on the first day of a sex discrimination tribunal.

PC Karen Wicks, 44, accepted an undisclosed sum from West Yorkshire police after the force abandoned its defence against charges that she was taunted and humiliated as an "easy rider".

The highly experienced officer, who has 24 years' service, said that male colleagues undermined her with degrading comments when she joined the unit and was seen by some as a threat to its macho image. She said she was denied a new high-powered Honda Blackbird bike when the make was issued to the force, and obliged by senior officers to stick with her old BMW.

The hearing at Leeds industrial tribunal had been expected to last for 19 days, but West Yorkshire police offered to settle at the last minute.

Richard Critchley, of the Police Federation, which backed PC Wicks's case, said that the tactics used against her had been "disgusting", and that she had been forced to take unpaid leave to present her case.

The compensation figure is being kept confidential as part of the settlement, but PC Wicks welcomed the outcome after brief formal proceedings at the tribunal. She said: "I'm just delighted and relieved and I'm now looking forward to getting on with my job."

Graham Moore, chief constable of West Yorkshire, said: "I am pleased that this matter has been concluded satisfactorily and that PC Wicks can now move forward in her career as a member of the force. We are committed to eradicating all forms of discrimination and I expect high standards of fairness from all.

"We go to considerable lengths to ensure that any member of the force who might feel that they were the subject of discrimination, whether racial or sexual, has an effective avenue of complaint."

fields.headline: Handle with care
fields.standfirst: Bomber, a drama about bomb-disposal experts, has everything audiences could possibly want: sex, suspense and house-levelling explosions. But as  Nicholas Barber  discovered, it could never have been made until now
fields.trailText: Bomber, a drama about bomb-disposal experts, has everything audiences could possibly want: sex, suspense and house-levelling explosions. But as Nicholas Barber discovered, it could never have been made until now
fields.body:
Viewers in Ireland won't be able to watch Bomber, a two-part drama that begins tonight on ITV. The channel's schedulers have deemed the title too sensitive for people both north and south of the border, even though the programme, about the army's bomb-disposal officers, barely mentions Ulster. Bomber is an intricate, brooding, psychological whodunit, starring Mark Strong from Births, Marriages And Deaths and Andrew Lincoln from This Life. The only politics in it are sexual ones, and the person who sets the explosives is motivated by a personal grudge, not a terrorist cause.

Still, even if not everyone in the British Isles will be allowed to see Bomber, the very fact that it has been made is a sign of the times. If there were still a reasonable chance of a real bomb going off the night before transmission, the mini-series would have never got beyond the basic idea. (In this case, oddly enough, the basic idea came from Leslie "Dirty Den" Grantham.) Bomber's writer, Rob Heyland, agrees that in the climate of just a few years ago the drama would have been impossible. "I don't think I would have had access to the EOD [Explosive Ordinance Disposal] people for a start", he says. "They were incredibly sweet and accommodating and quite amused by the idea of a tubby idiot coming in and saying, 'I'm going to write a story about you.' I spent a lot of time with them, I watched them training and I got all sorts of information that, previously, you would have had to be John Pilger to get access to."

Heyland, who also created Between The Lines, adds that not every insight into the life of a bomb-disposal officer was very helpful. "They're fantastically professional", he says. "They have their routines and procedures, and they're amazingly dry and phlegmatic. A realistic evocation of their daily lives wouldn't have any drama in it at all."

For their part, the Royal Logistic Corps, from which EOD officers are drawn, could hardly be expected to enjoy the results of their co-operation. Bomber is a sympathetic, unsensationalist portrayal of decent people doing a dangerous job, but it's hardly an army recruitment film. Half the time the EOD officers have no clue that a bomb exists until it detonates, and when they do locate an unexploded device, they are shown either failing to defuse it, or defusing it more by luck than judgment. One scene has two soldiers crouching over the same bomb, each convinced that a different wire should be cut. Over the course of the drama, three soldiers are blown to pieces. Another old soldier has had his hearing damaged by a blast. And, by the way, military men are crap at relationships with their wives and families, too.

All the same, Heyland insists, most of the soldiers who have seen Bomber were impressed. "There were tremendous divides between officers and men, as there always are", he says. "The lads were quite pleased by the way the Ruperts [derogatory term for junior officers] were shown to be very fallible and quite infantile when it came to partying. The officers thought it was very interesting, but weren't terribly flattered. And two officers who aren't in the Logistics Corps any more said it was awesomely authentic, which was the most pleasing reaction of all. They were jumping with laughter and shouting, 'I served with him!' and 'That's how my mate got killed!'"

Apart from the improved climate, there is a less positive reason why Bomber was so much more feasible a project than it might have been in the past: it's now a lot easier to make bombs. Indeed, in tomorrow's episode, levelling a house appears to be a straightforward, Blue Peter-style matter of arranging a clothes peg, a battery, a light switch and some string in a Tupperware box. But again Heyland has the research to back the story up.

"I did wonder when I started writing it - am I going to create trouble? Am I going to provoke people to do things?" he says. "Then my nephew told me that it was easy to get books on how to make bombs sent from America. You shouldn't be able to, but you order them on the net, and customs officers don't check books. And I've got a whole box-file of stuff printed directly off the net. One's titled, The Best Non-Nuclear Explosive Available To The Modern Terrorist, and there's a two-page recipe of how to cook it."

A few minutes of conversation like this and you find yourself wondering if it's such a terrible thing that some viewers aren't getting to see Bomber. Perhaps we should be watching television that doesn't have any suggestion of violence or terrorism at all. In Ireland tonight, ITV has scheduled Die Hard With A Vengeance.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Absolute Power | Origins: The Genesis Factor
fields.body:
Mark Tavener, having killed off his booze-sodden BBC crime correspondent George Cragge, now concentrates on Charles Prentiss and Martin McCabe, minor characters in his comedy-thriller cycle In The Red. They have axed the Beeb's management so successfully that they now find themselves jobless and setting up as spin doctors. Absolute Power (11.30am, Radio 4) gives Stephen Fry and John Bird one or two nice one-liners - but nowhere near enough to sustain 30 minutes.

However, let it not be said that radio is getting dumber. Over the coming three weeks Paul Davies investigates how life on earth started. In Origins: The Genesis Factor (9.0pm, Radio 4) he hears that fossils indicate that single cell organisms emerged around 3,800 million years ago, roughly when the first rock strata were being formed. But how could living things survive amid all that heat and turmoil? Well, one scientist has discovered microbes thriving in rock formations 5km below ground.

webTitle: Another grandee takes a swipe at Hague

fields.headline: Another grandee takes a swipe at Hague
fields.standfirst:
Tory revolt: Howe joins Major and Clarke in criticism of opposition leader amid suspicion of organised campaign against move to right

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Tory revolt:  Howe joins Major and Clarke in criticism of opposition leader amid suspicion of organised campaign against move to right
fields.body:
The men in grey suits are rumbling. When William Hague returns from his skiing holiday in Montana, he can expect a frosty reception from Tory grandees who fear their young leader has become a dangerous liability.

The former deputy prime minister, Geoffrey Howe, yesterday became the latest in a series of Tory elder statesmen to warn Mr Hague that he is in danger of destroying the party unless he returns to the centre ground.

Lord Howe, the famously lampooned "dead sheep" who briefly came alive to wound Margaret Thatcher in his devastating 1990 resignation speech, said with uncharacteristic bluntness that the Tories were not "widely regarded as a credible alternative government".

The monetarist former chancellor, who fell foul of Thatcher because of his love of Europe and his plodding manner, rounded on Mr Hague for his foolishness in dispensing with the services of his deputy, Peter Lilley, and his leader in the Lords, Viscount Cranborne.

"By these standards even Sir Keith Joseph might have been lucky to survive," Lord Howe said in a reference to the free thinking rightwinger who laid the basis for Thatcherism during the Tories' last spell in opposition.

For a time after victory in the Falklands, Lady Thatcher's power had become almost literally magnetic, Lord Howe said. But later, ministers were spinning off like sparks from a Catherine wheel.

"Mr Hague thus risks finding himself at the Catherine wheel stage, without having enjoyed any magnetic interlude on the way."

Hagueites, confident that the man who brought down their heroine poses no threat to Mr Hague, dismissed Lord Howe's outburst as his "annual rant".

However, their bluster masked a growing fear that Lord Howe's intervention is part of an orchestrated fightback by grandees exasperated by the way in which Mr Hague has allowed himself to fall into the hands of the Thatcherites.

Last week John Major warned Mr Hague that he would lose votes if he allowed "the ghost of government past to lead the party by the nose".

The attack from the former prime minister, who had vowed never to criticise his successor, came hard on the heels of a characteristically barbed outburst from Kenneth Clarke against the "way-out young ideologues" surrounding Mr Hague.

Fears at Central Office that the grandees are plotting against Mr Hague were fuelled when the former minister David Curry, who served as Mr Clarke's campaign manager in his 1997 leadership bid, said that Mr Major had tipped him off about his intervention.

"John told me he had written [his] piece, so I have been waiting for this Exocet to go off," Mr Curry said of Mr Major's piece, published in the Spectator.

Although heads have been put together, it is too early to talk of a plot among the likes of Mr Major, Mr Clarke and Lord Howe.

A few rungs down on the grandee ladder, however, there is growing cooperation among former ministers who fear that Mr Hague is in danger of blow ing away what little support the Tories still retain. The pro-European former environment secretary, John Gummer, and the Eurosceptic former education secretary, Gillian Shephard, are just a few of the senior Tories who believe that Mr Hague is lurching too far away from the party's mainstream supporters.

There is talk of a senior deputation from the "men in grey suits" - with Mrs Shephard on board they may have to be re named the "people in grey suits" - calling on Mr Hague when the Commons returns next week.

A little-noticed new year's message from the pro-European MP Peter Luff gives a flavour of the growing dismay among centre-ground Tories.

Mr Luff, a former aide to Ted Heath but one who has gone out of his way to be loyal to Mr Hague, said that Mr Major and Mr Clarke were right to say that the party had given the appearance of moving to the right. "Our party does have a problem. Perception is reality [which means] it's what people think about you that really matters.

"Our policies are not wrong, but their presentation is unbalanced. This lop-sided presentation gives credence to the allegations that we are becoming extreme."

Inexperienced Hagueites are likely to make the mistake of dismissing interventions from the Luffs and the Clarkes as embittered outbursts.

However, the young Turks would do well to listen to Lord Howe who quoted the late Angus Maude - father of the shadow chancellor - who said that newcomers should listen to their seniors even if they have been on the losing side.

'Not a credible alternative'

"Today's Conservative party - to put it gently - is not widely regarded as a credible alternative. William Hague lost both his leader in the Lords and his own deputy. By these standards, even Sir Keith Joseph would have been lucky to survive."
Lord Howe of Aberavon

"There are no votes in yesterday and many to be lost if the Ghost of Government Past appears to lead the party by the nose. The harking back to the 1980s at the party conference may have appealed to the activists, but was a real turn-off to the undecided voter. Rallies for Pinochet were not a good idea. They distracted from the new agenda William set, and in any event, Pinochet's alleged misdeeds are for the courts, not the politicians."
John Major

"I fear the party has moved very strongly to the right. The great danger for the Conservative party is to make sure that it does not imitate the Labour party after 1979 when it lurched far too far to the left and made itself unelectable."
Kenneth Clarke

"It is natural for parties to want to regress to what they regard as their heartlands. I think that is a temptation which has to be avoided. You get a great cheer at your party conference but you will be addressing an ever-diminishing audience."

webTitle: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: OK, so you could probably find more deserving outlets for your sympathy, but it's just going from bad to worse for errant hip-hop mogul Sean "Puff Daddy" Combs, whose seasonal festivities were thoughtlessly disrupted by the NYPD arresting him after the December 27th shooting of nightclub bouncer Julius Jones.
fields.body:
OK, so you could probably find more deserving outlets for your sympathy, but it's just going from bad to worse for errant hip-hop mogul Sean "Puff Daddy" Combs, whose seasonal festivities were thoughtlessly disrupted by the NYPD arresting him after the December 27th shooting of nightclub bouncer Julius Jones.

Already waiting on a number of firearms charges, Combs's belated attempts to distance himself from the incident then received a blow on Monday when the self-proclaimed "Bad Boy" found himself named in Jones's $800 million personal injury lawsuit: a statement from Puff's legal team later described the action as "frivolous", which probably isn't the word most of us would use. And that wasn't all for the hapless rapper, after his ex-girlfriend Kim Porter spent the New Year hiring a divorce lawyer to seek as-yet-unpaid child support for Daddy's 20-month-old son Christian; Puffy, perhaps understandably, is reportedly keen to keep the matter out of court

Contrasting fortunes for the Sheen family, meanwhile, as patriarch Martin spent a night in custody last week after being arrested at an anti-nuclear demonstration in Nevada, whereas perennial black sheep Charlie - with the help of his attorneys - steered himself out of court and free of potential clink. How so? Well, having been hit with a damages suit by porn stars Erin Sieman and Christine Lee (professional names: Charlisse L'Amour and Teri Star) after their alleged assault at the hands of Sheen's bodyguard Curtis Hunt (professional name: Zippy), the one-time bright young thing of 80s cinema was finally delivered from the threat of courtroom action through an undisclosed settlement on Monday afternoon. Which, fortuitously enough, means Sheen can now face the new millennium with only his continuing probation for battery of a former girlfriend to worry about. Hooray for Hollywood!

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText:
One Night Stand (Mike Figgis, 1997)
12.20am, Sky Premier
fields.body:
One Night Stand (Mike Figgis, 1997)
12.20am, Sky Premier

Intriguing to see Wesley Snipes as non-action man in this thoughtful, melancholy study of relationships and life's little ambushes, similar in tone to Figgis's Leaving Las Vegas. Snipes plays Max - a role originally intended for Nicolas Cage - a married LA advertisements director, whose shallow life is shaken to the core by a brief sexual encounter with Nastassja Kinski's Karen, and by his renewed friendship with the Aids stricken Charlie (Robert Downey Jr).

The performances are excellent - Snipes should perhaps hang up the guns 'n' ammo a little more often.

The Vanishing (George Sluizer, 1988)
1.50am, FilmFour

A young Dutch couple holidaying in France stop at a service station where the woman (Johanna Ter Steege) goes missing: an unexceptional start to no ordinary thriller. For the next three years the man, Gene Bervoets, is taunted by postcards from the kidnapper (Bernard-Pierre Donnadieu), until finally he is invited to meet his tormentor.

A real nightmare, this: a breathtaking study in the banality of evil by Donnadieu, and a shuddering conclusion.

webTitle: What people who work in TV watch on TV

fields.headline: What people who work in TV watch on TV
fields.trailText: Huda Ali, freelance producer: "I watch late-night TV mostly, 4 Later because it's really weird and surreal, and it's also the time I get back from work, and daytime TV is pants - I make it and I know.
fields.body:
Huda Ali, freelance producer: "I watch late-night TV mostly, 4 Later because it's really weird and surreal, and it's also the time I get back from work, and daytime TV is pants - I make it and I know.

I am obsessed with TV. A friend and I have just been discussing TV: A Question Of Pop - neither of us has seen it but I do dislike Theakston quite strongly. It's always the same mindless presenters on television. I watched Forgive And Forget, which was hyped incredibly and I thought it was nothing really, not controversial at all. ITV are doing a lot of these one-off dramas, whereas the BBC doesn't anymore which I find peculiar. It's a reversal."

Siobhan Donnelly, assistant producer, Big Breakfast: "I watch the Big Breakfast, not every day, but I do see most shows. I used to watch TFI Friday but I don't now, I think it's gone downhill.

Sunday night is the only night I'm in and I was hooked on Wives And Daughters - I loved that. I didn't like Oliver Twist, though. Streetmate was great, people making fools of themselves; that possibility of romance - then the couple never see each other again. I'm proud to say I've never watched Coronation Street - I caught a glimpse but I've never watched a whole episode. What do I switch off? Most stuff. There's no programme that I wouldn't miss."

James Peak, BBC Research Department: "I'm a big fan of the BBC Natural History Unit - the effort they go to is incredible. I really enjoyed the time-lapse film over Christmas. From a production point of view, it would have been amazing to work on, to get your teeth into.

One of the best programmes was also Living With The Enemy - so simple but so effective. There was more drama in that than on most drama series. The Cambridge oik who went to live with the pro-cannabis community - it really showed him to be arrogant, snide little fool. What I don't like is too many "pets and vets" and that sort of thing. I don't have a garden and I don't have a pet, so a lot of scheduling is not for me."

webTitle: Dobson's rivals win battle of Labour list

fields.headline: Dobson's rivals win battle of Labour list
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone and Glenda Jackson will today receive copies of Labour's London membership list after a three-month battle to get access to the 70,000 names and addresses.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone and Glenda Jackson will today receive copies of Labour's London membership list after a three-month battle to get access to the 70,000 names and addresses.

The party hierarchy hopes the move will end a damaging internal row over how their rival for Labour's nomination for London's mayor, Frank Dobson, obtained details last October to send out letters seeking support.

The Euro MP Richard Balfe, who admitted securing the list for Mr Dobson, is to make copies available to the former health secretary's opponents.

Mr Livingstone and Ms Jackson complained that they had been put at a disadvantage by being prevented from mailing members who make up one third of the party's electoral college.

The pair will now come under pressure to drop complaints against Mr Dobson's campaign, but the data protection registrar could press ahead with an investigation.

The Dobson team is accused of not having a licence to possess the names, and of obtaining them unfairly.

Mr Dobson put pressure on Labour's Millbank HQ to make the names available to his rivals after realising the row was damaging his campaign.

Senior party figures had previously claimed a copy could not be handed over to Mr Livingstone because he was backed by far left groups who might misuse it.

Mr Livingstone, the former leader of the old Greater London council, accused his critics of smear tactics.

He said that his surveys showed he was on course for victory next month.

A supporter of Mr Dobson, Tony Blair's favoured candidate, said: "Hopefully this will draw a line under the controversy over membership lists.

"What counts is who will be the best mayor, and Ken and Glenda have got away scrutiny-free so far."

webTitle: MoD seeks more cash in weapons row

fields.headline: MoD seeks more cash in weapons row
fields.trailText: The ministry of defence was in urgent talks with the treasury yesterday to secure more money after leaked army documents claimed that British troops in Kosovo were issued with inadequate equipment.
fields.body:
The ministry of defence was in urgent talks with the treasury yesterday to secure more money after leaked army documents claimed that British troops in Kosovo were issued with inadequate equipment.

John Spellar, the armed forces minister, admitted yesterday that the army was facing financial problems and blamed it partly on the Tories' defence cuts. "We inherited a horrendous over-run, tremendous problems ... that is putting pressure on the budget."

Though he said there would be an inquiry into the leaked reports - written by Lieutenant Colonel Paul Gibson, commander of the parachute regiment's first battalion, and Brigadier Adrian Freer, commander of 5 airborne brigade - Whitehall observers say the situation has done no harm to the ministry of defence's case in its talks with the treasury.

The Kosovo campaign cost the MoD an extra £100m according to the latest estimates, Paul Beaver, spokesman for Jane's defence publications, said yesterday. However, this is a small fraction of the £21bn defence budget and the treasury is likely to want to know why so much of the army's equipment is unreliable.

Mr Spellar agreed that radios used by soldiers in Kosovo were "requiring repair" and due to be replaced.The MoD was also looking at modifications to the army's new light machine gun, described in the leaked reports as "insufficiently robust". The treasury is likely to question the MoD about its handling of defence estate sales, and about promised rewards from its "smart procurement" policy.

Menzies Campbell, Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, told the Guardian that the leaked reports indicated a deeper government malaise.

webTitle: Move to raise select committees' profile

fields.headline: Move to raise select committees' profile
fields.trailText: MPs are drawing up plans to boost the prestige and independence of cross-party select committees at Westminster amid fresh evidence that Labour's huge Commons majority is hitting attendance rates on both sides.
fields.body:
MPs are drawing up plans to boost the prestige and independence of cross-party select committees at Westminster amid fresh evidence that Labour's huge Commons majority is hitting attendance rates on both sides.

Members of the liaison committee, which includes all 33 select committee chairmen, are expected to recommend tougher powers to scrutinise Whitehall budgets, extra back-up staff and ways of breaking the control of party whips on who gets appointed to plum committee posts, often a reward for "loyal" service, when they publish their select committee report around Easter.

With too few Conservatives elected in 1997 to make much impact on Tony Blair's 179-seat overall majority, select committees have been the one bright spot in parliament's struggle to hold the government to account on issues like Sierra Leone and rising taxes. But the committee system has been hit by a rise in absenteeism up from less than a quarter to more than one third, according to a new survey. The number of MPs who failed to turn up rose from 23.3% in the mid-1990s to 34.2% in the session which ended in November.

The veteran Labour ex-minister Robert Sheldon, chairman of the standards and privileges committee, conceded last night that attendance was patchy and also that some committees had suffered heavy turnover as MPs were promoted.

In a separate survey yesterday, the 22 Labour and nationalist MPs who also sit in the Scots and Welsh devolved parliaments were accused of mass absenteeism from Westminster, despite retaining their full £47,008 a year Commons salaries, plus one-third of their devolved pay, which takes them to around £60,000 a year.

fields.headline: Charles Earland
fields.standfirst: Hero of the Hammond
fields.trailText: The jazz organist Charles Earland, who has died of a heart attack aged 58, was the most excitingly imaginative arranger linked to the Hammond B3 organ. Playing the instrument in 1970 he put together a 15-minute version of Killer Joe that ranks among the greatest live performances in jazz.
fields.body:
The jazz organist Charles Earland, who has died of a heart attack aged 58, was the most excitingly imaginative arranger linked to the Hammond B3 organ. Playing the instrument in 1970 he put together a 15-minute version of Killer Joe that ranks among the greatest live performances in jazz.

He was trained as a saxophone player - making him an exception amidst hundreds of ex-pianists - approaching the organ orchestrally, like a swing bandleader born out of time. Any treatise on the use of background riffs to cushion and propel musicians must take his arranging work into account.

His records sold well beyond the world of jazz buffs. He collaborated in the mid-1970s with Patrick Gleeson, the brains behind Herbie Hancock's early synthesized groups and, to judge by the cover versions, his favourites must have included Sly Stone and the way trumpets and saxophones buttressed the sparkling, jagged-edge funk purveyed by Stone's groups.

Earland's most endearing crossover trait was to revive pop ballads by giving them a jazzy patina. Few remember 1960s group Spiral Staircase: he transformed their big hit More Today Than Yesterday, via a slinky bounce tempo, on his 1969 Prestige debut album Black Talk! Other pop singles given the treatment included the Carpenters' We've Only Just Begun and Age Of Aquarius from Hair.

Born in Philadelphia, Earland played saxophones in high school, a contemporary of future stars like Bobby Timmons, Lew Tabackin, Pat Martino and the then trumpeter and early 1960s pop star Frankie Avalon. Working with Jimmy McGriff, he took a fancy to the Hammond and was forever trying things out on McGriff's instrument. Shortly after forming his own group, Earland made the switch permanent, although he occasionally used a saxophone right to the end.

Apart from a late 1960s spell with saxophonist Lou Donaldson, Earland was always in charge. Compared to other organists, his groups tended to be larger and the music more structured. Recordings in the early 1970s moved gradually towards synthesizers and electric funk, typified by the score for the blaxploitation film The Dynamite Brothers, where he adapted his sense of orchestral colour to a big band. He was also heard on the soundtrack to the 1972 cartoon, Fritz The Cat.

Such albums - often collaborations with his wife, the singer/arranger Sheryl Kendrick, who died in 1985 - alternated with more conventional organ dates up to the 1990s, when Earland reverted to the old jazz and funk mix, acting as producer on his own albums and on those by other artists. Among the latter was his recent collaboration with vocalist Irene Reid, which I picked as a record of the year for no better reason than that I couldn't stop playing it. Earland's hand can be seen in the crafty arrangements and in the choice of unlikely songs, including a superb remake of More Today Than Yesterday.

Nicknamed the "Mighty Burner", no one was better than Earland at bringing music to the boil. The best tracks on his albums are usually the longest, where his solos recall Mae West's remarks about men who take their time. Earland seldom strays from a collection of familiar phrases, introduced casually over a chorus or so as his pounding bass lines cut through. Gradually, the whines, wheezes and tremelos predominate, a drone builds up steam and it's merely a question of how he manipulates yet another roof-raising climax.

Killer Joe was an example of improvisation at the perfect tempo being enhanced by the surrounding structure. There was hardly a wasted note and the surprise coda, based around a different tune given similar treatment, sets the seal on a masterpiece. He is survived by his wife Sheila and three children.

fields.bodyText: The jazz organist Charles Earland, who has died of a heart attack aged 58, was the most excitingly imaginative arranger linked to the Hammond B3 organ. Playing the instrument in 1970 he put together a 15-minute version of Killer Joe that ranks among the greatest live performances in jazz. He was trained as a saxophone player - making him an exception amidst hundreds of ex-pianists - approaching the organ orchestrally, like a swing bandleader born out of time. Any treatise on the use of background riffs to cushion and propel musicians must take his arranging work into account. His records sold well beyond the world of jazz buffs. He collaborated in the mid-1970s with Patrick Gleeson, the brains behind Herbie Hancock's early synthesized groups and, to judge by the cover versions, his favourites must have included Sly Stone and the way trumpets and saxophones buttressed the sparkling, jagged-edge funk purveyed by Stone's groups. Born in Philadelphia, Earland played saxophones in high school, a contemporary of future stars like Bobby Timmons, Lew Tabackin, Pat Martino and the then trumpeter and early 1960s pop star Frankie Avalon. Working with Jimmy McGriff, he took a fancy to the Hammond and was forever trying things out on McGriff's instrument. Shortly after forming his own group, Earland made the switch permanent, although he occasionally used a saxophone right to the end. He was also heard on the soundtrack to the 1972 cartoon, Fritz The Cat. Nicknamed the "Mighty Burner", no one was better than Earland at bringing music to the boil. Earland seldom strays from a collection of familiar phrases, introduced casually over a chorus or so as his pounding bass lines cut through. fields.headline: Harinder Veriah
fields.trailText: The lawyer Harinder Veriah, who has died aged 33, linked the worlds of Asia and the west. This Indian woman from a Sikh family in Kuala Lumpur working (as a rare south Asian) in a British law office in Hong Kong, and married to an Englishman, was a figure of outstanding promise, suddenly cut short.
fields.body:
The lawyer Harinder Veriah, who has died aged 33, linked the worlds of Asia and the west. This Indian woman from a Sikh family in Kuala Lumpur working (as a rare south Asian) in a British law office in Hong Kong, and married to an Englishman, was a figure of outstanding promise, suddenly cut short.

Eastern and western politics framed her life. In 1959, her father Karam Singh became the youngest MP in the first parliament of independent Malaysia, sitting for the Socialist Party. Shortly after Veriah's birth he was held in detention for four years for organising a militant march of rubber plantation workers.

Since 1994 she had been linked with a man of equally patent leftwing background, Marxism Today's Martin Jacques: they married in 1996.

A daughter of the generation that won freedom, she remained non-political, straddling and combining her worlds: proudly Malaysian, and multilingual, except in the ancestral Punjabi - the family spoke English.

Though she had practised law in Kuala Lumpur, it was brave to do so as an Asian woman in London on the strength of an external London LLB, even when supplemented in Britain by study for an LLM. Perhaps it was an appreciation of her achievement, as well as her quiet but confident mind, which impressed the City firm of Lovell's enough to take her on, first in London and, since 1998, in Hong Kong.

Veriah was remarkable in every respect: sharply, sometimes tartly,intelligent, but with a vast capacity to make friends; a committed full-time professional; and a devoted wife, and mother to her young son Ravi. She concealed her epileptic attacks, but one struck her down after she returned from a holiday visit to Hanoi with family and friends.

Eric Hobsbawn

fields.headline: Prudence Smith
fields.standfirst: Radio producer whose microphone 'captures' ranged from French existentialists to African statesmen
fields.trailText: Prudence Smith, who has died aged 76, was a philosopher queen who became a star of international radio, working for the BBC - both on the Third Programme and with the Open University.
fields.body:
Prudence Smith, who has died aged 76, was a philosopher queen who became a star of international radio, working for the BBC - both on the Third Programme and with the Open University.

Born in Johannesburg, she spent much of her childhood in the magical garden her mining-engineer father had created by allying water to the sunshine of the veldt. She loved the large, enclosed garden and its creator, and she loved her young black nanny, Lottie.

The only book she wrote, The Morning Light, about politics and gardening, is to be published soon in South Africa, and contains many scenes of her childhood. From about the age of seven, she would climb on to the roof of the carriage house, taking a newspaper to sit on as the tin roof was very hot, and look down on what was happening in the road outside, where she was forbidden to go.

"Sometimes there were gatherings of the neighbours' servants, men and women laughing together, who could rarely have much contact in the conditions of their captivity - if their regimes were anything like that in our house. And there were many, many tired and ragged men trudging from front gate to front gate asking for work. I did not know, then, about the natives land act of 1913, which, long before apartheid, effectively delivered tens of thousands of black peasants into servitude."

In roundabout ways she spent her life attacking apartheid, and encouraging others to do the same.

Smith became a student at Witswatersrand University of Johannesburg at the age of 16 and emerged with a degree in English and French. After teaching at Wits, she got a government scholarship to Oxford, to Somerville College, where she studied philosophy, and Latin and Greek history, language and litera ture. Janet Vaughan, the medical doctor and pioneering scientist, was the principal of Somerville, and became her lifelong friend.

After her Oxford studies, Smith became ever more meticulous, to my mind even pedantic, in the use of words. I remember once standing with her outside the Golders Green crematorium, both of us arguing fiercely about a word I had coined, meritocracy. It was to figure in the title of my book, The Rise of the Meritocracy. It combined a Latin and a Greek word and on that account, she said, I absolutely must not use it.

While at Somerville, she married Michael, a young English architect whom she had first met in South Africa.

After she left Oxford she became producer in the talks department of the BBC's Third Programme. It was the most highbrow station ever. John Reith, the director general, thought that, since the BBC of his time had a monopoly, it should serve minority audiences as faithfully as the generality. The Third Programme's mission was to get hold of the very best people in philosophy, literature, all the other arts and humanities, and in all the sciences, and persuade (not train) them to talk intelligibly for an appreciative audience. In his history of the Third Programme, The Envy of the World, Humphrey Carpenter chronicles some of the people Smith put on the air. Michael Ventris was one: it was on the programme that he first announced he had deciphered Linear B, the Minoan script.

Smith also got Iris Murdoch to talk for her, and Iris introduced her to Sartre and a whole school of French existentialists who became regular broadcasters.

During the 1950s, she also took her microphone to Africa's leaders such as Nyerere, Kaunda, Lumumba, and Luthuli.

Her next notable job, after a spell at home and at the Africa Division of Longmans publishers, was in the BBC again, but in a special unit where she was the production director for the Open University. She had to train its academics in how to put themselves across on the radio. From 1970-78 she shuttled back and forth between Alexandra Palace in north London (where the BBC studios were) and Milton Keynes, home of the OU. She and her colleagues in all parts of the OU blended radio and TV with corres-pondence courses and face-to-face tuition in what was to become the most important development in higher education in the 20th century.

After that, Smith became more of a freelance, starting a new educational radio station in Thailand, and working for the International Extension College in Somalia and Zambia. In the 1990s she at last returned to her beloved South Africa to train the first of a new generation of black educational radio producers in a new team with the name of Ulwazi (Knowledge).

One of the great experiences of her life was watching a great queue of people, many of them disabled, hobbling or being carried, to a Johannesburg polling station on election day in 1994, hoping, like them, that a beginning was to be made in repaying the debt to a million Lotties.

The great gardens she visited all over the world, and those she made herself, were metaphors for the cultivation of herself and her original country, in a world she could live in without shame, a little more beautiful, a little less unjust, a little more human.

Her husband died in 1971, but she is survived by three daughters and a son.

Michael Young
