fields.headline: Croatian centre-left in landslide victory
fields.trailText: Croatia moved into a new era yesterday as the centre-left opposition won a historic victory in the country's parliamentary elections.
fields.body:
Croatia moved into a new era yesterday as the centre-left opposition won a historic victory in the country's parliamentary elections.

With more than 80% of Monday's votes counted, 56% went to the alliance of Social Democrats and Social Liberals while the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ), the party of the late president Franjo Tudjman, claimed only 24%. The rest of the votes were shared by smaller parties.

The nationalist HDZ, which has ruled Croatia since 1990, has already conceded defeat.

Ivica Racan, 55, the Social Democratic leader almost certain to be the next prime minister, vowed to offer a "modest and moderate" government.

He said his priority would be to revitalise Croatia's ailing economy. Attention will now switch to the presidential election, due on January 24.

The fall of the HDZ will be seen as a signal by some of the 100,000 Croatian Serbs who are still living in exile that they may be able to return home.

The result is likely to have implications for the entire Balkan region. It was received coolly by the Serbian government but was welcomed by Muslim and Serb leaders in Bosnia.

"The outgoing government had a hypocritical policy towards Bosnia," said Mirko Galic, editor of the newspaper Globus. "While they were nominally for its unity and independence, what they actually did in practice was to try to divide it."

Perhaps the hardest foreign policy issue the new Croat government must face is its relationship with the UN war crimes tribunal at the Hague.

The west has accused Croatia of failing to respect human rights and of blocking the operations of the tribunal. Mr Racan vowed yesterday that in future Croatia would "be a good partner to the international community".

Later this year Croatia may be asked to hand over paramilitaries believed to be responsible for war crimes against ethnic Serbs during Operations Flash and Storm in 1995, when Croatia seized territories taken earlier by Serb forces.

webTitle: Two more arrests as FBI investigates 'bomb plot'

fields.headline: Two more arrests as FBI investigates 'bomb plot'
fields.trailText: Two more people have been arrested in Seattle and New York, FBI officials said yesterday, as investigators tried to break up a suspected terrorist network they believe was plotting a bomb attack against a US target .
fields.body:
Two more people have been arrested in Seattle and New York, FBI officials said yesterday, as investigators tried to break up a suspected terrorist network they believe was plotting a bomb attack against a US target .

One of the suspects, Abdelwaheb Hamdouche, a naturalised French citizen of Algerian origin, was detained as he prepared to board a flight to France on Saturday, and was held as a witness after a closed hearing of a federal court in New York on Monday.

The second man, Abdel Hakim Tizegha, an Algerian, was picked up on Christmas Eve after he entered the US from Canada by walking through woods along the border. According to court papers, he tried to flee when he was arrested.

He was charged on Monday in Seattle with entering the country illegally, but the FBI said it was also questioning him about his role in the suspected conspiracy.

Both men had links with Algerians already arrested in connection with the alleged plot. Mr Tizegha had been in contact with Ahmed Ressam, who faces five charges in connection with explosives and timing devices allegedly found in his car boot when he was picked up in mid-December as he was trying to drive across the Canadian-US border near Seattle.

Mr Tizegha is also a friend of Abdel Ghani, who is charged with acting as Mr Ressam's accomplice. Both Mr Ressam and Mr Ghani are thought to be members of the extremist Algerian movement, the Armed Islamic Group (GIA).

Mr Hamdouche, 34, who lived in the same building as Mr Ghani, was detained when Mr Ghani's flat was raided last week. He was released, only to be picked up again when he tried to leave the country.

It is still far from clear what the target of the suspected plot was supposed to be, but an FBI official said yesterday that it was likely that the bomb would have been timed to go off at New Year celebrations.

It is also unclear whether the suspects were acting on behalf of the GIA, which has never before targeted Americans, or whether they were working as "hired hands" for other militant Islamic groups. Mr Ressam is believed to have trained in Afghan guerrilla camps run by Osama Bin Laden, the Saudi fugitive millionaire suspected of masterminding bomb attacks on US embassies in Africa in 1998.

Graham Fuller, a specialist on Islamic extremism and a former CIA analyst, said: "I'm a little sceptical about the possibility that the GIA is now targeting us because it would have been accompanied by some kind of rhetoric. Therefore I would speculate that these guys are working on their own or hired by someone else."

And Mr Fuller argued that Mr Ressam's Afghan training was not conclusive evidence of a Bin Laden connection.

"Virtually every serious mujahed, every Islamic fighter, would have been in Afghanistan, would have received training for building car bombs, and would probably have come across Bin Laden. We have to be careful when we talk about 'links'."

fields.headline: Train disaster kills seven.
fields.standfirst: British skiers in heroic fire rescue
fields.trailText: At least seven people died and dozens were injured yesterday when two passenger trains carrying 96 people collided in Norway. A fire on one of the trains, right, hampered efforts to locate victims, and police feared that the death toll could rise.
fields.body:
At least seven people died and dozens were injured yesterday when two passenger trains carrying 96 people collided in Norway. A fire on one of the trains, right, hampered efforts to locate victims, and police feared that the death toll could rise.

"It can take easily until tomorrow morning before we can get into the train," said a local police spokesman, Ove Osjelten. "There are still people in the trains. I can't even guess how many."

A British skier on one of the trains described how he and seven friends dragged injured passengers away as diesel fuel sprayed into the wreckage from an overturned locomotive, fuelling a massive fireball.

Ben Stephenson, a geologist, 30, from Chester, said a number of passengers were obviously dead inside his group's carriage, but others were trapped behind seats and tables, unable to escape.

"The fire was coming down the train very quickly and we needed to get people out before they were burned alive," he said. "We had to scramble out of the broken window on to the track, where we were helped by local villagers."

The Britons, in their 20s and 30s, were travelling north from Hamar, on the way home at the end of a seven-day skiing holiday, when their train collided head-on with a train travelling south from Trondheim, at about 1.30pm, 110 miles north of Oslo.

"Without warning there was an almighty bang and the train rocked on to its side and burst into flames," Mr Stephenson said.

He and fellow survivors were taken to nearby homes where they were wrapped in blankets and given hot drinks.

He said they had lost all their luggage in the fire. "We have nothing at all left, everything was burned including our passports."

The British group, none of whom was seriously hurt, is staying at a hotel close to the crash scene.

The counting of victims was last night being complicated by the injured being sent to different hospitals and some of the unhurt passengers walking away from the site. Between 20 and 22 were unaccounted for. Agencies

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Six shot dead by Algerian rebels
Six civilians were killed and 14 were wounded when gunmen, thought to be radical Muslim rebels, raided a village in Algeria on Monday.
fields.body:
Six shot dead by Algerian rebels
Six civilians were killed and 14 were wounded when gunmen, thought to be radical Muslim rebels, raided a village in Algeria on Monday.

The attackers fled Haouch Germain, 40 miles west of Algiers, after a policeman fired back. The violence comes as a January 13 deadline for Muslim rebels to claim amnesty approaches. The largest rebel group, the GIA, has rejected a proposed peace deal as a sellout. Reuters, Tipaza.

Storms cost France £7.5bn
The total bill from the storms that swept France between Christmas and the new year could run to £7.5bn, according to estimates yesterday.

The two days of 100mph-plus gales caused more than 90 deaths and huge damage to buildings, businesses and agriculture. The forestry sector was hardest hit, losing up to 270m trees. Jon Henley, Paris

Swedish police in arson arrests
Three men have been arrested on suspicion of carrying out a 1998 arson attack on an overcrowded dance hall in Gothenburg in which 63 teenagers were killed and 200 were injured, Swedish police said yesterday.

webTitle: Angolan rebels accused of killing French children

fields.headline: Angolan rebels accused of killing French children
fields.trailText: The Namibian army has accused Angola's Unita rebels of killing two French children and their adult brother in an ambush on Monday night. Several people were wounded in the attack on four cars just inside the Namibian border, including a Briton who was taken to the capital Windhoek for an emergency operation.
fields.body:
The Namibian army has accused Angola's Unita rebels of killing two French children and their adult brother in an ambush on Monday night. Several people were wounded in the attack on four cars just inside the Namibian border, including a Briton who was taken to the capital Windhoek for an emergency operation.

A group of men in combat uniform opened fire on the vehicles near a Namibian military base on the edge of the Caprivi game reserve. Two girls, 10 and 15, and their brother, 18, were shot dead and their father severely injured. There were unconfirmed reports that two other people may also have died.

The first two vehicles, including one carrying the French family, were brought to a halt by a barrage of bullets. Both cars had been looted by the time police arrived.

The other two vehicles were carrying 14 workers with a Danish aid agency. They were mostly Britons, South Africans and Australians returning from a holiday in Zimbabwe. Both drivers were wounded but managed to speed away.

Namibian police said that a British woman, Syma Damil, was among those taken to the capital for emergency operations yesterday.

Last week the Foreign Office advised Britons to avoid the Caprivi strip, after the Angolan army launched an offensive to dislodge Unita from its southern strongholds.

The army's chief of staff, Major General Martin Shalli, accused Unita of the killings, but a rebel spokesman blamed Angolan government soldiers.

The incident took place near a Namibian military base used by Angolan soldiers for cross-border attacks on Unita. The attacks have helped to drive the rebels from their former headquarters at Jamba.

The government claims to have secured the 750-mile border, but Unita appears able to continue its incursions.

At the weekend, about 20 civilians were abducted near Bagani, in western Caprivi, a short drive from the site of Monday's killings. Eight people were wounded, four of them seriously, in the attack. The police again blamed Unita, saying that the attackers had planted landmines and retreated into Angola.

Namibians living near the frontier say they have regularly been robbed by armed bandits since the war escalated. Many have fled their homes. Villagers also report seeing Unita moving freely on the Angolan side of the river which forms the border.

The Namibia Press Agency reported that Unita sent a letter to a village chief on Sunday saying that its forces would soon arrive to collect medicine from a clinic in the area.

Namibia's paramilitary Special Field Force, which is responsible for rounding up illegal immigrants, has added to the tensions in the area. The force has been accused of beating Namibians suspected of harbouring Angolan refugees.

fields.headline: Santana tops Grammy list nominations
fields.trailText: The much-trumpeted explosion in the popularity of Latin-based music was acknowledged by the music industry's Grammy award nominations yesterday, though the focus of attention was a 52-year-old rock warhorse rather than a snake-hipped youth.
fields.body:
The much-trumpeted explosion in the popularity of Latin-based music was acknowledged by the music industry's Grammy award nominations yesterday, though the focus of attention was a 52-year-old rock warhorse rather than a snake-hipped youth.

Ricky Martin may have won the battle of the magazine covers through the past year but it was Carlos Santana, whose sound was fashioned in the San Francisco of the 1960s, who was favoured with most nominations.

Santana, who could claim to have predated the world music genre by 20 years, was named in 10 categories, including best record and album for Supernatural which, at almost five million copies, was one of the biggest sellers in the United States last year.

The record is the guitarist's first collection of new material in seven years, though he has continued touring, peppering long sets with musings about Miles Davis, Bob Marley and the future of the planet.

"This CD is a miracle from beginning to end," he said, warming to the speech patterns of the decade on which he first left his mark. "Music has enormous power, like a shaman. It takes you to a place where time doesn't exist any more, gravity doesn't exist, fear doesn't exist."

Supernatural includes collaborations with Eric Clapton, Lauryn Hill and Dave Matthews. The single Smooth, with Matchbox 20 singer Rob Thomas, made it to number one on the Billboard charts and is in the running for record of the year and best pop performance with vocals.

Santana, installed in the Rock'n'Roll Hall of Fame a year ago, was ignored by the Grammys in the 60s and 70s but he did win one in the rock instrumental category with Blues for Salvador in 1988.

The awards, decided by 10,000 members of the academy, will be handed out in Los Angeles next month. Santana faces competition for the best album prize from the Backstreet Boys with Millennium, the Dixie Chicks and Fly, Diana Krall's When I Look In Your Eyes and TLC's Fanmail.

Nominations for best new artist contain a surprise, the inclusion of the relatively obscure blues guitarist Susan Tedeschi alongside the R&B singer Macy Gray and the teenage pop stars Christina Aguilera and Britney Spears. TLC made in on to six lists, the same as the conductor Pierre Boulez, and one more than the western swing old-timers Asleep At The Wheel. Emmylou Harris, The Backstreet Boys, the Dixie Chicks, Lauryn Hill - a big winner last year - and Whitney Houston, each have three nominations.

Martin, the Puerto Rican poster boy for Latin pop, was not overlooked entirely. Livin' La Vida Loca made the record of the year list and the album Ricky Martin was included in the best pop category.

fields.headline: Woman awakes after 16 years
fields.standfirst: Patient asks for pizza after shock recovery from vegetative state
fields.trailText: If life seems a bit of a blur after the holidays, think of Patti White Bull, who woke up on Christmas Eve after spending the previous 16 years as a catatonic statue, unable to speak, swallow or move.
fields.body:
If life seems a bit of a blur after the holidays, think of Patti White Bull, who woke up on Christmas Eve after spending the previous 16 years as a catatonic statue, unable to speak, swallow or move.

When Ms White Bull lost consciousness delivering her fourth child, Ronald Reagan was president, the Soviet Union was still the "evil empire" and no one had heard of the world wide web. She awoke, aged 42, on the brink of the 21st century.

Her first words were: "Don't do that" to a group of astonished nurses who were going through the daily routine of fixing her bed at a residential home in Albuquerque, New Mexico. Her mother, Snowflake Flower, was summoned, and declared it a Christmas miracle. Indeed her daughter's first words to her were reported to be "Merry Christmas".

The doctors were equally dumbfounded by the sudden recovery. "I've never seen anything like this," said Elliot Marcus, a specialist in long-term care at the Las Palomas nursing and rehabilitation centre. "I can't come up with a medical explanation."

No one is quite sure what, if anything, Ms White Bull, was thinking during her long vegetative interlude. She is still struggling to relearn a basic vocabulary, which should eventually allow her to describe her experience. Her hands are just beginning to loosen after being clenched in a 16-year fist.

Her children, who had been told that their mother would never wake up, rushed to her bedside. "I just went up to her and gave her a hug and she gave me a hug back," said Cindi, her oldest daughter. "It was the first time she had ever hugged back. It was scary at first."

Once she could walk with the aid of a stick, Ms White Bull's first request was to head to the nearest shopping mall, where she had a slice of pizza. Later, she was driven up into the New Mexico mountains to breathe the mountain air. Pointing to a new pair of training shoes, she told journalists: "I'm going to run."

Ms White Bull's case is a boon to opponents of euthanasia, who argue that the human body has extraordinary powers of recovery and should be kept alive at all costs. According to Dr Marcus, the 26-year-old Sioux woman originally fell into her semi-vegetative state after complications during a caesarean section. A blood clot lodged in her lung and she stopped breathing and her heart stopped beating. She was resuscitated but suffered brain damage from lack of oxygen.

After that she lay in bed being fed through a tube into her stomach and drained through a catheter, but she was not in a total coma. Her eyes stayed open, and would occasionally move. Ms White Bull sometimes crossed her legs or moved her arms, but she showed no significant response to pain and she never communicated.

However, Dr Marcus warned that Ms White Bull's hold on consciousness could be temporary - she could remain at her current level of functioning, she could improve or she could fall back into the semi-vegetative state.

Her former husband, Mark, stayed in Albuquerque for three years after she entered the catatonic state, but then moved with their children to the Standing Rock Sioux reservation in South Dakota, where he took a job in the tribal government. "I grew to accept that nothing was going to change," he said.

He filed for divorce, but when asked this week whether the couple had a future, he replied: "If she recovers and she wants to re-establish a relationship with me, I'm here."

webTitle: Fonda and Turner put marriage on pause

fields.headline: Fonda and Turner put marriage on pause
fields.trailText: Ted Turner, the man who gave the world 24-hour television news, chose the medium of the moment - the internet - to announce last night that he and his wife Jane Fonda are splitting up.
fields.body:
Ted Turner, the man who gave the world 24-hour television news, chose the medium of the moment - the internet - to announce last night that he and his wife Jane Fonda are splitting up.

The news came after persistent reports that all was not well in the nine-year union of Mr Turner, the mercurial founder of CNN and vice-chairman of Time Warner, and Ms Fonda, an Oscar-winning member of one of the American cinema's best known acting families.

The couple said in a statement on CNN's website: "While we continue to be committed to the long-term success of our marriage, we find ourselves at a juncture where we must each take some personal time for ourselves. Therefore we have mutually decided to spend some time apart. We ask you to respect this decision."

Mr Turner, 61, who started CNN in 1980 against all advice to the contrary, floated the idea last year of running for president but said that his wife was against it.

Ms Fonda, 62, known as Hanoi Jane for her opposition to the US war in Vietnam, won her academy award for her performance in the 1971 movie Klute but has appeared rarely on screen since she married Mr Turner nearly a decade ago.

She is the daughter of the late Hollywood screen legend Henry Fonda. Her brother is Peter Fonda, star of the counter-culture classic Easy Rider. The actress Bridget Fonda is her niece.

Both components of the pairing of media flair and screen sheen have been married three times and they were reported early last year to have had counselling. "Jane wants me to be a saint, but I'm not," he said more than 14 months ago.

CNN became the hub of a media empire. Turner Broadcasting System merged with Time Warner in 1996.

And there was evidence two years ago of the saintliness Ms Fonda sought when Mr Turner donated $1bn to the United Nations for medicine, food and aid programmes.

He said at the time: "When I got my statement in January, I was worth $2.2bn. Then I got another statement in August that said I was worth $3.2bn. So I figure it's only nine months' earnings. Who cares?"

fields.headline: Tight security surrounds Egyptian burials
fields.trailText: Under tight security, priests conducted funeral prayers yesterday for the 18 Christians killed in clashes with Muslims in southern Egypt as villagers taunted police for failing to contain the violence.
fields.body:
Under tight security, priests conducted funeral prayers yesterday for the 18 Christians killed in clashes with Muslims in southern Egypt as villagers taunted police for failing to contain the violence.

Armed policemen riding armoured vehicles surrounded the church where the prayers were conducted for the victims killed in Sunday's violence in the nearby al-Kosheh village, 275 miles south of the capital, Cairo.

No relatives or local people were allowed inside the small church, while most shops remained shut for third day in Dar el-Salam, a Muslim-dominated town. After the funeral, police took the coffins to al-Kosheh, six miles away, for burial at a cemetery there.

Two others were also killed in the clashes - one Muslim who was buried earlier, and another victim who had not been identified.

The unprecedented police involvement in the funeral was evidence of the government's efforts to ensure the sectarian furore does not flare up again.

In Cairo, the information minister, Safwat el-Sherif, said: "The government will severely react against any attempt at instigation." The cabinet had taken several steps to "confront the extremist elements and instigators from both sides", he said.

Although minority Christians often complain of discrimination and occasional violence at the hands of Muslims in Egypt, the two communities have generally lived together peacefully. Al-Kosheh, however, has proved to be a tinderbox in the simmering tensions.

fields.headline: Exile on mean street
fields.standfirst: Newport, Gwent, is officially Britain's most violent town.  Stephen Moss, who grew up there, looks at how a solid Welsh community has been overtaken by drink, drugs and deprivation
fields.trailText: Newport, Gwent, is officially Britain's most violent town.  Stephen Moss, who grew up there, looks at how a solid Welsh community has been overtaken by drink, drugs and deprivation
fields.body:
Newport is a chameleon. In the 60s it was at the forefront of industrial growth, with the massive Llanwern steelworks as its centrepiece; in the 70s and 80s it suffered a catastrophic collapse of its economic and social infrastruture; in the 90s it re-emerged as an economic force, thanks to the growth of electronic and computer companies along the M4 corridor, and was hailed as Britain's answer to Seattle because of its association with a slew of new rock bands. Now, on the basis of crime figures released this week, it has been tagged "the most violent town in Britain", not an accolade you want to shout about.

Newport is also in the running to be given city status - to become, in effect, the first new British city of the millennium. It is an outsider in a large field, well behind such squeaky-clean favourites as Milton Keynes, but it would surely be an obvious choice - a declaration of intent, and of war against the criminals.

I should declare an interest. Newport is my home town. I grew up and went to school there in the 60s and early 70s when, while far from perfect, it was economically buoyant and socially cohesive. I left to go to university and witnessed what happened over the next couple of decades from afar. But, in my view, the decline of the town offers salutary lessons for us all.

Even in Britain's most violent town - 2,039 violent crimes per 100,000 people in 1998-99, according to new home office figures, well above London and Manchester in per capita terms - all things are relative, and my relatives insist that a sense of perspective is kept. It is not downtown Washington and the principal weapon is the fist, not the gun. Much of the violence occurs at the weekend when Newport lives up to its reputation as Wales's rock capital. Crowds of clubbers swarm around the rundown city centre and visitors from the valleys do battle with the locals.

But some of the crimes are much more than drunken yobbery. On New Year's Day, 40-year-old Shaun Mahoney died in an arson attack on his house near the town centre, one of four attacks in the same area. One more senseless crime from which it would be dangerous to draw too many inferences but a tragic way to greet the new millennium.

The local council's executive service leader, Bob Bright, issued a statement yesterday. Clearly, he sees it as a problem that surfaces at chucking-out time. "As a council we have taken steps through our licensing committee and have also introduced a noise abatement zone which will help to tackle this problem," he said. The police also seem to believe that drink and drug-fuelled weekend violence is the key. "We get up to 8,000 people coming to Newport on Friday nights," Chief Inspector Ray Wise was quoted as saying. "It is not surprising we get violence."

In Chief Inspector Wise's view, the violence is almost a product of Newport's success - of being a magnet for clubbers and music fans. But such a view is far too rosy and overlooks the fact that many of the town's long-term problems - the steady rise in drug use and crime over the past 20 years - are the result of economic decline and social dislocation.

In the 60s, Llanwern had a labour force of more than 10,000. In the 70s that began to fall and privatisation in 1988 accelerated the process. The total number of those employed was more than halved; but equally debilitating was the fact that many remaining jobs became contract-based. A large, stable workforce was replaced by a smaller, much less stable one.

The Newport I knew was an old-fashioned, undeniably macho place. Men worked in steel, chemicals or at the docks; women were slowly entering the labour force. Life revolved around home, pub and sport, especially rugby. In the 60s and early 70s, Newport RFC - the team of David Watkins and Keith Jarrett - was a match for any side in the world, including the All Blacks who went down to a famous defeat in 1963. That, a generation later, Newport were languishing and this season have been rescued only by the deep pockets of a millionaire is symptomatic of what happened to the town: a confident working-class community has been undermined and is now at the mercy of the market.

I lived on a vast housing estate which was almost completely crime free. I went to a comprehensive school with 2,000 pupils which, without appearing to recognise the minor miracle it was achieving, taught everything from Oxbridge entrance to remedial forestry. When I was there, the sixth form numbered more than 150 and five in my year applied for Oxbridge. The rugby team - coached by JPR Williams and a host of Welsh stars - was brilliant; the under-13 soccer team, coached by an old Newport County stalwart, unbeatable.

There was little other culture to speak of in the town - none of the great valleys choirs, no backbone of religious non-conformity, none of the multi-cultural energy of Cardiff's docklands. The society was based on economic confidence: working-class men expressed themselves through work; the bonds between them relied on what they did, what they produced. Once that was taken away, so was the town's raison d'être.

Estates became riven with drugs; crime spread in their wake; good, confident schools became sinks; teachers - always accorded great respect in Wales - lost their self-belief. Welsh-speaking Wales clawed back some of that confidence in the 80s with the state-sponsored rebirth of the language, but this English-speaking no-man's land in the east felt excluded from that renaissance, resentful of the money poured into the launch of a channel in Welsh for a country in which only a fifth of the population speak the language.

A community needs a focus, a means of cultural expression. Newport had none. What do you tell a 14-year-old at a failing school with no prospects of a stable job? How do you build a cohesive community when such a high proportion of men are unemployed or have taken early retirement? How does a society that was based on community and solidarity adapt to a world that runs on possessive individualism?

Newport has yet to find a confident cultural voice to replace what a decade of Thatcherism destroyed. It is alienated from New Labour - it is no coincidence that this is where Arthur Scargill, founder of the Socialist Labour Party, chose to stand in the 1997 general election, opposing the Conservative defector Alan Howarth - and feels no affinity with even the half-hearted nationalism that produced the Welsh assembly. There is a vacuum that drink, drugs and crime fill, in Newport and across the valleys. That is both a tragedy and a condemnation of our complacent metropolitan political class. It is not Friday night that is the problem but Monday morning; not play but work.

In the 60s it was at the forefront of industrial growth, with the massive Llanwern steelworks as its centrepiece; in the 70s and 80s it suffered a catastrophic collapse of its economic and social infrastruture; in the 90s it re-emerged as an economic force, thanks to the growth of electronic and computer companies along the M4 corridor, and was hailed as Britain's answer to Seattle because of its association with a slew of new rock bands. Now, on the basis of crime figures released this week, it has been tagged "the most violent town in Britain", not an accolade you want to shout about. Newport is also in the running to be given city status - to become, in effect, the first new British city of the millennium. It is an outsider in a large field, well behind such squeaky-clean favourites as Milton Keynes, but it would surely be an obvious choice - a declaration of intent, and of war against the criminals. I should declare an interest. Newport is my home town. I grew up and went to school there in the 60s and early 70s when, while far from perfect, it was economically buoyant and socially cohesive. I left to go to university and witnessed what happened over the next couple of decades from afar. But, in my view, the decline of the town offers salutary lessons for us all. Even in Britain's most violent town - 2,039 violent crimes per 100,000 people in 1998-99, according to new home office figures, well above London and Manchester in per capita terms - all things are relative, and my relatives insist that a sense of perspective is kept. It is not downtown Washington and the principal weapon is the fist, not the gun. Much of the violence occurs at the weekend when Newport lives up to its reputation as Wales's rock capital. Crowds of clubbers swarm around the rundown city centre and visitors from the valleys do battle with the locals. But some of the crimes are much more than drunken yobbery. On New Year's Day, 40-year-old Shaun Mahoney died in an arson attack on his house near the town centre, one of four attacks in the same area. One more senseless crime from which it would be dangerous to draw too many inferences but a tragic way to greet the new millennium. The local council's executive service leader, Bob Bright, issued a statement yesterday. Clearly, he sees it as a problem that surfaces at chucking-out time. "As a council we have taken steps through our licensing committee and have also introduced a noise abatement zone which will help to tackle this problem," he said. The police also seem to believe that drink and drug-fuelled weekend violence is the key. "We get up to 8,000 people coming to Newport on Friday nights," Chief Inspector Ray Wise was quoted as saying. "It is not surprising we get violence." In Chief Inspector Wise's view, the violence is almost a product of Newport's success - of being a magnet for clubbers and music fans. But such a view is far too rosy and overlooks the fact that many of the town's long-term problems - the steady rise in drug use and crime over the past 20 years - are the result of economic decline and social dislocation. In the 60s, Llanwern had a labour force of more than 10,000. In the 70s that began to fall and privatisation in 1988 accelerated the process. The total number of those employed was more than halved; but equally debilitating was the fact that many remaining jobs became contract-based. A large, stable workforce was replaced by a smaller, much less stable one. The Newport I knew was an old-fashioned, undeniably macho place. Men worked in steel, chemicals or at the docks; women were slowly entering the labour force. Life revolved around home, pub and sport, especially rugby. In the 60s and early 70s, Newport RFC - the team of David Watkins and Keith Jarrett - was a match for any side in the world, including the All Blacks who went down to a famous defeat in 1963. I lived on a vast housing estate which was almost completely crime free. I went to a comprehensive school with 2,000 pupils which, without appearing to recognise the minor miracle it was achieving, taught everything from Oxbridge entrance to remedial forestry. fields.headline: Pavarotti
fields.body:
Age: 63

Appearance: Corpulent, crowd-pleasing opera singer, chat-show guest and Spice Girl escort.

Italian chappie, isn't he? Interesting question, actually. Everyone assumes that's the case - and he was born in the northern Italian university town of Modena - but since 1983 he's been registered as residing in Monte Carlo in the Mediterranean tax haven of Monaco.

But surely that's just a sensible financial strategy for a multi-millionaire musician. Perhaps - but Italy's fiscal authorities reckon Don Luciano has been gambling on even higher stakes than the rest of Monaco's casino-addicted population. They've landed him with a weighty £5m bill in back taxes, arguing that he has really spent the past decade domiciled in his homeland. The singer initially resisted the claim, but this week, according to an Italian newspaper, he's finally decided to face the music.

How was the authorities' suspicion aroused? It could have something to do with the fact that his Monte Carlo apartment has less than 100sq metres of floor space - an insufficient area to accommodate his family, as the Italians tactfully put it. Meanwhile, back home, the maestro whiled away his days in a £2m, 15-residence village outside Modena, and a hillside villa complex in Pesaro.

So now he'll be tightening his belt? A most unappetising image, but yes. He's chosen to pay the first £1.7m in 36 monthly instalments, even though that means incurring an extra £145,000 in interest charges.

£145,000? I've had better deals on extended warranties from Dixons. It's a sort of "Confess now, pay later" arrangement. And Pavarotti needs it: he's still expensively embroiled in a costly divorce settlement with his former wife and business manager Adua Veroni.

Forthcoming appearances: The Cunning Little Vixen; The Remarriage of Figaro.

Do say: "How extraordinarily clever of the Italian tax authorities to make five million out of a tenor."

Don't say: "Hello? Reader's Editor? There's an appalling homophone near the end of today's Pass Notes."

fields.headline: Sound of a painting
fields.standfirst: She danced with Clark Gable, drank with Dylan Thomas and wrote for Muriel Spark. And although she is completely blind, her first love is collecting art.  Lynn Bushell  meets IM Birtwistle in her caravan gallery
fields.trailText: She danced with Clark Gable, drank with Dylan Thomas and wrote for Muriel Spark. And although she is completely blind, her first love is collecting art.  Lynn Bushell  meets IM Birtwistle in her caravan gallery
fields.body:
Gertrude Stein claimed that bells rang in her head whenever she met a genius. They rang, she declared, triumphantly, when she met Picasso. IM Birtwistle recognises works of art by the vibrations they give off. She has a bell, too, to summon her assistant, as she is totally blind. It isn't just this that sets her apart from the common run of humanity, however. It is the fact that she combines her blindness with an obsession for collecting works of art. In a caravan on the north Norfolk coast, she has amassed a collection of contemporary art unrivalled even in the galleries of Cork Street.

It isn't the most accessible of venues. Arriving at the caravan, which is of the cardboard 50s variety rather than the modern house on wheels sort, one feels rather as a pilgrim entering Santiago da Compostela in the 12th century might have felt - glad to be there, but not yet certain whether the relics will justify the journey.

She lives in the house opposite the grove of pear trees protecting the caravan. Just as the paintings crowd together without ceremony, so do the rooms of her home, lovingly accommodating themselves to the extraordinary personality of the occupier.

It is a Miss Havisham house. Nothing has been thrown away, and a fine layer of dust lies over everything. Photographs, pottery, dried flowers, books and paintings jostle for space on every available surface. A cardboard box on the floor is labelled "Poetry". Birtwistle, after a brief flirtation with art at the Reiman School, found that she had more to say as a poet and photographer. Her work was published in Horizon, the New English Weekly and Poetry Review, edited by Muriel Spark, who has become a close friend.

"I was lucky," she says. "In those days I seemed to be able to publish everything I wrote. But when I started going blind, over 40 years ago, I couldn't see the shape of the words on the page, and I need to. I'm a very visual person."

In 1951 she was introduced to Robert Graves, who had expressed admiration for her work. She visited him in his menage in Majorca and, despite his avowed paganism, both spiritual and sexual, remained fascinated: "It was like being caught up in an electrical storm."

His books, too, adorn the bookshelves. "I can't get rid of anything," she says, "even if I can't use it any more. The present and the past are locked together."

The twilight rooms, crammed with beloved objects and bric-a-brac and lit only from the skylight above, create a sense of time suspended. Even the photograph of Nick Cave with its fond dedication has a curiously 30s feel to it.

She compares Cave to Thomas Merton, the scholar, poet, Trappist monk and writer: "Nick rushes through one's life like a meteor, sharing his ideas like sharp and brilliant stars. As a blind old bat I have been much moved by his perspicacious care while acting on my behalf as a two-legged guide dog."

Blindness makes the difference between day and night less vital. She wakes any time after four in the morning, but won't answer the telephone or receive visitors before 11am. Breakfast is half a banana, which is good for her arthritis, and half a pint of coffee, which isn't.

She has normally finished giving audiences and running the gallery by 5pm, has a nap until 10pm and then settles into the night-time hours with Book at Bedtime and the World Service and a stash of classical CDs.

She drinks only in company, "coming as I do from a long line of alcoholics", and she thinks about death all the time, not in a fearful way, but merely as the next stage.

She is a curious mixture of the frail and the forceful. There is a disturbing physical resemblance to Lady Thatcher in the mouth and the cheekbones, but then the hat and the rings are pure Quentin Crisp. She is a staunch Catholic and "racks the rosary every day", but then, as she says despairingly, you can only try and fail. Living gets in the way.

As far as art is concerned, she is unequivocal. "If you see a work of art you want, you should be prepared to kill for it." Her artists also have to be completely committed. Each of the 12 (the number seems symbolic) submits his or her entire collection of drawings, sketches, working studies. It is all or nothing with Birtwistle.

There are more than 3,000 works here, including those of David Greenall, a former fisherman who now commands four-figure sums. In the days of her first gallery in the WI hall in Walberswick, Philip Sutton and Jefferey Camp were among her artists, and she sold Hockney drawings for £5 each.

She insists on you handling each painting; most are unprotected, perhaps so that you too can experience the vibrations. Not surprisingly, it is texture Birtwistle responds to principally, but she rejects the suggestion that blindness would make collecting sculpture more reliable. At present Rosalind Stracey, now in her 90s, is the only sculptor in the group.

"I don't need to touch art to know its value. When I'm asked to judge something I leave it in a corner of the room and wait for it to work on me. I can hear and sense a painting."

In the past, her extrasensory perceptions sometimes surfaced inconveniently. A family picnic ended when she suddenly insisted on putting everything back into the hamper and leaving the spot immediately. She afterwards found that there had been a gallows on the site.

During the blitz, when she was driving ambulances, she stopped one night at a club for something to eat, only to find herself unable to get out of the vehicle. "I discovered afterwards that the infamous satanist Aleister Crowley was inside." Despite its horrors, the war was a good time for "Lilla", as her close friends call her. She doesn't divulge her Christian name lightly: "It would make me too vulnerable."

The Birtwistles were an old established Red Rose family in Lancashire. "Life was made comfortable by loyal servants, nannies and governesses. There were always skating parties, balls and dances. The war simply continued that. Before joining WRNS, I drove for the MTC and then the US army and met Generals Patton and Bradley. I danced with Clark Gable and drank with Dylan Thomas in the Mandrake Club. It was all tremendous fun, and there were so many gorgeous young men about. Sticking with one would have been like only having one chocolate out of the box."

Her Catholicism has never got in the way of her enjoyment of life, but it remains a vital background corollary. Behind the appreciation of literature and music, the love of company and the sensuous hunger for colour and texture, there is a stern morality. Art and life are inextricably tied.

Her brave and outstanding collection of work deserves to be seen by thousands, not just the handful that make the trek to Burnham Deepdale each year and feel fortunate to have found the place, let alone be let in.

And yet it is this that contributes to the quality of the experience. Inevitably, it is only a matter of time before her artists are whisked away to show their work in glossier and more salubrious venues and the caravan is boarded up and abandoned.

This is a pity. She is one of the last true eccentrics. She and her artists are of a piece; they are thoroughly at home in their caravan. Like Mole and Ratty on the riverbank, they need protection from toads and weasels but they should never be brought "inside".

 Deepdale Exhibitions, Burnham Deepdale, Norfolk (closed Tues/Weds). Call 01485 210781

fields.headline: Welcome to planet Nerd
fields.standfirst: Jim White on: The bug hoodwink |  Helping police with their  enquiries | Branagh in the  Blair mould
fields.trailText: Jim White on: The bug hoodwink |  Helping police with their  enquiries | Branagh in the  Blair mould
fields.body:
Remember a film called Revenge of the Nerds? Thought not. In truth it was not Hollywood's finest moment. Released in 1984, the movie is a sub-Animal House student romp centring on a group of pizza-faced boffins who, fed up with years of bullying at the hands of the jock establishment, wreak allegedly humorous campus havoc by re-programming the college computer. In the process they win over the pneumatic cheer-leading sorority who obligingly remove their bras in admiration.

When his feeble effort plunged straight to video, little did the director Peter Samuelson realise that, 16 years later, the movie would provide the perfect commentary on our times. As the last few days have proved, the Nerds have got their revenge: the 21st century belongs to them. Not only do Nerds officially occupy most of the higher positions in the world's rich list, they have now assumed a position of absolute power over all our lives. Young, clever and knowledgable in way which we techno-Luddites cannot imagine, we are terrified of them. We will do anything they tell us, throw any amount of money in their direction, just as long as they keep our computers working.

On a local scale, we all fall into the thrall of the Nerd the moment we buy a PC, something we are constantly told we must do if we wish to keep apace with the revolution out there. In some barn on a ring road, a youth with perma-gelled hair fills your head with talk of mega rams and sends you home with a ludicrously expensive machine apparently capable of launching the space shuttle but incapable, you discover the moment you switch it on, of printing a letter.

So you call a telephone support operative, sitting in an aircraft hangar somewhere near Dumfries. There is nothing in the world capable of inducing a volcanic loss of temper as quickly as a telephone support operative, especially when they ask if Sir has plugged the computer in yet. As they utter platitudes in that jargon-filled argot designed entirely to make you feel stupid, you splutter: "But don't your realise my business depends on this?" And when they respond with a meaningful "Ah well, if Sir is using the computer for business purposes, Sir should have bought a business machine in the first place," you find your mouse has been smashed into a dozen pieces beneath your fist.

So you ring a Nerd prepared to come for a house visit, even though his hourly call-out rate matches that of a libel QC. Like a digital garage mechanic or roofing contractor, he sucks through his teeth on his arrival and tells you that you need an extra giga-byte, with hard disk overdrive. And because you haven't a clue what he is talking about, you take his word and pay up, softened by his console-side manner, the technological equivalent of old ladies who make over their entire will to the doctor who speaks kindly to them on their death beds.

So it was with the millennium bug. Few of us could quite understand why it was that our microwave would be confused by the change of century into thinking it was preparing M&S chicken madras on January 1 1900, and thus refuse to defrost, but if a Nerd told us that would happen we believed them. Then we paid them whatever they told us was necessary to make sure that come the day, our curry cooked in time. At the BBC, for instance, more than £10m was spent getting the corporation compliant. That's enough to have kept Des Lynam. Well, almost.

Encouraged by uber-Nerd John Birt, fighting the bug was given top priority at the Beeb. Distinguished programme-makers found themselves bullied by 23-year-old computer boffins telling them they couldn't do anything until the bug was sorted. I know this because I met the BBC's Y2K supremo just before Christmas. Disarmingly cheerful as the predicted armageddon approached, he had clearly had the time of his life this past year, as anyone would when operating in the joyous knowledge that everyone will do whatever you tell them. After a taste of being in charge he wasn't going to let anything as trivial as the arrival of 2000 see him out of a job.

"There's going to be plenty of follow-up work all through next year," he told me.

So prevalent was the Nerd agenda at the BBC that, during the marathon television coverage of the millennium, a rumour swept TV Centre as midnight passed in Moscow that the bug had triggered a nuclear assault and the missiles were on their way. For a few moments, panic gripped the studio; everyone was going to die, and all because the Russians couldn't be arsed to ring the government help line.

Bizarrely, even though in the end nothing happened, even though poor Peter Snow's Bugometer only twitched briefly in the direction of a tax office in Gabon, the Nerds have still come out of it all smelling of cash and influence. They tell us nothing went wrong, not because there was never any threat in the first place, but because relevant, pricey precautions were taken. This is the really clever bit of the Nerd revenge: since we don't know, we can't gainsay them. And so we yield afresh to the new masters of the universe.

My part in the Cézanne heist

Living a few doors down from Oxford's Ashmolean museum, scene of the New Year's Eve Cézanne heist, I have been involved for the first time in my life in that great British institution: the house-to-house inquiry. Ever since the robbery, our street has been filled with police, large men in para-military garb with macho displays of hardwear dangling from their belts staring into our cellar and bringing to mind thoughts about stable doors and bolting horses.

Yesterday a constable appeared on the doorstep asking if I had been in the neighbourhood on the night of the robbery. People always say that when a policeman knocks on the door, however innocent you might be, a strange panic kicks in which obliges you to provide far more information than is strictly necessary. Now I know it is true. Instead of a simple sorry, I wasn't here, it was after all New Year's Eve, I found myself spewing out details of the party we were at, the location, the guest list, the quality of the fireworks, the fact I'm more of a Monet man myself. I only just stopped short of offering Jeffrey Archer's name as a corroborative witness for an alibi.

"I'd better come in and get all this down," said the policeman.

And in he came, jovially confiding that this inquiry made a change from the usual "mundane stuff".

"Mundane stuff?" I said.

"Oh you know," he said. "Bottlings, glassings, stabbings, your usual New Year's Eve."

After 20 minutes he had extracted from me my name, address, age, telephone number and the fact I had seen absolutely nothing. Plus a couple of Jaffa cakes. Now, if the thief is apprehended and the painting returned, I will be able to sleep easier in my bed, knowing I played my part.

Keep Ken out

In common with most newspapers, the Independent on Sunday greeted the new year with a bit of speculation about what might lie in store. Under the headline "We Have Seen The Future", there was a photo-montage of Mr Tony, arms spread at a familiar evangelical angle, there was also William Hague, Al Gore and Michael Portillo, all reflecting a potential political landscape. And in the middle of them all, his head popping out from behind a trading screen, for no apparent reason was none other than Kenneth Branagh.

Underneath the picture was a long article full of references to those other great Kens, Livingstone and Clarke, but without mention of the Branagh moniker. It turned out the text referring to the cinematic polymath was confusingly buried a couple of pages away from the illustration. But at first glance, it seemed as if the paper really had looked into the future and produced a stunning political idea.

Think about the possibilities, for instance, of the brilliant marriage of luvvies and politicos that would arise from a Branagh candidacy for London mayor. Branagh has, after all, long since proved his credentials as an operator straight out of the Blair mould. Thus instead of Tony's Cronies, should he be elected in May, we could have Ken's Friends appointed to all the right places. Helena Bonham Carter, perhaps, as the capital's first minister for the underclass; Emma Thompson given the new parenting portfolio; and in charge of transport, with special dispensation to smooth the passage of those seeking cross-channel travel in a hurry: Stephen Fry. On second thoughts, just thinking about it gives a whole new dimension to the Stop Ken campaign.
fields.bodyText: Remember a film called Revenge of the Nerds? Thought not. In truth it was not Hollywood's finest moment. Released in 1984, the movie is a sub-Animal House student romp centring on a group of pizza-faced boffins who, fed up with years of bullying at the hands of the jock establishment, wreak allegedly humorous campus havoc by re-programming the college computer. In the process they win over the pneumatic cheer-leading sorority who obligingly remove their bras in admiration. When his feeble effort plunged straight to video, little did the director Peter Samuelson realise that, 16 years later, the movie would provide the perfect commentary on our times. As the last few days have proved, the Nerds have got their revenge: the 21st century belongs to them. Not only do Nerds officially occupy most of the higher positions in the world's rich list, they have now assumed a position of absolute power over all our lives. Young, clever and knowledgable in way which we techno-Luddites cannot imagine, we are terrified of them. We will do anything they tell us, throw any amount of money in their direction, just as long as they keep our computers working. On a local scale, we all fall into the thrall of the Nerd the moment we buy a PC, something we are constantly told we must do if we wish to keep apace with the revolution out there. In some barn on a ring road, a youth with perma-gelled hair fills your head with talk of mega rams and sends you home with a ludicrously expensive machine apparently capable of launching the space shuttle but incapable, you discover the moment you switch it on, of printing a letter. So you call a telephone support operative, sitting in an aircraft hangar somewhere near Dumfries. There is nothing in the world capable of inducing a volcanic loss of temper as quickly as a telephone support operative, especially when they ask if Sir has plugged the computer in yet. As they utter platitudes in that jargon-filled argot designed entirely to make you feel stupid, you splutter: "But don't your realise my business depends on this?" And when they respond with a meaningful "Ah well, if Sir is using the computer for business purposes, Sir should have bought a business machine in the first place," you find your mouse has been smashed into a dozen pieces beneath your fist. So you ring a Nerd prepared to come for a house visit, even though his hourly call-out rate matches that of a libel QC. Like a digital garage mechanic or roofing contractor, he sucks through his teeth on his arrival and tells you that you need an extra giga-byte, with hard disk overdrive. And because you haven't a clue what he is talking about, you take his word and pay up, softened by his console-side manner, the technological equivalent of old ladies who make over their entire will to the doctor who speaks kindly to them on their death beds. So it was with the millennium bug. Few of us could quite understand why it was that our microwave would be confused by the change of century into thinking it was preparing M&S chicken madras on January 1 1900, and thus refuse to defrost, but if a Nerd told us that would happen we believed them. Then we paid them whatever they told us was necessary to make sure that come the day, our curry cooked in time. At the BBC, for instance, more than £10m was spent getting the corporation compliant. That's enough to have kept Des Lynam. Well, almost. Encouraged by uber-Nerd John Birt, fighting the bug was given top priority at the Beeb. Distinguished programme-makers found themselves bullied by 23-year-old computer boffins telling them they couldn't do anything until the bug was sorted. I know this because I met the BBC's Y2K supremo just before Christmas. Disarmingly cheerful as the predicted armageddon approached, he had clearly had the time of his life this past year, as anyone would when operating in the joyous knowledge that everyone will do whatever you tell them. After a taste of being in charge he wasn't going to let anything as trivial as the arrival of 2000 see him out of a job. "There's going to be plenty of follow-up work all through next year," he told me. So prevalent was the Nerd agenda at the BBC that, during the marathon television coverage of the millennium, a rumour swept TV Centre as midnight passed in Moscow that the bug had triggered a nuclear assault and the missiles were on their way. For a few moments, panic gripped the studio; everyone was going to die, and all because the Russians couldn't be arsed to ring the government help line. Bizarrely, even though in the end nothing happened, even though poor Peter Snow's Bugometer only twitched briefly in the direction of a tax office in Gabon, the Nerds have still come out of it all smelling of cash and influence. They tell us nothing went wrong, not because there was never any threat in the first place, but because relevant, pricey precautions were taken. This is the really clever bit of the Nerd revenge: since we don't know, we can't gainsay them. And so we yield afresh to the new masters of the universe. My part in the Cézanne heist Living a few doors down from Oxford's Ashmolean museum, scene of the New Year's Eve Cézanne heist, I have been involved for the first time in my life in that great British institution: the house-to-house inquiry. Ever since the robbery, our street has been filled with police, large men in para-military garb with macho displays of hardwear dangling from their belts staring into our cellar and bringing to mind thoughts about stable doors and bolting horses. Yesterday a constable appeared on the doorstep asking if I had been in the neighbourhood on the night of the robbery. People always say that when a policeman knocks on the door, however innocent you might be, a strange panic kicks in which obliges you to provide far more information than is strictly necessary. Now I know it is true. Instead of a simple sorry, I wasn't here, it was after all New Year's Eve, I found myself spewing out details of the party we were at, the location, the guest list, the quality of the fireworks, the fact I'm more of a Monet man myself. I only just stopped short of offering Jeffrey Archer's name as a corroborative witness for an alibi. "I'd better come in and get all this down," said the policeman. And in he came, jovially confiding that this inquiry made a change from the usual "mundane stuff". "Mundane stuff?" I said. "Oh you know," he said. "Bottlings, glassings, stabbings, your usual New Year's Eve." After 20 minutes he had extracted from me my name, address, age, telephone number and the fact I had seen absolutely nothing. fields.headline: Ringing the changes
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
The fireworks, bonfires and wild revelling spread across the landscape as far as the eye could see. There was an incredible sense of community and moment, an explosive joy of celebration.

Flames from the Wrekin fire shone as they did at the turn of the last millennium and probably for several millennia before that. Though far smaller, our fire on Wenlock Edge echoed the same primal urge to burn away the stuff of past years and ignite a future world, to set something in motion, however vague and fuzzied by booze.

But as the party energy subsided like the fire, the coming of the new year/ century/millennium really belonged to the stars, owls and dark trees. The night was mild and clear. Stirring the embers with a stick sent sparks flying, echoes of the vast starry night, and the owls began calling through the hanging woods between. In the shadow of the Edge it doesn't really dawn, it just gets gradually lighter around us.

Going up the Wrekin the following day is an annual new year's pilgrimage, one shared by hundreds of others. A fresh breeze swept the summit. The day was bright and the far hills of south Shropshire and the Welsh border were clear, their snow gone.

Clouds of steam struck by sunlight pushed out of the power station in the Ironbridge gorge. The factories of Telford and the West Midland towns were quiet. The roads had hardly any traffic.

Folks from all over had come to the top of this hill to see their land - perhaps to check that it was still there; that it hadn't become a smoking ruin on the stroke of midnight; that the clouds still cast shadows and birds sang in the woods.

This landscape, which had erupted in a wild, joyous yell to see in the new year of all new years, may well have changed greatly over the last millennium, but the river Severn running through it and the Wrekin hill remain an unchanged, imutable, constant.

They may not have changed, but has something changed within us?

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Guardian sells stake in GMTV
Breakfast time broadcaster GMTV saw the reshaping of its ownership structure completed yesterday when Scottish Media Group announced that it and two other companies had bought the 15% shareholding owned by Guardian Media Group.
fields.body:
Guardian sells stake in GMTV
Breakfast time broadcaster GMTV saw the reshaping of its ownership structure completed yesterday when Scottish Media Group announced that it and two other companies had bought the 15% shareholding owned by Guardian Media Group.

SMG, Carlton Communications and Granada have increased their holdings by 5% to 25%. Walt Disney owns the remaining 25% of GMTV.

The transaction follows GMG's decision to sell its stake and step up its presence in radio. The other shareholders held pre-emption rights over the shares.

SMG said it paid £5.6m for the stake, with a further £500,000 assumed in loan stock. Chief executive Andrew Flanagan said GMTV's financial prospects had improved significantly since its licence terms were amended as part of its renewal process.

Although SMG was reported to be interested in buying all of GMTV, such a move would not be possible without the agreement of the other shareholders.

Sobs fails to block B&B
The campaign by Save Our Building Societies (Sobs) to block the demutualisation of Bradford & Bingley, Britain's second largest building society, has failed.

Bob Goodall, Sobs' coordinator, said his organisation failed to acquire the 500 members' signatures required to lodge a resolution. Sobs could only rally support from 358 members through a campaign based on word of mouth and correspondence with local newspapers.

He said that despite the shortfall he was pleased with the number of respondents and said it compared favourably with the efforts of Murray Financial to canvass supporters to convert Leek United Building Society into a bank.

Richard Yendall, organiser of Carpetbagger.com, the organisation hoping to convert Chelsea, Portman and Skipton building societies, said the failure illustrated the way that the new rules requiring 500 signatures had reduced members' democratic rights. "This man seems to have dedicated his life to issues surrounding mutuality. If he can't get support how will any normal member with a day job manage it," said Mr Yendall.

Fidelity seeks freer Magellan
Mutual funds company Fidelity Investments wants its large Magellan fund to be able to invest as much as a quarter of its assets in a single company, according to records.

Magellan, the world's largest mutual fund with assets of more than $100bn (£61bn), is limited to placing no more than 5% of assets in any one stock, with the aim of protecting the fund's investors with a spread of investments.

"The proposal would give the fund greater investment flexibility by permitting it to acquire larger positions in the securities of individual issuers," Fidelity said in a filing with the American securities and exchange commission.

"In particular, it would increase fund management's ability, where appropriate, to overweight positions that represent significant percentages of market benchmarks," the filing said.

BA starts £5m campaign
British Airways said it has launched a £5m new year tickets promotion. The project involves a mail drop to 23m homes in Britain with 30,000 prizes on offer.

The voucher promotion includes 1,000 vouchers enabling two people to fly Concorde for just £160 - a saving of about £5,000 off the standard price, and 1,000 vouchers for two people to go around the world for just £40 - a saving of more than £1,000 off the standard price.

fields.headline: Factories race into 21st century
fields.trailText: British industry ended the last century on a high note, with factories increasing output in December at the fastest pace for more than three years.
fields.body:
British industry ended the last century on a high note, with factories increasing output in December at the fastest pace for more than three years.

Millennium-related orders caused an end-of-year production surge, the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply said yesterday. The institute's monthly index of activity stood at 56.1 in December, the best reading since November 1996 and the seventh month in a row that the survey has shown the sector expanding.

Economists said the figures showed that British manufacturing was in good shape. "Overall, this is an upbeat survey, indicating further growth in manufacturing even if one-off millennium orders and the high exchange rate slow the pace of activity in January," said David Coleman, chief economist at CIBC world markets.

Despite the improving business climate, manufacturers resumed cutting jobs last month. "Productivity improvements enabled firms to increase output whilst at the same time reducing staffing levels," the institute said. Manufacturers shed about 150,000 jobs last year, according to official figures.

The strengthening UK and world economy is helping firms offset the impact of sterling's strength, according to Jonathan Loynes, UK economist at HSBC Markets. The pound is now worth nearly 15% more against the currencies of Britain's leading trading partners than three years ago.

"The strong recovery in demand both at home and abroad... should see industry continue to strengthen for at least another few quarters," he added.

Evidence that manufacturing has weathered the worst of the storm may help tip opinion at the Bank of England in favour of an early rate rise, though there are few signs of resurgent inflation.

The CIPS survey showed raw material costs rose in December, but at a slower pace than in November. Oil prices, a big influence on recent increases in fuel and material costs, fell back last month.

webTitle: Clinton offers Greenspan a fourth term

fields.headline: Clinton offers Greenspan a fourth term
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton ensured that the year AD2000 would not become AG1 yesterday when he renominated Alan Greenspan as the head of the world's most powerful central bank.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton ensured that the year AD2000 would not become AG1 yesterday when he renominated Alan Greenspan as the head of the world's most powerful central bank.

The announcement comes more than six months before Mr Greenspan's fourth four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve comes to an end in June.

Analysts and economists, who welcomed the reappointment of a man some have referred to as "God", said that Mr Clinton was keen to remove any uncertainty over the appointment in a presidential election year.

The reappointment, still to be voted on in the senate, reflects the importance of Mr Greenspan to the world's financial markets. Some commentators have used the term AG to refer to the post-Greenspan era.

In announcing his decision, Mr Clinton credited the Fed, which controls monetary policy, for its role in the longest peacetime economic expansion in the United States. He praised Mr Greenspan for inspiring confidence around the world and overseeing the stock market gains of recent years. He even joked that if he could only take "Alan.com" public he might be able to clear the national debt earlier than expected.

Mr Greenspan, first appointed by President Reagan in 1987, is 73. He explained his desire to continue in the post by speaking of the "unimaginable intellectual interest one gets... from putting broad theoretical concepts to the test in the marketplace".

However, the man who can make share prices plummet with a passing reference refused to respond to the US markets' performance yesterday as they traded sharply lower.

Robert Albertson, hedge fund manager at Pilot Financial Management, echoed popular sentiment when he said: "Familiarity breeds a lot of comfort. I think it's great." After Wall Street's vote of confidence most presidential contenders have supported the move, with only Steve Forbes being negative.

Leading Republican contenders are supportive, with John McCain even suggesting pretending Mr Greenspan was still alive should he meet an untimely end. More important for Mr Clinton, perhaps, is that Al Gore is an enthusiastic supporter.

webTitle: National Express wants two new rail franchises

fields.headline: National Express wants two new rail franchises
fields.trailText: National Express, the acquisitive transport group, is keen to take on more rail franchises in Britain and expand its bus operations in the US and Australia after paying $172.5m (£106m) for Chicago-based ATC yesterday.
fields.body:
National Express, the acquisitive transport group, is keen to take on more rail franchises in Britain and expand its bus operations in the US and Australia after paying $172.5m (£106m) for Chicago-based ATC yesterday.

William Rollason, finance director, disclosed that the group is preparing to bid for at least two of the new-style rail franchises being auctioned by the shadow strategic rail authority (SSRA) next month.

National Express already operates rail services under five franchises - Gatwick Express, Silverlink, Midland Mainline, Central Trains and ScotRail. But Mr Rollason said it was keen to gain a better geographical spread beyond its Midlands base.

The SSRA will be auctioning bids for a new set of franchises which need not match the existing regional map, including London commuter services into Paddington, Liverpool Street and Waterloo; inter-urban trans-Pennine services; Wales and north-west England; and services in and around Birmingham and Manchester.

Mr Rollason said National Express would be interested in several of these. The group kept out of the first round of new bids - for GNER, Chiltern and London South Central - and has eschewed interest in taking over troubled bus operator MTL.

Yesterday's purchase, for cash, of ATC is the group's second US bus acquisition in six months: it paid $178.5m in August for school bus operator Durham.

ATC, operating in 44 cities in 18 states, is the largest privately owned provider of public transit services in America and last year made $10.9m on $153.1m sales. It runs all the buses in and around Las Vegas and carries more than 102m passengers a year.

Mr Rollason said National Express planned to take on a third leg of its US operations by spending a similar amount on acquiring an operator of commuter buses - and expanding the business through other bolt-on purchases.

The ATC purchase will boost buses' share of group turnover to 35% and of profits to 40%.

The US bus business is set to provide about 15% of group sales of £1.5bn but the aim is to double the figure to about $600m.

North America contributes about 15% of group profits as well but could see greater growth than in the mature British market, said Mr Rollason. "I would be very disappointed if we could not get double-digit margins out of the business," he said.

Only 16% of the $9bn a year US bus market, where British rivals Stagecoach and FirstGroup are also active, has been privatised.

 Prism Rail said it had received a number of approaches which could lead to an offer for the company as transport operators try to expand rail activities in response to the SSRA's programme.

Prism operates four franchises - two serving London, LTS and WAGN, and two serving Wales, Wales and West and Cardiff. Shares rose 35% to 500p valuing the company at more than £130m.

fields.headline: Hunt for Electrolux accomplice
fields.trailText: Electrolux is investigating the possibility that the un-named rogue trader thought to have cost the consumer appliances group about £18m may have had an accomplice. It is also trying to establish whether he ran up additional sour positions in the foreign exchange markets with banks other than those with which the group usually deals.
fields.body:
Electrolux is investigating the possibility that the un-named rogue trader thought to have cost the consumer appliances group about £18m may have had an accomplice. It is also trying to establish whether he ran up additional sour positions in the foreign exchange markets with banks other than those with which the group usually deals.

An audit hit squad from accountant KPMG has arrived in Siege, Germany, to begin a full internal inquiry into the unauthorised currency speculations which are likely to wipe up to 5% off Electrolux's 1999 profits. The rogue trader's office has been sealed and the hard disk on his computer removed.

The Siege office managed currency dealings for the Swedish group's exports and imports across Germany's frontiers. Since confessing on December 29 to nearly a year's worth of unauthorised currency speculation, the employee has been suspended.

Electrolux spokesman Lars Johansson said: "It's a lot of money and people are very upset that it has happened." But he said the cost to Electrolux should be kept in proportion, at between 2% and 5% of net profits for last year.

The employee has told Electrolux that he worked alone and engaged in speculation for the greater profitability of the group and not for personal gain. These assertions are being checked by the KPMG team, reporting on a daily basis to the group. Once the in quiry is complete its findings will be handed to the German authorities.

The employee is a German national, and has worked for Electrolux for three and a half years. Yesterday, the group - the world's largest maker of household appliances - said it was reasonably confident the £18m figure represented the whole of the losses, but added that it could not be sure if there had been any transactions with banks with which Electrolux does not normally deal.

fields.headline: DaimlerChrysler may seek small-car partner
fields.standfirst: Four-seater Smart for 2003 on drawing board
fields.trailText: DaimlerChrysler expects to unveil its small-car strategy by the end of March but refuses to be drawn on whether it will go it alone or seek a partnership with another global car maker.
fields.body:
DaimlerChrysler expects to unveil its small-car strategy by the end of March but refuses to be drawn on whether it will go it alone or seek a partnership with another global car maker.

A key part of its approach is the so-called Smart car. DaimlerChrysler sold 80,000 of the two-seater version last year - below initial expectations - and expects to sell a further 100,000 this year.

The company is planning to introduce a four-seater version by 2003.

Yesterday Reinhard Lyhs, the president of DaimlerChrysler France, said the company was in talks with Peugeot, Honda and Fiat over possible cooperation deal.

"We have to decide on one of the partners by March," he said.

Mr Lyhs said Honda would make a good partner because of its marketing strength in Japan and other Asian countries, while Peugeot and Fiat were experienced in manufacturing small cars.

Separately, the German magazine Der Spiegel reported that DaimlerChrysler chairman Jürgen Schremp was considering taking a stake in one of the three car companies as part of the small-car strategy or in truck maker Nissan Diesel.

A spokesman for DaimlerChrysler declined to comment on what he described as speculation.

He acknowledged that the Stuttgart-based company was working on a small-car strategy in order to meet the problems caused by issues such as emission requirements but that nothing had yet been decided at board level.

He said the company was confident it could develop a small-car strategy on its own but that it would be able to save money and time by using a platform or components developed by another manufacturer.

" It [a partnership] is an option but its not eat or die," the spokesman said, adding that a solution was expected by the end of the first quarter of this year.

 Sales of Rover cars have developed "very positively" over the past three months, according to a spokesman for the British car maker's German parent, BMW.

Losses at Rover are expected to top 1998's 1.9bn German marks (£607m) but earnings this year should be "significantly better" on the back of new model sales, BMW spokesman Richard Gaul told the Die Welt newspaper.

The spokesman said the company expected the European commission to give "unlimited and speedy approval" to the British government's £150m aid package for the Rover plant at Longbridge.

The EC competition authorities have said they want to examine whether Longbridge faced a genuine challenge from a green-fields development in Hungary as the site for the production of the new Rover 25 and 45 models.
