webTitle: Selfish act of a passing president

fields.headline: Selfish act of a passing president
fields.standfirst: Notebook Is Greenspan the right choice?
fields.trailText: Think of news without context and without characters. An outgoing president reappoints an ageing banker to head the country's central bank for his fourth consecutive term, despite the fact that the incumbent will be in the thick end of his eighties if and when he finishes the job.
fields.body:
Think of news without context and without characters. An outgoing president reappoints an ageing banker to head the country's central bank for his fourth consecutive term, despite the fact that the incumbent will be in the thick end of his eighties if and when he finishes the job.

There is no debate over this, no dissent, no succession battle, no offering-up of alternative candidates. It is taken as the natural thing to do, and is accompanied by all the usual verbal back-slap ping. The financial world really is in danger of assuming that Mr Alan Greenspan is a new biological paradigm - not just the man who brought us a fresh economic one.

President Clinton certainly bears the Federal Reserve chairman no ill will, and it would have looked a tad ungrateful to crowbar the man from his post when he has professed himself to be fit and ready to fight on.

In one month's time the American economy will have been growing for the longest unbroken period since economic reckoning began.

Mr Greenspan's record is pristine: re-inflating the American economy out of recession a decade ago; managing the bond blow-out four years later; then applying careful massage in the wake of the multiple shocks of the past two years - Asia, Russia, Long Term Capital Management, Brazil.

He, more than anyone, is responsible for a sense that the Fed, sitting at the centre of the world's financial apparatus, has become truly adept at controlling what on paper appears to be uncontrollable. Why try to fix something that is not broken?

Now slip on your political specs. Wall Street has been gossiping since last spring about when exactly Mr Clinton might renew Mr Greenspan's contract. A consensus had developed that the presidency was holding off from a statement on the succession at the Fed as a sort of subtle lever on policy - in an election year it did not want either an emboldened Mr Greenspan applying the monetary screws too soon or the potential dislocation that a replacement for Mr Greenspan might bring about in the markets.

So the timing of Mr Clinton's statement - on the second business day of the year and with world markets appearing as jittery as we have seen for many months - smacks of White House spin. It is as though there is a burning, short-term desire to underwrite the asset price bubble on Wall Street.

But the real medium-term effect is to push out the debate about Mr Greenspan's successor even further, just at a point - to be cold and real - when the odds on the great man dropping dead one day are beginning to shorten alarmingly. He might well become other worldly in a literal sense. By shouting "four more years", rather than "two more" and then posting a job advertisement, Mr Clinton has just increased the risk premium attached to the world's leading stock markets.

Peg etiquette

The last echoes of the 1997 currency crisis may be fading, but efforts to prevent a repeat of the south-east Asian market meltdown rumble on. Finance ministers jetting into Tokyo for the meeting of the G7 industrialised nations this month can expect to be faced with a Japanese proposal for the creation of a basket of leading currencies - the yen, the dollar and the euro to name but three - against which emerging market economies might peg their currencies.

Such thinking is unsurprising. Currency instability on the scale which shocked south-east Asia in the autumn of 1997 and from which Latin America has suffered from time to time is widely regarded as bad news.

Nor is currency pegging a new idea. The question is whether exchange rate stability can be an instrument of economic policy or a consequence. Hong Kong has successfully pegged its currency to the greenback for years, but arguably the region's exposure to the American economy makes the peg a workable option.

Aspiring members of the European Union may see sense in tracking the euro - but only because their long-term goal is one of close convergence.

Britain's flirtation with even so flexible a "peg" as the exchange rate mechanism shows the dangers of linking exchange rates between economies which are out of step. It can be difficult, too, to command political support for the surrender of monetary policy authority implicit in pegging.

Using a basket does have an advantage over a single currency tie in that it mitigates the risk of a sudden, sharp movement of the reference currency dragging the pegged currency in an unwanted direction.

But without the right mix of economic policies, pegs turn the foreign exchanges into a happy hunting ground for speculators.

Currencies - like any target - are easier to hit when they are anchored.

webTitle: Wickes on the mend as it adds 'calibre'

fields.headline: Wickes on the mend as it adds 'calibre'
fields.trailText: Wickes, the DIY retailer, yesterday showed further signs of its rehabilitation, when it made fresh appointments to its management team.
fields.body:
Wickes, the DIY retailer, yesterday showed further signs of its rehabilitation, when it made fresh appointments to its management team.

Bill Grimsey, the chief executive who took over after the company uncovered accounting irregularities in 1996, said the fact the group could attract new "calibre" employees was evidence of its turnaround.

Wickes shares gained 5p to 271.5p on the appointments which Mr Grimsey said marked the end of restructuring to the top management. He said the focus was to rebuild the group's brand and that further appointments would take place lower down the organisation, which was dogged by distribution problems last year.

Norman Bell joins from Somerfield, where he was responsible for the integration with Kwik Save, as operations director. Gerry Johnson, who moved last year from Allied Maple, becomes logistics director while Sanaya Bhote and Des Pullen are from Safeway. Ms Bhote is to be director of finance while Mr Pullen will be head of human resources. Amir Afkami, from investment bank Robert Fleming Securities becomes head of business research and development.

The group, which is half way through a five year restructuring programme instigated by Mr Grimsey, last year spent £50m on changing its distribution, warehousing and refurbishing 35 stores. It will spend a similar amount this year upgrading 30 more stores.

fields.headline: Focus
fields.standfirst: Sage
fields.trailText: Sage
fields.body:
Accountancy software company Sage rarely attracts any bad publicity.

After ending the 1990s as the stock market's star performer, those shareholders who stuck with it throughout the decade are hardly likely to complain.

A 28,000% rise in the company's share price meant that £500 invested 10 years ago would be worth around £14m today - this happens to be the market's best performer of the 1990s.

The company's 2m small business customers seem content, too. Only rivals have been left to carp, and comparative tiddler Pegasus Group has decided to have the first pop of the new century.

Pegasus is to complain to the takeover panel this week because it is confused over what exactly Sage is playing at with its recent takeover at tempt. Just before Christmas, Pegasus recommended a £30m or 430p a share bid from Australia's Solution 6. But as the City was winding down, Sage said it was pondering a rival bid.

Pegasus thinks Sage is playing games. "We consider Sage's statement confusing, as there have been situations in the past when they have also offered to make an offer and then withdrawn," said director Chris Leak. "We will be asking the takeover panel to seek clarification from Sage at the earliest possible opportunity."

Pegasus shares fell 12% to 480p as hopes of a counterbid faded away.

Sage would not comment but its shares - which had risen to a record 880p - gradually fell, closing down 55.5p at 700p; profit-taking in burgeoning hi-tech stocks accentuated the fall.

fields.headline: Thomson sets sights on Racal
fields.standfirst: Group dismisses reports of £2bn deal
fields.trailText: Thomson-CSF, the French defence electronics group, is expected to launch a full-scale bid for Racal within the next few days after confirming yesterday it hopes to reach an agreed takeover.
fields.body:
Thomson-CSF, the French defence electronics group, is expected to launch a full-scale bid for Racal within the next few days after confirming yesterday it hopes to reach an agreed takeover.

But Thomson made plain that it is unwilling to pay over the odds for Racal and dismissed reports it would be ready to put up £2bn for the British group headed by Sir Ernest Harrison.

News of Thomson's interest initially sent Racal's shares soaring in a depressed overall market to 630p but, as the French group's caution became apparent, the shares fell back to end the day just 36p higher at 591p, valuing the group at more than £1.6bn.

An agreed deal would be the icing on the cake for Sir Ernest, the king of shareholder value who has won City plaudits for raising billions through the float and sale of Vodafone, Chubb and, only two months ago its telecoms arm to US group Global Crossing, which paid £1bn.

Sir Ernest, who is expected to retire later this year after heading Racal for 33 years, has engineered a substantial rise in Racal's overall value in the past few weeks through the proposed sale of the defence arm - and float of both its security and payments business and half-share in a telematics firm - for staggering sums.

The French group, regularly jilted as a partner for other Eu ropean defence companies in the current wave of consolidation, is keen to establish itself as a strong competitor for BAE Systems and EADS, the rival group being forged from the merger of France's Matra Aérospatiale, Germany's Dasa and Spain's Casa.

But company sources indicated that Thomson, in which telecoms and engineering group Alcatel holds a 25% stake and the French state a further 34%, is also keen to expand its industrial electronics business.

Analysts said the two groups would be a good fit: Racal has 37% of sales in industrial electronics and 45% in defence electronics.

But many warned that the price demanded could be an insurmountable obstacle; some have put a target price on Racal of 580p but others see it at 675p-700p.

Insiders said Thomson made an initial approach to Sir Ernest in early November and made an offer worth around 400p a share or £1bn later that month. Or, as it said yesterday, "significantly lower than the closing price [555p] on December 30,1999".

That initial 400p or so offer excluded the £500m special dividend worth 167p a share being paid to Racal stockholders on January 14 as part of the proceeds for the sale of the telecoms business.

News of the Thomson offer and the special dividend sent Racal shares up more than £1 in 14 days but sources close to the French company said repeatedly that the initial bid already contained a hefty premium and the markets should not expect any new "wild and wacky" numbers.

Thomson's own shares underperformed the CAC-40 index substantially last year and fell back 25 cents to close at €33.75 (£21) yesterday.

Racal facts

Founded 1950 by Ray Brown and Calder Cunningham

Chairman and chief executive Sir Ernest Harrison, renowned for creating shareholder value, since 1966

Turnover £982.8m and pretax profits of £80.8m recorded last year

Employees Some 9,000, including 8,000 in Britain

Main activities Defence electronics; radar; electronic warfare; command information services; transportation, including share of £1bn Connect project for London Underground's communications system

Owns 26.7% of lottery operator Camelot , 20% of Satellite Information Services providing live feed of horse races to betting shops and 50% of Global Telematics . Floated Vodafone in 1991; Chubb security business in 1992 and telecoms division for £1bn last year

webTitle: Sale of the centuries but festive retail fortunes are mixed

fields.headline: Sale of the centuries but festive retail fortunes are mixed
fields.trailText: Seasonal trading statements over the next three weeks are expected to show a sharp contrast in the fortunes of clothing and non-clothing retailers.
fields.body:
Seasonal trading statements over the next three weeks are expected to show a sharp contrast in the fortunes of clothing and non-clothing retailers.

On the day that the London toy shop Hamleys started its first sale in more than 200 years, city experts said that retailers were expected to report a tough festive period, with the middle market of Marks & Spencer and Arcadia particularly hard hit.

Although analysts believe clothing retailers generally had a pretty sticky run-up to Christmas, they anticipate that high-fashion brands such as Oasis, Monsoon and French Connection will have fared less badly than the middle market.

Analysts believe the post-Christmas sales have started well for clothing retailers, cautioning that they are again having to discount heavily. But data is expected to confirm that sales of electrical items are continuing to boom and analysts anticipate that home furnishings and DIY will do well.

John Lewis released figures for the week to December 18 which showed store sales up 17.1%. The group highlighted "great strength" in its furnishings business. Analysts think that Harveys, DFS Furniture and Courts have all made solid starts to new year sales.

"It's been a strange Christmas," said one analyst. "If you look at the John Lewis figures you'd think it was boom time again. If you believe the Marks & Spencer figures you'd think the world was coming to an end."

Verdict Research, the retailing consultancy, says that the downturn is part of a "seismic shift in the nature of the marketplace". In a report released today, Verdict says that retailers will have to change from their traditional focus on the young to mature customers. With an ageing population "achieving this is essential to growth," says Verdict's Richard Hyman.

In a report released today, Verdict says that retailers will have to change from their traditional focus on the young to mature customers. With an ageing population "achieving this is essential to growth," says Verdict's Richard Hyman.

fields.headline: Thus may escape telecom reckoning
fields.trailText: Market forces
fields.body:
The run up to the stock market flotation of Thus, the erstwhile Scottish Telecom, generated palpable excitement.

Shares in the company were oversubscribed nine times causing the price to be revised upwards before they joined the market at 310p valuing it at £2.2bn. Less than a year earlier parent company Scottish Power had been negotiating to sell the business for half that sum.

Since joining the market in mid-November however shares in the business have failed to catch fire, reaching 442.5p at the beginning of December only to trickle back to 387p yesterday, down 0.5p.

A lukewarm broker's note from Investec Henderson Crosthwaite describes Thus as a long-term buy, noting at least that, as the larger players consolidate, smaller stocks such as Thus will be put into play.

"This could be the year of reckoning," one analyst warned privately yesterday. "After two extremely strong years for telecom stocks some valuations are looking dangerously high and the truth is with some of the newer companies no one really knows what they should be."

Thus has two things going for it -it is close to making money at a time when it is unfashionable to do so and it has strong exposure to the internet.

The business is focusing on the small to medium sized corporate sector. Thus has a core telephony division built on the Scottish Power electricity network and is investing a large part of the £335m proceeds of the flotation in building its network out nationwide including fibre optic rings of 27 UK cities.

Thus entered the internet market through the acquisition in 1998 of Demon Internet for what now looks like a rock bottom price of £66m. It now claims to be the biggest web hosting business in Britain and in the top five worldwide. It also has a call centre division which includes Microsoft and OnDigital as clients and the aim is to offer a one-stop shop of voice, data and internet.

Pre-tax losses last year were £9m on revenues of £166m - negligible when compared to some of its rivals. In the year to March 31 £84m of those sales were generated by the internet. Demon has 240,000 subscribers paying £10 a month.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The holiday hangover turned out to be a real thumper. Having gone up like a rocket over Christmas and ahead of the new year, the proverbial stick came dropping back to earth yesterday as the London market sank almost 4%.
fields.body:
The holiday hangover turned out to be a real thumper. Having gone up like a rocket over Christmas and ahead of the new year, the proverbial stick came dropping back to earth yesterday as the London market sank almost 4%.

In points terms the drop amounted to 264.3 off the FTSE 100 index, which settled at 6665.9.

The blame was placed on the yawning gap between bond yields, which rose to take into account of the likelihood of higher borrowing costs and soaring equities - just one of the traditional valuation measures which have been ignored by speculators recently.

The real damage to the Footsie came in the form of several heavyweight fallers.

British Telecom , for instance, shrank from £15.13 to £14.23, BP Amoco gave up 26p to 596p and HSBC ran back 40p to 822p.

But the rout was broadly spread, with AstraZeneca falling from £25.68 to £24.53, Peninsular & Oriental shedding 48p to 985p and Dixons losing 65p to £14.24 - all dropping around 5% during the session.

Well-known internet casualties included QXL.com , which saw its shares fall from £14.55 to £13.42p. That compares with a pre-Christmas high of £18.50 and last year's post-flotation low of 170p. Similarly, Baltimore Technology , the Irish hi-tech counter, slid a little further from its recent highs to close at £49, down 212p. But the stock is still up more than tenfold over the past 12 months. Freeserve dropped from 590p to 523p.

Against all this, however, Marks & Spencer managed to advance from 295p to 310p. Explaining the move against the trend, brokers simply pointed to the number of new year newspaper tip columns which have featured the stricken retailer.

Other tip gainers included Santuary Group , the operator of a heavy metal website, which jumped from 40p to 48p, and reflective inks specialist Reflec , which gained 5p to 21p. The same forces were behind software group Sopheon - up 110p to 437p, even though just 10,000 shares changed hands - and Underwriting & Subscription , a net investment company which joined the market last month at 25p a share. Yesterday the price was up an extraordinary 55p to 120p.

Going the other way, Sherwood Group , which is in the old-fashioned business of producing frilly knickers, fell 2p to 12p.

The company has warned that it will report a small op erating loss for the full year and is likely to pass its final dividend.

South African-based Old Mutual fell 11p to 157p after selling its British life insurance business.

The deal involved a complicated two-pronged sale which it said was at £15m above the book value of the business - which has been closed to new policies since 1998.

While Old Mutual is keen to expand its asset management operation in Britain it might also be tempted to take a punt at Royal & Sun Alliance - which has been linked to Zurich Financial Services over the holidays.

fields.headline: The end of the word?
fields.standfirst: You'll have heard about the crisis in playwriting. Sarah Kane is dead, Mark Ravenhill has left the critics cold, and the Royal Court has put off reopening. So why is no one panicking, asks  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: You'll have heard about the crisis in playwriting. Sarah Kane is dead, Mark Ravenhill has left the critics cold, and the Royal Court has put off reopening. So why is no one panicking, asks Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
It is not hard to date the start of what has been called the new-play renaissance. The Royal Court's 1994/5 season, which included works by Joe Penhall, Sarah Kane and Nick Grosso, was the start of an extraordinary run of plays at the Royal Court, the Bush and beyond that saw Kane's Blasted making the front pages, Mark Ravenhill's Shopping and Fucking not only taking over the West End but also making Bury St Edmunds sit up and take notice, and Patrick Marber's Dealer's Choice and Closer packing out the National Theatre with young audiences usually to be found at the cinema.

It generated a sharp new sense of optimism. British theatre was once again hailed as the most exciting in the world. Over the past five years there have been over 400 productions worldwide of plays premiered at the Royal Court.

But when it comes to new writing, confidence plays a part. It is rather harder to place the moment when the jitters set in a few seasons later. Perhaps it was the night last spring when Kane committed suicide aged just 28. Or maybe it was the moment in early summer when Out of Joint announced the delay of Ravenhill's Some Explicit Polaroids, widely seen as the follow-up to Shopping and Fucking by those who conveniently forgot that Ravenhill had already produced two further fine plays, Faust and Handbag. When Polaroids finally premiered at the New Ambassadors in the autumn, its merits tended to be overshadowed by the fact that this was no Shopping and Fucking.

Then there were the Evening Standard theatre awards and the widely publicised decision not to give an award in the best new play category. The National too has played its part in the haemorrhaging of confidence: the poor reviews for Stephen Poliakoff's Remember This and Nick Stafford's Battle Royal once again raised niggling doubts over the appointment of Trevor Nunn as artistic director. Nunn's directorial prowess has never been doubted but he has never been noted for his espousal of new writing.

In the circumstances, the opening of the Royal Court's newly refurbished £26.5m building in Sloane Square, scheduled for this week but now delayed by technical hitches (not a confidence booster, that), and the arrival this week of the Soho Theatre Company in a new £10.5m building in the West End that is due to open its doors in March, could hardly come at a less auspicious time. Who needs £37m-worth of buildings devoted to new writing if new writing is in the doldrums? It rather puts you in mind of Richard Eyre's original comment on lottery-funded projects: lots of wonderful new restaurants and no food.

Such thinking is regarded as heretical by the Court's literary manager, Graham Wybrow, and Abigail Morris, artistic director of the Soho Theatre Company. Both argue persuasively that if there is any crisis in new writing - which they doubt, pointing to the fact that each could have filled their opening season two or three times over - then it is only a minor wobble, and perhaps entirely due to their theatres' prolonged absence from producing. The Royal Court's move from the West End back to Sloane Square means it has produced no new work since early 1999, and the Soho's enforced inactivity has created a crucial imbalance at the bottom of the new-writing pyramid where writers start out.

Over at the Bush, which has just enjoyed one of its most successful seasons with audience attendance averaging 74%, artistic director Mike Bradwell is also sceptical about reports of the death of new writing. But then, he's always been pretty sceptical about the boom.

"The so-called renaissance in new writing was a renaissance in writing about new writing, which became fashionable because of all those boys' plays - and I include Sarah Kane - at the Royal Court. It's a fashion, just in the way that finding Goethe plays and staging them on slopes was a fashion in the 80s," says Bradwell.

He points to the Bush's own success last year with accessible, popular plays such as Mark O'Rowe's brilliant Howie the Rookie and Catherine Johnson's girls-behaving-badly drama Shang-a-Lang, which packed out in London before touring the regions.

"We are feeling pretty buoyant," says Bradwell, while still pointing out that the Bush faces huge difficulties. "We pay the same for a commission now as we did 10 years ago and we very quickly lose writers to film and TV." He also believes that the Almeida and Donmar-led trend for event theatre stuffed full of Hollywood stars makes audiences more demanding. "They cherry-pick. They only want to see hits."

It is a point that Jack Bradley, literary manager at the National Theatre, takes up: "People go to the movies and come out saying, 'Well, it wasn't Citizen Kane but it was a pleasant night out.' But they have a different attitude to theatre. They say 'This isn't as good as Richard III' and feel unhappy."

Certainly, besides the desire to see Nicole Kidman with her kit off, there also appears to be a huge hunger in audiences for theatre that offers a more visceral and participatory experience than is generally available from the play, new or otherwise. The sell-out success of shows such as Shock-Headed Peter, De La Guarda, Deborah Warner's Tower Project and Frantic Assembly more than bears that out. But literary managers such as Wybrow are canny enough to realise that blaming the audience for a crisis of confidence in new writing is silly.

If, like the Royal Court, it is a theatre's remit to find and put on new plays, then it is that theatre's responsibility to create the conditions that allow writers to flourish," he says. "It is a culture, not a fountain. I still feel that we have to prove this is a sustainable culture against the lost generations of writers from the 80s when attacks on text-based theatre predominated. The conditions for new plays and playwrights are always precarious. It is our responsibility to fight for them and it means you have to have an eye on both the present and the future."

Yet despite the efforts of people like Wybrow, a lack of confidence does persist in some quarters. As one literary agent told me: "I think there is beginning to be a backlash against the literary text. It makes theatres less bold and more reluctant to take risks. We have a lot of plays that ought to find homes but I know won't. That is not an encouraging situation for writers to be in. They give up writing plays and write screenplays or novels instead."

Bradley at the National believes that the energy that was focused on theatre may now have moved to Wardour Street and the British film industry, but adds that appearances may be deceptive and that there is no shortage of new work coming out of the National Theatre Studio. From his point of view the problem is programming it within the context of the theatre's ensemble and spaces, which demand plays of a certain scale. "You can put a big play in a small space but you can't put a one-man show in the Olivier," he says. But he argues that the National has some gems and that depending on the public's appetite for The Mysteries (currently running till the end of March) we will see an entire season of Studio-generated work in the Cottesloe some time after Easter.

Despite the hitch that means Conor McPherson's Dublin Carol will now open at the Old Vic before transferring to the Royal Court for its delayed opening in February, the Court's return to Sloane Square should be enough of an event in itself to give new writing a fillip. But as Soho's Morris, who has already had experience of opening a new theatre, points out, there are pitfalls involved. "People tend to look at what you do very critically. Everyone knows how much the Court and the Soho have cost and if you're not careful, they will look at the first work you put on and what will run through their minds is the thought 'Is this play worth £11m?' "

The Soho's solution is a plan to programme a wide-ranging season of work that will have short runs, so that no single play or playwright carries the burden of expectation and critical attention.

"We can only do that because we've got so many good plays looking for productions," says the Soho's literary manager, Paul Sirrett. "I think this is a fantastic time for new writing and that the Court and we are going to be producing again just at the right moment. It's just doom-mongering to start saying new writing is dead. People like to impose history. We'll only really know in the year 2020 if new writing did die in 1999. The obituaries are premature."

 Conor McPherson's Dublin Carol is at the Old Vic, London SE1 (0171-565 5000), from January 15, and transfers to the Royal Court, Sloane Square, London SW1, in mid-February.

fields.headline: Teen spirit of adventure
fields.standfirst:
The outdoor lobby is delighted that the government wants all 16-year-olds to have a place at an activities centre. But are there enough to go round? asks 
Phil Revell
fields.trailText: The outdoor lobby is delighted that the government wants all 16-year-olds to have a place at an activities centre. But are there enough to go round? asks Phil Revell
fields.body:
On Thursday, the outdoor education community will see two years of intense lobbying finally bear fruit, when David Blunkett outlines proposals to give all 500,000 of Britain's 16-year-olds a place at a summer adventure camp. At the North of England education conference in Wigan this week, the education secretary is expected to flesh out the details of a scheme that will see lottery money fund a residential outdoor experience for any 16-year-old wishing to take up the offer.

"It's marvellous news," says Randall Williams, vice chair of the English Outdoor Council and co-author of a 1997 report that challenged the incoming Labour government to offer a residential experience to all. "This is exactly what we were asking for."

It's a welcome surprise for an education sector that has felt beleaguered since local management of schools made local authority provision problematic. Fair funding proposals, adopted in the autumn, would have delegated the monies to individual schools. Tim Brighouse, director of education in Birmingham, led a rearguard action that persuaded the Department for Education and Employment to treat outdoor education in the same way as peripatetic music teaching - and retain some local authority funding.

Birmingham already offers an outdoor experience to all its schools and thousands of schools in other areas use outdoor education as a way to promote personal development. In a recent, unpublished report, Ofsted found that pupils in both primary and secondary schools gained "enormous benefits" when the Outdoor and Adventurous Activities option in Physical Education was adopted by the schools, "with a discernible impact on pupils' behaviour and relationships".

Blunkett is keen to target the thousands of young people who leave school without any qualifications. Research has shown that the summer break after leaving school can be a critical time for these youngsters; many drop out of the system altogether at this stage.

The government could be looking to build on the experience of centres such as Westfields in Kirklees, a pupil referral unit dealing with excluded and disaffected pupils. Much of Westfields' work is based around an energetic outdoor education programme, which takes pupils with severe behavioural difficulties and exposes them to the challenges of the outdoors. "A lot of values are learned through the outdoors," said a Westfields instructor. "They find their personal strengths and learn to use the strengths of others to support their weaknesses."

While looking to use adventure as a way to pull disaffected young people back into the system, ministers are keen to stress that the new summer camps will be offered to all.

"We expect that people from vastly different backgrounds will come together at these camps," said an education department source. Finding enough providers qualified to run the camps could present ministers with their first difficulties. There are just under 900 centres licensed to run the kind of adventurous activities envisaged in the scheme. An optimistic assessment would suggest that around 100,000 young people could be accommodated - if every centre was used to the full. But that is only 20% of the places that would be required.

"If we're really talking about every single 16-year-old, then some special provision will have to be made," says Randall Williams. Another hurdle could come with marketing the idea to today's cool young teens - who may see a tented summer camp as something to be avoided like the plague. "An active selling job will be called for," says Williams. "Simply making it available isn't going to work."

Brian Davies, chair of the Association of Heads of Outdoor Education Centres and Oxfordshire's advisory headteacher for outdoor education, gave a broad welcome to the proposals, but warned about the possible impact on the environment. Activities like rock-climbing, hill-walking and canoeing need a venue, which could be damaged by overuse. "This will have to be carefully managed," he said. "There are concerns about access and sustainability at the sites we use now."

While looking to use adventure as a way to pull disaffected young people back into the system, ministers are keen to stress that the new summer camps will be offered to all. "We expect that people from vastly different backgrounds will come together at these camps," said an education department source. Finding enough providers qualified to run the camps could present ministers with their first difficulties. There are just under 900 centres licensed to run the kind of adventurous activities envisaged in the scheme. An optimistic assessment would suggest that around 100,000 young people could be accommodated - if every centre was used to the full. But that is only 20% of the places that would be required. "If we're really talking about every single 16-year-old, then some special provision will have to be made," says Randall Williams. Another hurdle could come with marketing the idea to today's cool young teens - who may see a tented summer camp as something to be avoided like the plague. "An active selling job will be called for," says Williams. "Simply making it available isn't going to work." Brian Davies, chair of the Association of Heads of Outdoor Education Centres and Oxfordshire's advisory headteacher for outdoor education, gave a broad welcome to the proposals, but warned about the possible impact on the environment. Activities like rock-climbing, hill-walking and canoeing need a venue, which could be damaged by overuse. "This will have to be carefully managed," he said. "There are concerns about access and sustainability at the sites we use now."

webTitle: IRA killer caught in on-off extradition row

fields.headline: IRA killer caught in on-off extradition row
fields.standfirst:
Irish judge halts move north at last minute

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: An IRA man convicted of the murder 20 years ago of an SAS captain in Belfast was last night at the centre of an astonishing extradition wrangle with the Irish Republic after a high court judge in Dublin dramatically halted his return to Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
An IRA man convicted of the murder 20 years ago of an SAS captain in Belfast was last night at the centre of an astonishing extradition wrangle with the Irish Republic after a high court judge in Dublin dramatically halted his return to Northern Ireland.

Armed gardai were already escorting fugitive Angelo Fusco, 43, back to the custody of the RUC when Sinn Fein successfully appealed for a delay. He had been held at a routine police checkpoint near his former home at Tralee in Co Kerry late on Monday.

Fusco was jailed in June 1981 with a recommendation that he serve a minimum 30 years for the shooting dead in May 1980 of Captain Herbert Westmacott, 28. But he had escaped with six co-accused shortly before the verdict when they shot their way out of Crumlin Road courthouse.

He was a member of the notorious M-60 gang - named after the heavy-duty machine gun they used - which surrendered when they were surrounded in north Belfast after the murder. Westmacott was shot in a bungled SAS attempt to prevent an attack on an RUC station.

Under the early release programme, a key part of the Good Friday agreement, Fusco could expect to be released next July even if he were returned to Northern Ireland. He has spent 10 years in jail in the Irish Republic for his Belfast jailbreak.

Republicans were enraged at Fusco's arrest, but Unionists were also furious after Mr Justice Joseph Finnegan stopped his return, scheduled for yesterday evening at the border on the main Belfast to Dublin road. It brought back bitter memories of several IRA suspects who evaded extradition to Northern Ireland.

The furore did little to aid the fragile peace process, and there were indications of frustration among Northern Ire land officials. Graffiti on one republican estate last night read: "Extradite Bloody Sunday war criminals, not Fusco."

Garda sources quickly damped down speculation that Fusco had been held in the police crackdown on dissident republicans. They said he had been held at one of scores of checkpoints aimed at tackling drunken driving.

They denied that Fusco had been living openly with his wife and three children in Tralee. But residents suggested that he did visit regularly, and Sinn Fein believed he could have been picked up before. One republican said: "The question is: why now?"

Ken Maginnis, the Ulster Unionist security spokesman, also believed Fusco could have been held earlier. But he said it would undermine confidence in the legal system if he now avoided extradition.

Sinn Fein's reaction made it clear Fusco was not a dissident. He had worked for its election team several times and was described as a supporter of the peace process.

Martin Ferris, a leading Sinn Fein figure based in Kerry, who knows Fusco well, said: "For the Irish government to involve itself in the extradition of any Irish citizen on political charges is completely at odds with the commitment to release all political prisoners. That lies at the heart of the Good Friday agreement.

"The Irish government should immediately move to rescind the warrant against Angelo Fusco. The action will cause great anger and resentment within the nationalist community."

Five more IRA men are fighting attempts to extradite them back to Northern Ireland to serve out sentences, among them at least two who escaped during the mass IRA breakout at Maze in September 1983. There are many more suspected of terrorist crimes in Northern Ireland living openly in the Irish Republic.

Unionists are particularly furious at allegations that the IRA double murderer Liam Averill is reguarly seen in Northern Ireland. He escaped from the Maze two years ago while dressed as a woman during a Christmas party.

Fusco was being sent back to Northern Ireland immediately after arrest because he had exhausted all attempts to avoid extradition. The Irish supreme court finally brought his six-year fight to an end in February 1998 when it ruled that he must be returned. He had jumped bail by then.

Mr Justice Joseph Finegan's decision means Fusco, in Mountjoy prison in Dublin last night, will have another chance at the high court tomorrow. His lawyers lodged an application for habeus corpus on the grounds of the altered political context.

Last night's handover had been scheduled for Kileen on the border between Co Louth and Co Armagh. It was the point used for several republic suspects who failed to beat extradition, including the Inla's Dominic McGlinchy more than 15 years ago.

webTitle: Software shares hit as Baan chief quits

fields.headline: Software shares hit as Baan chief quits
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Software shares throughout Europe were unsettled yesterday when the continent's second largest business software company announced the resignation of its chief executive along with an unexpected profit warning.
fields.body:
Software shares throughout Europe were unsettled yesterday when the continent's second largest business software company announced the resignation of its chief executive along with an unexpected profit warning.

Baan Company stunned the Dutch stock market by announcing that it could incur a loss of up to $250m (£155m) in the fourth quarter and that its chief executive, Mary Coleman, was quitting only seven months after taking up the post.

Shares in Baan dropped 32% on the announcements, prompting profit-taking in rival firms' shares in Britain, Germany and France.

SAP of Germany, which is Europe's largest business software company, lost 4% of its value while French computer consultancy Cap Gemini closed off 4.3%; British competitor Sage saw 7% wiped off its value, closing down 55.5p at 700p. Traders tried to play down the losses as more of a problem in Baan than in the sector as a whole.

Baan, which had been hit by a pre-millennial slowing of spending on new software, revealed plans for a $200m restructuring programme and almost 200 redundancies.

Analysts said the restructuring charge was high - especially as it came so soon after a substantial reorganisation at the beginning of 1999.

Baan's third-quarter loss of $24.7m was already below market forecasts, and yesterday's announcements led some brokers to issue "sell" notes, which are rarely seen in the sector.

The projected loss will be Baan's sixth successive quarterly loss. The company has been built up on integrating businesses' in-house administration to make them more efficient. It will now focus increasingly on the internet and the medium's capacity for business-to-business links.

Ms Coleman, an American who was seen as crucial to Baan's revival hopes and its chances of making an impact on the internet, is to return to Silicon Valley to pursue "other technology-related opportunities", the company said.

Many analysts have interpreted Ms Coleman's departure as further evidence of trouble at the company.

"Mary always had a very good reputation," said Edwin Flick of MeesPierson. "We're not sure why she had to go."

Ms Coleman will be replaced by Pierre Everaert, the 60-year-old chairman of Baan's supervisory board and former chief executive of Dutch grocery group Ahold, until a permanent replacement is found.

webTitle: Banks clear record £25bn to beat bug

fields.headline: Banks clear record £25bn to beat bug
fields.trailText: The banking system yesterday beat the millennium bug by processing a record 48m retail transactions worth £25bn through the Bacs clearing system, four times the usual amount on an average day.
fields.body:
The banking system yesterday beat the millennium bug by processing a record 48m retail transactions worth £25bn through the Bacs clearing system, four times the usual amount on an average day.

The trades, which involve payments made between banks including such items as salaries and mortgage payments, were input into the sys tem on December 29, when it reopened after Christmas, and settled this morning when the banks opened for the first time this millennium.

The Financial Services Authority said that business resumed as normal on the financial markets for the first day of trading. "The evidence we have received so far from financial institutions around the country confirms that services and systems are working well," said Michael Foot, managing director and head of financial supervision at the FSA.

The FSA will continue to monitor the situation over the coming days but expects to close the millennium event office today. Only minor glitches were reported after banks and financial services companies spent millions of pounds checking their computer systems. Lloyds TSB alone spent £150m.

The Bank of England, which said a record £30.3m of cash is in circulation, had stockplied £7bn of additional notes of which only £1m was needed.

The bank will start to destroy older £20 notes which were left in circulation a year longer than usual to meet any surge in demand.

Other notes will remain in branches or be returned to the bank and circulated when needed.

fields.headline: Bugged by crashed computers
fields.standfirst: All sense of control flies out of the window when our computer breaks and we are in the hands of a voice on the end of the phone says Judi James
fields.trailText: It's been a glum start to the new century for all those technophobes praying the millennium bug would smite big-time, which would have proved once and for all that Bill Gates is the anti-Christ and anything invented since the spinning jenny is just part of some ludicrous global domination front by Trekkie nerds.
fields.body:
It's been a glum start to the new century for all those technophobes praying the millennium bug would smite big-time, which would have proved once and for all that Bill Gates is the anti-Christ and anything invented since the spinning jenny is just part of some ludicrous global domination front by Trekkie nerds.

Was it just a nationwide hallucination brought on by a Bristol Cream and Fererro Rocher overdose or did we really get treated to the sight of Peter Snow - current holder of the Magus Pike Award for his ability to perform cartwheels without either foot ever leaving the ground - on bug patrol on millennium night, prancing in front of a screen full of cockroaches with gimlet eyes fixed on potential world apocalypse?

Due to a severe shortage of Jumbo jets raining down from the skies, the phobes had to be content with the sight of a static millennium wheel to remind us all that when technology slips up it tends to do so spectacularly.

The same applies in business. All the IT gubbins has made dependants out of us all and we secretly hate it because we know deep inside that, as with the millennium wheel, it is bound to let us down sooner or later. Which is why IT departments are the most hated in any company despite the fact that all the Wallace and Grommit fans who work there tend to see themselves as corporate saviours and the rest of the workforce as ungrateful, whinging wretches.

IT breakdowns tend to make complete and instantaneous dorks out of the equipment user, which is probably why Premier Blair's speech prior to laser-blasting the Wheel was so terse and lacking in flamboyance, and why he hightailed it back to the shadows of the Embankment straight after pulling the lever. If that wheel didn't spin, he didn't want his name or gawping face on the credits.

Apart from the PC, the only other piece of equipment most workers are enslaved to is the car. When this breaks down it is inconvenient but, unlike the computer, very rarely fatally embarrassing. We have sufficient knowledge to tinker with it ourselves, and getting it done in a garage can be put down to the fact that we don't want to get our hands dirty.

Computer breakdowns mean complete impotence following a period of disbelief. All sense of control flies out of the window and we are in the hands of a voice on the end of the phone. Stress courses are currently filled with delegates suffering from aftershock from watching their computer crash in front of their eyes, or Lightpro presentation achieve meltdown behind their back while they were in full flight, and interpersonal skills courses bulge with people wanting to acquire the skills to persuade, negotiate with, and even threaten the person whose job it was to help them at that point.

Coping when the system crashes requires resolve and skill. Try this simple, six-step guide to avoiding hospitalisation:

1. Get out of the area immediately. Go to the coffee machine, walk to the loo. Whatever you do, don't sit there gazing at your screen in disbelief as this can lead to a phase of denial when you start tinkering yourself, making the problem 100 times worse.

2. Spend five minutes thinking of trees, woodland creatures and snowflakes on noses.

3. Write down exactly what happened and stick only to the facts. Add no emotional details. No unfeeling nerd is remotely interested in our projectile vomit panic-attack or the fact you face the sack if you don't get to your emails within the next three minutes.

4. Go down to IT in person. Never phone. Personal contact flummoxes them slightly. Find the one with the shortest hair and verbalise your request for help, adding a brief monotone recitation of what occurred.

5. Following this, smile, and be nice. This will be a novel and confusing experience for the dweebs in the basement. Engage them in small-talk about the X-Files or the new drama series, Gormenghast. This may lead to bonding.

6. Tell them you believe you saw a message form something called The Matrix just before the screen died. This last step will guarantee that they turn their immediate and undivided attention to your PC.

fields.headline: Getting under our skin
fields.standfirst:
The Borrowers
Polka, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Charles Way's adaptation of Mary Norton's classic books, about a family of little people who live underneath the floorboards of an old house, is likely to prove a little slow for those familiar with Peter Hewitt's unfaithful but immensely exciting movie version with John Goodman as the baddie, and lacking in detail for those who fondly remember the BBC series starring Ian Holm and Penelope Wilton.
fields.body:
Charles Way's adaptation of Mary Norton's classic books, about a family of little people who live underneath the floorboards of an old house, is likely to prove a little slow for those familiar with Peter Hewitt's unfaithful but immensely exciting movie version with John Goodman as the baddie, and lacking in detail for those who fondly remember the BBC series starring Ian Holm and Penelope Wilton.

It has, however, oodles of charm on its side, although it does make you wish that those adapting children's novels would take a leaf out of the book of stage adapters such as Polly Teale (Jane Eyre) and Helen Edmundson (Mill On the Floss, War and Peace) who have shown that books only really come alive in the theatre when narrative plays second fiddle to the internal experience of the characters.

There is something a mite stodgy about this version, although Vicky Ireland's clever production plays neatly with perspective so the world of human beings co-exists with the tiny Borrowers, who are sometimes represented by puppets and sometimes by real actors. It is a measure of the production's magic and the seamlessness of the stagecraft that you almost completely forget which is which.

Less successful is the attempt to use the story as an educational tool about refugees. The final scene with the gypsy who wishes the Borrowers, outcasts like himself, "good luck to you and all your kind" reeks of an unnecessary political correctness.

After all, Norton's books don't need to have a theme imposed upon them to make them connect with our own time. They are already, in the story of Arrietty Clock who longs to escape the dark under- the-floorboards world where she lives and discover the world beyond, about the growing up and growing away process that is part of the relationship of every child and his or her parents. The evening's most poignant moment comes when, told of her cousin's unfortunate accident with a cat, Arrietty declares: "At least she got out and saw the blue sky and tall grass. Just once."

But this is an enjoyable enough Christmas treat, enlivened by Rosalind Paul's Arrietty and Richard Tate's long-suffering, amiable Pod and most of all by Norton's natural sense of justice - her belief that little people are just as important as big ones. Children will warm to that.

 Until February 5. Box office: 0181-543 4888

fields.headline: Postcards from the edge
fields.standfirst:
Duncan MacAskill
Sadler's Wells, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText: Artists have long been inspired by dance, from Degas and the ballerinas to Robert Morris, whose first Minimalist objects in 60s New York were made as props for Simone Forti's avant garde dancers. This affinity between the visual and terpsichorean arts has enabled Sadler's Wells to create an ambitious foyer art programme, including commissions from Anya Gallacio and Gary Hume. So it is a shame that the year's culmination should be a "wall sculpture" and mall art effort by Duncan MacAskill that would look more at home in a 70s school gym.
fields.body:
Artists have long been inspired by dance, from Degas and the ballerinas to Robert Morris, whose first Minimalist objects in 60s New York were made as props for Simone Forti's avant garde dancers. This affinity between the visual and terpsichorean arts has enabled Sadler's Wells to create an ambitious foyer art programme, including commissions from Anya Gallacio and Gary Hume. So it is a shame that the year's culmination should be a "wall sculpture" and mall art effort by Duncan MacAskill that would look more at home in a 70s school gym.

The welded and painted metal frame that MacAskill has run up a high wall of the foyer is designed to be climbed on, a challenge or goad to dancers. I didn't see it during a performance, and it is possible that some spectacular stuff has been done by dancers climbing like monkeys up the twisting blue, red and green poles. But you can say the same of any climbing frame. To be worth displaying as an art work the frame needs to have its own sculptural presence. It has none, neither disciplining nor dramatising space. It resembles an attempt to brighten up a dismal institution - a hospital or a council office plaza - with art that is itself dismally institutionalised.

The excuse for the shoddiness of this art is that it is a bit of seasonal fun, to coincide with the production of Dick Whittington, and accessible to children. The artist has also sent "funny" postcards on a Whittington theme, which are displayed on a shelf near the climbing frame. But there is so little visual or tactile excitement here that I can't imagine children getting any more fun from it than they would from a piece of string. The ideal home for this bleak exercise in late-modernist jollity would be a concrete ape enclosure at a zoo, where the imprisoned animals would doubtless ignore their jauntily painted climbing frame, but might at least enjoy eating the postcards.

 Until April 8. Details: 0171-729 5366
fields.bodyText: Artists have long been inspired by dance, from Degas and the ballerinas to Robert Morris, whose first Minimalist objects in 60s New York were made as props for Simone Forti's avant garde dancers. This affinity between the visual and terpsichorean arts has enabled Sadler's Wells to create an ambitious foyer art programme, including commissions from Anya Gallacio and Gary Hume. So it is a shame that the year's culmination should be a "wall sculpture" and mall art effort by Duncan MacAskill that would look more at home in a 70s school gym. The welded and painted metal frame that MacAskill has run up a high wall of the foyer is designed to be climbed on, a challenge or goad to dancers. I didn't see it during a performance, and it is possible that some spectacular stuff has been done by dancers climbing like monkeys up the twisting blue, red and green poles. But you can say the same of any climbing frame. To be worth displaying as an art work the frame needs to have its own sculptural presence. It has none, neither disciplining nor dramatising space. It resembles an attempt to brighten up a dismal institution - a hospital or a council office plaza - with art that is itself dismally institutionalised. The excuse for the shoddiness of this art is that it is a bit of seasonal fun, to coincide with the production of Dick Whittington, and accessible to children. The artist has also sent "funny" postcards on a Whittington theme, which are displayed on a shelf near the climbing frame. But there is so little visual or tactile excitement here that I can't imagine children getting any more fun from it than they would from a piece of string. The ideal home for this bleak exercise in late-modernist jollity would be a concrete ape enclosure at a zoo, where the imprisoned animals would doubtless ignore their jauntily painted climbing frame, but might at least enjoy eating the postcards.  Until April 8. fields.headline: Hangover hurts markets
fields.standfirst: Rates fears and dot.com profit-taking force down shares
fields.trailText: Share prices plunged on both sides of the Atlantic yesterday as investors woke up to the realisation that interest rates are poised to rise around the world.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor, Charlotte Denny and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Share prices plunged on both sides of the Atlantic yesterday as investors woke up to the realisation that interest rates are poised to rise around the world.

The Eurotop 300 index of Europe's leading companies fell 4% while the FTSE 100 index fell 3.8%, the 8th largest percentage fall in its 16-year history.

In the US, markets opened sharply lower for the second day and by the London close the Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 200 points, triggering emergency trading curbs to prevent volatility. It continued to fall and was more than 300 points down an hour before the Wall Street close. The US technology index Nasdaq was off 3.8% at the London close after setting a record high on Monday.

Europe could be the first to endure the pain of higher borrowing costs after the European Central Bank meets today. Britain's monetary policy committee meets next week.

In the US, where financial markets often set the tone for Europe, investors could be jittery until the next meeting of the banking authorities in February.

"The US financial markets are waking up to the fact that US interest rates need to go up," said Gerard Lyons, global head of treasury research at Standard Chartered.

The realisation appeared to be reflected in the sharp rise in very long-term US interest rates on Monday when yields on 30-year US government bonds reached two-year highs. That suggested investors expect inflationary pressures to build up in the years ahead, prompting increases in official rates from the the authorities to curb price rises.

Among the sectors hardest hit were the "dot.com" stocks and particularly telecoms as well as companies sensitive to interest rate movements such as banks.

One analyst said highly geared hi-tech stocks were extremely sensitive to interest rates on long-dated bonds because their stock market valuations are based on expectations of future earnings, which might be eroded by higher inflation.

The end of year rally in "dot.com" stocks, fuelled by small investors, also allowed some big players to realise their potential gains yesterday. "It's profit-taking on the back of the recent strong run, and concerns over interest rates have been the catalyst," said Jeremy Batstone, head of research at NatWest stockbrokers.

Mr Batstone said rumours that the European Central Bank was poised to withdraw liquidity injected into the market at the end of the year to cushion any pain from the millennium bug - which failed to materialise - had also served to unbalance sentiment.

Not all shares fell sharply. One of the day's biggest gainers was Marks & Spencer which jumped more than 5% on speculation that it will be taken over by a rival. Some big internet stocks such as Psion also registered rises.

Few analysts suggested yesterday's sharp falls marked the beginning of a prolonged bear market, describing the move instead as a much needed pause for breath in an overheated market.

Many, though, believe the internet sector, which drove much of last year's rally, might be the first to fall back. Byron Wein, the bearish but widely followed chief market strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, predicted a correction among internet stocks this year. "I am not saying that the internet is not going to reward investors over the long term," he said. "But a number of these stocks have gone ahead of themselves."

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: How I became a better manager
fields.trailText: How I became a better manager
fields.body:
Sarah Stevens, 28 sales manager

In my first managerial job, I started off as a conduit between my boss and my staff. I had three people in my department and we worked in an open-plan office. My boss complained because we made too much noise, so I just told my staff what she said and asked them to be less rowdy. They gave me a lot of flak because they felt I hadn't supported them. I went back to the boss and explained the situation, that as a sales team we had to chat people up on the phone, so we were going to make more noise. I realised that as a manager you have to negotiate, rather than just pass information on.

Ellie Dupe, 32 strategy/operations manager

I've learnt you have to understand how your staff tick to manage them properly. I have one member of staff who is a terrible worrier. She'll have a sleepless night if the petty cash balance isn't right to the last penny. If on a Friday I have to tell her something I know will worry her, I'll leave it until Monday, otherwise she'll spend all weekend fretting about it. It's just counter-productive. Another member of staff hates dealing with changes, so I give her early warning of them. Then she's happier about the situation and does a better job.

Katie James, 42 project manager

I learnt how to manage by being badly managed myself. I had a boss who would constantly avoid discussing issues with me. When I became a manager myself, a really nice guy worked for me who was just not performing well. I supported him but it still wasn't working and it wasn't helped by the fact that he had a stiff upper lip and just tried to get on with it. In the end I had to let him go. He broke down and it's awful for a woman to have a man break down like that. You just have to be sympathetic and practical. I found him a job in another part of the organisation and he was tremendously grateful.

Christopher Jones, 30 restaurant manager

It's important to see things from your staff's point of view. One employee came to me upset that she always had to work on a Friday night; when she approached the general manager, he said there was nothing he could do. I told her to keep copies of her shifts for a month, then we took them to show him. He accepted there was a problem - rare for him because he was very defensive. But I had offered proof and a solution rather than accusations. It's essential as a manager to get on well with those above and beneath you in the pecking order.

Robert Saunders, 27 IT manager

You get more out of people if you show them you appreciate their work and reward them accordingly. I used to have a real disciplinarian for a boss and although we all worked hard, we did it through gritted teeth. As a manager, I run a relatively relaxed ship. I reckon you should try to enjoy yourself in your job as far as possible and fit in some quality time with your staff. We have a monthly breakfast at the Savoy at 8.30am, where we don't talk shop, and we go on office trips every summer. It just makes sense to me that the happier people are, the harder they work.

fields.headline: A bug's life
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's the second day back and with no bugs in sight, the danger of exhausting those kissy greetings and having to do some work grows with each passing second. But don't despair. The prediction that the bug may twitch back to life later this year opens a chink of hope for the determined Work Avoidance artist. A nippy trade in Y2K bug scams is prospering on the internet - not how to trigger the crash, of course, but how to counterfeit its effects. The most sophisticated requires some, although not very much, computer knowledge.
fields.body:
It's the second day back and with no bugs in sight, the danger of exhausting those kissy greetings and having to do some work grows with each passing second. But don't despair. The prediction that the bug may twitch back to life later this year opens a chink of hope for the determined Work Avoidance artist. A nippy trade in Y2K bug scams is prospering on the internet - not how to trigger the crash, of course, but how to counterfeit its effects. The most sophisticated requires some, although not very much, computer knowledge.

1 When your colleague is not in his seat, take a screen shot (a computer-generated photograph) of his desktop. Save and paste it up as wallpaper (the desktop's background illustration). Hide the real icons (ideally in the trash) and when your colleague tries to activate his machine by clicking on the fake folders, it will appear frozen.

Time lost: half a day.

2 Disconnect the monitor cables and reconnect to the wrong machines. Quick, easy and disastrous if enough computers are involved and IT support has its customary slow response time.

Time lost: a whole day.

3 Set the background colour on everyone's screens to black, or fiddle with the contrast until the cursor and icons are lost in darkness and the computer appears to have died. Change the properties on everyone's mouse buttons, so left and right clicks are reversed. Count the times your colleagues reboot to solve the problem.

Time lost: days.

4 Send a request from every machine in the office to download and print out the internet.

Time lost: weeks, possibly years.

5 The lo-tech option: hang "Out of order" signs on everything.

Time lost: half an hour, including a quality few seconds while colleagues stare blankly at the decommissioned stapler and wonder what it portends.

fields.headline: Markets dive on rate fears
fields.standfirst: Off-loading of inflated stocks hits world markets, wiping £53bn off British equities
fields.trailText: More than £53bn was wiped off the value of British shares yesterday, as the governor of the Bank of England reiterated warnings that internet stocks could be overvalued. Round the rest of the world, fears of higher interest rates sent share markets crashing.
fields.body:
More than £53bn was wiped off the value of British shares yesterday, as the governor of the Bank of England reiterated warnings that internet stocks could be overvalued. Round the rest of the world, fears of higher interest rates sent share markets crashing.

The FTSE 100 index of leading shares plunged 264 points to 6,665, the biggest one-day fall in its 16-year history and larger than the drop of 250 points that marked the October 1987 crash. Because the market is now almost three times its late-80s levels, however, the 3.8% fall was not a record in percentage terms.

Analysts said that yesterday's plunge was a reaction to the stock market's record high at the year end when small in vestors were scrambling to buy hi-tech shares - called the "dot.com" stocks. These investors pushed the market to inflated values while the big City firms were inactive over the long holiday.

"The market is just readjusting to some proper prices. It all got a bit ridiculous over Christmas," one shares salesman at a British investment bank said.

Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, started the rout when he warned yesterday morning that even if new technology was improving the performance of the economy, the "dot.com" bubble could burst.

His comments added to growing fears that central banks on both sides of the Atlantic are poised to raise the cost of borrowing. But the threat of higher interest rates failed to scare off small investors who remained faithful to the "dot.com" stocks which have seen such remarkable price rises over the last four months.

Internet and telephone stock broker Charles Schwab reported only a small let-up in business yesterday, when it handled 10,500 trades, down from the record levels in December. The broking firm said the activity was well above usual and when its phones started ringing at 6am yesterday morning, there were plenty of "buy" orders for technology related stocks.

Mr George said yesterday: "There is this huge revolution in information and communications technology which is contributing to productivity improvements in the United States and that makes the performance of the stock market somewhat more understandable." But, he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme, "That doesn't mean that we can all relax." Stock prices could "get ahead of themselves".

The stock exchange's new techMARK index for internet related companies fell 2.7% - or 102 points - to 3,677 points.

Institutional investors started cashing in by selling highly valued technology stocks, as well as shares in major oil and banking companies. In percentage terms the FTSE 100 saw a 3.8% drop, the eighth largest on record.

The decline in the main FTSE quickened when trading opened in New York in early afternoon. By the time London closed, the Dow Jones index of leading shares had fallen 200 points - partly because of fears that the Federal Reserve may raise rates to rein in the booming US economy.

British base rates could rise as early as next week. Manufacturing output is increasing at its fastest pace in three years, according to the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.

fields.headline: Nasdaq to shed mutual status
fields.trailText: Nasdaq, America's second largest stock exchange, is poised to become the country's first to be owned by shareholders rather than member firms after a board meeting voted on its restructuring yesterday, writes Jane Martinson in New York.
fields.body:
Nasdaq, America's second largest stock exchange, is poised to become the country's first to be owned by shareholders rather than member firms after a board meeting voted on its restructuring yesterday, writes Jane Martinson in New York.

The proposed conversion from a mutual into a private, for-profit company comes at a time of upheaval for the world's stock exchanges as they face increased competition from electronic stock trading networks and other exchanges.

Nasdaq - an electronic, dealer-run market - is expected to raise more than $1bn (£611m) through two private share placements by the summer. The new shareholders are expected to include existing member firms such as Wall Street brokerages, institutional investors and some of the technology firms listed on the exchange, including Microsoft, the world's largest software company.

In the first planned placement, the National Association of Securities Dealers, a membership organisation that owns Nasdaq, is expected to keep a majority stake in the new company. However, this is likely to fall to 20% by the second placement in the middle of the year.

The money raised from the shares is expected to finance NASD regulation, the group's regulatory arm that will remain a not-for-profit unit.

An initial public offering of shares could come as early as next year after a board is elected by the new shareholders.

Yesterday's long-expected vote was expected to include concessions to more than 5,500 small member brokerages in order to secure their approval of the plan.
