fields.headline: Send in the clowns
fields.standfirst:
Heard the one about the comedy workshops at Jongleurs for stressed-out executives? No, it's not a joke: employers have finally realised that a happy team is a creative team. Anita Chaudhuri reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Heard the one about the comedy workshops at Jongleurs for stressed-out executives? No, it's not a joke: employers have finally realised that a happy team is a creative team. Anita Chaudhuri reports
fields.body:
Not so long ago, stressed-out executives at embattled Marks & Spencer were packed off on a training course. Nothing so very unusual about that. After all, if there's one thing guaranteed to set racing the pulse of any middle manager, it's the prospect of spending a day off work, locked in a room with a jug of coffee and a board filled with motivational acronyms.

But the M&S team were in for a surprise. There was no time management seminar, no flashy flip-charts. Instead they were faced with cardboard, paint and glue - not that useful when it comes to working out how to sell more cashmere cardigans but essential for the mask-making workshop their boss had signed them up for.

Organised by creativity group Oracy, the day-long session required each delegate to create a mask to represent the face they presented at work. "Mask-making is a very effective corporate tool," claims Charlene Collison of Oracy. "Often people create faces that are anxious and alienated. It helps them access their intuitive, imaginative skills. Companies are starting to nurture those qualities."

It's an unconventional approach but one that is catching on fast. The business sections of booksellers' are crammed with creativity manuals including The Artist's Way At Work, a corporate version of Julia Cameron's million-selling 12-step programme for blocked creatives. Further proof comes in the unlikely guise of London comedy club Jongleurs, which has launched a corporate programme to inspire stressed-out executives by teaching them to do stand-up routines. A host of firms have already signed up.

Creativity has become a highly-prized commodity, even in less than fizzy professions such as accountancy. Whereas once we could drag ourselves into work each day, safe in the expectation of doing nothing more taxing than, er, work, now bosses have other ideas. They have finally begun to see that if you sit in a boring meeting in a boring conference room, you will inevitably emerge with boring ideas.

Work, it would appear, is no longer working. "Play is becoming the buzzword," says Patrick Burns, policy director of the Industrial Society. "As companies become desperate to harness creativity and lateral thinking, they are being forced to look at new ways of fostering those talents. These days, we are seeing everything from mime, circus skills and comedy to finger-painting and story-telling."

As one would expect, the roots of the play industry lie on the other side of the Atlantic. Ten years ago, marketing firm Play pioneered the techniques now taking off here. Staff at Play invent their own superheroes and make their own costumes. They have an office play-room and a company dog which is picked up for work even when its owner is away, and there are no conventional job titles. Instead, employees have business cards printed with peculiar slogans such as "What if" and "Voice of reason".

"When you turn work into a place that encourages people to be themselves, have fun and take risks, you unleash their creativity. The best ideas come from playful minds and the way to tap into that playfulness is to play together," says Andy Stefanovich, Play's 33-year-old co-founder.

Maria Kempinska, co-founder of Jongleurs, believes this approach has helped her own business and inspired her to set up the corporate comedy school. "All companies are hungry for new ideas," she explains, "but if you push and pull in a pressured environment, ideas rarely come. Forward-looking companies realise a good atmosphere at work and good relations with colleagues are crucial to hanging on to staff. Teaching them how to laugh with each other and communicate honestly is a good start. So far, surprisingly few have used the workshop to have a go at their boss."

Kempinska does admit, however, that the types of companies who are likely to sign up are the ones who have least need for it: young, gung-ho firms in new media and advertising. Jim Andrews of Thinc! Digital, a new media firm, was one of the first guinea pigs. "It was great fun! I do a lot of presentations to clients and you do them in a linear way. But this made me think laterally. Some companies send people on challenges and adventure things - this is another way of getting people together, focused and excited."

Charlene Collison believes creativity breeds confidence. "As well as mask-making, we do story-telling workshops. One client, the Humberside Training and Enterprise Council, found these particularly beneficial. There was one woman who presented a story about how nervous she felt giving a presentation to the board; she said she felt like a rabbit caught in the headlights and her teeth felt too big for her mouth. So we acted out a story with her as the rabbit and the humour of it allowed her to overcome that fear. Often we use heroic myths and symbols, slaying dragons and other metaphors."

It all sounds worryingly new age but Oracy has been called in by Smith Klein Beecham, Hedron, Chesterton Property and various government agencies. They have also worked with staff at the Industrial Society. "We asked them to describe the Society as if it were a landscape," Collison says. "At first everyone talked about how it was a beautiful, serene place. Then someone described a bog, another a volcano about to erupt. It's all about encouraging better communication."

Collison believes the benefits to firms are tangible. "We've had lots of feedback, about how staff bring more passion and ideas to their work, whatever field they are employed in. They take more risks and are more adventurous and more honest."

There are signs that the spirit of playfulness has its uses beyond rescuing companies from creative bankruptcy, too. Phil Besley of Fools Gold runs clown workshops for companies as diverse as Norwich Union, Warwick University and British Gas. He claims playing can help employees confront their inner fears. "We get people to write a story about a situation that's bothering them, then we clown it. It's not about being funny, it's about developing self-expression. A clown is like a shaman, he can transform difficult issues."

One suspects British Gas won't like to be reminded that their employees have this special skill next time one of us decides to quibble about our bill.
fields.bodyText: Not so long ago, stressed-out executives at embattled Marks & Spencer were packed off on a training course. Nothing so very unusual about that. After all, if there's one thing guaranteed to set racing the pulse of any middle manager, it's the prospect of spending a day off work, locked in a room with a jug of coffee and a board filled with motivational acronyms. But the M&S team were in for a surprise. There was no time management seminar, no flashy flip-charts. Instead they were faced with cardboard, paint and glue - not that useful when it comes to working out how to sell more cashmere cardigans but essential for the mask-making workshop their boss had signed them up for. Organised by creativity group Oracy, the day-long session required each delegate to create a mask to represent the face they presented at work. "Mask-making is a very effective corporate tool," claims Charlene Collison of Oracy. "Often people create faces that are anxious and alienated. It helps them access their intuitive, imaginative skills. Companies are starting to nurture those qualities." It's an unconventional approach but one that is catching on fast. The business sections of booksellers' are crammed with creativity manuals including The Artist's Way At Work, a corporate version of Julia Cameron's million-selling 12-step programme for blocked creatives. Further proof comes in the unlikely guise of London comedy club Jongleurs, which has launched a corporate programme to inspire stressed-out executives by teaching them to do stand-up routines. A host of firms have already signed up. Creativity has become a highly-prized commodity, even in less than fizzy professions such as accountancy. Whereas once we could drag ourselves into work each day, safe in the expectation of doing nothing more taxing than, er, work, now bosses have other ideas. They have finally begun to see that if you sit in a boring meeting in a boring conference room, you will inevitably emerge with boring ideas. Work, it would appear, is no longer working. "Play is becoming the buzzword," says Patrick Burns, policy director of the Industrial Society. "As companies become desperate to harness creativity and lateral thinking, they are being forced to look at new ways of fostering those talents. These days, we are seeing everything from mime, circus skills and comedy to finger-painting and story-telling." As one would expect, the roots of the play industry lie on the other side of the Atlantic. Ten years ago, marketing firm Play pioneered the techniques now taking off here. Staff at Play invent their own superheroes and make their own costumes. They have an office play-room and a company dog which is picked up for work even when its owner is away, and there are no conventional job titles. Instead, employees have business cards printed with peculiar slogans such as "What if" and "Voice of reason". "When you turn work into a place that encourages people to be themselves, have fun and take risks, you unleash their creativity. The best ideas come from playful minds and the way to tap into that playfulness is to play together," says Andy Stefanovich, Play's 33-year-old co-founder. Maria Kempinska, co-founder of Jongleurs, believes this approach has helped her own business and inspired her to set up the corporate comedy school. "All companies are hungry for new ideas," she explains, "but if you push and pull in a pressured environment, ideas rarely come. Forward-looking companies realise a good atmosphere at work and good relations with colleagues are crucial to hanging on to staff. Teaching them how to laugh with each other and communicate honestly is a good start. So far, surprisingly few have used the workshop to have a go at their boss." Kempinska does admit, however, that the types of companies who are likely to sign up are the ones who have least need for it: young, gung-ho firms in new media and advertising. Jim Andrews of Thinc! Digital, a new media firm, was one of the first guinea pigs. "It was great fun! I do a lot of presentations to clients and you do them in a linear way. But this made me think laterally. Some companies send people on challenges and adventure things - this is another way of getting people together, focused and excited." Charlene Collison believes creativity breeds confidence. "As well as mask-making, we do story-telling workshops. One client, the Humberside Training and Enterprise Council, found these particularly beneficial. There was one woman who presented a story about how nervous she felt giving a presentation to the board; she said she felt like a rabbit caught in the headlights and her teeth felt too big for her mouth. So we acted out a story with her as the rabbit and the humour of it allowed her to overcome that fear. Often we use heroic myths and symbols, slaying dragons and other metaphors." It all sounds worryingly new age but Oracy has been called in by Smith Klein Beecham, Hedron, Chesterton Property and various government agencies. They have also worked with staff at the Industrial Society. "We asked them to describe the Society as if it were a landscape," Collison says. "At first everyone talked about how it was a beautiful, serene place. Then someone described a bog, another a volcano about to erupt. It's all about encouraging better communication." webTitle: Brief encounters: an industrial tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an industrial tribunal lawyer writes
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: "You have to bear in mind that by the end, he had complained about everybody in the office," Mr Manager explained to the tribunal. "They all just hated him." The chairman was clearly finding this rather strong stuff. "But can you give us some examples?"
fields.body:
"You have to bear in mind that by the end, he had complained about everybody in the office," Mr Manager explained to the tribunal. "They all just hated him." The chairman was clearly finding this rather strong stuff. "But can you give us some examples?"

"Oh, it was endless. He'd complain about people talking near his desk. Or he'd dob people in for playing computer games or coming in five minutes late. He wouldn't let anyone open the window." Even Mr Manager seemed to see this was not coming across as a brilliant justification for the campaign of retribution his colleagues had waged against Mr Complainer. A campaign to which Mr Manager had allegedly turned a blind eye.

We had already been treated to some highlights: the colleague who had stirred Mr Complainer's coffee with his penis, or at least said he had in an anonymous note. The family meal-deal from Pizza Palace that arrived at Mr Complainer's desk. Superglue on his keyboard ...

I would have felt worse about representing Mr Manager if Mr Complainer had not been the sort of man who somehow repelled sympathy. Perhaps it was the endless memos we'd looked at where he griped about the positioning of his VDU in relation to the sun. Perhaps it was just the sound of his voice. Even the tribunal seemed to be finding him hard to like. But Mr Complainer still had something up his sleeve, or rather in his briefcase.

"This was the final straw," he said, taking it out, turning it on, flourishing it so we could all see the Post-It note that said simply YOU. "I believe it's what you call a dildo," he said, for the benefit of those who had led sheltered lives. He carried on talking as it writhed impotently on the table like a beetle trying to right itself. The chairman cleared his throat. "I think we have the idea, Mr Complainer. Perhaps you could turn that thing off?" He even managed to turn off a vibrator self-righteously.

Mr Manager remained cheerful as we coasted towards the inevitable defeat. I suspect he would have forked out personally to see the back of Mr Complainer. As it was, it was only his company paying for that pleasure.

In the waiting room as we packed up, he began to giggle. "Tee hee," he said. "When he turned on that Squirmy Tickler, hee hee." I took this to be a brand name of sorts and it confirmed a suspicion I'd been growing all day about Mr Manager. I gave him a quick homily about the risks he was running for his employer, blah, blah. But Mr Manager was still giggling as he departed. Some days I think this is no job for a grown-up.

webTitle: Look out Ken! They're behind you

fields.headline: Look out Ken! They're behind you
fields.standfirst:
Dick Whittington
Richmond Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText: It is impossible to watch Dick Whittington without transposing its mayoral mayhem on to real-life events. Producers know this: it is no accident that Dicks have been spotted all across the capital this festive season. Ken Livingstone may find Richmond Theatre's spin on the hoary fairytale instructive, even if Keith Simmons's script parallels him not with the eponymous hero, but with the villainous, verminous King Rat.
fields.body:
It is impossible to watch Dick Whittington without transposing its mayoral mayhem on to real-life events. Producers know this: it is no accident that Dicks have been spotted all across the capital this festive season. Ken Livingstone may find Richmond Theatre's spin on the hoary fairytale instructive, even if Keith Simmons's script parallels him not with the eponymous hero, but with the villainous, verminous King Rat.

"I once ruled London with a rod of iron," cackles the outsize rodent, now bent on reclaiming his lost eminence. In his way stand Darren Day's dashing Dick, Melanie Stace as an independent Alice Fitzwarren (her dad, the Alderman, has been written out, like Jeffrey Archer) and Marti Webb as Fairy Bowbells.

It is a matter of civic pride Britain-wide: who has got whom in their panto. What Richmond lacks in former soap stars, it more than makes up for in light entertainers. Paul Burnham as Idle Jack gets a dig in at a local rival. "Didn't you go to their panto?" he asks an infant volunteer from nearby Wimbledon. "Leslie Grantham not good enough for you?"

I happen to think that pantomime, for all the derision heaped upon it, has much to teach more hallowed forms of theatre. But Richmond's effort, directed by Martin Connor, is fairly pedestrian, and imagination tends to cede to formula.

Few demands are made on dishy Day and "best legs on television" Stace's talents. Day ambles through it all with his trademark blokish insouciance, as if eager to prove that he is cooler than his career suggests.

The music is mostly of the jukebox variety. Queen's Don't Stop Me Now heralds Dick's appearance. His fairy godmother sings Lloyd Webber - and she is supposed to be a goodie! - while his mayoral fantasies play out to the tune of Somewhere Over the Rainbow. Note to Mr Livingstone: "The dreams that you dare to dream really do come true."

Red Ken would approve of little else. The cast promote their sponsors' chocolates. Morocco, to where our adventurers travel, is a superannuated stereotype. At least the puns flicker with life: "Do not call me 'mate', just kneel!" orders the Sultan. "Sorry, Neil," says Idle Jack. Luke Baxter makes a lithe, menacing King Rat with a satisfyingly malevolent laugh.

But the evening's most authentic expression of ruthlessness came from the audience. "What shall we do to him?" asks Dick of his too-easily vanquished foe. Cue the attendant kids, as one: "Kill him!"

 Until January 23. Box office: 0181-940 0088
